site_title: Bachelor pad
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bachelor pad

Ian Fong redesigned his one-bedroom apartment in Cairnhill and the Arne Jacobsen's Egg chair is among his favourite buys. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IAN Fong is the sort who moves house every few years, and each one looks vastly different from the previous. Some years ago, he lived in a HDB terrace home at Whampoa which was done up in an eclectic and English style. When he moved into his current home, a one-bedroom apartment in Cairnhill in 2010, he did up the place in a modern and somewhat minimalist look. Four years on, Mr Fong, the CEO of Sirius Art, has decided to stay put in this apartment. "This is the longest that I have lived in one apartment, as I have grown to like the place," he says.

He was set on this one-bedder when he was house-hunting back then. At 818 sq ft in size, it is a fairly large one. "It has a big living room which is good, especially when I have friends over," he says. "But yet at the same time, it is small enough, so that I have an excuse not to let friends sleep over."

He says while he welcomes friends, he draws a line at letting them stay the night. "I can't be myself then," he says. "My friends know that although I'm an extrovert, I am still quite reserved."

But since he has decided not to move, a revamp was in order for the apartment. Last year, he changed the look by rearranging the furniture and adding new ones.

A number of designer chairs dot the apartment, despite Mr Fong saying that he does not collect chairs but buys them simply because he loves them. "I appreciate beautiful design, and I respect timeless classics, so I am willing to spend on them," he says.

One of his favourite pieces is Arne Jacobsen's Egg chair. Mr Fong first saw it 20 years ago, but could not afford one then. "If I can't afford a piece, I will not buy a knock-off," he says. He bought the chair recently, and decided to go with the one in tan leather, despite it costing three times more than the fabric version. It comes as a surprise when Mr Fong confesses that the chair "isn't very comfortable. You cannot lounge in it". For a period of time, he could not believe that he had spent a five figure sum on the chair. "But it will not ever look outdated, and I can pass it down to my niece and nephew. So this is my heirloom piece," he says, justifying what he calls his most insane purchase.

Another Arne Jacobsen piece he has is the Series 7, used as a dining chair. "Again, I picked this because I appreciate Scandinavian design. It is functional yet aesthetically pleasing, and made of wood, which complements the home," he says. Unfortunately, the seat suffered a scratch after a particular dinner party, but Mr Fong brushes it off. "Of course, it pains my heart, but, it is just too bad," he says. He is better able to tolerate scratches on the floor, as "they give a lived in feel".

His favourite spot in the home is the sofa, where the TV addict can indulge in his pastime. "When I was a child, and there was no cable TV then, I used to watch everything on TV, even the Malay and Tamil programmes, just so that I could avoid doing homework," he says, These days, he is more likely to be watching "anything from legal dramas to sci-fi, to Channel 8 drama serials".

Mr Fong's appreciation for well-designed pieces extends to his choice of home accessories. One conversation piece is a limited edition wooden crate from Cassina, designed by Le Corbusier. Mr Fong gushes about the smooth finishing, and the flawless joinery. He says excitedly that while it looks like a fancy crate, it can be used as a side table, a low chair or as a foot stool. "Some friends love it so much that they want to get one too, while others think I'm crazy for buying this."

Sharp-eyed visitors will notice several animal accessories around the home, such as the Eames House Bird, the Magis Puppy, and a rooster perching on a stand. "I trained in zoology, although I never practised," he says.

On the TV console is a red plastic toy car, from British label Playforever. "The red makes it look like it doesn't fit in with the rest of the apartment, and I like throwing in surprises like that," says Mr Fong.

The bachelor also gives his personal touch to the home by displaying family photos in his bedroom. "There are some of me from my younger days, some with my niece and nephew. I am constantly adding new ones."

Mr Fong's eye for detail goes beyond furnishings to the hardware. Rather than paint the walls, he prefers wallpaper. One wall in the living room is covered with textured, black wallpaper, while the opposite wall shows off a striped pattern. The apartment's white laminate cupboards were replaced with black ones that have a slight leather finish. "To me, it is not just the colour that matters, but the texture as well."

Black features mostly in the apartment, and the colour initially did not go down well with Mr Fong's father. "He kept asking me if I was sure about it, especially when black is an unusual colour for the living room. But he likes the end result," says Mr Fong. "I had to reassure him that I knew what I was doing."

The apartment's revamped look makes it look cosy, but Mr Fong says he would rather not put a label on it. "Let's just say this the Ian Fong look."

site_title: The Arts House like you've never seen it
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The Arts House like you've never seen it

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN The Arts House turns 10 next month, it will be transformed almost beyond recognition. For the low ticket price of $10, you get to wander its classic colonial halls, and stumble into a dance club, a lover's quarrel, a cleaner's monologue, an alternate history tour, and even a horror story or two.

The lover's quarrel, incidentally, will be played three times, each time by a different couple - just in case, you know, you can't get enough of it. (Of course, you don't have to watch all three performances.)

Meanwhile, the cleaner's monologue will be performed by Siti Khalijah Zainal, the white-hot comedian who's the latest addition to the cast of popular sketch-show The Noose. And the strange guided tour - well, let's just leave it at "strange".

Conceived by award-winning playwright and director Chong Tze Chien, The Arts House is marking its 10-year milestone by, well, "disappearing". It wants to imagine a scenario in an alternate universe where The Arts House has been replaced by a dance club or a mega bookstore.

And, considering how other old buildings such as Capitol and Rex Cinemas have been taken over and refurbished for other commercial purposes, it's an alternate reality that's not all that hard to imagine.

The Arts House itself is housed in a 200-year-old building that was formerly Singapore's first Parliament House, before being renovated in 2002 and converted into The Arts House on March 26, 2004.

As director William Phuan explains: "We are playing with the concept: can the absence of The Arts House make the heart grow fonder?"

Apart from the immersive visual and performance installation show within the building, there will be concerts on March 28 and 29 on the lawn, with a line-up of Singapore musicians, including Gareth Fernandez, Nick Chim and Natalie Hiong. There will also be an audio-visual installation featuring 30 recordings of poems about places in Singapore read by the poets themselves, including Arthur Yap, Alfian Sa'at and Edwin Thumboo.

The Arts House anniversary programmes run from March 26 to April 6. For a full list of the programmes, visit

SUBSCRIBERS

A balanced package

More independent wellness-related businesses are forming clusters to offer a total health experience. By Rachel Loi and Chew Hui-Yan

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT'S easy to say that you want to become healthy and fit, but trying to find the right wellness plan could well stymie your best intentions. First, you need to find the right gym. Then, what diet to follow. And where to find a doctor who can give you good advice. Or a nutritionist, a physiotherapist or even a yoga instructor?

Apart from big wellness centres like COMO Shambhala or Veritas Spa, more independent health-related businesses are joining forces to offer one-stop holistic programmes to make the transition to good health a logistical breeze.

Take Ian Tan - co-founder of Ritual Gym - who has a personal interest in exploring all healthy avenues apart from his specialist fitness centre. Since he started Ritual early last year with his partners, Mr Tan has come across other small outfits with a similar vision of providing quality healthcare and services.

He has since teamed up with physiotherapists, local eateries and even a small family-owned American shoe company which makes minimalist shoes that help keep your feet healthy, to create a network of services for his clients, mainly Singaporeans or expatriates working in the CBD. Their programmes have already gained traction, says Mr Tan, adding that their list of seven restaurants serving "Ritual style" meals - served with more vegetables and less carbohydrates - will soon double due to interest from eateries as well as clients' demands. It's basically a value-added service for clients, as the gym only stands to gain more awareness, explains Mr Tan. "Since we're interested in this, why not point people in the right direction so they don't have to waste time learning about this stuff on their own," he reasons.

Sharing his view is Adeline Tan of LINS Smoodees, who started her green smoothie business in 2010, and recently teamed up with local clinical and holistic nutrition company Biotailor, as well as certified yoga instructor Johnson Anand Saurabh. Together they are planning a programme called the LINS Energy Detox Series, in line with Ms Tan's ultimate goal to be a concierge to her clients and help them find the services they are looking for, since there is a limit to what she can provide. "It's out of passion anyway," she explains. "I was always driven by 'kaypoh-ness' to make referrals and recommendations, because people were always coming to me and asking where to get this or that done."

Another thing she notes is that there has been growing public interest in this area, with more Singaporeans aware of their own health. Echoing her view are the owners of Afterglow, who have also noticed more Singaporeans taking charge of their health. The lifestyle and food concept started off as a vegetarian deli but has now expanded to even organising a yoga farm tour in March, which will take place at local organic farm Quan Fa. "When we talk to customers who come in and mention they do yoga and things like that, we thought why not tie everything together?" says Carmen Low, co-founder of Afterglow. "People are genuinely interested in these things, which are sorely lacking in Singapore." According to Ms Low, their community started with the intention of making a healthy lifestyle accessible to people, while at the same time expanding their own clientele. "Because everybody knows that if you just focus on being a vegetarian place, you will alienate a lot of people. And I want people to actually like coming here," she explains.

But a more cautious voice against the trend comes from nutritionist Dana Heather of Balanced Living - a wellness centre offering consultations, workshops, as well as a healthy food joint called The Living Café. She prefers to engage overseas experts to conduct her talks and workshops instead of teaming up with local businesses because she feels the players in the Singapore wellness industry still lack proper information to back up their practices.

"I think there are a lot of new kids on the block that are finding things like detoxification a trendy little thing," says Ms Heather, 49, who holds a pre-med degree and a masters in holistic nutrition. "They're like: 'Let's do a cleanse here and a cleanse there', but they don't really know what they're doing. Information can change a life, not trendy things. So it should not be about the latest health trend, it should be about the shift in consciousness and awareness. They should be looking at empowerment through education," she adds.

By Rachel Loi

site_title: Made by me
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Made by me

The cottage industry is alive and well in Singapore, with several small scale businesses growing out of passion and hobbyist ventures. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NOWADAYS, when it's so easy to buy things off the shelf or online made by yet another big manufacturer, the sight of something made by hand is bound to attract attention and appreciation. At the Made in SG Market held over the weekend at the National Design Centre, the crowds who thronged the site could not get enough of these hand-made products, touching them and chatting with their makers. Sparking off hopes that the cottage industry has a welcome place in Singapore, BT Weekend speaks to a group of people who are driving this movement with their bare hands.

GSH Conserves

www.gshconserves.com

POP quiz: name a local jam that is not kaya. If you are hard-pressed for an answer, don't be. After all, most jams sold at supermarkets are often made with imported fruits; strawberries, Valencia oranges and such. Joey Gan, 31, a former conservation officer with the National Parks Board, wants to change that with his range of jams.

Called GSH Conserves, the jams he makes use only tropical fruit, such as lychee, dragonfruit, mango and passionfruit. GSH is an acronym of Mr Gan's Chinese name, Gan Soon Hock.

"I wanted to start something on my own, and found that the jam business is quite untouched in Singapore," says Mr Gan. "Plus having my own line of jam complements the ever growing local baking scene."

He also noticed that there was a dearth of jam made from local or tropical fruits. By researching online, and after weeks of trial and error, he developed his own jam recipe.

Using tropical fruits meant that he could introduce new jam flavours to Singapore, and also do his bit for the environment by reducing the carbon footprint incurred when selecting local ingredients. He sources for his fruits from the Pasir Panjang wholesale centre. Jam making takes place in a kitchen in Macpherson.

The process involves cutting the fruits and boiling them to the right consistency. Some sugar is added to the mix, but Mr Gan leaves out any artificial preservatives. He also does the bottling himself.

Since last October, he has been selling five types of jams: dragonfruit and lychee, pumpkin and cinnamon, passionfruit, mango and lime and sweet chilli dip. A 50ml jar costs $4, while the bigger 180ml jar retails for $10. Passionfruit is the best-seller.

Mr Gan produces about 60 to 80 bottles of jam each day. GSH Conserves are sold at Strictly Pastry cafe at Joo Chiat Road, Salad Stop! at Pasar Bella, The Gardens Shop at Singapore Botanic Gardens and Overdoughs Bakery in Middle Road.

He also retails at flea markets, such as the recent Made in SG Market at the National Design Centre, where he sold out 400 bottles of jam over two days.

It's a one-man show and Mr Gan admits that jam-making can sometimes get dull because it is a repetitive job. "I'm doing this alone," he says. He is at the kitchen three times a week, five hours each time.

There are no plans yet to introduce new jams, but Mr Gan hopes to hire help, so that he can expand the business.

He believes that homemade jams like his have great appeal, because "people are used to buying food off the shelves. But when they buy something that I've made, they get to meet the person behind the product too."

Go nuts

The Hunters' Kitchenette

www.hunterskitchenette.com

IT'S all about clean eating in the Salim household. "We follow the Paleolithic diet, eating natural food that our ancestors ate when they were hunter-gatherers," says Herbert Salim, 38, an architect.

No processed food for his family of four and that extends even to their choice of bread spreads. Rather than buying off-the-shelf spreads, Mr Salim makes his own.

Friends and family love what he has done, and together with his wife, Natalia, they recently started retailing their own brand of nut butters. The Hunters' Kitchenette range of nut butters include almond, macadamia, pistachio, cashew and hazelnut. The name is a play on the hunter-gatherer diet that the family is on.

From 9pm to 1am, the couple are at a commercial kitchen in Macpherson, churning out the nut butters. Raw nuts, purchased from a local supplier, are roasted before they are ground into a buttery paste.

"We don't add any additional oil to the mixture. But we do add sea salt and coconut palm sugar to enhance the taste," says Mr Salim. "There are no artificial preservatives added either." This means that the butters can only keep for three months once opened, compared to two years for commercially made ones.

Apart from producing the butters, the couple also do the bottling themselves, and are able to produce about 15 bottles of nut butter in an hour.

The nut butters cost from $12.50 a bottle, depending on the type of nut. Pistachio is the priciest of the lot at $17.50 a bottle, but it is also the best selling flavour.

The hazelnut butter came about as his children were fond of a particular commercial hazelnut chocolate spread. "Unfortunately, sugar and palm oil are its two main ingredients, which is not good," he says. His hazelnut spread has some cocoa powder in it, and tastes more natural too.

The nut butters are currently on sale at Takashimaya food hall till tomorrow, and he also sells them at the Farmers' Market at The Pantry at Loewen Gardens.

"The expatriate crowd is familiar with nut butters, but for the locals, this is still something new," he says.

Flavours in the works include pecan and walnut, and even a mixture of nuts. Once, a customer asked for him to mix almonds, macadamias, pistachios, cashew and hazelnuts all into one spread. "It turned out surprisingly good," he says. He adds that he can make customised nut butters too.

For now, this is a sideline business, but Mr Salim is passionate about it. "It is heartening to know that I can make something good for others as well."

All fired up

Weekend Worker

weekendworker.sg

MOST people are likely to spend their weekends chilling out at cafes or spending the day at the mall, but not this trio of friends - Ivan Lee, Ong Su Loon and Chloe Tan.

You are more likely to find them in a studio in Changi, that is so hidden away, it cannot be located on Google maps.

The three form Weekend Worker, a ceramics collective that creates pieces that are simple in design, yet have a distinctive look. "We aim to take everyday objects and translate them into treasured experiences," says Ms Tan.

"We met about two years ago, when all of us were trying our hand at ceramics," says Ms Tan. "Our frequent chats with each other drew us together to start Weekend Worker, a platform for us to share our craft with others who may be interested in ceramics."

All three have day jobs, which they declined to reveal. Ceramic production usually takes place over the weekends, hence the name.

Their studio is nothing fancy, save for three throwing wheels and an electric kiln for production and firing. "Ceramics was the medium which brought the three of us together. It is a therapeutic routine which we enjoy - finding inspirations from daily objects and applying them onto our craft process and pieces," says Ms Tan.

Each of them come up with their own creations, which are mostly cups and bowls. "The pieces are all functional ware, because this is what we like to do, and along the way, we can use them ourselves too," says Ms Tan.

For example, Mr Lee once made an unusually large bowl that could hold two packets of instant noodles because there was not a bowl big enough in the market.

Making ceramics is not something that gives instant gratification, as after moulding the clay, the piece has to be left for almost two weeks to dry completely.

Once it has reached the bone dry state, it is then fired in the kiln, before a glaze is applied.

"The beauty of a handmade product is such that each product has a thought process, idea and story behind them," says Ms Tan. "With the rise in popularity of locally designed and made products, we believe that the market for handmade products in Singapore is growing."

Weekend Workers pieces retail at pop-up cafe, Compl(e)ments Of at Dunlop Street till March 28, and at Necessary Provision cafe at Eng Kong Terrace.

Mr Ong also has some pieces that he created on sale at online store, Haystakt. A textured bowl costs $70, while a marbled vase retails for $180.

Refined craft

The J.Myers Company

www.jmyersco.com

WITH its fancy sounding name, The J.Myers Company could easily be assumed to be an American brand, but it's really the name of a leather goods maker located in the heart of Chinatown.

"The name J.Myers is a pun on my name," says Jeremiah Ang, 30, who started the company about four years ago.

It was the hunt for a belt that led the former photographer's assistant to start the company. "I wanted to buy a belt from an online shop, but shipping it here would cost me $300," recalls Mr Ang, who says that since his younger days, he was always trying to make things on his own.

He read up on leather crafting, bought himself some equipment, such as pliers, knives, stitching oil and leather hides, and made his first belt.

But that was not enough. "The books only taught a rugged style of leather crafting," says Mr Ang. "I'm more keen on the kind of leathercrafting that the luxury houses do."

Unfortunately, Mr Ang found little resources in this area, and there was no craftsman that he could learn from. But he was undeterred. "I would try different styles of stitching the leather, and then stand outside the Hermes shop window to compare my stitching with theirs," he says.

The self-taught leathergoods maker would also take apart old wallets to study how they were put together. For example, a bifold wallet could have 20 to 30 pieces of leather to put together. "I had to learn how to fit all the pieces together to form a wallet. For example, the outer piece must be longer than an inner piece," says Mr Ang, who adds that even the thickness of the leather hide can make or break a piece.

Using the 'dissected' pieces of the wallet, he would draw up patterns, much like what a tailor does.

"Without a good pattern, the final result would not look right," he says.

He used to accept customised orders for leather bags from private clients, but no longer does that.

These days, he works with companies to create bespoke leather goods for their customers. His clients include Bentley, Lexus, and the Singapore Stock Exchange, for which he has designed and produced small leather goods such as cardholders, wallets and luggage tags.

For private clients, Mr Ang creates bespoke watch straps. "Most watch dealers only have a small selection of straps. But I can customise one for them," he says. Wrist measurements are taken and Mr Ang creates straps patterns that are unique to each client.

When it comes to choice of hides, Mr Ang uses calf and alligator, sourced from a local tannery. Clients can pick their choice of grain as well. Each watch strap takes about four to six weeks to complete, and costs from $160 for a calf hide strap and from $280 for an alligator one.

"I like working with leather, because the material has value," says Mr Ang. "You can create leather pieces that have a heirloom quality."

His monthly paycheck goes towards new tools and leather hides. "The business doesn't really pay well, but I do it because of passion."

Home brew

Jungle Beer

www.junglebeer.com

SEMBAWANG may be the last place you would expect to have a microbrewery, but it is home to Jungle Beer, which began selling craft beer in 2011.

The company was started by Adi Challa, 32, together with three college friends. "I lived in the US and the UK and was interested in beers besides lagers," says the South Indian national.

With an interest in brewing his own beer, Mr Challa packed his bags, and headed to Edinburgh to study brewing, later working at a microbrewery there.

The four decided on Singapore as their location of choice to start a microbrewery. "Back in 2009, the craft beer scene was just starting and we saw the potential of its rapid growth, and it also helped that we could find support from the government," says Mr Challa.

They spent 2010 looking for equipment and developing the business model, and by July 2011, they began retailing beer.

Today, Jungle Beer offers six types of beers, each with a local sounding name, including Siloso Beach, Kiasu Stout, Quayside Coolie and Uncle Sam. Its two most popular beers are Singlish Ale, a strong English ale with caramel, and Orchard Road, which has hints of mango and orange with the sharpness of wheat beer.

The beer is brewed entirely in Singapore, using malt that is mostly imported from the UK, hops from the US and Britain, yeast from France, and good ole' tap water from Singapore.

The microbrewery produces 5,000 litres of beer a month, and Mr Challah says it can produce 12,000 litres if needed to.

While some other microbreweries operate a bar on the premises, Mr Challa says Jungle Beer is solely a production brewery. "We are not really into running a pub, and we have more confidence in the brewing business," he says.

The beer is sold in draught form and in bottles. Mr Challa also works with restaurants to produce bespoke beers.

Slightly more than two years since running the microbrewery, the group realised that "it is expensive to brew beer in Singapore", says Mr Challa. The craft beer scene has also become more competitive with more imported beers being sold here. He hopes to find a location outside Singapore to start another microbrewery.

But passion keeps him in Singapore for now. Mr Challa, who was previously working in the service line, says that while he enjoyed his old job, it had "intangible value". But with beer brewing, it is a different story. "I am creating a product, something that is tangible, and I know that people enjoy it."

content:
Hone your investment game and win prizes

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

FROM today, users of BT's investment portal

BTInvest

can trade stocks in real time with virtual money and stand to win prizes. BT has teamed up with the popular virtual trading platform TrakInvest to offer this service at no charge.

All users need to do is sign up on the BTInvest home page (

BTInvest.com.sg

) for a free TrakInvest account. BTInvest is also free to access. Upon registration, users will be allocated S$100,000 in virtual cash, which they can use immediately to invest based on actual market prices. They will also have free access to more than 12,000 research reports on companies, which are updated weekly. If they wish, they can participate in a competition. The three users who grow their portfolios the most by April 15 will win Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 tablets. The competition is open to all residents of Singapore - although the platform is open to users anywhere. The platform covers six equity markets: Singapore, the US, Hong Kong, India, Australia and China.

TrakInvest's goal is financial education and talent identification. BT's goal is to give BTInvest users a new way to not only view market data, but interact with it in a collaborative, immersive and risk-free way.

"The best way to learn how to invest is with real stocks, at real prices, in real time - but not with real money," said BT associate editor Vikram Khanna.

The TrakInvest platform also has a social element: Users can track and follow other successful traders and, if they wish, emulate their moves. Since real names are required by TrakInvest not just for registration but to claim prizes, users can be reasonably confident that they are following actual people.

Singapore-based TrakInvest was founded in January 2013 by Bobby Bhatia, whose background includes a stint at AIG as head of principal investments. Prior to AIG, he was a principal at JP Morgan Partners working on Asian leveraged buyouts.

The platform is used by more than 150 educational institutions in more than 80 countries.

"TrakInvest and BT share a common vision of democratising news and information," said Mr Bhatia. "I believe TrakInvest's platform, in collaboration with BTInvest, will effectively reach out to a broad group of Singaporeans including students, retail investors, retirees, etc, and to empower them to learn and improve their trading skills."

Afterglow

24 Keong Saik Road, 62248921

Partners include:

lululemon athletica

83 Club Street #04-01, 64386502

Quan Fa Organic Farm

35 Murai Farmway, 67937693

WHEN Carmen Low and Lionel Ang first opened their raw food deli in January, it was called Glow in the daytime - serving wheat, sugar and dairy-free foods that adhered to raw food principles. At night, it morphed into Afterglow, a bar serving alcohol and raw bites as well. But with its official opening this month and the widening of its business to include retailing toiletries and tie-ups with other health-related entities, the two partners decided to rebrand and just use the name Afterglow.

The first tie-up was with Thai organic toiletries company Urban Tree, which makes paraben and sulfate-free toiletries such as soap and shampoo, which Ms Low and Mr Ang sell at the deli. "We believe that the stuff you put into your body and what you use externally does affect you," explains Ms Low.

The duo are constantly looking for partnerships that would complement the Afterglow philosophy. "We look for like-minded people," adds Mr Ang.

They have also hooked up with yoga apparel brand lululemon athletica and organic farmers Quan Fa for yoga farm tours. The first tour on March 16 kicks off with a one-hour session of yoga by lululemon volunteer teachers on Quan Fa's farm located at Woodlands, followed by a tour of the farm grounds and a lesson on how to grow sunflower sprouts. Finally, Ms Low and Mr Ang will conduct a class on how to use the sprouts in salads. Depending on the success of this inaugural tour, the partners will decide whether to carry out more tours in the future.

Valenssa Lee, showroom manager for lululemon, is enthusiastic about working with Afterglow and Quan Fa on the tour. She says: "We love to work with local businesses and support them. We are also trying to promote yoga as part of a healthy lifestyle."

Jun Jie, the business development manager of Quan Fa Organic Farm, explains: "We supply Afterglow with fresh produce that they use at their deli. Moreover, our focus at Quan Fa is to show people that organic farms exist in Singapore. Through the yoga farm tour, we achieve that while encouraging people to eat healthily."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

AIA S'pore logs 15% rise in net operating profit

Value of new business up 22% at US$269m

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

STRONG momentum and higher agent productivity drove AIA Singapore's growth in the fiscal year that ended on Nov 30.

Its operating profit after tax rose 15 per cent to US$396 million; its value of new business (VONB) rose 22 per cent to US$269 million, and VONB margin rose 2.2 percentage points to 67.3 per cent.

AIA chief executive Tan Hak Leh said the "solid" performance was attributable to an increased uptake of protection and long-term savings products. "The amount of protection business has grown substantially industry-wide. We're happy to make a meaningful contribution to that. Measured by the protection value or sum assured, we have close to a quarter of the business.

"Growth in the protection business pretty much cuts across the board, from the mass market covering premature death, critical illness and medical insurance to the higher end of the market such as jumbo universal life . . . business."

AIA Group, which released its annual results yesterday, reported that group operating profit after tax rose 16 per cent to US$2.5 billion.

Net profits, which include marked-to-market movements from the equity portfolio, fell 7 per cent to US$2.8 billion, reflecting a decline in equity markets in the second half.

The group achieved a 25 per cent rise in VONB to US$1.49 billion; its VONB margin rose 0.5 of a percentage point to 44 per cent.

Operating earnings per share rose 16 per cent to 20.91 US cents.

The board recommended a final dividend of 28.62 Hong Kong cents per share, subject to shareholders' approval; this takes the total dividend for 2013 to 42.55 Hong Kong cents per share, a 15 per cent increase over 2012.

In a statement, AIA group chief executive and president Mark Tucker said: "Asia continues to provide one of the most attractive and resilient life insurance markets in the world. The demographic drivers in the region, coupled with low levels of social welfare provision and the rapid expansion in the numbers of middle and high-income households, provide enormous growth opportunities and all of this is happening at an unprecedented scale.

"AIA is exceptionally well positioned to capitalise on these opportunities, given the quality and scale of our distribution platform, our depth of experience . . . and our unrivalled financial strength."

In Singapore, Mr Tan said, the agency's force remains the main channel of distribution. The company now has some 4,000 agents, up from about 3,500 two years ago. Its recruitment programmes delivered a 44 per cent rise in the number of active new agents over that in 2012.

Last year, when HSBC Insurance announced that it would cease selling products through tied agents, it was reported that AIA Singapore would offer jobs to about 400 HSBC agents.

Standard & Poor's yesterday said its rating on the holding company AIA Group and its subsidiaries were unaffected by the group's results.

"We consider the group's financial flexibility to be strong, and believe that its capitalisation will remain supportive of the rating for the next two years."

site_title: Tax deductions for banks' Basel III issues
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tax deductions for banks' Basel III issues

Additional Tier 1 instruments to be treated as debt for tax purposes, to level field for S'pore-incorporated banks

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOCAL banks which have been selling debt to boost their capital in order to fall in line with stricter regulatory requirements gained more clarity yesterday on the tax treatment for their funding instruments.

The government said: "To provide tax certainty and maintain a level playing field for Singapore-incorporated banks which issue Basel III Additional Tier 1 instruments, such instruments - other than shares - will be treated as debt for tax purposes.

"Hence, distributions on such instruments will be deductible for issuers, and taxable in the hands of investors, subject to existing rules."

Banks like DBS Group Holdings, OCBC bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have been issuing Additional Tier 1 instruments such as perpetuals to meet the requirements of Basel III, the global standard to strengthen bank capital requirements by increasing bank liquidity and decreasing bank leverage. Basel III requirements kicked in here last year, two years ahead of the international deadline of Jan 1, 2015.

UOB's managing director and head of investor relations Jimmy Koh said: "We welcome the government's efforts to provide certainty on the tax treatment of Basel III Additional Tier 1 instruments. With this certainty, we are likely to see more Basel III instruments issued in the market; investors will benefit from having more options to choose from."

A DBS spokeswoman commented that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has always adopted a prudent, disciplined approach in supervising financial institutions, while preserving the industry's high level of competitiveness. Noting that Singapore banks are being required to comply with Basel III earlier and at higher standards than in other jurisdictions, she added: "The tax deductibility for issuers of Basel III additional Tier 1 instruments is encouraging, as banks here (make the) transition to a Basel III regime."

Consultants also agreed that the change removes uncertainty for tax purposes.

Amy Ang, a financial services tax partner in Ernst & Young, said: "For accounting, it remains equity, based on features of Basel III, but it is debt for tax purposes."

Paul Lau, a financial services tax partner in PwC Singapore, said: "It's good for the local banks, giving additional clarity in terms of treatment and it makes issuance of such instruments more efficient."

Other changes for the sector were the rationalising of tax concessions and extending them for the fund-management industry for another five years.

The 2012 Singapore Asset Management Industry Survey by MAS noted that Singapore-based managers were managing $1.62 trillion in assets.

Lim Maan Huey, a PwC Singapore financial services tax partner, expressed hope that the extension and the enhancements would enable the $1.62 trillion figure to be breached quickly and establish for Singapore a greater market share in the global asset management arena.

To boost Singapore as an infrastructure business trust-listing destination, the tax-exemption for foreign-sourced interest for these listed entities has been expanded.

Ms Lim said: "Singapore already has good treatment for business trusts; the issue was that it had conditions attached... This makes the listing process easier."

The Budget also extended the waiving of withholding tax requirements to non-banks - as has been done for banks since February 2012.

To reduce compliance costs for businesses, payers will no longer need to withhold tax on payments such as royalties and interest paid to the Singapore branches of non-resident companies.

Alan Lau, a KPMG partner and head of financial services tax, said: "It's win-win, the reduction of compliance costs is for the payer, while for the recipient, they don't have to face a cash-flow crunch."

site_title: FY2013 surplus revised upwards to $3.92b
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

FY2013 surplus revised upwards to $3.92b

Actual FY2012 overall surplus also revised upwards to $5.82b from $3.86b, with operating revenue of $55.81b

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LARGER than the official estimate, but smaller than the market's forecast - such was the $3.92 billion Budget surplus amassed by the government in FY2013, thanks to stronger-than-expected collections from stamp duties and vehicle quota premiums.

While lower than the actual FY2012 overall surplus - which was revised upwards to $5.82 billion, from $3.86 billion - FY2013's surplus is about 1.62 times the government's earlier estimate of $2.42 billion.

"The stronger fiscal surplus was mainly due to cyclical factors. They will not last, and we should see a tighter Budget position in the coming years," said Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam in his annual Budget speech yesterday.

Private sector economists were expecting a far fatter surplus, with predictions reaching up to $7 billion. But they did not foresee the larger-than-projected spending on special transfers that happened in FY2013.

Special transfers, excluding top-ups to endowment and trust funds, swelled to $3.22 billion, almost two-and-a-half times the $1.3 billion estimated a year before. This was due to higher Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) Bonus and PIC cash payouts, as well as the bringing forward of the first tranche of the Wage Credit Scheme payout to FY2013.

Revised figures for FY2013 show that operating revenue hit $57.15 billion - 3.9 per cent or $2.12 billion more than estimated - with stamp duties and vehicle quota premiums as the main drivers behind the increase.

Despite several rounds of cooling measures which have reduced overall demand somewhat, the property market remained firmer than the government had expected. As a result, stamp duty collections exceeded estimates by 31.5 per cent, or $1 billion, to reach $4.05 billion in FY2013.

Revenue from vehicle quota premiums, too, came in higher by 13.2 per cent, or $0.32 billion, to total $2.76 billion. Motor vehicle taxes grew 8.7 per cent, or $0.14 billion, to $1.69 billion.

A higher-than-expected number of vehicle deregistrations (which in turn led to higher quotas of certificates of entitlement issued in FY2013), as well as more commercial vehicles being renewed helped to bolster these increases.

Corporate income taxes, however, was one of the few line items which came below expectations. At $12.55 billion, corporate income taxes were 3 per cent or $0.39 billion lower than estimated, because of higher claims for capital allowances.

The revised total expenditure for FY2013 was $52.34 billion - 2 per cent less than the previous estimate of $53.41 billion - mainly due to lower spending by the Ministry of Transport (MOT) and the Ministry of National Development (MND).

At MOT, the insolvency of one of the Downtown Line Stage 2 contractors meant delays in progress; at MND, there was lower spending for public housing upgrading programmes, due to the slow progress and deferment of some initiatives.

Top-ups to endowment and trust funds were unchanged at $5.59 billion. Net investment returns contribution (NIRC) was $7.94 billion, 3 per cent or $0.24 billion higher than the $7.7 billion earlier estimated.

Separately, actual figures for FY2012 also yielded positive surprises. Operating revenue was $55.81 billion, surpassing the $55.18 billion published last year.

Total expenditure was $49 billion, below the projected $50.11 billion.

site_title: Firms warn of layoffs to cope with costs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Firms warn of layoffs to cope with costs

They say there is more focus on long term than immediate concerns

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

COMPANIES here may have to lay off workers to cope with cost pressures as they respond to what they say is a Budget that is more focused on the long term than addressing their immediate concerns.

While business leaders whom BT spoke to commended the government for doing more to encourage productivity and innovation, they felt that the absence of direct measures to help firms with cost and cash flow issues meant that they might need to try to do more with less by cutting their headcount.

"I applaud the government's efforts to cater to the needs of SMEs in the Budget. But even though this is a good start, I believe the government can still do more, as SMEs are often faced with pressure margins and rising costs," said Yong Yean Chau, CEO of Parkway Trust Management.

"There are good things in the Budget to push through the economic transformation. In order to gain productivity, companies will need to look at technology and automation, but there is a limit to how much of that we can do," added Douglas Foo, chairman of Sakae Holdings.

Ong Jun Quan, executive director of Soon Li Heng Civil Engineering, said that he had hoped that the Budget would provide some cash grants to SMEs to help them with their cash flow problems.

Given the Budget's emphasis on restructuring, firms said that they will leverage on the productivity measures to reduce manpower costs. "The Productivity and Innovation Credits (PIC) scheme is a major point in the Budget, and it is beneficial to SMEs. But as costs continue to rise, we will have to do with lesser manpower and more efficiency. Through the PIC, the government is helping us to do that," said Arun Narula, chairman of Mercantile Pacific Asia. His company aims to be more efficient in two years' time by tapping the extended PIC scheme and introducing new technology and automation.

Sakae Holding's Mr Foo acknowledged that the enhancement of the Continuing Education and Training (CET) system through a $500 million increase of the Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund (LLEF) will help people to upgrade their skills and be more mobile. He explained that with gains in productivity, if companies needed fewer man-hours for projects, then "they do not need full-time employees to be there all the time". This frees up employees to work freelance or part-time for a few employers in the industry, he said. Under such a shared-labour resources model, companies can become more nimble with a leaner workforce.

Mr Foo noted that since there are limits to how much productivity certain sectors can gain through technology and automation alone, the Budget could have introduced measures to help companies relook their business models and address their cost problems. "The Budget contained measures to help start-ups, but I feel that there is already enough help for start-ups out there. Instead, there should have been a focus on helping SMEs with business model innovation through grants to engage consultants, for example, so that they can review their business models to remain more competitive," he said.

The Budget was also concerned with improving productivity in the construction sector through raising levies for lower-skilled foreign labour, a skills upgrading scheme for these workers, the use of more productive materials and extended employment stay in Singapore for higher-skilled labourers.

Soon Li Heng's Mr Ong said that these measures were designed to help construction firms reduce their reliance on manpower, particularly low-skilled foreign labour. For instance, the push for more productive materials such as prefabrication units would cut down on the amount of manpower needed.

While he welcomed the skills upgrading scheme, Mr Ong felt that this was bitter-sweet for him. "As for the skills upgrading course, some of my workers are really good in some skills but they are generally not good in English or languages in general. Therefore they will fall through the cracks because they may not be able to pass the course and upgrade even though they are really good in their work," he said.

As for the extension of period of employment for higher-skilled workers, he pointed out that this only applied to workers from non-traditional sources (NTS) and China, but the bulk of his workers came from traditional sources, particularly India. "So for me, this measure does not change my situation. Again, they are on the same shorter work permit stays as before, unless I now go and replace them with NTS workers."

Interestingly, the companies that BT spoke to seemed unfazed by the the increase in employer's contribution to CPF, saying that this was likely to have a minimum impact on them.

Some firms welcomed the measures to boost the internationalisation of local companies. "With the simplification of programmes such as the Market Readiness Assistance and Global Company Partnerships, SMEs are a step closer to having the support needed for their plans to succeed internationally," said Ingrid Sidiadinoto, managing director of UPS Singapore.

Mr Narula added that these measures are positive as they will help increase Singapore brands globally. "From our perspective, we welcome these timely measures as we are preparing to expand our brand globally in the next few years."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

EMS Energy back in the black with $3.81m profit

Factors include revenue rise and higher gross margin

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CATALIST-listed EMS Energy returned to the black for the full year of 2013 thanks to higher revenue, improved gross profit margin, a disposal gain and the absence this time round of a goodwill impairment.

The group yesterday posted a net profit of $3.81 million for the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2013, a reversal from a net loss of $16.91 million for FY2012.

Revenue from continuing operations rose 13 per cent to $21.12 million, attributed mainly to the accelerated progress of all ongoing projects, particularly during the second half of the financial year which followed efforts to improve internal efficiency and project management.

Gross profit was $4.18 million, against FY2012's $359,000, as gross margin rose to 19.8 per cent from 1.9 per cent.

The bottomline got a major boost from "other income" which rose to $7.9 million from $171,000. This was attributed mostly to a one-time gain of $7.09 million from the disposal of a stake in a subsidiary.

Ting Teck Jin, executive chairman and chief executive officer, told The Business Times that this was to allow the company to focus on its core business.

Administrative expenses more than halved to $9.26 million from FY2012's $19.36 million, which included a goodwill impairment of $10.22 million for discontinued operations.

FY2013 earnings per share from continuing operations came to 0.48 cent, against the previous year's loss per share of 3.48 cents.

EMS said yesterday that it has entered into an agreement to lease from JTC a 23,237.88 square metre parcel of land in Tuas for 16 years and eight months, commencing May 1 this year. EMS will be constructing a new facility for its offshore and marine activities that will be five times bigger than its current premises.

The company will pay JTC annual rent and annual water frontage fees of about $360,000 and $158,000, respectively.

On completion, the facility will replace the group's current premises, which has 13 years of remaining lease. The group expects to move into its new premises by FY2015.

Mr Ting said: "Upon completion of the new waterfront facility in Tuas, the group is positioned to take on much larger projects especially with the major advantage of a waterfront boundary. It will also allow us to bring various services - currently outsourced - under one roof, leading to economies of scale and lower costs."

The group's order book to-date stood at about $55 million, mostly for delivery over the next 12 months.

On the business outlook, EMS is seeking to secure two repeat DES contracts from Koastal and a separate DES contract from another third-party in FY2014, each estimated to be worth US$36 million.

EMS expects its revenue in FY2014 to exceed that of FY2013.

The counter closed trading 0.7 cent up at 7.6 cents yesterday.

No easy money to be made

Published Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE investor Zheng Yang Yan became acquainted with Bitcoins in April last year, when the digital currency's price had spiked to around S$260 - and then subsequently crashed to about S$50.

Its very volatility piqued Mr Zheng into doing research as to how to "mine" Bitcoins for money. Fast forward to today, and the 29-year-old investor and Bitcoin miner has realised just how tough it is to break even from the exercise - let alone profit from it.

Bitcoin mining is the act of validating Bitcoin transactions, that is verifying that the recipient in a transaction is authorised to receive the amount of digital currency stipulated by the owner of the Bitcoins. When an online community gets together to do this verifying work, it maintains and secures the Bitcoin network - crucial, given that the currency is not managed by any central bank.

site_title: Fourth-quarter GDP growth cut to 2.4%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fourth-quarter GDP growth cut to 2.4%

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Washington

THE US government has slashed its estimate for fourth-quarter growth as consumer spending and exports were less robust than initially thought, leaving the US economy on a more sustainable path of modest expansion.

Gross domestic product (GDP) expanded at a 2.4 per cent annual rate, the Commerce Department said yesterday. That was down sharply from the 3.2 per cent pace reported in January and the 4.1 per cent logged in the third quarter.

It is not unusual for the government to make sharp revisions to GDP numbers, as it does not have complete data when it makes its initial estimates. In fact, the latest figures will be subject to revisions next month as more information is received.

The revision left GDP just above the economy's potential growth trend, which analysts put somewhere between a 2 per cent and 2.3 per cent pace.

Consumer spending accounted for a large chunk of the revision after retail sales in November and December came in weaker than assumed.

Consumer spending was cut to a 2.6 per cent rate, still the fastest pace since the first quarter of 2012. It had previously been reported to have grown at a 3.3 per cent pace.

Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, contributed 1.73 percentage points to GDP growth, down from the previously reported 2.26 percentage points. As a result, final domestic demand was lowered two-tenths of a percentage point to a 1.2 per cent rate.

The loss of momentum appears to have spilled over into the first quarter of 2014, with an unusually cold winter weighing on retail sales, home building and sales, hiring and industrial production.

The Federal Reserve, which has been cutting back on the amount of money it injects into the economy through monthly bond purchases, views the recent soft patch as temporary.

Fed chairman Janet Yellen told lawmakers on Thursday that the cold weather had played a role in the weakening data. She said, however, that it would take a "significant change" to the economy's prospects for the Fed to suspend its plans to wind down its bond buying.

Despite the first quarter's weak start, economists remain optimistic that growth this year will be the strongest since the recession ended almost five years ago. For all of 2013, the economy grew 1.9 per cent.

Trade also weighed on fourth-quarter revisions, after a fall in exports in December resulted in a bigger trade deficit in the fourth quarter than the government had initially assumed.

Trade's contribution to growth was lowered to 0.99 percentage point from 1.33 percentage points. It was still the largest contribution to GDP growth since late 2010.

Inventories, previously reported to have risen by US$127.2 billion in the fourth quarter, were revised down to US$117.4 billion. The rise in the stocks of unsold goods was still the largest since early 1998 and followed a gain of US$115.7 billion in the third quarter of 2013.

The contribution to growth from inventories, which the government put at 0.42 percentage point a month ago, was revised down to only 0.14 percentage point. Excluding inventories, the economy grew at a 2.3 per cent rate, revised down from a 2.5 per cent pace. Reuters

site_title: The new gold of mining, and just as risky
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The new gold of mining, and just as risky

Bitcoin mining seems deceptively simple, but is a minefield

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE increasing use of virtual currency Bitcoin has spurred the growth of Bitcoin mining, with some Singapore firms eyeing a slice of what is a potentially lucrative - but tricky - business.

In Bitcoin mining, miners verify and record Bitcoin transactions made in exchange for transaction fees and newly minted Bitcoins. Seen as gold's "new rival", the Bitcoin mining process mirrors that of gold mining.

Introduced in January 2009 by its developer Satoshi Nakamoto, the deregulated cryptocurrency has quickly caught the attention of entrepreneurs, investors, politicians and regulators. However, the wide fluctuations in Bitcoin's market value overshadow its protocol, which includes its mining component.

Bitcoin mining aims to prevent fraud and double-spending by verifying transactions between Bitcoin wallets, as well as introduce more people into the system when miners are rewarded with Bitcoins.

At first glance, Bitcoin mining seems to be easy money: The necessary software and hardware are easy enough to obtain and with quick installation, miners can start profiting from mining.

That said, Bitcoin mining consumes a good amount of energy and is unconducive to countries with high electrical costs such as Singapore. Also, as good mining hardware with high raw speed performance is highly sought after, they must often be pre-ordered months in advance and can easily cost a few thousand dollars. Those available second hand are usually older-generation models with lower processing power, and are uncompetitive in the crowded mining space.

To profit from Bitcoins, miners must ensure that the total value of Bitcoins mined is higher than the total cost incurred from mining activities. Costs include the purchase of mining hardware, energy costs incurred from mining and the market value of Bitcoins (characterised by high fluctuations).

Today, there are about 12 million Bitcoins in circulation. With its total supply capped at 21 million, the system designed by Mr Nakamoto automatically adjusts to the difficulty of mining for Bitcoins, depending on how fast its algorithms are being solved.

This means that as Bitcoin mining becomes increasingly popular, it gets harder and harder to solve the algorithms and be rewarded with Bitcoins to ensure that the cryptocurrency is "unearthed" at a sustainable rate.

The remaining unmined currencies are released at a slower pace. And every few years, the creation rate of Bitcoins is halved and profitability squeezed further. It is not uncommon for miners to go into the red, as Singapore players are learning the hard way.

site_title: Getting a flick fix
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Getting a flick fix

Discerning local cinephiles are getting their fill from alternative film events, reports DYLAN TAN

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT'S no secret that Singaporeans love going to the movies. On any given weekend, the multiplexes sell out sessions hours ahead in advance, and an increasing number of cinema operators not only run midnight screenings on weekdays but even go to the extent of operating 24 hours on weekends to cope with the demand.

Cinephiles who want to go beyond mainstream releases are also getting their fix outside the multiplex with various independent outfits organising their own film events. These range from regular screenings at smaller venues in museums to larger outdoor festivals.

Fort Canning, which has hosted numerous "live" concerts, was transformed into an open air cinema last year for Films at the Fort. All 6,000 tickets for the four-day event were completely sold out, and it will be expanded to 10 days this year to feature a wider variety of films.

Perfect weather

Ben Williams of Groundswell Events, the Films at the Fort organiser, says that the concept of open-air cinemas is popular in Europe, North America and Australia. In major cities such as Paris, New York and Sydney, it often heralds the arrival of summer.

Barring rain, our tropical climate makes it suitable for holding such events all year round. "Singapore has pleasant balmy evenings that are perfect for the outdoor cinema experience," says Mr Williams. "(Open air cinemas) are a great place to relax with friends, watch a film under the stars and enjoy being in the outdoors."

Movie fans do not even need to wait till August for the next Films at the Fort because a new outdoor film event will be held at the same venue next month.

Billing itself as Singapore's first on-screen music festival, Encore will feature three nights of screenings plus themed after-parties with a "live" DJ that will kick off after the final credits roll.

"This is a new brand of movie festival for Singapore's entertainment scene," says Adela Teo of Sirens Network, the organisers of Encore. The 17-year-old company is a specialist in open-air cinema events, and incidentally handled the audio-visual equipment for Films at the Fort. It prides itself on challenging the conventional movie-going experience, and so far has organised screenings everywhere from beaches to rooftops.

Different movie-going experience

Festivals like Encore and Films at the Fort's aim is to provide movie-goers with a totally different experience from what they get at a multiplex. For instance, both offer gourmet food and drinks which one will not find at a typical cinema concession stand.

The beverage selection at Films at the Fort last year included Australian and New Zealand wines, French champagnes, boutique beers and ciders; while food came from Deliciae Hospitality Management, the owner of restaurants such as L'Entrecote and Sabio. This year, festival goers can pre-order picnic hampers if they want to skip the F&B queue. Encore has roped in a sponsor, Kronenbourg 1664, to run a full bar and will offer free-flow popcorn alongside a selection of other food and beverages.

Like the after-party segment that Encore has added on, Films at the Fort also went beyond just screening the main feature every night - it added one short film by an emerging Singaporean filmmaker every evening in a show of support for the local arts scene. "A short film about karung guni was a real hit with the audience," remarks Mr Williams.

Souping up the classics

While the line-up for these festivals usually feature titles that have already been cinematically released and are available to rent or buy on DVDs, Ms Teo feels confident of drawing a crowd because the three movies that Encore is running - The Beatles' 1964 black-and-white comedy A Hard Day's Night; John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John's 1978 high school musical Grease; and the 2008 big-screen adaptation of the ABBA juke-box West End hit Mamma Mia! - are "timeless classics".

"Even if you have seen them on your TV or cinema, the outdoor big screen is still a very much more organic and interactive experience compared to the solitary nature of watching a movie in a cinema," she says. "Movies like A Hard Day's Night and Grease really have to be seen on the largest screen and in immersive surround-sound to really feel their impact."

Not only that, Ms Teo adds that the older titles have been souped up from their original 35mm prints and mono sound to the latest 4k resolution and 5.1 digital sound. "The experience of watching these classics on the big screen should be as good, if not better than when they were on screens the first time round," she notes.

Films at the Fort's Mr Williams adds that when the Tom Cruise fighter-pilot classic Top Gun was screened last year, the audio set-up made it feel like planes were flying over the audience's heads.

Driven by passion

While Encore and Films at the Fort are ticketed events, SCUM (Society for Cult & Underground Movies) is a local collective of three working professionals who share their passion for alternative cinema by running free screenings of anything from old school gongfu flicks to blaxploitation, anime and long-lost creature features.

Formed in early 2007, it started as a one-man operation before manpower constraints took its toll and SCUM Cinema was suspended indefinitely, according to Herman Ho, who runs his own creative agency and is one-third of the collective.

But driven by their love of movies, SCUM decided to make a comeback last year with a new blog and a double bill of Shaw Brothers gongfu films held at its new home at The Arts House.

"Moving forward, we are aiming to hold a screening bi-monthly," says Mr Ho. "Our goal is to have a SCUM Film Festival in the near future which we can tour around the region, and who knows, maybe even around the world . . . We are also hoping to work directly with more film distributors and directors to expand our repertoire of films."

As a fully independent outfit, SCUM still faces many challenges: On top of dedicating time and effort to maintaining the website, its Facebook page and organising screenings, the trio also have their own careers to juggle.

In addition, operational and licensing costs come directly out of their own pockets. To defray that, original limited edition prints and merchandise - produced specifically for each screening - are on sale at the venue.

Mr Ho adds that "sheer passion" is what drives SCUM on, and the memory of Singaporeans filling out venues where alternative titles were being screened at the Singapore International Film Festival during the 90s remains an inspiration for them to pursue this cause.

"Honestly, we hope to keep this going for as long as possible, and we strongly feel there is a market out there for such films," he says. "With all the cineplexes offering more or less the same Hollywood blockbusters, we believe that smaller film societies like SCUM Cinema can fill the gap to provide more film choices (for local cinema-goers)."

Or as Encore's Ms Teo simply sums it up: "We're just movie lovers who want to watch our favourite movies on the big screens the way we watched it when we were kids!"

site_title: Tharman strikes balance with few trade-offs
content:
Tharman strikes balance with few trade-offs

Pioneer Generation Package, higher CPF contribution rates for 'fair and equitable society'; PIC extended and other incentives sharpened to gun for 'quality growth'

Published

Sat, Feb 22, 2014 · 04:09 AM

Singapore productivity

Follow

Singapore

AS Singapore nears the half-way mark of its 10-year restructuring plan, Budget 2014 sought to strike a balance between growing social needs and businesses under stress - and it did so at a lower price than observers had expected.

Faint hopes of a rollback in property cooling measures did not materialise, and the income and wealth tax hikes some had expected to help pay for rising social spending did not come to pass.

But Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam did not need fresh revenue sources to sink a bold $8 billion into a fund that will pay fully for the Pioneer Generation Package, which will assure some 450,000 elderly Singaporeans of affordable healthcare for life.

And though there was no equivalent big-bang package for businesses this year, companies had little reason to complain about a Budget that was "more carrot than stick" - as more than one observer said - especially since the previous four Budgets have sent ever tighter foreign manpower curbs their way.

"The Singapore Business Federation is relieved that no major new manpower measures were announced in Budget 2014 to exacerbate the tight labour situation," said SBF CEO Ho Meng Kit. Most employers were spared the pain of further levy hikes or quota cuts, though Mr Tharman did slap a $100 levy hike on the construction sector, which has been a laggard in productivity growth.

Reiterating that "raising productivity is at the centre of our economic agenda" because it is the only way to raise living standards in coming years, Mr Tharman also extended the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme - meant to lapse in YA2015 - by another three years.

This was something all the major business groups had asked for.

While SMEs did not get the higher cash payout many had hoped for, the government did come up with PIC+ to help smaller enterprises make large investments to transform. PIC+ pushes up the expenditure cap for each qualifying activity by 50 per cent - so that SMEs can claim tax deductions of up to $1.8 million over three years, compared to $1.2 million before.

Together, the government's productivity support schemes will pump more funds back to businesses than the additional foreign worker levies collected in recent years, Mr Tharman said.

"However, we are not recycling monies indiscriminately, or seeking to benefit all firms equally. Our schemes will still favour the more dynamic and efficient players," he added.

Incentives were also sharpened to "enable innovation to pervade the economy", he said. These include ones to encourage investment in innovation and skills, support the piloting and scaling up of infocomm technologies, catalyse financing for companies at various growth stages and help firms go abroad.

The one piece of news that dismayed some businesses was that employer CPF contribution rates will be hiked from January 2015.

"Increases in employers' CPF contributions will not help and will impact small businesses as they employ more older workers, proportionately," said SBF CEO Mr Ho.

But the Singapore National Employers' Federation sought comfort in the $360 million that the government has set aside for one-year employment credits to help employers adjust, as well as the government's assurance that it would not raise the rate beyond 17 per cent any time soon.

DBS economist Irvin Seah said it can be viewed as an attempt to raise productivity - higher CPF contribution rates are more positive than raising foreign worker levies. "The hikes in employers' CPF rate will benefit Singaporeans directly, whereas, previously the hikes in foreign workers' levy benefited only the official coffers," he said.

But funds and measures can only do so much in service of what is a "major, multi-year undertaking". Mr Tharman said: "Transforming our economy is not just about technology and productivity is not ultimately about the dollars and cents of upgrading. It also means changing our social norms."

In his view, this ranges from creating a workplace culture that values employees' views, to a culture of job mastery, to changes in consumer habits - becoming at ease with self-service technologies, for instance. In fact, Mr Tharman's 90-minute speech outlined how the government, too, has changed its thinking.

As a country, Singapore has entered into a new phase: incomes are rising less quickly, the disparities between different groups are becoming more of a concern, and the population is ageing rapidly, often with fewer children to support older Singaporeans, he said.

"Our thinking has shifted in this new phase, and our initiatives are helping to level up our society and mitigate inequalities." Hence the raft of measures unveiled on the social front: higher healthcare subsidies, more assistance with pre-school fees for more families, higher bursaries for students in tertiary institutes and higher subsidies for children with special needs.

In addition, the government has set aside $360 million for utilities, rebates on Service and Conservancy Charges and cash grants (GST Voucher) to help older Singaporeans and lower and middle-income families hit by Singapore's rising cost of living.

However, as Singapore strengthens its social support and safety nets, the "whole approach must encourage a compact between personal and collective responsibility", Mr Tharman said.

"What is critical is not just how much we spend and redistribute resources, but how we do so. Our approach to uplifting the poor and levelling up society can only succeed if it supports a culture of personal responsibility - the desire to learn a new skill and work for a better living, and to make the effort to look after our own families. We know this from the evidence of half a century of major social interventions around the world, such as in the US and the European countries."

Including the hefty $8 billion set aside for the Pioneer Generation Fund, and factoring in a contribution from net investment returns on past reserves of $8.1 billion, the government is expecting an overall deficit of $1.2 billion, or 0.3 per cent of GDP. But the deficit - which if it materialises will be the first since the global financial crisis in 2009 - will not draw on past reserves, as there are sufficient surpluses from the last few years to balance this over the current electoral term.

"The relative absence of bad news and willingness to run a deficit invite speculation of early elections in 2015, with the bitter pill of higher taxes only likely thereafter," said Citi economist Kit Wei Zheng.

Seeking ways to lower mining costs

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

TO improve his Bitcoin mining profitability, local miner Derek Leong, a 39-year-old IT engineer, seeks methods to lower his cost and explore the market for the latest equipment.

"Because of the cost of electricity, it's not very feasible to mine at home," he said. Instead, he mines Bitcoins at his office as well.

Furthermore, HDB flats are not wired for industrial use, he said. With the introduction of more powerful mining machines which use a substantial amount of power, power cost will increase. There is also the possibility of tripping the main circuit at home.

site_title: SMEs on growth path to get leg up with better funding support
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SMEs on growth path to get leg up with better funding support

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SMALL and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) looking to join the big leagues will get a boost from a plethora of measures unveiled yesterday.

Support will come from existing schemes as well as a new "mezzanine" growth fund, as the government attempts to support financing needs at various stages of a firm's growth.

The first phase of the Co-Investment Programme - launched in 2010 with a provision of $250 million - will run together with a second phase, under which the government will inject another $150 million to match private sector investments. This sum goes into two funds: the SME Co-Investment Fund II that makes direct equity investments, and the SME Mezzanine Growth Fund, a hybrid of debt and equity.

Finance minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam yesterday said: "(The Mezzanine Growth Fund) provides a more flexible financing option for SMEs that do not wish to dilute their equity, but face challenges in increasing their borrowings from traditional banking sources."

In another initiative, the Micro-Loan Programme, Spring Singapore will raise the government's share of risk on micro-loans to young SMEs - firms registered for fewer than three years - from 50 per cent to 70 per cent, in order to spur lending. This is expected to catalyse an additional $32 million in loans over FY2014 and FY2015.

DBS Bank, which increased its number of micro-loans made to SMEs by a quarter last year, yesterday applauded this move and pledged to step up lending to these SMEs.

The bank's head of SME Banking, Lim Chu Chong, said: "We encourage the government to also look at increasing the loan quantum and tenure and relaxing the employee cap, which will further help banks to lend to small and young companies."

Micro-loan quantums are now capped at $100,000, and loan tenures, at four years. Firms need to have no more than 10 employees or no more than $1 million in annual sales to be eligible for such loans.

The government also announced that it will begin studying the potential for equity crowdfunding. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Spring Singapore are looking into an appropriate regulatory framework for such new business models, Mr Tharman said.

Andrew Tinney, a partner in Financial Services for KPMG Singapore, said: "Crowd funding is an exciting innovation and will help smaller firms raise capital at a time when banks are capital-constrained. However, it must have appropriate safeguards for investors."

It was also announced yesterday that IE Singapore's Global Company Partnership programme will be beefed up on the market access and manpower-development fronts.

For market access, the support level for pilot and test-bedding projects will go up from 50 per cent to 70 per cent for two years; for manpower development, support for staff attachments in overseas markets will also be expanded to cover the acquisition of new business or technical capabilities.

Firms looking to expand overseas by buying fixed assets or by investing in secured overseas projects will be able to draw on a higher maximum-loan quantum under the Internationalisation Finance Scheme. Doubled from $15 million to $30 million for two years, the higher ceiling is expected to trigger up to $500 million in loans in that timeframe.

These moves are expected to benefit some 200 firms over the next two years.

Tan Bin Eng, a partner in Business Incentives Advisory for Ernst & Young Solutions LLP, said that going forward, execution will be key: "These measures will be specific to each SME in terms of their needs and will require a lot more customisation. While I think the increase in support levels is great, it is even more important to find the right parties that need help."

site_title: Engrossing high-seas drama
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Engrossing high-seas drama

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WRITER-DIRECTOR JC Chandor couldn't have made a bigger splash with his sophomore feature, All Is Lost, an engrossing one-man high-seas survival drama.

A large chunk of the credit must go to Robert Redford, who despite having so few lines of dialogue they barely fill half a Post-It note, still manages to give a virtuoso performance simply by oozing plenty of screen presence.

Even without a back story (or a name, for that matter), the character the 77-year-old actor plays is a compelling one.

The film opens with a brief spoken prologue where "Our Man" (that's how Redford is credited) narrates a short farewell note before the story flashes back to about a week earlier when he's rudely awakened after his yacht collides with a wayward container.

It rips a gash in the hull and that's just the start of his problems for Redford's character.

Over the course of the film, things go from bad to worse as he battles bad weather, sun burn, sharks and the eventual loss of his yacht which forces him to make do with an emergency life raft.

Yet despite all the high drama, he wades through it with the masculine calm and suaveness of the Marlboro Man on water.

It's a masterclass in acting on Redford's part, to say the least; with his occasional manly grunts and piercing eyes doing all the work to give the film its measured dramatic pace.

Chandor also maintains a loose grip on the amount of action in this drama - All Is Lost isn't quite a one-man version of Titanic - but the tension remains taut enough for the audience to not take their eyes off the screen.

Like a piece of experimental cinema, All Is Lost looks and sounds a little dodgy on paper but Redford's ample screen charisma more than compensates for Chandor's minimalist script to bring the story to life onscreen.

In many ways, the film is a far cry from the latter's directorial debut, Margin Call (2011), a flashy ensemble-cast Wall Street takeover drama starring Kevin Spacey, Jeremy Irons, Zachary Quinto, Demi Moore and Stanley Tucci.

Here, it's just Redford steering the ship - that's not the meatiest of material to work with but he sails through the high waves like the saltiest of sea dogs, so to speak, with his acting chops.

Understandably, a survival drama this lean (but still mean) might not be everybody's cup of tea and the plot's abstract nature isn't the most conventional cinematic storytelling method and does leave a slightly unsatisfying feeling. But All is Lost also proves sometimes less can be more.

Rating: B+
