site_title: Budget must focus on business and society
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Budget must focus on business and society

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

TODAY, much of the business community's attention will be focused on the Budget for FY2014/15, which is to be unveiled in Parliament by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. Business leaders and tax experts have submitted their wish lists, but Mr Tharman will have to balance their concerns against the economic and social needs of Singaporeans at large and the economy as a whole. And there are some key themes that merit special attention.

One of the highlights of the last three Budgets was tighter policies on foreign workers, including through gradual increases in worker levies and more stringent criteria for the granting of employment passes. Companies are still having a tough time adjusting to these changes. Many, especially multinationals, have also called for more certainty in labour policy, rather than constant adjustments. Thus, business is crossing its fingers that at least there will be no new tightening.

Part of the reason for tighter regulation of foreign workers was to boost productivity. But this remains a challenge and will be a long-haul battle, for which supportive policies will need to remain in place for a number of years. Thus, there is widespread support for extending the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme (which is due to expire in the current financial year). While the scheme is reported to have a decent adoption rate of around 70 per cent, there are ways to make it still more attractive. One is to extend for a longer period the 400 per cent deduction for qualifying R&D activities and to raise the expenditure cap of $400,000 per year. The scheme could also be made more flexible for SMEs by removing expenditure caps on the six individual qualifying activities against which they can claim credits. Expanding the number of activities to include other forms of innovation would also bring more companies - especially smaller SMEs - into the PIC net.

To ease business costs, a number of tax incentives can be fine-tuned, for instance by enhancing tax deductions for a number of qualifying activities that are already in place plus introducing reliefs for some new activities such as home offices and e-commerce, which are both cost-savers. There is also a case to incentivise activities that serve social needs, such as healthcare and eldercare - which need to grow with the help of the private sector and have not enjoyed incentives thus far.

On property, the big question is whether this Budget will roll back some of the many cooling measures that are in place. While this is controversial, a case can be made to at least start the process, given that monetary policy (while still lax) will get progressively tighter and property values, and transactions, are already falling.

Finally and by no means least, the government must continue to focus on issues of social equity. Raising direct taxes can be problematic and compromise Singapore's tax competitiveness. The key to improving social equity will thus lie in boosting health and education subsidies and continuing to provide targeted income support programmes. In sum, the Budget will hopefully be both business-friendly and socially progressive.

site_title: Week's STI rise belies poor trading conditions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Week's STI rise belies poor trading conditions

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT has been an odd week for the local stock market with the Straits Times Index's (STI) 61 point or 2 per cent rise over the five days to 3,099.93 suggesting strong demand for stocks, which is not really the case. The reality is that volume has been poor for several months now, dealers spend a large portion of each day either trading on their own or playing computer games and penny stock turnover has been declining.

In yesterday's session when the STI added 13.29 points, volume was two billion units worth $1.1 billion, of which $640 million or 58 per cent was done in the 30 index stocks.

Underpinning the index's recovery over the past fortnight is a rebound on Wall Street, a bounce that has come despite weak employment and housing numbers and has probably been driven by a belief that interest rates will remain depressed for at least another a year.

Although trading conditions in Singapore are dire, investors might draw some consolation from the STI's performance. Since dropping to a 2014 low of 2,960 on Feb 5, the index has now risen 139 points or 4.7 per cent in 12 trading sessions, though it still is 68 points down for the year.

Apart from the banks and Jardine group which regularly play central roles in moving the index, a notable contribution this week came from Olam International, which gained 19 cents or 12 per cent over the week to $1.765.

In the penny segment, a popular theme has been China water treatment, a play which has brought HanKore, Memstar and various other low-priced water treatment counters into play. In HanKore's case, the stock is rated a "buy". However, the water treatment sector's leader, Hyflux, came under pressure after it reported a 28 per cent drop in net profit to $44 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2013.

In its "sell" on Hyflux, OCBC Investment Research described the results as "very disappointing" as core earnings were 15 per cent below forecast.

"Going forward, Hyflux also warns of a slower first half in 2014, citing the timing of its projects. Nevertheless, management remains upbeat about its prospects over the next 12 months, where it sees significant opportunities in its key markets with an estimated US$8 billion worth of projects made available for tender," said the broker.

"But we believe that investors may want to switch out of Hyflux first, hence we downgrade our rating from 'hold' to 'sell'. Our fair value also drops from $1.23 to 84 cents."

Hyflux's shares yesterday lost 4.5 cents to $1.195 with 2.5 million units traded.

HanKore, in the meantime, was rated a "buy" by OSK DMG. The broker said that HanKore chairman David Chen and chief financial officer Felix Yau participated in OSK DMG's Feb 19 non-deal roadshow (NDR) in Singapore.

"Hankore's strong points include further progress in its merger with China Everbright International (CEI), potentially lower financing costs and solid asset quality . . . We believe that as HanKore draws closer to completing its merger with CEI, its valuations will re-rate. This process is already under way. At the current price of 12.3 cents, the stock is trading at a 19x FY15 P/E (incorporating CEI's asset injection), compared with the peer average of 30x. Maintain 'buy', with our 16.1 cents target based on a 25x FY15 P/E."

In its Q1 Asia Outlook yesterday, JP Morgan presented one top buy and one top sell idea from each country. For Singapore, it said that there was a clear change in leadership away from domestic demand towards external factors for the first time since 2010.

"Shorter term, the market is beginning to bounce off of oversold levels and shorting activity for the market is close to all-time high reported levels . . . we would be selectively adding exposure to the Singapore market in areas with very heavy outstanding short activity that are very oversold. These include banks, industrials and telcos." JPM's top buy is Singapore Airlines and top sell is Far East Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Heritage hotels hark back to storied past
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Heritage hotels hark back to storied past

Time-travel to the 1800s to early 1900s when you stay in Colorado

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HOTELS set in historical buildings abound in Colorado. Those who like a bit of heritage with their travels, may want to head back in time at these properties.

The Brown Palace

321 17th Street Denver Colorado 80202

www.brownpalace.com

SOME hotels lose their shine and look their age after a few decades of operations, but not the Brown Palace Hotel & Spa. Much of Denver has changed since the hotel's opening in August 1892, but The Brown Palace still retains its grandeur and grace.

The 241-room hotel is named after Henry C Brown, a real estate entrepreneur who came to Denver from Ohio.

Back in the late 1800s, people from all across the United States were still flocking to the West, seeking their fortunes in gold and silver. Brown saw the opportunity to build a hotel in Denver: people would always stop in the city, regardless of whether they were settling down or passing through, and they would need a place to stay.

Brown spared no expense building his hotel, spending US$2 million, a huge sum back then. It was designed in the Italian Renaissance style, using Colorado red granite and Arizona sandstone for the building's exterior.

Inside, there is an atrium lobby with balconies rising eight floors above ground, surrounded by cast iron railings with ornate grilles. Onyx was imported from Mexico for parts of the hotel, no wood was used for the floors and walls, and the hotel was hailed as the second fire-proof building in the United States.

The hotel's original artesian well still exists. Located 720 feet underground, it continues to provide water to every faucet in the hotel.

Since 1905, nearly every US president has visited the hotel. While on their tour of the US in 1964, the Beatles stayed here too.

According to hotel trivia, the Brown Palace saw a great surge in applications for housekeeping by young girls. One of its four suites is named after the band. The interiors of The Beatles Suite may not be overly posh, but there are hints of the Beatles presence including a jukebox in the living room, and Beatles memorabilia on the walls. It comes as no surprise to hear that the hotel has some special guests from days of long ago. Each October, the hotel's historian leads guests on tours through some of the hotel's more hair-raising hauntings.

The Broadmoor

1 Lake Avenue, Colorado Springs, CO 80906

www.broadmoor.com

THERE are plenty of stories of people who made it big in the midwest in the late 1800s and early 1900s and one of them is Spencer Penrose, a Philadelphia entrepreneur who had made his fortune in gold and copper mining.

Penrose had earlier bought The Broadmoor Casino and Hotel, and had ambitious plans for it. With the objective of creating the most beautiful resort in the world, he imported artisans from Italy and other European countries to create the ornate mouldings and paintings which adorn the interior of The Broadmoor as well as the elaborate exterior detailing.

Stepping into The Broadmoor is much like going to a resort in Tuscany, back then something that was seen in the US, but today, is still just as impressive.

The hotel's architectural and design features include a spectacular curved marble staircase, dramatic chandeliers, Della Robbia-styled tiles, handpainted beams and ceilings, a carved marble fountain, and a striking pink stucco facade.

Besides US presidents, the hotel has also played host to numerous entertainment and sports personalities. In keeping with the times, amenities have been added on to the hotel, including a spa, golf course and convention facilities. Guests can choose to stay at one of its 756 guest rooms, 124 suites, 44 cottage bedrooms, or two brownstone apartments.

Back in its early days, The Broadmoor was known as the "European alternative", and many visitors came for the clean, mountain air, said to relieve symptoms of tuberculosis and other bronchial maladies.

These days however, no one would bat an eyelid, if you choose not to stay at the hotel, but to have Sunday brunch at its Lake Terrace dining room. The old-fashioned buttermilk griddle cakes with melted butter and Vermont maple syrup are worth the ride there.

The Mining Exchange

8 S Nevada Avenue, Colorado Springs, CO 80903

www.wyndham.com

IT is not difficult to guess what this hotel building was used for previously. The Mining Exchange, was once home to the Colorado Springs Mining Exchange to promote regional mining companies and their stock, in the 1920s. According to archives, the Exchange trading room was two storeys high, with a brass railing that separated the public area from the trading floor.

But as mining ebbed in importance to the region, the building opened to other businesses including law, architectural and oil companies.

Three years ago, American businessman Perry Sanders bought over the building, got rid of tenants, gutted the building to its core and restored it to its original grandeur. In 2012, The Mining Exchange opened, under the Wyndham Group.

The old trading room still exists, but part of it has been converted to form ballroom space. The Exchange's main vault still stands in the hotel lobby, becoming a photo spot for hotel guests.

Smaller vaults are on the remaining floors, and they no longer keep money, but have been converted into storage space for the hotel's housekeeping department.

Old

brick walls, much of them original, can still be seen in the hotel's 117 rooms.

site_title: Two US security workers found dead on ship
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Two US security workers found dead on ship

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[COPENHAGEN] Two American security workers have been found dead on the Maersk Alabama, a ship made famous by the Hollywood movie Captain Phillips, an oil and shipping group said on Wednesday.

AP Moller-Maersk said in a statement that the men were found dead in a cabin on board the vessel in the afternoon of Feb 18 in Port of Victoria in the Seychelles.

The Maersk Alabama was targeted by Somali pirates in an attempted hijacking off the east coast of Africa in 2009. The 2013 film Captain Phillips is based on the incident.

Maersk gave no details about how the two men had died. "The cause of the death for both men is part of the ongoing investigation, but it was not related to vessel operations or their duties as security personnel," its statement said.

Local law enforcement agencies are investigating the deaths on the Maersk Alabama, which berthed in Port of Victoria around midday on Feb 17. The security contractors had boarded the vessel on Jan 29, Maersk said.

Maersk Alabama is part of a US-flagged fleet controlled by Maersk Line Limited, a unit in AP Moller-Maersk, which performs military, government and humanitarian missions by transporting cargo on its container, tanker and multi-purpose ships, according to the company's website.

Maersk's statement said Maersk Line Limited contracts vessel security services to Trident Group in accordance with US Coast Guard security directives.

Contracted security is part of anti-piracy protection plans to safeguard crews and vessels.

It said the Maersk Alabama is persistently in high-risk areas since it provides feeder service - calling at smaller ports to collect containers that are later loaded on bigger container vessels - to the east coast of Africa.

Captain Phillips, directed by Paul Greengrass and starring Tom Hanks and Barkhad Abdi, is based on the attack on the ship in 2009, when Captain Richard Phillips was taken hostage by pirates led by Abduwali Muse in the Indian Ocean. - Reuters

site_title: 'The Little Caruso' is a big Latin lover now
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

'The Little Caruso' is a big Latin lover now

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AS a solo artiste, Carlos Marin may not be well known outside the Spanish-speaking universe, but as a member of the multinational pop-opera phenomenon Il Divo, it's a different story altogether. We're talking mob scenes, panting female fans (channelling their inner teeny-bopper) and an Armani-suited approach to showbiz that resembles the old-school sophistication of the Rat Pack days.

Granted, Marin and fellow Il Divo mates Urs Buhler, David Miller and Sebastien Izambard project a squeaky-clean image that the likes of Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jr could never be accused of. For the past decade, they have also been part of a polished stage act that is the elegant equivalent of, say, a PG-rated romance. It's a formulaic act that has its fair share of detractors, but you can't argue with mega-success: with a string of hit albums and sellout world tours to its credit, the group has been one of entertainment mogul Simon Cowell's biggest creations.

Each of Il Divo's members has a distinct vocal persona - the opera-trained Marin possesses a powerful baritone that in pop-music terms might be compared to Tom Jones (a personal favourite of Marin's). The resulting blend has been described by critics as "a huge explosion of vocals" and a "musical aphrodisiac" that leaves audiences swooning.

With dark eyes, a hairstyle with a signature curl and smouldering good looks, the Germany-born, Madrid-raised Marin, 45, plays his Latin lover role to perfection. True to form, he proudly proclaims that he loves women.

"I'm an old-fashioned romantic," he says over the phone from a London hotel room, just before embarking on the Asian leg of a tour that starts in Seoul tomorrow. "There's nothing more beautiful than to be with the woman you love, bring her flowers, go to a candlelit dinner and walk under the stars."

He adds: "Young people are missing that. In clubs these days, you can't talk to women and say the things you need to."

Marin, who is currently single (the only member of the group with that status), says he has "many girlfriends - not just one. I love to flirt, even when I'm in a relationship. I love to go places and 'go fishing' - I'm a gentleman, of course, but now I'm only faithful to myself."

It's tough being popular and even harder to sing each hit song like it's the first time, but then the level of fan appreciation helps. Marin reveals that female audience members present him with impromptu gifts every night - typically underwear wrapped around their phone numbers, he says in a matter-of-fact manner. Tom Jones would approve.

There is an easy on-stage camaraderie among the singers and - backed by a full orchestra and supported at times by guest artistes - an Il Divo concert may be predictable but rarely dull.

"I've been singing on stage for 37 years and the thing with Il Divo is that there are still many things to achieve," says Marin, who was known as "The Little Caruso" when young. "Our life has been like a movie - singing with Celine (Dion), Barbra (Streisand), Toni (Braxton) - but we're always trying to do something new to keep the audiences and fans awake."

He adds: "There is a huge age range among our fans - from seven to 105 - and the good thing is our style of song (the pop style of music with a slow build-up to an operatic climax) has wide appeal. There is an understanding among the four of us and we have a unique sound. We have many imitators; they do okay but they don't reach the excitement level that we reach."

The success of Il Divo means the group is constantly on the go, with tour dates, special appearances and multiple sponsorship obligations. A new album is also due in the coming year. They managed to play Broadway for the first time late last year, and elements from that show, A Musical Affair, have been incorporated into the current tour - the Singapore audience at their show next month can expect to be entertained by a repertoire of classic Broadway standards and more recent musical theatre hits.

Away from the madness, Marin says he enjoys being a music producer - he still works with ex-wife Geraldine Larrosa (stage name Innocence) - and will likely continue producing music for her and others when his singing career comes to an end.

His earlier career also spanned the world of opera but Marin says whereas an opera singer has to play a role, in pop music and musical theatre there is the opportunity to be more intimate with the audience. "With opera you have to act but you cannot really whisper something beautiful," he says. "I miss the opera, but I miss music more."

Marin allows that being in Il Divo is "a bit stressful. It's going to reach a point where we have a break, but it's beautiful to be in the group and also do solo stuff - I don't see ourselves not doing music." He adds: "It's going to be finished when Il Divo says it's finished or the audience says it's finished."

Meanwhile, the music plays on and the boys in the band keep on singing. Two years ago, Marin moved to Paraguay, where the weather is more agreeable and where the US is easily accessible. Most of his time, however, is spent in hotels and on the road. Marin says it's been a great ride so far and there's still a long way to go. "I'm a man that never regrets anything," he says.

site_title: Forex provisions hit QAF earnings
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Forex provisions hit QAF earnings

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

QAF Ltd, better known for its Gardenia Bread, reported a 13 per cent decline in net profit to $30.19 million for the full year ended Dec 31 due mainly to its provision for unrealised foreign exchange loss.

The group's revenue for 2013 rose 4 per cent from a year ago to $1.02 billion as the company recorded higher sales in all its business segments.

All of its bakery operations in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines and Australia achieved higher sales with new product launches, increased production capacities and increased market share.

Its Australia-based integrated meat producer, Rivalea (Australia) Pty Ltd, achieved sales increases while its trading and wholesale arm, Ben Foods (S) Pte Ltd, also marked higher sales in its food service and export businesses.

But QAF had to make a provision of $5.4 million for unrealised foreign exchange loss arising from the depreciation of its Australian-dollar denominated assets against the Singapore dollar. The preceding year recorded a forex loss of $1.5 million.

Rivalea also experienced margins squeeze from weaker-than-expected selling prices in the earlier part of 2013. Higher costs of animal feed and grain at Rivalea and increased ingredient costs at QAF's bakery operations mainly contributed to the 7 per cent rise in total costs of materials for the group at $558.5 million.

Profit before tax for the year fell by $6.2 million to $42.05 million as a result.

But QAF said that selling prices at Rivalea showed "encouraging signs of improvement" in late 2013.

"The group's bakery operations maintained its level of profitability despite facing higher ingredient and raw material costs in FY2013 as compared to FY2012," QAF said in its financial statement yesterday.

QAF said it is expecting less volatility in raw material and other operating costs for this financial year and expects to achieve "an encouraging level of profitability in FY 2014".

The group has proposed a final dividend of 4 cents per share, unchanged from a year ago.

Shares of QAF yesterday closed 0.5 cent higher at 82.5 cents.

site_title: New measures mostly in line with expectations
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

New measures mostly in line with expectations

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LET'S take a look at how this year's Budget has addressed what we view as the top three pre-Budget concerns in 2014.

Help for businesses

Singapore has set a target of increasing labour productivity by an average of 2 to 3 per cent each year until 2020.

While we are starting to see results, there is still some way to go. Many SMEs continue to be hard-hit by high business costs and tight labour quotas.

Against this background, there are more measures in Budget 2014 to help businesses - especially SMEs and micro SMEs - to stay on course.

The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme - one of the key incentives to promote productivity - is due to end in 2015. Following calls from businesses, the PIC scheme will continue until Year of Assessment (YA) 2018.

There will also be a new PIC+ scheme for SMEs effective from the YA2015, increasing the spending cap for SMEs to $600,000 per year from YA2015 to 2018.

The IRAS will be announcing further details of the PIC+ scheme in March 2014 and it is hoped that the new scheme will simplify the criteria for SMEs.

There are also enhancements to various other existing tax incentives to boost productivity and innovation. To promote innovation through R&D, Singapore will extend a 50 per cent enhanced tax deduction for qualifying R&D spending until YA2025. This will help businesses to better plan and commit to R&D programmes which will take time to conceptualise, develop, test and commercialise into innovative products or processes.

The writing down allowances for capital expenditure incurred on Intellectual Property Rights, due to expire in YA2015, will continue for another five years until YA2020. Likewise, the Land Intensification Allowance will be extended until June 30, 2020, to maximise land use, and will be extended to the logistics sector which appears to be a key growth sector due to the increasing flow of goods via e-commerce.

One change that went against the overall theme of helping business is the proposed increase in employer's CPF contribution rate from Jan 1, 2015. Although the increase is only one percentage point, this was not widely expected. However, a Temporary Employment Credit (TEC), which will partly offset the increases in CPF contributions rates for one year, will help cushion the impact.

Managing healthcare costs for older Singaporeans

Singapore has one of the most successful healthcare systems in the world and maintaining this success is no mean feat. With a fast aging population and rising healthcare costs, the elderly are at risk of being left out.

During the 2014 Budget, Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that Singapore would set aside an $8 billion fund to support the Pioneer Generation. Under the package, more than 450,000 older Singaporeans can get help to pay for their MediShield Life premiums. They can also expect subsidies for outpatient treatment and more top-ups into Medisave accounts.

While the focus was on the Pioneer Generation, other groups were not left out. Other than the increase in CPF contributions, Singaporeans aged 55 and above and not in the Pioneer Generation group would be entitled to receive a Medisave top-up of $100-$200 annually for the next five years.

Narrowing the income gap

Singapore's income gap, measured by the Gini coefficient, is higher than many developed countries.

Budget 2013 introduced various measures to help narrow the income gap with measures such as the Wage Credit Scheme put in place to help lower-income groups. Indeed, in Budget 2014, Mr Tharman noted that Singapore's Gini coefficient was lower in 2013 than it has been in over a decade.

Continuing in the same vein, Budget 2014 offers more support to the lower-income groups and elderly to help ease the cost of living. This will include a variety of subsidies for medical, education and transport costs. There will be a one-off GST Seniors' Bonus of up to $250 for Singaporeans aged 55 and above in 2014. There will also be an increase in parent reliefs and personal tax reliefs for those with handicapped dependents.

There have been calls over the weeks leading to Budget 2014 to increase the marginal personal tax rates and/or introduce further measures to tax the wealthy, but this did not happen. Obviously, the better-than-expected surplus has helped and there is no need for the government to turn to these measures. We should, however, be seeing a tighter Budget position in years to come and it may be a matter of time before additional tax revenue sources may be required.

Conclusion Singapore is currently at an inflection point. Overall, the measures are in line with our expectations. Moving to 2014, we need to continue with the restructuring process to ensure that Singapore's economy remains competitive and vibrant. As Mr Tharman said: "It is a major, multi-year undertaking" for Singapore, but by undertaking this, there can be better jobs for Singaporeans and a brighter future for all.

Low Hwee Chua is head of tax services and Yap Hsien Yew is senior manager at Deloitte Singapore

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Divestment gain boosts UEL full-year bottom line

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

UNITED Engineers Limited's (UEL) net profit for the full year ended December jumped 64 per cent to $118.1 million from $72.2 million a year ago, helped mainly by a divestment gain.

Revenue surged to $2.01 billion from $595.7 million due mainly to the consolidation of WBL Corp Ltd's revenue of about $1.37 billion, as well as increased rental from the group's income-producing properties, revenue recognised from Eight Riversuites, and higher contribution from UE E&C Ltd.

Gross profit rose 61 per cent to $313.5 million.

Including non-controlling interests, attributable profit dropped 31 per cent to $60.3 million.

Following the successful takeover offers for WBL in May last year, WBL became a 56.8 per cent subsidiary of UEL. On Feb 11 this year, the group increased its shareholding in WBL to 67 per cent following the close of its exit offers to acquire all the stock units and outstanding convertible bonds of WBL.

Its other segments also posted increases in revenue. Engineering and construction saw revenue increase marginally to $455.7 million in 2013 from $452.8 million. Revenue from property rental and services increased 14 per cent to $205.7 million. Revenue from property development was $39.9 million compared with $150,000 previously.

Notably, other income increased to $184.8 million from $21.3 million due mainly to the divestment gain of about $115.9 million from the sale of UE Bizhub East, the deemed disposal gain of about $21.4 million from available-for-sale financial assets previously held directly and indirectly through associated company UE group, and a gain of about $12.3 million from the disposal of available-for-sale financial assets held by WBL Group.

Earnings per share were 24.5 cents versus 20 cents (restated) previously. As at Dec 31, the group had cash and cash equivalents of $889 million, of which $291 million was contributed by WBL Group.

A first and final dividend of five cents per ordinary stock, a special dividend of two cents per ordinary stock, and a preference dividend of 7.5 per cents per preference share have been proposed.

site_title: Life and death by a promising playwright
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Life and death by a promising playwright

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

READING about the religious conflicts that have dominated headlines in recent years so fascinated 17-year-old Jovi Tan that he read as much as he could on the subject and even wrote a play about it.

Titled Marco Polo, the play deals with the afterlife and he finished writing it in 24 hours, winning the Student Category of TheatreWorks' long-running 24-hour Playwriting Competition last year. Written as an absurdist piece of theatre influenced by Harold Pinter and Samuel Beckett, Marco Polo is about two blind friends who meet up after death, and try to figure out if they ended up in heaven or hell. Amid the uncertainty, they begin to understand what it is to be lonesome, fearful and utterly lost, and try to recapture emotions they had when they were alive.

The Raffles Institution student had only written one play for school before, and likes writing poetry in his spare time. He adds: "The plays that strike a chord with me are Singapore plays, that tell the Singapore story."

His play will be directed by veteran independent director Sean Tobin and performed by Bright Ong and Ebi Shankara. This is the first time that Tobin is working with TheatreWorks' 24-hour Playwriting Competition winners but says that it's the absurdist tone of the play that drew him in. "I liked the idea, and found it challenging and imaginative," he shares. "I was quite amazed that it was so polished and tight, as a first script."

Tan didn't have to finetune the play, although if he could, he says he would have made the language more precise and impactful and given the two characters more personality.

The challenge is presenting an absurdist play without dumbing it down, adds Tobin, but thinks there's a lot of scope to create that "after world". Tobin is no stranger to directing plays for the community however as he's long worked with The Necessary Stage.

The 30-minute play will be performed at the Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall and also at one of the domes at Gardens by the Bay, as part of TheatreWorks' Writing & Community programme started in 2008 when the Writers Lab first partnered the South East Community Development Council.

The whole idea is to identify potential playwrights, explains Tay Tong, the company's general manager, and then help them to develop their scripts into productions which are then staged outside the usual performance venues in the city.

"The performance series aims to bring works that resonate with the audiences who may not necessarily often go to the theatre," he adds.

Life and death, passion and religious allegiances are certainly intriguing and thought-provoking enough to engage an audience, whose added advantage is to catch the first play by a young playwright with potential.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Otto narrows Q4 loss, ends year in the black

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

OTTO Marine sank to a net loss of US$9.7 million for its fiscal fourth quarter after three quarters of gains, even though it managed to report a net profit for the full year.

The offshore and marine group's net loss for the October-December 2013 period was, however, substantially lower than the net loss of US$66.8 million a year ago. The company said the Q4 results last year were primarily affected by a forex loss of US$4.8 million and the dry docking of vessels which were due for their five-year survey.

For the full year, Otto Marine made a net profit attributable to shareholders of US$14.08 million, compared with a loss of US$103 million in FY2012. Gross profit grew 450 per cent to US$46.5 million, led by higher profits from its chartering and shipbuilding business, while profit from leasing and subsea fell sharply.

Chartering gross profit doubled to US$31.3 million despite flat revenue of US$265.55 million, resulting in a gross profit margin of 12 per cent compared with 6 per cent previously. The company said lower operating costs led to the higher profits. Chartering accounted for 67 per cent of group gross profit.

Otto Marine owns and charters out a diversified fleet of 65 vessels ranging from ultra-large anchor handling tugs and supply vessels (AHTS) to crew transfer vessels, working with oil majors and offshore exploration and production companies.

Gross profit from the group's shipyard posted a turnaround to a profit of US$11.8 million compared with a loss of US$0.25 million previously. The group's shipbuilding, repair and conversion division was the second-largest contributor to gross profits.

The group also posted a gain of US$64 million on the deconsolidation of Reflect Geophysical, following a court order to wind up the company. This was offset by a doubtful debt provision of US$45.3 million for debts due from Reflect.

The group said it will continue to grow its chartering fleet and maximise utilisation rates and optimise efficiency in both the offshore services vessels (OSVs) and the subsea sectors. The group continues to see growing demand for its services in the deepwater sector.

While management expects the shipbuilding industry to remain challenging, it said the group is increasing its order intake of repair and fabrication projects as well as select newbuild orders for the Indonesian cabotage markets, even as outstanding contracts for more complex and high-spec vessels are being completed and delivered.

Otto Marine shares closed trading yesterday at 8.7 cents, down 0.1 cent.

site_title: Carrots and sticks for construction industry
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Carrots and sticks for construction industry

Levy for basic skilled worker to go up; upgrade to higher skilled level made easier

Mindy Tan

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE construction sector was singled out as the only sector bucking the trend of slowing foreign workforce growth by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam yesterday, as he unveiled a mixed toolkit of carrots and sticks aimed at the construction sector.

The biggest stick in the toolbox was the increase in levy for basic skilled construction workers that will take effect in July 2016. Specifically, the levy for these workers (R2 work permit holders) employed within Man-Year Entitlement (MYE) will be increased from $600 to $700 while levies for higher-skilled workers will remain unchanged.

Despite the fact that the levy hike will only take effect in two years, construction firms involved in larger projects which take a longer time to complete will still be affected, said Ho Nyok Yong, president of The Singapore Contractors Association Limited (SCAL).

"Now he gives me the warning: 2016 is $700 (for R2 workers); it's 2014 now and before July, I was paying $450. If my project takes three years, I am still hit. Who compensates us? (If your pricing is) too competitive, you lose money; but if you price higher, you don't get the job," said Dr Ho.

But the writing has been on the wall for the construction industry for some time, said Selena Ling, head, treasury research and strategy at OCBC Bank.

"Looking at construction productivity numbers, you can understand why they have to press on with the upgrading and restructuring process," she said. That being said, it is a bit of a "double whammy" for builders, she conceded.

"The government has said it is too early to do any unwinding of property measures which impacts demand side; and on the supply side, this levy hike won't help matters," Ms Ling said.

But measures aimed at helping construction firms were also rolled out.

For instance, firms looking to upgrade their R2 workers to R1 status will be provided with an additional avenue.

The Market-Based Skills Recognition Framework, which kicks in from Aug 1, will allow basic skilled workers who have worked in Singapore for at least six years and who earn a salary of at least $1,600 to upgrade to R1 status. Currently, work permit holders are required to pass a skills test and have at least four years' experience in Singapore before they are classified as higher skilled.

According to the Ministry of Manpower's (MOM) estimates, some 17,000 existing R2 construction workers will be eligible for R1 status under the framework this year. As more work permit holders meet the salary and experience requirements over time, this figure is anticipated to grow.

Dr Ho lauded the move but stressed that the upgrading process would take time. At present, only about 10 per cent of the work permit holders are of R1 status, he said.

Additionally, to facilitate firms looking to retain experienced workers, the government will extend the maximum period of employment for R1 work permit holders from non-traditional sources and China from 18 to 22 years. This extension, which takes effect from May 1, will also apply to the marine and process sectors.

This measure is expected to help companies in these sectors retain 8,700 existing skilled workers for a longer period. These workers will have otherwise reached the maximum period of employment of 18 years within the next five years, said MOM in a statement yesterday.

The extension will not increase the number of work permit holders in Singapore as businesses are still required to keep within their dependency ratio ceilings, it added.

The measures introduced are part of a longer-term plan which will involve looking into mandating a minimum proportion of R1 work permit holders at the firm level to improve the skill profile of the foreign workforce, said Mr Tharman.

"We will continue to closely monitor the growth of foreign manpower in other sectors to ascertain whether further tightening measures, including levy increases, are needed for 2016 and beyond," he said.

That a carrot and stick approach was adopted should not surprise the construction industry, said Tan Tay Lek, partner at PwC Singapore.

"The tax benefit of the enhanced PIC (Productivity and Innovation Credit) incentive should go some way in relieving the industry of these transition pains although more sustained measures would be welcomed as this industry transformation process will not be achieved in the short term," he said.

Meanwhile, a range of upstream measures to tackle construction productivity were also introduced.

For selected government land sales (GLS) sites for instance, the use of productive technologies such as prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction and prefabricated bathroom units will be mandated in the tender conditions. JTC will also stipulate a minimum percentage level of prefabrication as part of the tender conditions for industrial government land sales (iGLS) sites.

The government will also continue to increase the legislated buildability scores and constructability scores for projects, said Mr Tharman.

From September this year, private projects that are outside the GLS programme will need to meet the same higher standards as public sector projects and private sector projects on GLS/iGLS sites. This is expected to reap 9-14 per cent in manpower savings on such projects, he said.

But while such measures will reduce builders' reliance on manpower, views on the implementation remained mixed.

"The prefab units will be easier to use in projects where the designs are similar. If the designs are different, then using prefab will become a challenge," said Ong Jun Quan, executive director of Soon Li Heng Civil Engineering. "The other downside to using prefab is that in terms of design and architecture, it may stifle creative designs and lead to boring architecture. But overall, it is a good thing for the industry to use as it will be cheaper and quicker."

Other measures being rolled out include the requirement of standardised floor heights and building components such as drywalls for new projects, and encouraging developers to adopt productive technologies in developments on non-GLS sites.

"One of the complaints made previously by companies was that moves by the government were ad hoc. The announcements made in the Budget pull these measures together into a more complete approach which construction firms are likely to welcome," said Teo Han Jo, partner, building sector, at KPMG in Singapore.

"In addition, measures related to the upgrading of skilled workers to R1 or Higher Skilled status will contribute positively towards overall productivity and provide more certainty, and will be welcomed by the sector," he added.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Yeo Hiap Seng's Q4 profit more than doubles to $17m

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

yeo hiap seng

Follow

Singapore

YEO Hiap Seng (YHS) reported a net profit of $17.07 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, up from $7.75 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, thanks in part to strong contributions from its food and beverage (F&B) business.

Revenue for the quarter, however, slipped from $106.4 million previously to $103.42 million while earnings per share for the quarter under review worked out to 2.97 cents, up from 1.35 cents previously.

For the full year, net profit slumped to $87.63 million from $98.8 million on the back of lower profits from the property division, while revenue dropped from $566.4 million to $515.33 million.

"While the group's F&B division has achieved improved sales and gross profit in 2013, its margins are expected to be squeezed by competitive selling prices in the markets in the next 12 months," it said. However, it also highlighted it remains optimistic that the F&B business will keep growing "at a satisfactory level".

During the financial year, revenue from F&B division rose 8 per cent to $430.58 million while its gross profit improved 9.2 per cent to $159.68 million.

In an update on its property business, YHS said that it has some land parcels and defunct factory premises in Malaysia and China which could be re-developed.

"The group may either dispose these land parcels or re-develop to monetise these assets at the opportune time. Until such time, the property development segment will be dormant," it went on to say.

YHS, which released its results yesterday after the market closed, has declared a first and final dividend of two cents per share and a special dividend of five cents per share.

The counter closed unchanged yesterday at $2.18.

site_title: More needs to be done to leapfrog the competition
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More needs to be done to leapfrog the competition

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR businesses looking to the Singapore Budget 2014 for government assistance to help them with more value-creation activities, the mention of "quality growth focusing on innovation" seemed like just the very lifeline they were waiting for. But, do the measures announced go far enough to encourage more value-creation by businesses?

While the government has heeded calls from the business community to encourage more innovation through investment in research and development (R&D), exploration of new markets, and building of new capabilities through adoption of information-communication technology (ICT), these measures are one step short of encouraging companies to focus more on the type of value-creation activities that can take Singapore on a path of sustainable long-term business performance.

First, let us focus on the good news.

The extension of the popular Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme for another three years until Year of Assessment (YA) 2018 is a move in the right direction. As we had pointed out in our Budget Wishlist, the productivity journey is a long and continuous one.

What is even better is the PIC+, which increases the expenditure cap to $600,000 a year up to a maximum of $1.8 million over three years. It is a tailor-made tax incentive for small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs), providing them with the necessary support to encourage equipment and technology investments for longer term and more sustainable business performance.

Combined with existing broad-based measures such as the $5,000 Innovation and Capability Voucher (ICV) and the Capability Development Grant (CDG) schemes, businesses will be given a leg up in value-creation activities.

Businesses should be especially cheered by the extension of the research and development (R&D) incentives for a further 10 years to 2025 as the government clearly recognised that such innovation activities have a longer time-frame to bear fruit than productivity investments. And these were exactly what we had called for in our Budget Wishlist.

The push to encourage SMEs to adopt ICT through the ICT for Productivity and Growth (IPG) programme will also provide funding for companies, especially SMEs, to tap on more innovative ICT solutions for growth, beyond merely purchasing computers and software.

But while these measures and others, like the financing provided to support internationalisation, will help more companies in their bid to innovate, the not-so-good news is that all these incentives may not go far enough to support cash-strapped companies.

In particular, companies are allowed only to receive up to $60,000 in cash grants per year under the PIC, but which will not cover the more significant investments, especially in R&D.

One area that businesses may be particularly disappointed in is how there isn't more support for branding initiatives.

Current incentives do not recognise the tangible nature of efforts to create a strong brand. Heeding KPMG's call for a tax incentive by way of a tax allowance for internally generated brands would have signalled the government's commitment to encourage pervasive innovation.

Branding helps to improve competiveness of businesses. This is especially so with the regional goal of having the single Association of South East Asian Nations Economic Community (AEC) come on line in 2015. Singapore may have lost an opportunity in this year's Budget to place the Republic's businesses in a position of strength to exploit the potential benefits of the AEC.

This, perhaps, is something the government can look into for future Budgets to encourage local companies to pursue originality and value creation.

As the late Steve Jobs who made Apple the household name it is today once said: "Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower", so it is that only through greater innovation can Singapore companies leapfrog ahead of their competitors.

Tay Hong Beng is Head of Tax, and Harvey Koenig, Partner, KPMG in Singapore

site_title: CEVS extended until June 2015
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

CEVS extended until June 2015

Published

Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Carbon Emissions-based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS) will be extended by six months until June 2015, with a view towards continuing the scheme thereafter, Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said yesterday.

This is because the CEVS was introduced last year amid changes to the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) system and the introduction of tiered Additional Registration Fee (ARF).

"We should observe the full impact of CEVS before making refinements," said Mr Tharman.

At the same time, the Green Vehicle Rebate scheme for commercial vehicles, buses and motorcycles will also be extended by six months to June 30, 2015.

CEVS was introduced in January 2013 to improve the take-up of green vehicles, with cars enjoying ARF rebates of up to $20,000 for having low carbon emissions, while those with high carbon emissions have to pay a registration surcharge of up to $20,000.

"We are encouraged by the results so far - more than 50 per cent of the new cars registered in 2013 received CEVS rebates while about 10 per cent paid the surcharge," said Mr Tharman, who added that this was an improvement over 2012, where only about 40 per cent of the new cars registered would have been in the rebate bands and about 14 per cent in the surcharge bands.

Some motor distributors had expected the government to tweak CEVS by expanding the type of pollutants being measured, such as nitrogen oxide and particulate matter.

They say both these emissions, considered more harmful than carbon dioxide, are higher in diesel-engined cars than petrol-powered ones. But under CEVS, diesel cars of similar capacity are more likely to qualify for a higher rebate.

Turning to the Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) for commercial vehicles, he said the bonus COE period will be enhanced to further incentivise owners to replace their goods vehicles early.

The scheme was introduced last year to encourage the replacement of old commercial diesel vehicles to meet the new Euro V emissions standards. Owners who de-register their pre-Euro and Euro I vehicles before the end of statutory life pay lower, pro-rated COE premiums for their replacement vehicle, with the unused COE period and bonus COE period used to offset the Prevailing Quota Premium or PQP payable.

More details of the enhancement will be announced by the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources during the Committee of Supply debate.

One commercial vehicle dealer welcomed the news, saying the current discounted PQP is not attractive enough to encourage most owners to switch over to Euro V.

"(About) 38,000 old vehicles qualify under the scheme but, so far, fewer than 1,000 new units have been registered," he added, referring to the 614 commercial vehicles registered under ETS up until last month.

site_title: A sampling of Spain's most iconic wines
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A sampling of Spain's most iconic wines

Wines by producers Pablo Alvarez, Alvaro Palacios and Peter Sisseck are a good contrast to lighter-bodied Burgundies, says NK YONG

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

'THE rain in Spain falls mainly in the plain . . .' Those immortal lines from the musical My Fair Lady came to mind one Sunday in January, when not rain, but wine came down on us from Spain, thanks to three of the country's most famous producers:

DOMINIO DE PINGUS

Flor de Pingus 2010 and 2009

Both Dominio de Pingus and Vega Sicilia sit on a plateau 600 metres above sea-level, thus experiencing a refined continental climate, with wide diurnal temperature differences especially in the summer.

Both vintages are very black red, 2009 darker than 2010. Rich aroma of very ripe fruit and liquorice. Stronger in 2009 with a touch of mint. Dense big wines, very ripe fruit, with taste of liquorice, caramel, mint, dried fruits especially prunes and plums. 2009 is denser.

Pingus 2010 and 2009

Both intensely almost black-red, with 2009 darker. Aromas of very ripe sweet fruit, lots of caramel, liquorice, coffee and good minerality. 2010 is more elegant and super-concentrated, while 2009 is perhaps a touch better balanced.

ALVARO PALACIOS, PRIORAT

Alvaro's original winery which he started in Gratallops in the Priorato region, as a member of the Gratallops group led by Rene Barbier.

Gratallops 2011

Eighty per cent Garnacha (Grenache), 20 per cent Carinena (Carignan)

Black-red, lovely but with a faint nose of very ripe fruit; attractive palate of sweet ripe fruit, coffee, pears, soft tannins and good length. A very pleasing wine.

Finca Dofi 2011

Hundred per cent Garnacha.

A more serious wine, from very old vines. Black-red, with a sweet ripe fruit nose, palate of very ripe black berry fruit, chocolate, orange peel, touch of mint, and a long finish with citrusy notes. Very complex.

L'Ermita 2011

Alvaro's flagship wine. Ninety per cent Garnacha, 3 per cent Garnacha Blanca, 7 per cent Samso

A huge wine, black-red, with the aroma of very sweet ripe berry fruit, a very dense concentrated wine with thick texture, touch of mint, and a long finish. Needs another decade!

La Montessa 2011, Palacios Remondo

From the family winery in Alfaro, Rioja, which Alvaro took over on the death of his father a few years ago.

Eighty per cent Garnacha, 18 per cent Tempranillo, 2 per cent Mazuelo.

A soft, very drinkable and likeable wine, good fruit, good length.

Propriedad 2011, Palacios Remondo

Hundred per cent Garnacha.

A more serious wine than Montessa. Darker red, with a light caramel-orange nose, good tannic structure, liquorice and black coffee on the palate. Needs ageing.

BODEGAS DESCENDIENTES DE J PALACIOS, BIERZO

Villa de Corullon 2011

Ninety per cent Mencia, 5 per cent white grapes.

Good dense black-red, with a very sweet, ripe berry fruit aroma, coupled with a palate of liquorice and very ripe raisins; very big wine. Good introduction to Alvaro's Bierzo wines!

Las Lamas 2011

A single vineyard wine.

A huge wine that's black-red, with a sweet citrusy and caramel bouquet. Very concentrated, with a very dense sweet palate, liquorice, lightly minty, lightly tannic long finish.

La Faraona 2011

Alvaro's most exclusive wine from Bierzo, which comes from a small plot of vines in the middle of a very steep hill slope of 800 metres elevation.

Black-red with a faint aroma, dense, minerally, very ripe fruit, very precisely defined, a bit of an aristocrat, very long lightly tannic finish. Needs another 10 years.

PABLO ALVAREZ

Pintia 2010, Bodega Pintia, Toro

Pintia is always a most enjoyable and drinkable wine from Vega's Pintia estate in Toro, to the west of the Ribera. Fruity and characterised by good balance and complexity, the 2010 is a worthy example. It has a lovely luscious seductive nose, with a very sweet thick-textured entry, thickly liquorous, but good minerality, with a long smooth finish. An excellent, well-priced easy-drinking wine.

Alion 2010, Bodega Alion, Ribera del Duero

Alion was acquired by the Alvarez family to produce a Ribera wine more in tune with contemporary wine tastes in contrast to the Vega, which continues serenely on the same course it has done since its inception.

This is like the Pintia, very likeable and very drinkable. Black purple, with a caramel butterscotch nose, big wine, cedar and coffee, and liquorice on the palate. Very long and quite aristocratic in style.

Macan 2010, Bodegas Benjamin Rothschild & Vega Sicilia

Hundred per cent Tempranillo.

Very black red, with a very dense black coffee on the palate with a touch of liquorice, cedar and mint. Long smooth finish. A medium-priced wine which should gain many followers. The problem is one would have to wait years for it to be ready to drink.

Valbuena 2010, Vega Sicilia

Ninety per cent Tinto Fino, 10 per cent Merlot.

This is always a most attractive wine, a junior edition of Vega's main wine, the Unico. Black-crimson, with vanilla, tangerine on a seductive bouquet; creamy texture, with orange, caramel and coffee on the palate, and very very long. A beauty.

Unico Gran Reserva 2004, Vega Sicilia

Hundred per cent Tempranillo.

Pablo Alvarez believes this to be the successor to the famous 1970 Unico.

Impenetrably black, with a lovely, seductive and elusive nose, touch of aniseed; concentrated sweet ripe fruit, slightly minty, goes on forever. Unico has never been a block-buster wine. Its hallmark is the suggestion of aristocracy in its bouquet and taste, a reserved nature and complexity being its strengths. This is very young, just been released, and will need another good five or more years to reach full maturity.

Unico Gran Reserva 1994, Vega Sicilia

A great vintage 10 years older than the preceding. A light orangey tint on the nose, a huge concentrated wine, refined and elegant, very complex, very long. Goes on and on. An aristocrat of a wine in its elegance and refinement.

Unico Gran Reserva Especial, NV

(Blend of 1990, 1994 & 1996 vintages of Unico Gran Reserva vintage.)

Beginning to show brown tints in the otherwise deep red. A very very complex wine, with great class, refinement and elegance. A softish palate, very ripe fruit, very refined.

An appropriate finale to this near-monumental tasting of some of Spain's most iconic wines, entertainingly presented by Alvaro Palacios and studiously by Pablo Alvarez. Peter Sisseck unfortunately could not be present and his wines were presented by his great friend Alvaro Palacios.

This third session of the Paulee, which consists of Spanish wines, followed the Saturday's complete day of Burgundy wines. It was designed to act as a counterpoint to the extensive tasting of Burgundies, with the lighter-bodied Burgundies set off by the heavier-textured Spanish. That contrast could not have been more emphatically presented. The white burgundies proved very welcome and refreshing, as well as being in themselves very brilliant.

Disclaimer: I am involved in the distribution of Peter Sisseck's wines

site_title: ARA Asset's Q4 profit up 25% at $22.1m
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

ARA Asset's Q4 profit up 25% at $22.1m

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ARA Asset Management saw net profit for the fourth quarter ended December jump 25 per cent from $17.69 million to $22.13 million on the back of revenue rising 19 per cent to $43.83 million.

This was boosted by its acquisition, divestment and performance fees which increased to $11.8 million from $1.5 million a year ago, thanks to fees received in relation to Fortune Reit's acquisition of Kingswood and Suntec Reit's progress payment for its acquisition of the 177-199 Pacific Highway property in Australia.

Excluding unrealised marked-to-market gains/losses, net profit was $24.6 million for Q4 compared to $16 million a year ago, representing a 53 per cent year-on-year increase.

For the full-year ended December, net profit rose 2 per cent to $74.3 million while revenue rose 5 per cent to $140.4 million.

Specifically, recurrent management fees rose 11 per cent to $114 million, driven mainly by higher Reit management fees and real estate management fees.

Separately, the group's portfolio management fees from the private funds division increased on the back of contributions from the ARA Asia Dragon Fund II and the ARA China Investment Partners, as well as the higher valuation of the property in the ARA Harmony Fund post the completion of its asset enhancement works.

The group also launched a new separate account platform, Morningside Investment Partners, in November last year, which also contributed to the increase. This was partially offset by the reduced fees from the Asia Dragon Fund as its investment assets are progressively divested.

Meanwhile, the group's acquisition, divestment and performance fees grew 78 per cent year-on-year to $14.7 million. Excluding the unrealised marked-to-market gains/losses, the group would have achieved an adjusted net profit of $81.4 million for FY2013, 28 per cent higher year-on-year.

As at end-December, the group's asset under management (AUM) attained a new high of $25.5 billion.

"We are pleased to have achieved another year of strong results, particularly in the growth of our recurrent management fees and recurrent net profit by 11 per cent and 17 per cent, respectively. Notwithstanding the persistent global economic uncertainties, we continued to grow our resilient earnings and increase our AUM," said John Lim, ARA Group chief executive officer.

The counter rose one cent to end trading at $1.735 yesterday.

site_title: Like-minded tie-ups
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Like-minded tie-ups

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Ritual Gym

11 North Canal Road, #03-01 6536 7291

contact@ritual.sg

Membership costs $239 for off-peak gym usage and $369 for full gym usage

Partners include:

Tucker Medical

8 Sinaran Drive Suite #04-03, 6659 6918

In Touch Physiotherapy

22 Malacca Street (Raffles Place), 6533 0968

Lems Shoes

www.lemsshoes.com

Shoebox Canteen

36 North Canal Road, 9296 4836

RITUAL Gym co-founders Brad Robinson and Ian Tan are relentless when it comes to researching and hunting down anything that will keep them in tip-top physical condition. Even when it comes to medical doctors. "We had read up so much that we could tell what rubbish a lot of the GPs were telling us," says Mr Tan, 27, who is also the gym's programme director. Ritual offers a 30-minute workout session, comprising an intense 20-minute session that allows users to get in and out quickly.

It took over a year of consulting several GPs before they finally found Tucker Medical, which practises "functional medicine". Mr Robinson explains: "If you have a lower back problem, most doctors will recommend surgery, or painkillers. But the problem is often in your ankle or knee, which is what this guy will try to find out."

Dr Steven Tucker of Tucker Medical says he joined forces with Ritual because the synergy is more effective in encouraging people to stay healthy. He says: "People, not just 'patients', need regular feedback and counselling on lifestyle issues; the tie-ups help because now you have a team dedicated to improving your health."

Ritual also works with In Touch Physiotherapy which specialises in injury rehabilitation, and American family-owned shoe company Lems Shoes which sells minimalist shoes - lightweight footwear designed to minimise strain on the feet.

Food-wise, eateries like Shoebox Canteen, Muchachos and Platypus Gourmet2Go have developed "Ritual-style" meals, usually comprising a main protein like chicken or fish, with extra vegetables and less carbohydrates. "They're places that Brad and I eat at," says Mr Tan. "We're not trying to advocate a super strict pro-athlete type of eating, we just want to give people good food choices."

The restaurants benefit as well, as they get customers directed their way. Shoebox Canteen's co-owner Beverly Yeoh observes: "Increasingly we have more customers asking for non-carbohydrate meals so we recommend the Ritual-style meal we modified for them - by substituting the carbohydrates with more fresh vegetables." For example, their "Ritual-style" baked snapper ($18) is served with seasonal greens and fennel foam instead of couscous.

Not just any eatery or service can be part of the Ritual style network - there is one important trait that they all must have. That is, they have to care about what they're doing, says Mr Tan. "Our philosophy here is giving the best product and customer experience possible. I want my clients' 30 minutes at Ritual to be the best part of their day," adds Mr Robinson. "We want to work with businesses that have the same idea - to go out of their way and make that extra effort."

By Rachel Loi

content:

Ezion Holdings' Q4 net profit almost doubles

Performance helped by higher charter income; full-year leaps 103.4%

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

OFFSHORE marine group Ezion Holdings posted a 97.3 per cent year-on-year rise in its Q4-FY13 net profit to US$40.5 million, led by higher charter income from its offshore-service rigs and logistics-support vessels from the group's Australian projects.

Group revenue for the three months increased 60 per cent year-on-year to US$83.7 million on additional units of the group's liftboat and jack-up rigs being deployed, as well as higher contributions from its offshore logistics units working on three LNG projects off Australia.

With the final quarter well ahead of market consensus estimates, the group's FY13 net profit jumped 103.4 per cent to US$160.4 million. This was despite higher interest expense and depreciation costs.

Group revenue increased by 77.7 per cent year-on-year to US$281.9 million for the year, while gross profit increased 88 per cent to US$133.2 million, with gross profit margins at 47 per cent, compared with 45 per cent previously.

Finance costs for the year increased 57.4 per cent to US$12.2 million, largely because of the issue of S$270 million in notes under a Multicurrency Debt Issuance programme and higher bank loans to fund new service rigs and vessels.

The group had total financial liabilities of US$1.09 billion as at Dec 31, including the notes issue.

Despite a 97 per cent rise in pre-tax profits to US$162.9 million, Ezion's tax bill decreased 32.8 per cent to US$2.6 million, helped by the tax exemption on charter income derived from Singapore flagged vessels under Section 13A of the Income Tax Act of Singapore.

Management said the group has seen "an increased focus on platform- and well-related work by the oil majors in the Asia-Pacific, the Middle East and West Africa".

As a result, the group expects to continue to invest in service rigs to meet the strong demand and to explore new ways to restructure its port and marine based business to allow the group to concentrate on its current key businesses.

The group announced on Feb 12 that it had terminated its bid to acquire a 45.15 per cent stake in mainboard-listed Ocean Sky.

The failed bid involved a reverse takeover plan by Ezion, which wanted to inject its marine supply base business in Australia, Ezion Offshore Logistics Hub, into Ocean Sky. Ocean Sky has interests ranging from construction and civil engineering to property management.

In its statement last week, Ezion said the reverse takeover would have resulted in "protracted timings" and all sides had agreed to terminate discussions relating to the plan. It added that because of conditions pertaining to the share subscription not having been met, the deal had lapsed.

Analysts remained upbeat on the stock, with 14 out of 15 rating it a "buy", with an average 12-month price target at $2.95.

Consensus estimates for Ezion's FY14 net profit stand at US$228 million, and for FY15, US$282 million.

This means an average annual growth of 33 per cent on the back of a continued growth in its fleet of offshore service vessels. Based on the profit estimates, the price-earnings ratio for FY14 is at 9.7 times and for FY15, 7.9 times.

Ezion closed down one cent at $2.30 yesterday, with 5.4 million shares traded following the early-morning results announcement.

content:

Holistic healing

Published

ADELINE Tan's mission has always been to heal through seven senses: sight, sound, smell, taste, touch, movement and mind. When she launched her green smoothie business four years ago, she focused solely on taste - through her healthy blended fruit and vegetable concoctions.

Now, Ms Tan is expanding to include the other six senses by teaming up with a nutritionist and yoga instructor in her newly launched LINS Smoodees Energy Detox Series.

She explains: "I find that there are a lot of people coming to me and asking me: 'Where can I get this done?' and 'Where can I get that done?' Furthermore, since setting up LINS Smoodees, I have met so many healers and therapists. I was motivated to create a space for everybody to come to."

One of her partners is Biotailor, a nutrition consulting company run by Sujvot Sakhrani, senior nutritional consultant.

Ms Sakhrani conducts the clinical and holistic rejuvenator plan where, over two sessions, an analysis of the client's lifestyle and diet is carried out. This costs $400 (without blood test) and $480 (with blood test). According to Ms Sakhrani, a blood test which can be done at Huang Surgery at Valley Point, where LINS Smoodees is located, will provide a more accurate analysis. At the end of the sessions, a lifestyle management programme and diet plan, which may include Smoodees from LINS, is created for the client.

Ms Sakhrani believes that she and Ms Tan share a similar vision. She says: "LINS Smoodees and Biotailor are both committed to enhancing the health of our clients through nutrition and lifestyle balancing. Supporting our clients and understanding what works for their unique bodies is the focal point of our services."

Adds Ms Tan: "We will work with you one-on-one and at your comfort level. We will then determine if you're ready to push the boundaries or if it is even necessary at all."

Meanwhile, yoga instructor Johnson Anand Saurabh offers healing through mind and movement with a Mind, Body and Soul workshop scheduled for the middle of the year. The first workshop was conducted earlier in January and Ms Tan hopes that they can conduct a third one at the end of 2014. The workshop is helmed by Mr Saurabh while LINS Smoodees provides the food and drink.

According to Mr Saurabh, the workshop's emphasis on meditation and yoga complements the LINS Smoodees detox. "Adeline's liquid detox and raw food lightens up the body, allowing the person to more easily enter a state of peace," he explains.

Aside from the Energy Detox Series, Ms Tan also plans an April launch for The Healing Concierge which will oversee programmes such as the Energy Detox. This service will provide clients with referrals whenever they are in need of a health-related service. She adds: "If clients come to me and I do not have ready contacts for what they want, I will source for them. If there are other detox programmes out there and I find that they are suitable for the client, I will refer them."

site_title: $8b fund to benefit Pioneer Generation
content:
$8b fund to benefit Pioneer Generation

It will help 450,000 elders with their healthcare costs for the rest of their lives plus extra health subsidies

Lee U-Wen

Published

Sat, Feb 22, 2014 · 04:09 AM

Medisave

Follow

Singapore

THE government will pump $8 billion into a new fund that will help Singapore's pioneers - those aged 65 or older this year - with their healthcare costs for the rest of their lives.

This money, with accumulated interest over time, will be enough to pay for the full projected cost of the Pioneer Generation Package, including a buffer for inflation.

The cost of providing the extra healthcare benefits to the group of 450,000 recipients over their lifetime will be slightly over $9 billion in nominal terms, said Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam in Parliament yesterday as he unveiled the full details of the package.

Of the $8 billion in the fund, about half that amount will be drawn down in the first 10 years due to the age profile of these pioneers and the higher benefits that will be given to those who are older.

Mr Tharman added that all those eligible for the package - those who were at least 16 years old in 1965, and (for practical reasons) had became citizens before 1987- will get the special benefits regardless of their income level today.

"Our objective is to honour the contributions of this whole generation. However, (those) who are less well-off will benefit more where there are higher underlying subsidies for all lower-income Singaporeans," he said.

He added that it was "right and prudent" to set aside money now to pay for the package while the country has sufficient resources to do so.

"With this fund, we assure the pioneer generation that Singapore will honour our commitment to them, regardless of future economic circumstances. The fund also ensures that Budgets in subsequent years can focus on the needs and challenges of the future, for all Singaporeans," said Mr Tharman.

He explained that the $8 billion in the fund was not meant to cover the underlying healthcare subsidies that the pioneers receive together with all other Singaporeans. These, he said, would continue to be funded from future annual budgets.

As he outlined the different components of the package, Mr Tharman revealed that all pioneers would get annual top-ups of between $200 and $800 in their Medisave accounts, depending on their age group.

He assured the pioneer group that they will get subsidies to pay for their premiums under the new MediShield Life, the universal health insurance scheme that will cover all Singaporeans for life.

Older people will get more subsidies. Those aged 65 will get a 40 per cent cut, and this rate will go up to 60 per cent for those aged 90 and above.

With this combination of subsidies and Medisave top-ups, a person aged 80 or older will have his or her MediShield Life premiums fully covered. Those who are younger, around 70 years old this year, will pay about half of their current premiums.

The MediShield Life Review Committee is currently reviewing the benefits and premiums, which will be ready later this year. The subsidies will be implemented at the end of 2015, when the scheme is eventually rolled out.

Pioneers will get a 50 per cent discount off their bills at specialist outpatient clinics and polyclinics, which will bring their total subsidies to 75-85 per cent of their bills. This, said Mr Tharman, is on top of the underlying subsidies that are means-tested.

Those with moderate to severe disabilities will get an extra cash boost of $1,200 a year under a new Disability Assistance Scheme.

All pioneers will also be automatically included in the government's Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS), which subsidises the cost of their visits to private general practitioners and dentists. In the past, only the lower and middle-income groups could qualify for this programme.

Mr Tharman recognised that there could be some who may have just missed out on the qualifying criteria for the Pioneer Generation Package but have "good claims" to be included. The government will set up a panel to assess these appeals on a case-by- case basis.

site_title: Exec jet market recovers after long slump
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Exec jet market recovers after long slump

Deliveries are expected to rise 10% this year

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DALLAS] Business-jet shipments worldwide rose last year for the first time since 2008 as corporate purchases of larger planes aided an industry that saw deliveries tumble by almost half during the recession.

Manufacturers shipped 678 of the planes, six more than in 2012, the Washington-based General Aviation Manufacturers Association said in a statement on Wednesday. That included a gain of 22 per cent to 249 for the bigger models while mid-size and smaller planes fell 8.3 per cent to 429.

"We're heading in the right direction but we're definitely not out of the woods yet," Pete Bunce, the trade group's president, said in an interview. "If you peel back the onion and parse the numbers a little bit, there are still significant problems in the light-to-mid area."

Chief executive officers from large companies are flying farther as international business expands, spurring demand for the biggest jets from makers such as Gulfstream Aerospace Corp and Dassault Aviation SA.

Manufacturers such as Textron Inc's Cessna that make smaller models still face a slow economic recovery, sparse financing and cheap used planes, Mr Bunce said.

Gulfstream, a unit of Falls Church, Virginia- based General Dynamics Corp, reported a shipment increase to 121 large-cabin planes from 83 in 2012, driven by the G650, its newest and biggest aircraft.

Dassault, based in Paris, delivered 43 of the Falcon 7X, its largest business jet, up from 37.

Profits for members of the Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 19 per cent to a record US$981 billion last year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. That's normally a good indicator for jet demand, Mr Bunce said.

Sales of smaller jets have been held back by sub-par economic growth in North America and Europe, which together accounted for 68 per cent of deliveries.

Business-jet deliveries are expected to rise 10 per cent this year as the inventory of used planes falls and flight hours increase, Joseph Nadol, a JPMorgan Chase & Co analyst, said in a Feb 12 note. Mr Bunce declined to forecast 2014 shipments.

"New demand remains tentative for now and any recovery should be gradual," Mr Nadol wrote.

Among other general- aviation aircraft, shipments of turboprops rose 10 per cent last year from 2012, as a drilling boom in the US increased the need for planes that can land at small airports near oil and gas fields in shale formations, Mr Bunce said.

Deliveries of even-smaller piston airplanes were up 2.7 per cent.

Shipments for all general-aviation aircraft, including business jets, turboprops and piston planes, climbed 4.3 per cent to 2,256. The value jumped 24 per cent to US$23.4 billion because of more large, expensive jets, Mr Bunce said. In 2008, 3,969 planes were shipped, with a value of US$24.8 billion.

This year, small and mid-sized jets will get a boost from new products that have begun or are about to start deliveries, including Cessna's Citation M2, Embraer SA's Legacy 500, Bombardier Inc's Learjet 75 and Honda Motor Co's first aircraft.

Almost all jet makers kept investing in new models even as sales lagged, Mr Bunce said.

During the next few years, business-jet growth will depend mostly on the pace of the North American and European economies, he said. In the long run, demand from emerging markets will rise as new airports in countries such as China, Brazil and Indonesia allow more general-aviation flights, Mr Bunce said.- Bloomberg
