site_title: Hedge funds raise bullish gold bets; analysts see rally faltering
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hedge funds raise bullish gold bets; analysts see rally faltering

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Hedge funds raised bullish gold wagers to a three-month high as signs of slowing US economic growth spurred demand for haven assets. Billionaire John Paulson maintained his bullion holdings last quarter.

The net-long position climbed 17 per cent to 69,291 futures and options in the week ended Feb 11, US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data show. Long wagers rose 8.8 per cent, the most since March. Net-bullish holdings across 18 US-traded commodities rose 18 per cent to 1.07 million contracts, the highest since October 2012, led by silver and coffee.

Investors' return to bullion after the bear market in 2013 is driving prices to longest rally since 2011. US factory output unexpectedly fell in January and emerging market equities and currencies weakened. Mr Paulson, the biggest owner of the largest exchange-traded product, left his holdings unchanged in the fourth quarter, a government filing showed. Goldman Sachs Group and Barclays plc say the rebound will falter.

"The run-up in prices in recent weeks has been attached to the meltdown in emerging markets, and adding to that concern is US economic news," said John Rutledge, chief investment strategist at Safanad. "It's still probably too soon to say the trend in gold market has fully turned. You've got people who are bears because they see inflation as under control, and others looking further ahead seeing inflation."

Futures in New York rose 4.4 per cent last week to US$1,318.60 an ounce, posting eight straight gains, the best streak since July 2011. The Standard & Poor's GSCI gauge of 24 raw materials climbed 0.8 per cent, while the MSCI All-Country World index of equities advanced 2.4 per cent. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, a gauge against 10 major trading partners, fell 0.6 per cent. The Bloomberg Treasury Bond Index lost 0.1 per cent. Gold rose another 0.7 per cent yesterday.

Holdings in the SPDR Gold Trust, the biggest ETP backed by bullion, climbed for three weeks, the longest stretch since August. Paulson & Co held 10.23 million shares as of Dec 31, unchanged from Sept 30 and valued at about US$1.19 billion, according to a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing made on Feb 14.

US retail sales fell in January by the most since June 2012, and jobless claims unexpectedly rose in the week to Feb 8, government data showed. Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen said on Feb 11 the recovery in the US labour market is "far from complete".

Gold jumped 70 per cent from December 2008 to June 2011 as the central bank pumped more than US$2 trillion into the financial system.

Prices plunged 28 per cent last year, the most since 1981, after some investors lost faith in the metal as a store of value. In November, Mr Paulson told clients that he personally wouldn't invest more money in his bullion fund because it was unclear when inflation would quicken. Gold held in global ETPs tumbled 33 per cent in 2013, and the value of the assets dropped US$73 billion.

This year's rally will "flounder" absent a "more meaningful shift" in investor sentiment, Barclays analysts said in a Feb 14 note. Goldman analysts led by Jeffrey Currie, the head of commodities research, said in a report two days earlier that gold will "grind lower" as US growth improves, reiterating a forecast for prices to reach US$1,050 by the end of the year.

The Fed cut monthly bond buying by US$10 billion at each of its past two meetings, leaving purchases at US$65 billion. Ms Yellen said last week reductions will continue in "measured steps". The US personal consumption expenditures price index, minus food and energy costs, rose 1.2 per cent in 2013, matching 2009 as the smallest gain since 1955.

"Gold may be establishing a bottom, but there are still a lot of headwinds," said Donald Selkin, chief market strategist at National Securities Corp in New York. "Yellen said that the tapering is going to continue, and inflation is still low."

Investors became bullish on silver, holding 7,675 contracts as of Feb 11, the CFTC data showed. That compares with a net-short position of 353 contracts a week earlier. Futures rose for 10 straight sessions through Feb 14, the longest streak since March 2008. In January, demand for silver coins sold by the US Mint almost quadrupled.

Bullish bets on crude oil climbed 11 per cent to 306,021 contracts, the highest since August, government data show. West Texas Intermediate advanced to the highest price in almost four months on Feb 12. Supplies at Cushing, Oklahoma, the delivery point for the futures, shrank to the lowest since Nov 1, the Energy Information Administration reported the same day.

Speculators expanded their net-bearish position in copper to 15,792 contracts, from 6,832 the previous week. Prices in New York climbed for two weeks, the longest rally this year. Refined imports in China, the world's biggest metals consumer, increased 53 per cent in January from a year earlier to a record.

A measure of speculative positions across 11 agricultural products jumped 30 per cent to the highest since late October, the CFTC data show. The S&P GSCI Agriculture Index of eight commodities capped a third straight weekly gain, the longest run since August. The measure is rebounding after tumbling 22 per cent in 2013, the most since 1981.

The net-long position in arabica coffee surged 97 per cent to 15,728 contracts, the highest since September 2011. Futures in New York gained 29 per cent this year, the most among the 24 commodities tracked by the GSCI. In Brazil, the top producer of coffee, sugar and oranges, the driest January since 1954 drained dams and seared plants. - Bloomberg

SUBSCRIBERS

LaGuardia pitched securitisation plan for overhaul

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] At least two European banks have floated the idea of applying a UK-style whole-business securitisation (WBS) approach to finance the US$3.6 billion overhaul of the United States' LaGuardia Airport, according to sources with knowledge of the proposals.

The overhaul project is one of the biggest so-called public-private partnerships (PPPs) to be undertaken in the US airport infrastructure market.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has narrowed competition down to four teams of high-profile private-sector bidders who are vying to take on the project. However, the financing options are far from being finalised.

While the type of financing has not been decided yet - and may ultimately include municipal bonds - at least two European banks have proposed the idea of securitising the lease cashflows from a new set of shops and concessions planned for the revitalised terminal.

Additionally, income from landing fees - including penalty charges for flights taking off or landing late - may be securitised as well, the sources said. "LaGuardia would make so much money if they chose the securitisation option," said the head of ABS at an international bank. "It seems like such an obvious option. Other airports have used this concept to great success."

Additionally, developing a shopping, dining and entertainment complex at the airport - which would bring in increased lease cashflows to be securitised - would make the airport a destination for patrons other than those taking flights. Hong Kong International Airport is one example of successful execution of this type of concept, the banker said.

"Securitisation would be an attractive route for LaGuardia to come to market, and it would be an interesting evolution in the US infrastructure market", said another senior UK-based DCM banker. "The same drivers exist in the US as in the UK to utilise that funding structure. It's just that the UK has a different legislative/ regulatory environment, and is more creditor-friendly."

UK airports operator BAA, owned by Grupo Ferrovial, used whole-business securitisations - which securitise all of the operating assets of a brand - for infrastructure projects on its airports, including Heathrow.

Similarly, The AA, a UK roadside recovery business, priced a WBS last summer. "There is scope to look at these UK examples and find better solutions and funding platforms rather than a more vanilla option in the US," the DCM banker said. "However, it might have to be in an amended form, given the different regulatory environment in the US."

The main advantages of a WBS-style structure would be to provide so- called ringfencing around the assets, as well as an element of ratings uplift or leverage uplift, the bankers said. - IFR

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

KL to set up website on home sales

It also plans buyer database 'to identify the number of houses owned'

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HOME buyers will be given quicker access to project sales data under a Web exchange to be established by the housing ministry by early April, according to its minister, Abdul Rahman Dahlan. The initial information, however, is likely to be limited to the number of units sold in an ongoing development.

"The ministry has all the information from the developers and I am sharing this information," the minister said, to enable purchasers to know at a glance which properties are still available and at what price range.

Mr Abdul Rahman also spoke about introducing new rules to curb bulk purchasing which had contributed to significant price increases in recent years.

"My ministry will also enforce a new condition for selling houses in bulk or en bloc, whereby developers who intend to make bulk sales of more than four units must obtain prior approval from the controller of housing. This condition will be prescribed as a mandatory requirement in every advertisement and sale permit for housing development," he said at the launch of the Sime Darby Property Housing-Income Index study yesterday.

While bulk discounts are not illegal, he said, the practice of property investor clubs obtaining a discount of some 20 per cent of the price from a developer and then on-selling it to their members at slightly below list price while pocketing the difference, is not healthy. Rehda, the housing developers' association, has, however, asked for "modified restrictions".

Mr Abdul Rahman said that a comprehensive database of house buyers would be established to enable the ministry to "identify the number of houses owned by an individual and take the necessary steps to curb unhealthy speculation".

The housing sector has slowed down since the October budget introduced a number of cooling measures following annual price increases of more than a tenth in the past few years in Malaysia's biggest cities.

But prices remain sticky for now, owing to a number of factors including the holding power of owners, the belief that prices will only increase in future and because of the scarcity of land in popular areas as well as higher inflation. Indeed, builders insist that prices are unlikely to drop although a few have said that they would start to build more affordable houses - nationally defined as units priced below RM400,000 (S$152,000).

Given escalating land prices, this will be difficult in the Klang Valley, Penang and parts of Johor Bahru. For a snapshot of the Klang Valley scene, the Sime Darby housing-income index study found that the mean household income of respondents in 12 selected locations in the greater Kuala Lumpur area (includes Nilai in Negri Sembilan) to be RM14,580 per month.

Sime's housing-income index was designed to enable individuals to estimate their mortgage affordability based on price-to-income ratio (PIR), mortgage-to-income ratio (MIR), and the housing affordability index (HAI) which measures whether the average family in a location qualifies for a loan on a typical house there.

The PIR revealed an affordable house price in the Klang Valley to be about 56 times the monthly household income (compared to the UN's average of 50 times), and that 26 per cent of monthly household income is used to service the mortgage. The HAI found households in Nilai which earn an average of RM9,430 to be more likely to qualify for a loan than those in Mont Kiara-Duta Hartamas where household income averaged RM20,160. (This is because the latter group is likely to be more leveraged). The sample size of 1,529 respondents comprised mainly middle to upper income. Some 28 per cent were Sime Darby homeowners.

site_title: Australia should rein in business subsidies
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Australia should rein in business subsidies

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AUSTRALIAN Prime Minister Tony Abbott started out determined to stick to his credo as an economic rationalist. He was nonchalant on hearing about the death knell for the nation's car manufacturing industry. After commiserating with the affected workers, he limited himself to expressing the hope that the workforce would move "from good jobs to better jobs". Last week, Toyota Motors decided to stop making cars in Australia from 2017. The decision comes hard on the heels of announcements by Ford and GM to quit manufacturing in the country, and spells the end of a A$20 billion (S$22.7 billion) industry. Together with engine, gearbox, seats and other car part makers, the combined industry employs upwards of 30,000 workers. Some economists predict that these closures will trigger a recession in those states where the car factories are located.

A few weeks earlier, Mr Abbott's government refused a A$25 million bailout to keep a fruit processing plant going. It has been speculated that the country's last fruit cannery, SPC Ardmona, could announce its closure by the end of this month with a loss of 1,600 jobs. Such a shutdown would ripple across the broader farm economy in the region. The plant has lost more than A$400 million in the past five years.

So far, so consistent. But Mr Abbott's government has a long way to go if it wants to end the subsidy mentality that many Australian businesses have come to expect as a matter of right. One major Sydney newspaper, using figures from the government's own Productivity Commission, has tallied the tax breaks and outright grants that various industries enjoy. Remarkably, one of the most coddled is its financial services industry. It has been given subsidies exceeding A$900 million, including tax breaks of more than A$840 million and direct grants of about A$70 million. Even more surprising, the mining industry enjoys tax breaks of A$300 million and direct grants of another A$400 million. Yet, the mineral extraction business has always painted itself as the sturdy engine that pulls along the rest of Australia's economy.

The gas, water and electricity suppliers receive direct grants of over A$1 billion and consumers (read voters) are kept happy. The other super-large subsidy system is for farmers. The primary production industry gets tax breaks of A$548 million and rakes in another A$891 million in direct handouts. And, because of the drought in certain parts of the country, there are cries for more taxpayer aid. But, unlike the factory workers who live in urban areas and tend to vote for the opposition Australian Labour Party, farmers constitute the bulwark for the rural-based National Party - junior partners in the ruling coalition. Although his government has so far stood firm against more subsidies and farmers were invited to debate sustainable agriculture in Australia instead, there are signs that some form of assistance will be forthcoming. Mr Abbott will be well advised to resist the pressure. His economic credentials will be judged on this issue.

site_title: Former MFA official pleads guilty to overstating pineapple tart claims
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Former MFA official pleads guilty to overstating pineapple tart claims

His lawyer explains extenuating circumstances of Lim's actions

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Lim Cheng Hoe, the former public servant accused of inflating his pineapple tart claims, yesterday pleaded guilty to all the charges against him - even as he explained that he did so only to make up for the other diplomatic expenses that he had incurred out of his own pocket.

The 61-year-old former chief of protocol with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) admitted to 10 charges of cheating, amounting to $35,160 worth of inflated claims. The remaining 50 charges against him will be taken into consideration for his sentencing.

The prosecution yesterday asked for Lim to be jailed for 18 months for his offences - six months for each charge, and for at least three of the charges to run consecutively.

Lim, who is suffering from a number of ailments including kidney disease and diabetes, turned up in court yesterday seemingly all ready to serve his jail time. He brought with him, among various things, a bag containing his supply of medication - and had even changed his metal spectacle frames to plastic ones, as no metal is allowed in prisons here.

However, District Judge Eddy Tham will sentence Lim on Thursday.

Lim had served as the highest-ranking protocol officer at MFA before he was charged last October. The long-serving civil servant was then in charge of the MFA directorate responsible for organising ministerial and presidential visits, and oversaw policies on diplomatic privileges and immunities.

He was accused of cheating the ministry of almost $90,000, between February 2008 and May 2012, by inflating the claims he made on thousands of boxes of pineapple tarts and hundreds of bottles of wine supposedly bought for official ministerial trips. For example, he would claim for 200 boxes of pineapple tarts when only 50 were used.

In making their case for Lim's sentence yesterday, deputy public prosecutors Kelvin Kow and Gregory Gan argued that Lim's actions were "an egregious abuse of his position and a gross betrayal of the trust placed in him". As the sums involved were taxpayers' money, the offences also "constitute an assault on public weal", they added.

They said his case has also "generated much public disquiet and brought disrepute to the public service", which has caused "an intangible harm" to the public service. They added that his actions were premeditated and deliberate, carried out over multiple occasions and a "prolonged time period of four years".

In mitigation, Lim's lawyer - Philip Fong, managing partner of Harry Elias Partnership - argued that there were extenuating circumstances surrounding his client's actions. He said Lim inflated the claims only to make up for the expenses he incurred in buying gifts for foreign diplomats whenever they hosted events in Singapore.

Mr Fong said Lim told him that it is not MFA's official policy to give gifts at such local functions; therefore, any MFA officials who gave gifts to these Singapore-based foreign diplomats would not be reimbursed for what they spent.

So, in his attempt to overcome what he felt was "bureaucratic red tape", Lim overstated his claims to make up for these expenses.

"His conduct was misguided but well-intentioned as it was for the purpose of using the excess claimed to purchase the gifts for foreign diplomats based in Singapore and overseas," Mr Fong argued.

"He did not obtain any benefit for himself. He did not pocket any money. He only did so as and when he felt he needed petty cash to purchase gifts for upcoming functions with foreign officials," Mr Fong added.

He also said his client had made significant contributions to the public service and had had a distinguished and illustrious career. He also said Lim was truly remorseful for his misconduct, had made full restitution, and admitted to his acts very early in the investigations into his case.

In arguing for a lower sentence, Mr Fong pointed to his client's ill health and advanced age, and the fact that he would likely "face financial hardship in the years to come without the support of any pension".

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan's below-par Q4 growth raises fears of a renewed slowdown

BOJ might announce fresh monetary measures today

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

JAPAN's economic growth came in well below expectations in the final quarter of last year, going by data released yesterday.

This has reinforced fears of a renewed slowdown in the world's third-largest economy, even as other leading economies show signs of a pick-up in activity.

The rate of real or inflation-adjusted growth in the final quarter of 2013 was just 0.3 per cent; the market had expected it to be 0.7 per cent.

The annual rate of expansion, at one per cent, fell well short of the expected 2.5 per cent or more.

As reported in The Business Times yesterday, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration has signalled its alarm that "Abenomics" may be losing some traction and begun preparing for measures to ward off a fresh slowdown.

Some steps could come as early as today, when the Policy Board of the Bank of Japan (BOJ) ends its latest monthly meeting.

Fresh monetary moves could include increased injections of cash into the Japanese banking system in a bid to spur lending and borrowing activity, analysts speculate.

Mr Abe yesterday put on a brave face in the wake of the disappointing fourth-quarter data, and said Abenomics had "helped boost the economy" since he took office in December 2012.

Minister for Economic and Fiscal Affairs Akira Amari noted that "the economy has been steadily picking up".

Yesterday's data showed that Japan's gross domestic product (GDP) grew at a real rate of 1.6 per cent last year, marking a second consecutive year of expansion.

However, the growth rate appears to be slackening, as the impact of the stimulus package wanes at a time when Mr Abe's promised structural economic reforms have not yet borne fruit.

Mr Amari promised yesterday that the government would "pursue swift and firm implementation" of its 5.5 trillion yen (S$68 billion) stimulus package, which involves cash payments to low-income earners and public works projects, including new infrastructure investments in the run-up to the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

The Japanese economy's continued reliance on official stimulus is a concern for the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

The deputy director of the fund's Asia Department Jerry Schiff noted in Tokyo last week that Japan's recovery was still very much stimulus-driven and that the success of Abenomics was "not yet assured".

Despite warnings by the IMF and others that Japan's fiscal position is becoming more precarious, Mr Amari has said that the government could postpone a planned second hike in the consumption tax from 8 per cent to 10 per cent in October 2015 if consumer demand continues to be relatively weak. (The first hike, to take the tax rate from its current 5 per cent to 8 per cent, is to take place in April.)

Weak consumer demand makes it more likely that the BOJ will need to announce further monetary-easing measures today or at a later date, economists say; its governor Haruhiko Kuroda has signalled the central bank's willingness to take fresh steps if needed.

This in turn implies that the yen could weaken even further than the roughly 20 per cent it has dropped against the US dollar and the euro last year; it has also declined against major Asian currencies.

The Tokyo stock market reacted little yesterday to the latest GDP data, as investors digested the implications while waiting to see what steps, if any, the BOJ will take today.

Despite the weaker yen, growth in Japan's exports was sluggish in the final quarter of last year, especially to the US market; growth in exports to Asia increased, yesterday's data showed. Exports grew 0.4 per cent during the October-December period, after a 0.7 per cent fall in the preceding quarter.

Economic recovery last year was led by firm consumer spending, but consumer demand in the fourth quarter was weaker than what economists expected.

Household spending rose only 0.5 per cent on quarter, against an expected rise of 0.7 per cent, Kyodo news agency noted.

Consumption, accounting for around 60 per cent of GDP, rose a real 0.5 per cent, but this was due in part to a surge in demand ahead of the planned three-point sales tax hike in April.

Corporate capital spending rose 1.3 per cent, and housing investment, 4.2 per cent.

A critical factor for the continued success of Abenomics in the short term lies in the willingness of corporate Japan to raise wages - thus boosting consumption - in the upcoming "spring wage offensive", but so far, indications have not been positive in this regard.

site_title: Airbus buys German lender to boost financing options
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airbus buys German lender to boost financing options

Move would allow it to deposit funds with the ECB

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[PARIS] Airbus Group pressed ahead with post-Lehman plans to acquire its own banking licence, saying that it would buy small German lender Salzburg Muenchen Bank AG to boost its financing options.

The European aerospace group, formerly known as EADS, first disclosed the plans in 2012 after becoming concerned about where to place its large cash pile during the credit crisis.

Owning a banking licence would allow the world's second-largest aerospace group to deposit funds with the European Central Bank, as well as potentially draw on ECB funds.The plan follows in the footsteps of engineering companies such as Siemens, whose banking licenses have allowed it to tap the ECB's low-interest loan programme directly.

But in announcing the deal on Friday to buy Salzburg Muenchen Bank for an undisclosed sum, Airbus Group made plain its reasons had evolved - even though the option of using the eurozone central bank's coffers as a safe haven still stands.

"In principle, it does entitle the bank to liquidity from the ECB; however, Airbus Group has no need to access any liquidity of the ECB at this stage," a spokesman said. "Also, the bank will provide Airbus Group with the possibility to deposit funds directly with the ECB." Airbus Group identified other possible uses including carving out some flexibility in areas that it said were usually reserved for banks, such as providing liquidity to non-controlled joint ventures. The bank "may provide trade financing with suppliers, hedge book services, etc to support Airbus's production and delivery efforts," RBC Capital Markets analyst Rob Stallard said.

Both Airbus and rival Boeing, which has an aircraft financing arm called Boeing Capital Corp, are increasing production after a boom in aircraft orders. Both companies face concerns about the ability of the supply chain to keep up. The bank is, however, seen as unlikely to handle the airline customer financing carried out by Airbus and which is already well established through a Dublin subsidiary.

Industrial companies have traditionally been wary of the increased regulatory scrutiny - potentially involving tens of millions of euros in extra audits and management time or processes - that such a move would bring.

Airbus and Boeing both offer customer financing to support aircraft sales as a last resort - an activity that has recently rarely been used as Asian lenders step in to fill the gap left by once-dominant French banks.- Reuters

site_title: Playing a part and standing together
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Playing a part and standing together

Is the concept of Total Defence still relevant to a business organisation today? How can businesses and corporates contribute towards national defence?

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Bryce Boland

CTO APAC

FireEye

TOTAL Defence has never been more relevant, but the threats and required responses have changed. The wealth and strength of a country resides not just in its land and its citizens. It also resides in the economy and intellectual property. This wealth is intrinsically tied to the global connectedness of the world through the Internet. This reliance on modern technology can be exploited from anywhere and is the new frontier for defence.

Corporations and the government need to remain vigilant and continue to seek the best possible intelligence to ensure that these threats are understood and defeated. The economic impact from sustained cyber attacks on critical infrastructure, government and corporations could be enormous or even catastrophic. The defence of the nation requires the most advanced thinking possible, and we must not be complacent about addressing these hidden but growing threats to national security.

Kwek Leng Joo

Deputy Chairman

City Developments Limited

SINGAPORE'S economic progress and prosperity are founded on national security. Total Defence plays a vital role in safeguarding our city's present and future.

As a country limited by natural resources, building upon our core strengths - the peace, stability and security we enjoy - makes Singapore an attractive global trading and investment hub.

It is the responsibility of every citizen - both corporates and individuals alike - to contribute towards sustaining Singapore's national defence.

As a homegrown corporation with a 50-year-old growth story that parallels Singapore's nation building history, CDL recognises the importance of Total Defence in providing a conducive environment where businesses and people can flourish.

Since 1999, we have introduced National Service (NS)-friendly policies that place high priority for our NSmen employees to fulfil their national duties. We have implemented various schemes and incentives to encourage them to be fit and diligent so that they can respond when called upon to carry out their national duties.

With proper manpower planning, CDL has achieved zero work deferment for over a decade. As an honorary member of the Minister for Defence Awards (MiDAS) League and on the Minister's Honour Roll (Star) accorded by the Home Team NS Awards for Employers, we wish to encourage more businesses to take on a proactive role in Total Defence. Supporting our NSmen employees is one way corporations can contribute to the nation's peace and security.

Teo Lay Lim

Senior Managing Director

Accenture, Asean

RISING citizen expectations, evolving crime types and shrinking budgets test the capabilities of police forces around the world. One way of overcoming these challenges is to tap into the power of analytics.

Analytics, which harness useful insights from disorganised data, can prove a valuable ally in combating crime. Singapore's new ''Safe City'' testbed is a step in this direction.

Accenture is proud to be part of this one-year programme in which we are responsible for testing how advanced analytic capabilities may be integrated into the existing video monitoring systems used in the city. This will aid city authorities to improve situational awareness, streamline operations and enhance the response times to public safety incidents.

Accenture's solution will also enable the relevant authorities to detect and monitor a variety of situations, including crowd and traffic movements, public disorder incidents and environmental threats such as flooding.

We continue to look forward to delivering innovative and advanced technology solutions that will help safeguard the welfare of the country and its citizens.

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

SINGAPORE was a developing country when the concept of Total Defence was conceived 30 years ago.

Today, we are a developed nation and our military, economy and social fabric are very much stronger compared to the early days.

But as much as the landscape has changed in the last three decades, I believe that the concept of Total Defence is still very relevant.

On a basic level, businesses have done their part in releasing male employees for reservist training, for example.

However, the broader view of businesses' contribution towards national defence falls on the economic growth of organisations.

It is about growing Singapore's economy by developing strong companies that can compete on the world stage.

This calls for strong management so one key area to look into is to develop business leaders and strengthen their leadership skills through continuing education and exposure, not only to grow the company but for them to grow personally as well.

Ultimately, as Singapore prospers economically, the taxes that companies and individuals pay can be used for nation-building - to build military might, infrastructure and other essential components to help safeguard our future.

Toby Koh

Group Managing Director

Ademco Security Group Pte Ltd

TOTAL defence is extremely important to the corporate community in Singapore. It has transcended the simple notion of protecting the country into a rally for a bigger cause.

In these times when social and economic pressures prevail more strongly than before, with more foreigners sharing space in Singapore, the integration of our citizens and foreign guests to further Total Defence is critical.

At our company events, we always make it a point to reflect upon how fortunate Ademco is to be headquartered here in Singapore. Stable government, pro-business policies, good health care and infrastructure are but simply a few of the many things worth protecting.

The constant reminders of how Singapore compares against our neighbours give fresh breath to our Total Defence movement. Corporate bosses should continue to place emphasis on Total Defence; it will go a long way to helping our people remain cohesive.

Dileep Nair

Ambassador

Ministry of Foreign Affairs

BUSINESSES can only carry out what they are doing provided the country is peaceful and secure. Foreign investments will shun the place at the hint of threats to the country's security and well being.

It is therefore only logical that all businesses must give their full and wholehearted support to Total Defence.

Aside from supporting staff that have to go for regular reservist training, businesses can make available their resources for national defence purposes if needed.

Sidney Lim

Managing Director, South-east Asia

Protiviti Pte Ltd

THE Total Defence concept was first conceived in the 1980s before the rise of the Internet.

While the concept is definitely still relevant, we should also consider the new risks faced by organisations in a changing environment, fuelled by rapid advances in technology, that could significantly threaten our national security.

Ensuring privacy/identity management and information security protection; cyber threats that could significantly disrupt core operations - these issues continue to be at the top of the mind in a recent Protiviti survey of 400 global CEOs.

They present a moving target in terms of changing technology that makes security and privacy more complex and tougher to manage and control.

Although new developments (for example, social business, mobile computing, new platforms and devices) present opportunities for companies to create new markets and disruptive business models, they also present fresh avenues for cyber attacks and mischief.

As part of Singapore's Total Defence strategy, both public and private organisations should ensure that they have a sound enterprise risk management system in place to protect themselves against these risks, as well as any confidential data and information leaks which could potentially harm our country.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

MORE than 20 years ago, Singaporeans debated widely a White Paper on Singapore's Shared Values. Parliament eventually adopted five statements as the nation's Shared Values on Jan 15, 1991.

The first value was ''Nation before community and society above self'': The spirit of putting the interests of society ahead of the individual. This is the backbone of Total Defence.

For a nation with finite and limited resources in both land and people, we all have to pitch in to contribute to the Total Defence of Singapore.

It is not just the job of the army, navy, air force, police or civil defence but every single person who resides in this country, be they Singaporeans, PR or foreigners working here.

As such, at the organisational level, companies regardless of national origin must play a part to ensure the security of this country which has provided them the environment to grow and thrive.

Doing so ensures the safety and security of everyone residing here as well as the privilege of continuing to thrive in an economic powerhouse such as Singapore.

As a Singaporean company, we have always prided ourselves on our ardent support of Total Defence, by making readily available our resources in service of our country: Our modern fleet of quality heavy haulage, marine and logistical equipment such as mobile cranes, trucks, tugs and barges are ever ready to be deployed to keep our country strong, safe and secure.

Janet Ang

Managing Director

IBM Singapore

EVERYONE has a role to play and Total Defence Day is an opportune time for us to bond with our fellow Singaporeans, strengthen our unity and be inspired towards a collective future.

The safe and secure environment helps to create a place where world-class facilities, infrastructure and talents converge to create exciting growth opportunities for all.

At IBM, we believe we have a part to play in strengthening these elements of Total Defence not just through the provision of IBM's leading innovation and analytical solutions for National Defence but also by inculcating in our workforce the importance of loyalty to our family and nation.

Alick Chia

Director, Business Support

SKF Asia Pacific Pte Ltd

SINGAPORE'S concept of Total Defence covering the five key components of military, civil, economic, social and psychological defence is a good strategy and an excellent approach. It will involve every Singaporean and every institution.

In recent times, it has been discovered in many countries that both corporations and rich individuals have been trying to avoid paying their share of taxes to their government.

For Singapore's total defence strategy to function well, it has to be financially supported. This could also mean that corporations and rich individuals should take responsibility to pay their taxes to help finance this strategy in the long term.

Responsible companies and individuals should be committed to pay their taxes according to what they have benefited either operating here or as individuals living in this country.

Our tax rate is already low, we should not try to avoid it at all.

If those (both corporations and individuals) who had previously evaded paying tax now start paying their dues, tax collections would increase.

This would allow the government to introduce more social help schemes for the poor and needy, and help reduce the income gap problem.

Schemes that help ensure good social mobility would make this country a place of hope for those born to poor families but are willing to work hard to improve their skills and competency to secure a better future for themselves and their families, like the pioneering generation did.

Dhirendra Shantilal

Board Director & Head, Asia-Pacific

Fircroft

WITHOUT the concept of Total Defence safeguarding our national security, businesses would not have a safe, sound and secure environment to thrive and prosper.

Singapore's economic growth has been largely due to its reputation as a stable, well-governed country, which has drawn foreign investments and encouraged multinationals to establish their headquarters here.

Businesses and corporates should continue to ensure that such an environment is maintained and enhanced. Companies should have robust business contingency plans and ensure that their staff are well-briefed, and maybe even trained, to handle emergencies.

In addition, individuals will need to constantly upgrade their skills and expertise to safeguard the economic defence of our country by remaining competitive.

In this respect, businesses can contribute towards national defence by providing regular upgrading and training opportunities, which will develop and cultivate talent that will help Singapore stay ahead of the curve.

Ho Meng Kit

CEO

Singapore Business Federation

THE concept of Total Defence continues to be relevant to businesses. It is a call for them to be prepared to ensure that their operational readiness and supply chain are not compromised in the event of a crisis.

It can be a national emergency or other natural and man-made disruptions. This translates into having business contingency plans to ensure the uninterrupted operations of our offices and factories during these emergencies.

The Singapore Business Federation (SBF), supported by the National Security Coordination Secretariat, conducts annual dialogue sessions to educate and engage the business community on the importance of preparedness to combat pandemics, cyber threats, natural disasters and other exigencies.

Through outreach programmes and best practice guides, SBF assists businesses to keep their Business Continuity Management (BCM) programmes relevant.

We believe that Singapore's continued growth and prosperity lies in the three pillars of our society - government, businesses and the public - working hand in hand to uphold the objectives of Total Defence.

Ang Swee Meng, Allen

Group Managing Director

Aldon Technologies Services Pte Ltd

TOTAL Defence is still relevant to enterprise today because security is a critical infrastructure that enables businesses to flourish.

Businesses can contribute to economic defence by building up a resilient economy and by working with the government to put in place contingency measures to keep offices and factories running during an emergency and NSmen and equipment mobilised.

Businesses can also support civil and military defence by facilitating employees to go for annual in-camp and other training as required by their units.

In the final analysis, the concept of Total Defence makes Singapore internationally more competitive as it seeks to avoid political and social uncertainties that plague some countries in the region.

David Siah

Country Manager, Singapore

Trend Micro

ONE of the biggest threats to organisations today stems from the fact that many companies are going digital and operating in a dynamic and complex IT environment with various apps and platforms at play.

These technologies expose networks to great risks, most notably cyber criminals. In situations like these, the concept of Total Defence is relevant to businesses, as every employee plays a part in the cyber security strategy.

As Singapore becomes a digital nation, we believe it is critical that the country's public and private institutions take heed of the threat posed by cyber criminals.

As threat defence experts, companies like Trend Micro contribute to cyber defence strategy by helping organisations adapt quickly to evolving user behaviour, technology, infrastructure and threat vectors.

This, in turn, improves consumers' confidence in the digital economy, one of the critical areas that will drive economic growth over the next few years.

Lawrence Koh

Founder and Managing Director

iFly Singapore

TOTAL Defence is relevant to businesses here as we seek to build values that would essentially strengthen national pride, build a cooperative workforce and, in turn, ensure economic security in the country.

As a mentor to my staff, I do my best to manage our work policies that are relevant to upholding the values and virtues of Total Defence.

By imbuing these values into our working lifestyle, Total Defence becomes an inherent part of our lives, not just another compulsory team-building exercise we have to go through as citizens and colleagues.

Business leaders can do their bit by supporting their staff when they are called to serve through government initiatives like Reservist or IPPT, as this builds faith in the stability of our defence system.

Businesses can also aim to build economic defence by maintaining world-class standards in service and management, and continually upgrading the skills of their staff, but this can still be done without compromising their roles or time in serving the nation, whether as NSmen or as civilians.

As support from corporations builds confidence in our nation's political and social agenda, the country can better withstand external economic or diplomatic pressures.

By upholding these values, Total Defence becomes, essentially, good for business.

Francis Fong

Managing Director

SAS Institute Pte Ltd, Singapore

INTELLIGENCE has always been the cornerstone of any defence strategy, and today more than ever, we see it playing a critical role in driving national security.

The ''big data'' explosion has provided a goldmine of information that includes news, social media, multimedia (''big data'') with traditional data sources which, when successfully exploited, not only provides a comprehensive picture in real time but can also identify patterns which give warning before events occur.

This is already possible today, and is an invaluable resource for national security agencies and for the health of the financial and governmental systems.

The challenge within government and defence agencies is to contextualise the ''big data'' that resides within their organisations.

This is where companies like SAS come in - to help make sense of the wealth of data available and to turn it into actionable intelligence and insight.

Our high-performance analytics help combat crime and terrorism in three ways - by enabling preventive policing, facilitating information sharing across agencies and borders, and leveraging social media intelligence - all of which are crucial to 21st Century national security.

Tom Zack

President SEA

EMC Corporation

THE definition of total defence is not only extremely relevant but also changing rapidly.

With evolving trends in communication and high reliance on cloud, virtualisation and mobile technologies, communication is getting borderless and so are the attacks.

Every mobile device opens up an organisation's network to vulnerabilities.

Trends around mobility alongside the blurring lines between business and personal devices highlight the need to ensure that the data residing in an organisation stays safe.

The growing incidence of cyber-attacks prove that failure to do so can have damaging long term implications on an organisation's success.

A recent EMC survey further highlights that at least 56 per cent of businesses in Asia faced a data breach or data loss in the last 12 months.

Analysts highlight that the ability to protect and empower employees will be the key differentiator between winners and losers this year.

Authentication, security, predictive analytics, back-up and recovery tools available today can help arm businesses with the right defence to protect and succeed against the challenges and demands of the digital age.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

THE concept is certainly still relevant to business organisations as one of the five key components of Total Defence is economic defence.

There are many examples around the world where economic and political turmoil cause social discord in a country so we need to safeguard against this by ensuring our country's good economic health.

The business community makes up a large pillar of society and businesses have a significant part to play in keeping the Singapore economy strong.

A solid economic foundation will provide Singapore's citizens with good job opportunities and this will in turn help protect social harmony.

As citizens, we have a responsibility to seek the welfare of our country, for in Singapore's welfare, we will find our welfare.

Of course, the economic race needs to be properly balanced with the other pillars of Total Defence, namely military, civil, social and psychological.

If not managed well, the push for economic competitiveness can easily create cracks in a small society like Singapore's.

So perhaps the concept of Total Defence is even more relevant today as we find ourselves in the transitional phase of economic restructuring.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

TOTAL Defence has served Singapore well throughout these years. Businesses can only flourish when the country is stable.

Therefore, Total Defence is definitely still relevant to business.

One of the ways we, as corporate citizens, can contribute is to ensure that our business operations can continue during crises.

Therefore, we need to have a business continuity plan and staff who can react and implement promptly.

This means that time and money have to be invested in periodic planning and staff training to make sure that we can cope with any new challenges (floods, riots and so on).

We have, after all, benefited greatly from Singapore's stability. Hence, we have a duty towards the country, and investing some time and money is the least we can do.

Seah Kian Peng

CEO (Singapore)

NTUC FairPrice Co-operative Ltd

TOTAL defence is a vital function in ensuring that Singapore continues to thrive in an increasingly volatile global socio-economic climate.

In a country that imports almost all our food supplies, NTUC FairPrice recognises the important role we play in contributing to our nation's food security and price stability.

This role becomes more apparent and critical whenever we face a crisis; for example in 2003/2004, FairPrice ensured a steady supply of vegetables, poultry and related products when the Sars outbreak and the bird flu pandemic caused supply shortages to the market.

Beyond ensuring adequate food supply, we also play an active role in moderating and even reducing prices during economic downturns such as during the rice crisis in 2008.

More recently during the haze crisis last year, we made face masks available widely to combat profiteering from supply shortage and overwhelming demand.

We are able to protect Singaporeans from volatile price and supply fluctuations because of the strategies we adopt, from source diversification, contract farming and stock piling, to forward buying, direct importing and bulk buying.

We remain committed to ensuring the affordability and availability of daily essentials for everyone; and in a way, this assurance provides peace of mind to our customers.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

I WAS conscripted into National Service in 1973. I retired as a Lieutenant Colonel in 1995, after having served 22 years of national service.

I believe I am among the early pioneers, who have an intimate knowledge of National Service and Total Defence, both as a citizen and an employer.

I was a key appointment holder and attended the first Reservists' Officers Staff and Command Course at the Singapore Command and Staff College from 1981 to 1983.

Much of my leadership skills were honed in National Service, for example, earning respect without having to use authority or, as they say, ''pull rank'' and dealing with complex situations, especially coordinating multi-dimensional needs and challenges.

Companies which I have worked for have benefited from my training. Based on my experience, Total Defence continues to be relevant and beneficial to business organisations today.

National Service in Singapore has now been institutionalised. Many parents today want their sons to go through National Service. This has underpinned Total Defence and helped institutionalise it.

Many employers like myself, who have undergone National Service, understand the need for Total Defence. We have accepted this as an integral part of doing business in Singapore.

When our employees go for in-camp training and our companies support Total Defence, we are all playing our part to keep Singapore safe round the clock while we conduct our businesses.

I remember this was the message I shared with the Ministry of Defence when I was invited to give inputs on the PR campaign to launch Total Defence 30 years ago, and later as an ambassador to promote Total Defence to businesses, schools and the community, both as a national serviceman and an employer.

What matters most in the ultimate test of defending Singapore is the psyche of all Singaporeans.

In this regard, the holistic approach taken by Total Defence continues to be relevant today. Beyond the recognition and awards for supporting Total Defence, businesses and corporations can and must continue to play a vital role to strengthen this psyche, by giving Total Defence the requisite priority and support it needs, on an on-going basis.

We do not want to be put to the test. Much is at stake for businesses. Total Defence ensures that this will not happen.

Mark Billington

Regional Director, South-east Asia

ICAEW

THE holistic nature of Total Defence, adapted from similar Danish and Swiss philosophies, remains as important today as it did 30 years ago.

Singapore's small size and global nature mean that we remain highly sensitive to external shocks and international economic trends, and building resilience into the system will help businesses shelter against difficult times.

Economic defence also includes maintaining our environmental resources so that they can support future generations in growth.

With limited natural resources, we are reliant on the little we have and those around us.

This is why ICAEW has championed accounting for natural capital as an essential part of business reporting.

Natural resources are a critical asset and it is becoming increasingly necessary for businesses and investors to factor natural capital into their strategies and decisions if their behaviour is to become more sustainable.

It is not just the obvious industries such as mining, forestry and agriculture which are affected.

Most supply chains start with a natural resource or use air, water and rely on unpolluted soil.

Eric Hoh

Vice President, Asia South Region

Symantec

AS Singapore commemorates three decades of Total Defence this year, it's noteworthy that the five pillars of Total Defence continue to remain relevant despite the changing security landscape.

They are also now intertwined and supported by the digital economy, and as we increasingly live and conduct our lives online, we need to ensure that online security is not taken for granted.

As recent events remind us, cyber attacks have the ability to seriously disrupt and affect a country and her citizen's everyday lives, emphasising the need for us to be mindful of new threats and dangers that can undermine the security of businesses and corporations.

By keeping IT policies and security software up-to-date and adopting best practices to protect critical data, we can work towards making every day a Safer Internet Day, minimising the risk of cyber attacks while doing our part for Total Defence.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

TOTAL Defence - to every Singaporean and organisation - is an immutable obligation. It is ingrained into the psyche of every Singaporean that national defence is about protecting and preserving our independence and freedom as a country.

It is not a question of relevancy but how each individual, organisation, business and corporate plays its role in Total Defence. This means being supportive of employees serving time in reservist training and celebrating with staff who excel in their service stints.

The Total Defence mentality must go beyond paying lip service; it must be an entrenched belief and conviction that it is only through Total Defence that Singapore could become what it is today, and how we can preserve our way of life, our cultures, our businesses and, most importantly, our national vitality.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

THE concept of Total Defence will stay relevant not only to business organisations but to the entire population for many years to come. Every individual and member of the business and civil sector has a role to play to make our Total Defence capability work for the nation. This is more so for us as a small nation. Possible threats not only in the form of military attacks but other non-military adversities like exploitation of any economic, social or psychological weaknesses can happen anytime.

As a member of the business sector, employers can continue to support Total Defence by ensuring that its operationally-ready NSmen are released for required courses and exercises when mobilised. Systems should be in place for covering arrangements to ensure business operations can continue smoothly without disruption when such situations arise.

It should be an accepted work attitude among employees and employers should set the lead in setting good examples in supporting Total Defence for the country. Business associations can include Total Defence education on an ongoing basis among businesses to increase awareness among employers.

Chris Comer

CEO and Property Developer

Castlewood Group

TODAY'S youth might believe that the world mentality was different two generations ago, and that wars, espionage, civil unrest and racial hatred are things of the past. We must therefore actively encourage learning and understanding of the five pillars of Total Defence. The pillars that are not so obvious need reaffirming - society, the economy and psychology of the nation are easily undermined, no thanks to the Internet.

Singapore's history must be taught and celebrated in the centres of education and the workplace, with parallels drawn to what else was going on in the world at the same time. This might make our youth far more patriotic and aware of the threats that our neighbours present to our national security. While our military and civil defences are very capable in defending us, it is far better to have a fence at the top of the cliff than an ambulance at the bottom.

David Low

CEO

Futuristic Store Fixtures Pte Ltd

SINGAPORE is economically well placed on the global map despite her size and scarcity of natural resources. One key driver behind Singapore's rise to its present status is confidence in the city-state, not just from internal but also offshore stakeholders. Confidence is key in attracting and acquiring funds and investors to keep the economy thriving. Total Defence is instrumental in instilling confidence.

I see civil defence as the main component where businesses could actively play a part. By pledging resources such as logistics supply and skilled workforce in trying times, we pool together a troop to battle situations with prompt readiness. Mindset is mastermind to success and it is important for businesses to stay positive and keep operations in continuity to enhance psychological defence. The concept of Total Defence certainly holds great relevance to the business environment today, as we continue to attract investments to the island.

Zaheer K Merchant

Regional Director (Singapore & Europe)

Qi Group of Companies

THIRTY years of Total Defence has led to it being even more relevant today. Aside from the combined elements of Total Defence, economic defence requires government, businesses and industries to organise and galvanise resources in a precise way.

The economy must continue to function even in the face of impending calamity. Strategic resource planning requires offices and factories to be able to continue operations even in a crisis with manpower or equipment shortages. The very act of planning - which should be a prerequisite for every organisation in Singapore - means that businesses are able to forward plan and develop contingencies in the use of resources in meeting different needs in times of strife.

This in turn enables business organisations to develop deeper and more progressive overarching thinking on all aspects of business, not simply fiscal considerations. It develops and upgrades skills, critical thinking, and potentially helps form business strategies beneficial overall, including cost efficiency. It puts us ahead of the curve. Just as Sun Tzu is deemed effective in the business world, no less should Total Defence be.

Farmers besiege Yingluck's office; economy hurting

Rice farmers push back riot police, demanding payment

Listen to this article

Published Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] Thai protesters seeking to oust caretaker Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra surrounded government headquarters yesterday in response to police efforts to clear them from the streets, as farmers besieged her temporary office to demand payment for rice.

Thailand has been in crisis since November, when protesters started a movement aimed at eradicating the influence of Ms Yingluck's brother Thaksin, a populist former premier ousted by the army in 2006 who is seen as the power behind her government.

Data published yesterday showed the economy grew just 0.6 per cent in the fourth quarter from the third and, with the country likely to be without a fully functioning government for months, the state planning board slashed its forecast for 2014.

site_title: SAP cautiously upbeat as growth returns
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SAP cautiously upbeat as growth returns

Firm's software and software-related services growth hit double-digits in Asia-Pacific region for 2013, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WITH 2014 marking its 25th year of operations in the Asia-Pacific, including Japan, German software major SAP AG is cautiously upbeat about growth despite slowdown and uncertainties in some markets.

Adaire Fox-Martin, SAP's chief operating officer for the Asia-Pacific region, quoted World Bank growth forecasts to indicate that global growth is set to accelerate this year as advanced economies turn a corner, five years after the global financial crisis.

"Growth is projected to strengthen to 3.2 per cent this year, 3.4 per cent in 2015, and 3.6 per cent in 2016 - up from 2.4 per cent in 2013," she noted.

Speaking to BizIT, Ms Fox-Martin observed that in the three months which ended on Dec 31 last year, the company marked another positive quarter (the company's fourth in fiscal 2013) in the region, with accelerated double-digit, year-over-year (YOY) revenue increases in software and software-related services (SSRS). The company also continued to see strong uptake in cloud subscription revenues.

She added that the whole region saw double-digit growth in SSRS for full-year fiscal 2013. The financial services industry (such as banking and insurance) and public sector have been the fastest-growing sectors for the region, she added.

"Within Asia-Pacific, South-east Asia performed very well in fiscal 2013, particularly during the second half of the year, recording strong, double-digit growth," Ms Fox-Martin said. "(Overall) this momentum bodes well for the current year as large enterprises in APJ continue to choose SAP over the competition."

She said that Singapore also registered healthy software and SSRS growth during the year.

Ms Fox-Martin said that companies in Asia face competition, demanding customers and regional and international expansion needs. "As a result, they are required to adopt and consume IT in a much faster and easier way. That's the way SAP is providing solutions to customers in the SAP cloud or on premise powered by our in-memory technology SAP Hana. We're making SAP the cloud company powered by SAP Hana for customers in Asia."

She said that data, devices and the people who use them are more connected than ever. There is immense value to be unlocked by connecting this information, the so-called "dark data", to the work people do every day, enabling users to quickly discover what is happening and then act with the power of collective insight, she added.

Ms Fox-Martin said that more companies today are seeing the opportunities created by the power of data and are aiming to find ways to harness the power of this data to make better business decisions in real-time and provide a better experience to customers.

"SAP's analytics vision is built around driving a near real-time connected experience across enterprise business intelligence (BI), agile visualisation and advanced analytics," she said.

"Analytic solutions from SAP help facilitate this discovery by connecting users, data, platforms and devices, allowing people to quickly and easily engage with their data, visualise what is happening and predict what comes next," Ms Fox-Martin added.

Mobile is no longer an option, it's everything, she observed. "Today, more technology vendors are recognising that the strength of this app-based economy lies in the enterprise. Once considered the sweet spot for Angry Birds, mobile developers have shifted focus to creating enterprise-grade mobile applications covering every possible mobile platform; and in 2014, we'll see that development continue to increase as developers take advantage of newly introduced, streamlined tools that help create and deploy the same mobile application across multiple platforms."

She said that SAP is "well positioned as a leader" in the cloud, though adoption in developed markets is different from adoption in developing markets. "All SAP's line-of-business applications (Human Resources, Procurement, Customer Relationship Management and others) are clearly moving to cloud and we are driving a cloud-first approach," Ms Fox-Martin said.

A triple-digit percentage growth in its Asia-Pacific cloud business during the fourth quarter marked the third time this happened in fiscal 2013. "The company's cloud business growth demonstrates SAP's successful transition to the cloud while managing the growth of its core business. We now have a cloud revenue run rate of more than one billion euros and we have the largest subscriber base with 35 million cloud users.

"In Asia-Pacific, we see the fast shift in markets like ANZ (Australia and New Zealand). Other markets like India and SEA also saw accelerated adoption rate of cloud."

Ms Fox-Martin pointed out that the days of building a business case to move to the cloud based on total cost of ownership (TCO) are over. "Companies will increasingly look to invest in the cloud as their innovation platform - as a way in which they can extend their existing infrastructure, enable new processes and achieve new insights that enable them to run their business in an entirely new way - not just do the same old thing using a different delivery model."

site_title: Buoyed by Yellen's words, earnings reports
content:
Buoyed by Yellen's words, earnings reports

Q1 earnings from 400 of S&P 500 firms beat estimates

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LAST week, the stock market fought almost all the way back to par for the year as it was convinced by the new Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen that the US central bank was in safe hands under her charge.

According to an old adage, the market prefers bad news to uncertainty. Ms Yellen made no bones about her intention to continue "tapering" bond purchases. So while that's bad news, at least one uncertainty is removed - traders do not have to worry if quantitative easing is going to carry on, or not.

In testimony before the House of Representatives and the Senate last week, the Fed chief made crystal clear that she will pick up the baton from Ben Bernanke and keep up with the move to wind down the bond purchases.

She reassured markets that the Fed in her care will not be easily swayed by weak jobs reports. Admitting that she had not anticipated the surprisingly poor jobs growth in January and February, Ms Yellen warned against jumping to conclusions on the overall trend of jobs growth based on only two reports.

Speaking at an event on Tuesday in Dallas, Fed regional president Richard Fisher said Ms Yellen had done a "great job". Mr Fisher said he and Ms Yellen had had differences of opinion in the past, but that she now spoke for him and the rest of the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee.

"Her job is no longer to express her views, but to lead us as Ben Bernanke led us," Mr Fisher said.

Ms Yellen was also unfazed by the emerging markets crisis, echoing statements from Mr Fisher and others who have said the current scare is unlikely to lead to a repeat of the currency crises in the developing world in the 1990s.

"The big risk out there is if you really see a slowdown in the economy due to turmoil in international markets, or some major credit crisis that would constrain liquidity out there," said Eric Marshall, portfolio manager at mutual fund firm Hodges Capital. "I don't think that's likely; otherwise the Fed wouldn't be curtailing the QE programme."

Major indexes were also lifted by earnings reports that were by and large positive last week. Industrial companies such as farming machinery giant Deere & Co and building materials maker Owens Corning exceeded Wall Street growth targets.

This suggests that two vital parts of the economy - farming and construction - are shaping up for a big sprint.

"In general, you're seeing construction markets pick back up," said Mr Marshall of Hodges Capital. "If you look at companies that sell building wire, that sell cement, that sell gypsum or wall board - they're taking price increases here in January, February, March . . . right before construction season."

Another sign of construction activity and the jobs market picking up in the spring was the statement from home improvement chain Home Depot, which said the company will hire 80,000 workers ahead of its busiest season.

A substantial majority - nearly 400 - of the Standard & Poor's 500 which have reported first-quarter earnings have surpassed the average analyst's estimate.

There were a few major disappointments in this buoyant earnings season, however. WellCare Health Plans, an administrator of health insurance to the poor and the elderly, indicated fees linked to the new healthcare legislation had eaten into its profits.

Mr Fisher, of the Dallas Fed, reiterated his argument that the regulations passed by US Congress have done more to harm than to help the economic recovery in the last several years. Mr Fisher said his major worry as a central banker was not inflation but stagnated growth in middle-income jobs, something he believes is a direct result of fiscal policy.

Traders have also looked past some weak economic reports recently, working under the assumption that the stronger reports in November and early December were more accurate reflections of economic activity.

A historically bad winter brought more blizzards to the south and eastern seaboard of the US last week. On Saturday, city workers had just finished clearing roughly one foot of snow off the streets of New York City when it began to snow again.

The jobs report two weeks ago and the retail sales report last week, which showed an unexpected dip in January sales, both partly blamed the poor weather for their underperformance.

"I think investors should prepare themselves for slightly negative news or small misses in terms of economic data as a result of all the bad weather the country's experienced," said Oliver Pursche, president of Gary Goldberg Financial Services.

"But that's going to be very temporary. I would expect a jump in jobless claim, perhaps even a slight uptick in unemployment numbers in February," he added.

Such a blip should not be misinterpreted as a change in course, Mr Pursche said. He has little doubt that the recovery is picking up.

"You saw it in a rise in small business optimism; you see it in inventory-to-sales ratios . . . Just about every leading indicator is pointing to continued strength," Mr Pursche said.

For now, it seems likely that the Dow Jones Industrial Average will test the record set in January and settle around 16,600 points, or perhaps even hit 17,000.

But should the economy fail to bloom in spring, the recent optimism could melt away with the snow.

SUBSCRIBERS

AirAsia to launch Japan carrier with new partners

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] AirAsia Bhd has decided on partners and top executives for a new discount airline in Japan after ending its tie-up with ANA Holdings last year.

The co-investors include listed companies, said Tony Fernandes, the Malaysian low-cost airline's group chief executive officer, without naming them. Yoshinori Odagiri, formerly CEO of AirAsia's Japanese tie-up with ANA, will head the new carrier with Osamu Hata, previously a chief financial officer at Japan's Dell unit, taking the top finance role, he said.

"We've gone with people we think are like-minded and bring strategic value," said Mr Fernandes, during a visit to Japan to meet them. "The timing is excellent for Japan with the new economic thinking." Japan's budget airline market has exploded in recent years, with three carriers starting flights in 2012, and Spring Airlines Japan set to start operations in May. The economy has expanded since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe became PM in 2012.

AirAsia ended its venture with ANA last year due to a disagreement over strategy, with ANA re-launching the carrier as Vanilla Air. AirAsia will hold 33 per cent of voting rights in the new carrier with flights probably starting next year, said Mr Fernandes. An announcement will be made in April, he said.It is considering airports including Nagoya's Chubu airport and Osaka's Kansai airport as possible bases for the new carrier, Mr Fernandes said. - Bloomberg

site_title: HKEx chief floats anew need for circuit breakers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

HKEx chief floats anew need for circuit breakers

Charles Li points to evolving market conditions for relook

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CAN Hong Kong continue to do without circuit breakers for stock trading just because the city's investors don't want it? Maybe not for long.

By devoting his latest blog specifically on the subject, Charles Li, chief executive of Hong Kong Clearings and Exchange, has put a spotlight on a controversial subject by revealing that "I think it is timely for a renewed debate on circuit breakers to determine if they are now needed in the Hong Kong market".

At least twice before, in early 1997 and 2004, HKEx dropped the idea after being met with lukewarm response from market participants. In his blog published on Thursday evening, Mr Li said this time, it's different. "Our market has discussed circuit breakers from time to time before, with the conclusion being that they weren't necessary. Some people say that circuit breakers are not suitable for our market and amount to market intervention, therefore, are a waste of time to consider. But I don't think that previous decisions necessarily apply to evolving market conditions today."

He confirmed earlier reports that the exchange is weighing the merits of introducing circuit breakers. "I think it is timely for a renewed debate on circuit breakers to determine if they are now needed in the Hong Kong market. So that's why we're looking at circuit breakers again."

His confirmation has political backing from the industry regulator, the Securities and Futures Commission, whose executive director Keith Lui publicly lent his support to an adoption of circuit breakers, saying it would bring Hong Kong in line with international practice.

When asked about a possible timetable for introducing circuit breakers for Hong Kong's exchange-traded products, a HKEx spokesman said: "We continue to monitor developments in the global markets and consider if any measures can further improve the efficiency and integrity of our market. We keep an eye on a wide range of issues and there have been no conclusions or timetables with respect to circuit breakers."

Among the opponents for adopting circuit breakers is Jeffrey Chan, chairman of Hong Kong Securities Association and founding partner of Oriental Patron Financial Group, who reportedly declared that Hong Kong's current trading system does not support any plans for a circuit breaker system and that any proposal will be subject to public consultation.

Others argued that HKEx's existing power to suspend trading of a stock, sometimes halting it for days or even weeks, is sufficient to prevent the market from suffering flash crash.

On the need for renewed debate, Mr Li cited the recent development in electronic trading, now often done automatically via algorithms "that have a chance, even if a remote chance, of generating erroneous orders which could create an overreaction and threaten market integrity". The consequence could be "considerable turmoil which could impact confidence in the market", he noted.

He explained that carrying out a review of circuit breakers is a response to request from the International Organisation of Securities Commissions, and in line with new electronic trading regulations to be implemented by Hong Kong early this year.

He also took the opportunity to debunk three misconceptions about HKEx's motive and about what model of circuit breakers would be suited to Hong Kong.

First, he dismissed criticism about HKEx being motivated by its wish to speed up connectivity in its market structure and infrastructure with that of China mainland where a circuit breaker mechanism has long been enforced. "Aligning with the mainland is not the objective. The objective is first to consider whether there is a need for circuit breakers in Hong Kong," he said. He added that building connectivity with the mainland is a strategic but long term goal, not something to be achieved overnight.

Second, it is about finding a model of circuit breakers that best suits Hong Kong. He explained that circuit breakers do not only mean strict daily price limits, as it is on the mainland or in other Asian markets. They could be designed "with thresholds that are not fixed but adjust dynamically with market movements, allowing price discovery to take place more normally".

The third is about not drawing up a direct correlation between circuit breakers and trading suspensions. Mr Li said some circuit breaker models, currently in use by some exchanges, could be done to provide a short "cooling off", usually lasting for a few minutes, while trading continues under certain limitations such as on the price at which orders may be executed.

"Where we decide to proceed with new initiatives, we will consult the market comprehensively; if the initiative is supported by the market, we'll implement it in an appropriate manner," Mr Li concluded.
