content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China maintains ban on giant ore carriers

Rules to take effect from July a setback for Brazil's Vale

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] China will only allow ships with capacity of up to 250,000 deadweight tonnes to berth at its ports from July 1, its transport ministry said, effectively keeping a ban on Brazilian miner Vale's huge iron ore vessels in place since January 2012.

It would be the latest setback for the world's top iron ore producer which has been hoping that China would lift the ban aimed at shielding its shippers.

Vale invested more than US$2 billion to build several 400,000-dwt vessels to slash transport costs to China by up to a third and better compete with Australian rivals Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton.

The expansion of Chinese ports has been "irrational" and they now need to shed capacity to meet a number of requirements, including the maximum capacity limit of 250,000 dwt on ships allowed to berth, according to a statement on the Ministry of Transport's website on Feb 10.

The new rules will come into effect from July 1, the statement said, adding "every port authority must direct port enterprises to restructure terminals in accordance with the requirements of large-scale shipping development".

While the Chinese ban does increase Vale's freight cost, deployment of these ships is not a problem since it is able to call on other ports, said Jayendu Krishna, director at shipping consultancy Drewry Maritime Advisors. "In the overall scheme of things considering the global distribution of iron ore, cost implication probably will not be too great," said Mr Krishna.

There are 30 Valemaxes sailing currently, some owned by Vale and the rest by other operators. Vale has said it was losing US$2 to US$3 per tonne in iron ore shipping costs because of the Chinese ban.

Due to the ban, the miner set up a transshipment terminal in the Philippines in February 2012 where the Valemaxes can transfer iron ore into smaller ships bound for China. It is also building an iron ore storage and distribution hub in Malaysia, expected to start operations this year.

The ships have also been docking at other ports, including in Italy, Japan, Oman and South Korea, said Mr Krishna.

In August, the transport ministry said in a draft document published on its website that ports may be allowed to receive ships based on the inherent capacity of their infrastructure, pending regulatory approvals. The ministry then sought feedback from the local marine industry.

Three months later, Xinhua news agency reported that China's state-owned Shandong Shipping Corp signed a US$500 million deal with Vale to operate four of the Valemaxes.

China barred the Valemaxes from its ports about a month after the first of the giant vessels docked at Dalian port in December 2011. But a Valemax managed to dock at China's Lianyungang port in April last year.

Besides Dalian and Lianyungang, other ports that may be able to accept Valemax vessels include Dongjiakou and Caofeidian, as well as Zhanjiang and Ningbo Zhoushan, which are under construction, industry sources said.

Most of the ships were built in Chinese shipyards and partly financed by the country's international development bank. - Reuters

SUBSCRIBERS

RBA to sell Sydney mansion amid high home prices

920 sq m Eversley mansion is in Kirribilli suburb, where median house price is A$2.35m

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] The Reserve Bank of Australia is seeking to sell a 920 square metre residential property in a harbourside suburb of Sydney amid the highest home prices the city has ever seen.

The central bank has listed for sale the six-bedroom Eversley mansion near the northern end of the Sydney Harbour Bridge through broker Ray White Group, according to a listing on the realestate.com.au website. No price guide was given for the property in Kirribilli, a suburb four kilometres north of the city centre, where the median house price was A$2.35 million (S$2.68 million), according to the website.

The RBA is putting the house up for sale after its record-low 2.5 per cent benchmark interest rate helped drive a 13.4 per cent gain in Sydney dwelling prices in the 12 months to Jan 31. While home prices are at a record, the country's jobless rate is at a decade-high 6 per cent, shrinking the likelihood of a rate increase that could arrest further price surges.

"It's a seller's market quite clearly: there are plenty of buyers out there, not many listings, and prices are rising, so it's not a bad time to sell," said Louis Christopher, managing director of Sydney-based real estate data provider SQM Research. "It's a little bit perplexing as to why the RBA was holding residential property."

Rachael Wright, marketing agent at Ray White, declined to comment on the listing, which shows the house, at 10 Carabella Street, has been split into two apartments. Colleague Kingsley Yates didn't immediately respond to a voice-mail message seeking comment. The RBA declined to comment on the sale. State government filings show the RBA owns both apartments.

Kirribilli, which is also the location of Sydney residences of the prime minister and the governor general, is surrounded by water on three sides, with views of the city's Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

The RBA bought 8 and 10 Carabella Street in 1986, and combined them with a neighbouring property that it already owned as part of a new staff training college, according to a city council document. The bank's HC Coombs Centre for Financial Studies is still located at the adjoining property at 122A Kirribilli Avenue, according to its website.

The value of the RBA's property, plant and equipment assets was A$491 million as of June 30, up from A$448 million a year earlier, the bank's financial statements for the 2013 fiscal year show.

The tenants of one of the apartments at Eversley gave notice of their plans to vacate in mid-2013, according to documents released in December under a Freedom of Information request. - Bloomberg

site_title: A smart way to property investment
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A smart way to property investment

Reits, with their high liquidity and lower capital requirement, are a good option, especially for a beginner, says CAI HAOXIANG

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PROPERTY investing has always been popular in Asia and especially in land-scarce Singapore. The common conception of how one can invest in property is often limited to buying a Housing Board (HDB) resale flat or a private condominium.

For the beginner investor with limited capital, a condo unit might not be the best type of investment to start out with. The downpayment for a suburban condo is likely to be at least $150,000. One takes on substantial debt of up to 80 per cent of the value of the property. The private property market, too, is showing signs of a market top. Rental yields have fallen while prices have risen.

The government's cooling measures also mean that most young people will only own one investment property for some time. This makes diversification difficult, but putting all of your eggs in one basket is risky.

By contrast, the publicly traded equity market offers more options. Property development companies, which buy land, build units and sell them off, are one way to get exposed.

A relatively recent innovation in Singapore is the real estate investment trust (Reit). Investors can buy small ownership chunks of portfolios of shopping malls, office buildings or industrial factories and warehouses. For example, one lot of CapitaMall Trust (CMT), the oldest Reit and biggest in Singapore, goes for about $1,800.

The publicly traded Reit market has suffered considerably since last May. Prices for Singapore Reits have corrected by around 20 per cent since fears of rising interest rates left financial markets shaken. Reit prices may very well correct further, depending on how high interest rates go.

This article will touch on why people buy property and outline the characteristics of the investment class. It will also discuss how buying a residential unit differs from buying a Reit. A future piece will elaborate on Reits specifically, and how to value them.

Why buy property?

The reasons why people buy property in general also apply to Reits. There are four main reasons to buy any sort of property: diversification, capital appreciation, rental income and as a hedge against inflation.

Property prices do not move up and down together with other asset classes such as stocks or bonds. This means that if you hold property together with stocks, for example, the overall fluctuations of your portfolio are reduced. You can sleep soundly at night knowing that your net worth is unlikely to change much on a daily basis, compared to the return you can get.

Capital appreciation comes about because Singapore is a relatively land-scarce country. If demand for land outstrips supply, prices are likely to rise. In the last 10 years, average property prices have doubled. This works out to an average yield of more than 7 per cent a year.

Retirees also like to hold property because of the rental income they provide. HDB flats and condos can be leased out to tenants on a long-term basis of six months or more. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) guidelines also state that the maximum number of occupants in a residential unit is eight, no matter how big the unit is, and each occupant should have at least 10 square metres of space.

Finally, property is regarded as a way to protect against inflation, or rising prices. When prices in an economy go up, rents and property values might also go up.

Residential properties versus Reits

Similarly, the value of a Reit's properties has the potential to appreciate. The Reit can then choose to sell the property and buy another one with a greater potential for growth.

The rental income a Reit collects and distributes to unitholders can also increase over time. Here, a key statistic to look out for is a Reit's occupancy rate. If you have a condo with three bedrooms, you want to make sure that all three rooms are rented out. Similarly, because Reits own large properties such as shopping malls or office buildings, they have to maximise their rental income.

Because of the potential for both capital appreciation and a steady stream of rental income, properties and Reits in particular are said to take on the characteristics of both stocks and bonds. Reits have high liquidity as they are divided into many tiny units which are traded like stocks. They also have bond-like characteristics because of rental payments from tenants. Just as a bond promises its holder a fixed sum of income twice a year for say five to 10 years, tenants pay rentals every month, and sign long-term leases to do so. One way to value a Reit is therefore to calculate, in today's terms, a stream of projected rental payments going into the future.

The risk of a Reit is also somewhere between that of a stock and a bond. Bonds are thought of as low-risk, low-return investments, while stocks offer higher risk for higher returns. Because they take on the characteristics of both, Reit prices should theoretically not fluctuate as much as stocks and offer investors a decent yield. This might make them good diversifiers to a portfolio.

Both Reits and residential property have similar features which potential investors would do well to take note of.

One characteristic relates to the use of debt. Property buyers generally take out loans to finance their purchases. If they can borrow at a lower interest rate than the yield they generate on their property, they will make money. Interest rate increases eat into their profits if they have to refinance their loans at higher rates.

The higher one's borrowings and the more one pays in monthly mortgages relative to one's income, the riskier the investment is. If you cannot service the property mortgage payments for whatever reason, the bank that lent you the money will have the right to claim the property and sell it off, because the property was used as collateral for the mortgage. This legal process is known as foreclosure.

Property prices are affected by the general economy. If an economy slows down or goes into recession, leading to retrenchments, some people will not be able to service their monthly mortgage payments. They might then be forced to sell their properties at a discount to repay a portion of their loan to the bank. This is known as a distressed sale. If there are many distressed sellers in the market, property prices are likely to fall. Even those holding on to properties which they have already paid off will see the values of their homes plunge.

Credit rating

Similarly, Reits borrow from banks or private investors to finance their purchases. They can also go to equity holders, but the cost of doing so is typically higher. Reits can borrow up to 35 per cent of the value of their property, and go up to 60 per cent if they obtain and disclose a credit rating from Fitch, Moody's or Standard and Poor's.

Reits typically borrow through short-term loans of a few years, and roll over their debt after the loan period is up by getting a similar loan at the prevalent market rate. In the 2008-2009 global financial crisis, financial markets feared that an economic downturn would cause tenants to go out of business and default on their rental payments. If that happened, Reits would face lower income streams and would not be able to refinance their debts. Many Reits were thus trading at extremely low valuations as investors wondered if they would go bankrupt.

An investor should therefore scrutinise the debt levels of a Reit and ask if they are sustainable. Some Reits are better placed to weather market downturns than others. In a sustained economic downturn, people might still need to shop for necessities, so shopping mall Reits might still perform well. But an office Reit might not if enough businesses decide to close shop or move somewhere cheaper.

Illiquid property

Another major characteristic of property is that it tends to be illiquid. This means that property cannot be easily disposed of. This illiquidity is due to the complexity of most property transactions, as well as the large values involved. To sell a unit without making a loss, one has to find a buyer who can pay more than what one bought it for. This is a process that can take weeks or months. In a weak market, like now, it might be difficult for an average property to fetch a good price. Even if you lower the selling price of your condo, for example, it takes time for the buyer to evaluate whether the price is worth paying, relative to other options he or she has.

By comparison, Reits and stocks of large corporations can easily be sold on the public market at any point of the economic cycle, with brokers and traders standing ready to take a position. If one desperately needs the cash, one would find it easier to liquidate a Reit investment than a property. The underlying property might still be illiquid, but the Reit itself is not.

A final characteristic of property investments is the management and maintenance costs which are required. If you own a condo for investment, you have to spend time and money advertising or sourcing for tenants, negotiating rental contracts, collecting rental payments and fixing property defects. If the property you own is old, you might need to spend money to renovate it so it will be more attractive to tenants.

On the other hand, a Reit employs an agent to help it manage the property. This is advantageous in a way. You do not have to worry about ceiling leaks or ageing facilities at a mall or office property when you buy units in a Reit. A professional manager will do it for you. Of course, the fees they charge have to be reasonable and free of conflicts of interest. Fee structures are disclosed in the Reits's annual report. We will discuss this in a future article.

The best managers will be able to add value to their properties through asset enhancement initiatives, or AEI for short. They can, for example, improve the layout of a mall to increase shopper flow. They can change the tenant mix, taking out unprofitable shops. Profitable tenants mean that Reits have the leeway to increase rentals, for example. Mall managers can also subdivide their space more efficiently to maximise rentals - witness how common spaces in malls are being used for promotional events now.

In short, property investments are usually classified as alternative investments, as opposed to the traditional classes of stocks and bonds. They can take on the characteristics of a growth stock during certain times, and offer the steady income streams of a bond in others. Those who cannot afford a condo but still want an instrument that gives a stream of income can think about getting a Reit first.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore banks should gun for compliance advantage

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE banks need to look at compliance efforts as more than just a cost burden that needs to be fulfilled, and regard it as a competitive advantage. In particular, improving trade finance processes to close any money-laundering loopholes would enhance the Republic's reputation as the financial hub of Asia-Pacific.

Speaking to BizIT, Hugh Jones, CEO of Accuity, illustrated the current challenges banks and other financial institutions face in ensuring compliance for cross-border trade finance transactions. Accuity is a data solutions provider with a stable of 17,000 corporate clients, of which 60 per cent are banks and another 20 per cent are non-bank financial institutions such as insurance firms. It is part of the Reed Elsevier family of companies, having been acquired in 2011.

Companies are still reliant on paper-based processes when it comes to trade finance - and this hinders their efforts to monitor and detect potential money-laundering activities, Mr Jones noted. It is easy, for instance, to overlook a transaction when a company shipping hammers worth, say, US$5 each receives an invoice stating the price of each hammer as US$1,000 when records are all stored in paper form and automated analysis to flag a suspicious transaction is not available, he explained.

Citing findings from a white paper by Swift/Fung Institute, he noted how traditional trade finance is costly and inefficient. In Asia-Pacific alone, the annual cost of processing paper- based trade documents was US$138 billion in 2010, Mr Jones added.

Such money-laundering practices affect popular port cities like Singapore, in particular, given that it was the port of call for 139,417 vessels in 2013, according to the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore.

Tracking, monitoring and reporting all cross-border trade and its financing to ensure compliance on such a scale is a "trillion-dollar opportunity", and Accuity is at the forefront of providing tools such as Compliance Link to companies to do so, Mr Jones said.

Trade between China and Hong Kong alone accounted for US$155 billion of laundered money from 2012 to the first quarter of 2013, he added.

A separate report released last December by Global Financial Integrity, a Washington, DC-based research organisation, revealed Asia-Pacific accounted for three of the top five countries with the highest measured cumulative illicit financial outflows between 2002 and 2011. China topped the list with US$1.08 trillion, while Malaysia in fourth spot contributed US$370.38 billion and fifth-placed India accounted for US$343.93 billion, it stated.

Mr Jones pointed out that improving communication between the trade finance department and the bank's compliance unit would also go a long way in helping close the money-laundering gap in this area.

He said the compliance team already has processes in place to run transactions through the gamut of regulatory requirements, but they need to sieve through the various transactional details logged in by the trade finance team and this is a time-intensive exercise with room for oversight.

He said banks and other financial organisations don't have to commit heavy investments to overhaul existing IT systems to implement more sophisticated monitoring tools to combat money laundering.

"Banks already have the data; it's just in paper form. If they could leverage existing transaction databases, all they need to do is build in new workflows and processes to detect and act against suspicious transactions," he said, adding that this needed the cooperation between the trade finance and compliance teams who have to sit down and work on the required processes.

Henry Balani, MD at Accuity, added that it is a matter of emphasis by banks in Singapore to tackle trade-based money-laundering activities with technology. Instead of using big data innovations solely to gain insights on customers' spending behaviour, the same technology can be used to offer intelligence around suspicious transactions, he said.

The challenges to combating money-laundering activities by banks here were reiterated in the inaugural National Risk Assessment (NRA) report released by the Ministry of Home Affairs last month.

The report noted, for example, how full banks and qualifying full banks (QFBs) are exposed to the highest level of risk to money-laundering activities across the entire financial sector.

"These banks generally have a significant global presence and engage in activities such as trade finance, cash management services and correspondent banking. Transactions could include cross-border transactions with jurisdictions of higher money-laundering risks, where the banks have to put in place additional risk mitigation measures," it stated.

Asking prices for UK homes growing at fastest pace in six years

Listen to this article

Published Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] Asking prices for homes in Britain rose at the sharpest rate in more than six years over the past 12 months despite a big rise in new listings coming onto the market recently, property website Rightmove said yesterday.

Rightmove's February house price index showed the price of properties coming onto the market in the four weeks to Feb 8 was 6.9 per cent higher than a year earlier, the biggest increase since November 2007. January's index showed a 6.3 per cent rise.

"New sellers are now asking over £16,000 (S$33,670) more than those who came to market a year ago, a rate of increase not seen since before the credit crunch took hold in 2008," Rightmove director Miles Shipside said.

site_title: Brighter skies ahead for firms
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brighter skies ahead for firms

Survey findings predict S'pore Q1 GDP growth of 5.4-5.9 per cent

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Business sentiment has finally turned a corner: optimistic companies outnumber pessimistic ones for the first time in more than two years, says the latest BT-UniSIM Business Climate Survey report.

The quarterly survey, whose indicators have shown a strong correlation with GDP growth over its 19-year history, also predicts that the Singapore economy could grow as much as 5.9 per cent in the first quarter of this year.

Of the 147 companies that responded to the survey in late December and early January, 33 per cent said that they expect business prospects to improve in the first half of 2014.

Though business gloom has been receding since the final quarter of 2012, the group reporting "worse" or "much worse" business conditions has remained larger than its more positive peer group since Q2 2011.

That changed last quarter. Fewer than three in ten companies now expect a deterioration in business conditions over the next six months. The business prospects net balance - the difference between the proportion of sanguine and pessimistic responses - thus jumped 15 percentage points to 4 per cent.

This first positive showing in more than 30 months brings the BT-UniSIM survey report broadly in line with what the latest official business expectations surveys of manufacturing and services firms say.

For services firms, the outlook for January to June 2014 remains positive, even though the net weighted balance of one per cent fell from the 8 per cent reported the previous quarter.

And a net weighted balance of 4 per cent of manufacturers polled by the Economic Development Board (EDB) say things are looking up in the next six months - an improvement from the previous quarter's one per cent reading.

Business expectations aside, the three other indicators tracked by the BT-UniSIM survey - sales, profits and new orders - continued to point to contraction in Q4, but a smaller one.

"The stronger net balances in Q4 2013, and the turnaround in business prospects to optimistic sentiment, suggest that Q4 2013 could well be the end of the current contraction phase (as measured by the poll)," said survey director Chow Kit Boey.

However, she noted that respondents have not turned as bullish as they were in Q4 2009, which was when the last contraction phase ended. Then, the business prospects net balance was a resoundingly confident 45 per cent.

"Optimism on business prospects is more subdued . . . This is probably due mainly to weaker growth in China and Singapore's steeper increases in business cost," said Ms Chow.

Even so, the turnaround in business sentiment bodes well for the wider economy. The report's various net balances, which bear a close correlation to year-on-year GDP growth in the following quarter, now predict that the Singapore economy will grow 5.4-5.9 per cent in Q1 2014.

That prediction is based on the official flash estimate of 4.4 per cent GDP growth in the final quarter of 2014.

Economists polled by Bloomberg say that the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) may revise this upwards, to 4.9 per cent, when it releases final growth figures on Thursday. This looks likely, after a surprising surge in December's industrial production.

The economists are projecting even stronger Q1 growth than the survey does, too: the median of seven banks' forecasts was 6.2 per cent.

Of the five broad sectors poll respondents fall into, those in the business of transport & communications had the best showing this round, with the strongest expansion in Q4 sales and profits, as well as the brightest business prospects for the six months ahead.

Manufacturing came in second best, topping the charts for new orders or business in Q4. More small and foreign manufacturers have also seen improvements in sales and profits.

Economists think manufacturing growth will continue to pick up. "Cyclically, we think the strengthening US economy will have positive spillovers to Singapore's manufacturing sector - in particular, the electronics industry," said Barclays economist Joey Chew.

However, she and others have noted that the US rebound's impact on the local economy may be crimped by Singapore's ongoing economic restructuring efforts.

Challenges that local enterprises face as a result of restructuring include "a decline in cost-competitiveness, the hollowing out of some production capacity, and increasingly binding resource constraints", including the tighter supply of labour, Ms Chew said.

site_title: Konica Minolta starts innovation centre in S'pore
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Konica Minolta starts innovation centre in S'pore

New enterprise-focused centre will be its Asia-Pacific HQ as company moves towards being an IT services provider

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

JAPANESE printing giant Konica Minolta is transforming itself from a traditional printer manufacturer to an IT services provider, and its first step in that direction was to set up an enterprise-focused "business innovation centre" in Singapore last week.

The company's plan is to eventually have five new such centres set up in distinct locations globally: Singapore, London, Silicon Valley, Shanghai and Tokyo. Singapore is intended as its Asia-Pacific headquarters, London will represent Europe and Silicon Valley for the Americas.

The facilities are funded by the company's R&D (research and development) efforts, and are intended to complement its research department by partnering industry players and tertiary institutions. The company couldn't specify how much of its revenue or R&D budget will go to the centres.

Konica Minolta's R&D offices in Japan and the US focus on technology research areas such as imaging, optics, materials and nano-fabrication, but the business innovation centres signal the company's new push into enterprise services.

The company is in the midst of a pivotal shift in the printing industry. Since the turn of the century, Japanese companies such as Konica Minolta, Fuji Xerox and Canon have wrested the multi-billion dollar printing market from US companies like Olivetti and Compuprint.

Today, Japan's vendors still play a huge part in the printing market, but increasing pressure from vendors outside continue to mount. Korean giant Samsung, for example, has released mobile printing apps that sync with its smartphones, allowing it to use its smartphone portfolio to make a bigger impact on the market.

Konica Minolta understands this pressure and is making a concerted effort away from the consumer market and deeper into the enterprise space.

Speaking at the launch of the facility, Masatoshi Matsuzaki, president and CEO of Konica Minolta, said that the five locations were chosen because they are intended to help the company get closer to enterprise clients in each geography. "We need to customise the (services) we come up with to fit each region's demands as closely as possible," he said.

He noted that 65 per cent of the company's printer sales in the US were driven by the IT services that it has been able to offer together with its printing hardware. For its next boost, the company intends to push harder into the Asia-Pacific region.

In a late-2013 interview, Jun Haraguchi, senior executive officer at Konica Minolta, said that the company is keen to grow the revenue contribution from Asia outside Japan from 10 per cent to 20 per cent in the next five years. Mr Haraguchi said that western countries are growing at a far smaller rate compared with Asia, driven by emerging markets in the latter region.

Globally, 72 per cent of Konica Minolta's US$10 billion revenue in 2012 came from its business technologies services, while 18 per cent came from industry business. Healthcare is one of the biggest standalone verticals, at 9 per cent contribution to its revenue, according to Mr Matsuzaki.

"We are trying to shift from being a hardware player to a services provider. We hope the business innovation centres will accelerate this," the CEO noted.

He said that Singapore was chosen as the Asia-Pacific centre because the company has ties with research institutions such as A*Star's (Agency for Science, Technology and Research) I2R (Institute of Infocomm Research) arm. It plans to extend its industry collaboration to start-ups and independent software vendors in the country, as well.

Yuji Ichimura, Konica Minolta's head of the IT service business, said that each centre will be rolled out with a staff of about 10, noting that Singapore has eight people now. The heads of the innovation centres for Silicon Valley and London have already been hired, and former NCS executive Rachel Goh will helm the Singapore facility.

Singapore will begin its research efforts with cloud-based service offerings, with the goal of developing more printing and document management services based on connected devices. The company explained that some of its enterprise clients have been pressing for cloud-based printing but need the vendor offerings to be based on tighter security restrictions. For example, companies may want to connect its mobile devices to office printer, but need to cordon the printers off within a private network in order to reduce the likelihood of third parties sniffing private documents, said David Kwok, principal architect at Konica Minolta.

One of Konica Minolta's clients, Kyoto University Hospital, recently implemented a setup like this. It had a set of printers on an Intranet network, but wanted them to connect with staff laptops which are connected to the public Internet. It eventually chose a private printing network tying the laptops and printers together, but allowed laptops to stay connected to the public network, so that staff would not have their Internet services restricted, said Mr Kwok.

site_title: Trades by company directors dive
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Trades by company directors dive

Significant buybacks seen in Keppel Land, Bionsensors, Cordlife Group and a rare insider buy in Suntec Reit, reports ROBERT HALILI

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

TRADING by company directors plunged in the past week, based on filings on the Singapore Exchange from Feb 10 to 14. Five companies posted 18 purchases worth $2.86 million, against one with five disposals worth $0.49 million. The figures were sharply down from the previous week's 14 companies, 36 purchases, and $6.85 million and two firms, 14 disposals, and $1.83 million. This was likely due to the busy reporting season as directors are prohibited from trading in their companies' shares one month prior to the announcement of results.

Trading by others last week saw five companies recording seven repurchases worth $1.13 million. The figures, however, were sharply up from the previous week's two firms, two trades, and $0.697 million.

Despite the low activity, there were several significant corporate shareholder purchases last week with buybacks in Keppel Land, Bionsensors International, and Cordlife Group and a rare insider buy in Suntec Reit. On the institutional front, there were rare fund manager sales in Dukang Distillers, Raffles Medical Group, and Keppel Corporation.

Keppel Land

Property developer Keppel Land recorded its first repurchase since buybacks were introduced by the Exchange in June 1999 with 130,000 shares purchased on Feb 14 at $3.21 each.

The trade was made on the back of the 14 per cent drop in the share price since October 2013 from $3.73. The counter was also down since January 2013 from $4.31. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since December 2011 from $2.22.

The company announced on Jan 22 a 7.1 per cent gain in fourth quarter profit to $584.435 million, while earnings for the full year rose by 4.5 per cent to $903.954 million. The stock closed at $3.21 on Friday.

Biosensors International Group

Medical devices developer and manufacturer Biosensors International picked up where it left off in January with 300,000 shares purchased on Feb 14 at 87 cents each.

The buyback was made after the company announced on Feb 12 a 55 per cent drop in third quarter profit to US$11.125 million. Earnings in the first nine months fell by 60 per cent to US$34.48 million. The group previously acquired 6.4 million shares from Dec 30, 2013 to Jan 8 at an average of 84 cents each, 21.017 million shares from Aug 12 to Oct 7, 2013 at 84 cents to 97 cents each or an average of 88 cents each and 12.75 million shares from April 19 to June 17, 2013 at an average of $1.16 each. Prior to the repurchases since April 2013, the company acquired 19.77 million shares from November to December 2012 at an average of $1.11 each. The counter closed at 87 cents on Friday.

Cordlife Group

Private cord blood banking services provider Cordlife Group bought back for the first time since November 2012 with 360,000 shares purchased from Feb 12 to 14 at an average of $1.19 each.

The trades, which accounted for 11 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made on the back of the 16 per cent drop in the share price since September 2013 from $1.42. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since March 2013 from 62 cents.

The acquisitions were also made after the company announced on Feb 11 a 25 per cent drop in second quarter profit to $4.232 million. Earnings in the first half, however, rose by 52.9 per cent to $12.9 million. The group previously acquired 200,000 shares on Nov 21, 2012 at 51.5 cents each.

Also positive this quarter are non-executive director Jin Lu, chairman Ho Choon Hou and FIL Limited. Non-executive director Jin Lu purchased 100,000 shares from Jan 14 to 17 at an average of $1.22 each, which increased her direct holdings by 15 per cent to 750,000 shares or 0.28 per cent of the issued capital. She previously sold one million shares in May 2013 at $1.02 each. Chairman Ho Choon Hou, on the other hand, acquired 60,000 shares on Jan 2 at $1.20 each, which boosted his direct stake by 10 per cent to 684,000 shares or 0.26 per cent. The chairman previously acquired 35,000 shares in October 2012 at 58 cents each.

Lastly, FIL Ltd reported a purchase-related filing on Jan 7 of 210,000 shares at $1.18 each, which increased its deemed holdings to 24.183 million shares or 9.05 per cent. The group previously sold 69,000 shares on Oct 23, 2013 at $1.00 each. Prior to that sale, the shareholder acquired a net 9.87 million shares from July 2 to Oct 9, 2013 at $1.06 to $1.34 each. Overall, FIL's stake is up by 59 per cent since July 2013. The stock closed at $1.18 on Friday.

Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust

Director Lim Hwee Chiang recorded his first on-market buys in real estate investment trust Suntec Reit since the unit trust was listed in December 2004 with an initial 1.000 million units (direct interest) purchased from Jan 27 to 28 at an average of $1.60 each. The holdings represent 0.04 per cent of the issued capital. The purchases were made on the back of the 7 per cent rebound in the unit price since December 2013 from $1.49. Despite the rebound in the unit price, the counter is still down since October 2013 from $1.74.

This recent purchase was very unusual as Mr Lim was a heavy seller from 2005 to 2013 with a whopping 70.86 million units sold worth $97 million at $1.15 to $1.85 each or an average of $1.37 each.

Investors should note that there were purchases by directors Vincent Chen Wei Ching and Yeo See Kiat in December 2013. Vincent Chen purchased 60,000 units on Dec 19, 2013 at $1.50 each, which increased his direct holdings by 20 per cent to 360,000 units or 0.02 per cent. He previously acquired 50,000 units in August 2013 at $1.53 each and 50,000 units in July 2013 at an average of $1.58 each.

Yeo See Kiat, on the other hand, acquired 200,000 units on Dec 17, 2013 at $1.50 each, which boosted his direct stake by 62 per cent to 525,000 units or 0.02 per cent. He also has deemed interest of 450,000 units or 0.02 per cent. He previously acquired 100,000 units on Nov 22, 2013 at $1.555 each and 100,000 units in May 2013 at $1.81 each. The unit trust closed at $1.64 on Friday.

Dukang Distillers Holdings

FIL Limited recorded its first sale in baijiu products manufacturer and distributor Dukang Distillers Holdings since it became a substantial shareholder in August 2013 with a disposal-related filing on Feb 11 of 361,000 shares at 22 cents each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 55.861 million shares or 6.99 per cent of the issued capital.

The filing was made on the back of the 49 per cent drop in the share price since November 2013 from 43.5 cents. The sale was also made three days before Dukang Distillers announced 93 per cent drop in second quarter profit to 10.039 million yuan. Earnings in the first half fell by 80.5 per cent to 40.493 million yuan.

FIL Ltd previously acquired 16.7 million shares from Aug 30 to Oct 8, 2013 at 42 cents to 46 cents each and an initial filing on Aug 29, 2013 of 1.049 million shares at 43 cents each, which raised its interest to 5.12 per cent. The counter closed at 21.5 cents on Friday.

Raffles Medical Group

Aberdeen Asset Management Asia Limited recorded its first sale in private integrated healthcare provider Raffles Medical Group since it became a substantial shareholder in November 2012 with a disposal-related filing on Feb 7 of 240,000 shares at $3.05 each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 38.722 million shares or 6.99 per cent of the issued capital. The filing was made on the back of the 11 per cent drop in the share price since the last week of April 2013 from $3.44.

The group previously reported a purchase-related filing in April 2013 of 325,000 shares at $3.31 each, a purchase-related filing in February 2013 of 195,000 shares at $3.20 each and an initial filing in November 2012 of 159,000 shares at $2.42 each, which raised its interest to 5.0 per cent. The stock closed at $3.17 on Friday.

Keppel Corporation

Aberdeen Asset Management Plc recorded its first sale in shipping, property, and infrastructure firm Keppel Corporation since it became a substantial shareholder in January 2013 with a disposal-related filing on Feb 10 of 1.18 million shares at $10.32 each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 107.705 million shares or 5.95 per cent. The filing was made on the back of the 9 per cent drop in the share price since December 2013 from $11.33.

The group previously reported a purchase-related filing in August 2013 of 90,000 shares at $10.31 each and an initial filing in January 2013 of 438,000 shares at $11.16 each, which raised its interest to 5.02 per cent.

Investors should note that executive director Tong Chong Heong unloaded 50,000 shares in November 2013 at $11.30 each, which lowered his direct stake to 2.465 million shares or 0.14 per cent. He previously sold 150,000 shares from March to April 2011 at an average of $12.33 each. The stock closed at $10.43 on Friday.

site_title: Risk of too quick a global rebound
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Risk of too quick a global rebound

Rate hikes will then take place earlier and all assets will be hit: HSBC manager

Published

Mon, Feb 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHILE the global economy appears to be recovering, one tail risk that HSBC multi-asset fund manager Denis Gould is concerned with is what happens if global growth becomes too strong.

In such an environment, interest rate hikes will take place earlier than expected as governments move to prevent prices from spiralling out of control. Financial markets are likely to experience a repeat of what happened last May and June, after then-Fed chairman Ben Bernanke said the US will soon slow down its bond purchases.

"Everything was hit. Everything fell, (equities), government bonds, corporate bonds. As a multi-asset manager, that's the worst environment," said Mr Gould, who is chief investment officer for Hong Kong Multi-Asset and Wealth and advises pension and insurance funds.

Growth "feeds on itself" and investors might start to worry about inflation again, given that a large pool of money is in the financial system after many years of loose monetary conditions.

"You throw all that new money into the system, more money should devalue money. That hasn't happened because the structure of the global economy is weak, there's excess global capacity. But if the capacity gets worked out, it could be less than we think.

"In that environment, cash is king. That's the only time you want cash, if you're quite confident that everything else will produce a negative return," he said.

But Mr Gould said the situation of strong global growth causing increases in interest rate is his least expected scenario, one he assigned a 15 per cent chance of happening.

The base case, which he assigned a two-thirds probability to, is that of "steady, unspectacular growth" and minimal inflation - the consensus view. In this scenario, equities will do well, followed by corporate bonds.

The final possibility, with a 20 per cent chance, is that the recovery falters and interest rates stay low. This can happen with a scheduled consumption tax hike in Japan, or when slowing China growth causes the global recovery to stall. In such a scenario, investors should hold long-dated government bonds and corporate bonds, he said.

Currently, he is "overweight equities, overweight corporate bonds, just moving shorter in duration, building up cash - we would sell 10-year Treasuries below 2.7 per cent, and be buyers at 3-plus". The yield for 10-year Treasuries was 2.58 per cent last week and 2.86 per cent last month.

Mr Gould also commented on the recent market wobble, when a confluence of China financial sector worries, slowing growth, US tapering bond purchases and disparate emerging market worries conspired to cause a 5 to 10 per cent correction in global markets.

The major reason for Asia's underperformance is concerns over shadow banking in China, he noted, pointing to the near-default of a wealth management product that had raised funds for a failed coal miner. His clients in Hong Kong are worried, he said.

"There's a lot of bad debt and unproductive investments in the Chinese financial system. The big concern is that this will somehow unwind in a disorderly fashion."

Mr Gould believes the situation can be managed by the Chinese government, and losses shared by the state-owned Chinese banks. Even so, investors in China will have the fear of a financial market collapse hanging over them for a long time to come, he said.

"The lack of trust and corporate governance issues will keep China cheap, and the sense of credit losses will continue to constrain it," he said.

Mr Gould, who picks stocks based on their fundamentals, reckons that opportunities abound in Asia. South Korea is among his favourites because of its low valuations and cyclical stocks that will benefit from a global recovery. However, he is unimpressed by Japan - a favourite of analysts - because he thinks profits will not be delivered.

"If the Japanese economy fades and Abenomics (the economic policies of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe) is suddenly thought to be a failure, the downside in Japan is pretty big because it just had a very large jump."

site_title: A question of pay
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A question of pay

How to put a check on high exec salary is a question being asked today amid the debate about the growing CEO-to-worker pay ratio, says ADRIAN CHAN

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE compensation of top executives has often come in for scrutiny and with it, the role of the board and shareholders in determining such pay.

In a Business Times report on Sept 10, 2013, the total remuneration of the top five chief executives in Singapore was found to be more than $44 million, an average of $8.8 million per CEO. In contrast, these five listed companies have a total of 38 other non-executive directors whose combined directors' fees approved at annual general meetings was under $7 million, or an average of about $180,000 per director.

It may appear ironic that the relatively small sums of the non-executive directors' fees are subject to shareholder approval at each AGM, while the much larger sums paid to the CEOs are not. In reality, executive compensation is determined by the non-executive directors forming the Remuneration Committee of the listed company.

Since the global financial crisis, income inequality and executive compensation has become a flashpoint. In particular, the ratio of the pay of the top executive to the average worker has been seized upon to illustrate how outrageous it has become.

According to the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the top US CEO pay relative to the pay of the average worker has widened from 42 times in 1982 to 353 times in 2012. In response to the groundswell of protests, the Sarbanes-Oxley and the Dodd-Frank Acts laid out some rules requiring new reporting procedures and increasing the extent to which directors can be held to be personally liable for pay excesses.

In Switzerland last year, voters backed the "against corporate rip-offs" referendum. Swiss lawmakers now have to draft a law giving shareholders the right to hold a binding vote on all compensation for company executives and directors.

In Singapore, the CEO-to-worker pay ratio has also been growing but has not yet reached the US level. A Business Times study put the average CEO-to-employee pay ratio at 122 times based on the six largest listed companies in 2010.

The question increasingly being asked is: How and who should put a check on high executive compensation?

The current legal position is that directors' fees are subject to shareholders' approval, while executive pay is subject to directors' approval.

That's how companies are constituted and governed. Shareholders elect the directors and agree to their fees. The directors have the power and responsibility to manage the affairs of the company, including hiring, firing and compensating the management team.

An executive director, meanwhile, wears an additional hat as an employee of the company. Employment terms are contractual matters between the employee and the company, which are matters under the purview of the board.

As such, if enough shareholders are unhappy with the performance of the board, they can (in extreme cases) remove the whole board, but they cannot remove the CEO or management of the company or determine how much to pay them. Only the board has that power.

In its recent review of the Companies Act, the Steering Committee appointed by the Minister of Finance had the opportunity to change this position. However, for better or worse, the decision was made to retain the distinction between the powers of shareholders and that of the board.

There are good reasons to retain this separation of powers. Directors have a fiduciary duty to make decisions in the long-term interests of the company. Shareholders owe no such duty.

There is increasing evidence that, generally, the outlook of shareholders are short-term in nature. It is not uncommon to see shareholders attempting to hold listed companies to ransom out of their own self-interest, say, by demanding more dividends, without considering the broader and long-term cash-flow needs and other issues facing the company.

However, giving the board unfettered power to decide on executive pay may lead to the negative trends on executive pay seen in the US and Europe. Current regulations in Singapore primarily emphasise disclosure. For example, Guideline 9.2 of the 2012 Code of Corporate Governance states that "the company should fully disclose the remuneration of each individual director and the CEO on a named basis".

A step further is to get shareholders' feedback through a non-binding vote to approve executive pay packages at the general meeting. This is being legislated in a growing number of countries including Germany, Australia, the UK and the US. The aim is that the vote will be a highly influential signal to a board to not raise salaries beyond reasonable levels.

While such "say on pay" legislation has not yet arrived in Singapore, it pays for boards to be sensitive to the current environment of perceived inequality and to increase the level of monitoring and oversight on executive remuneration. And ultimately, it is the shareholders who will decide how they want to hold the board they appoint accountable.

The writer is the first vice-chairman of the Singapore Institute of Directors

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IP reliance signals need for intelligent network security

Palo Alto Networks' tool will detect, prevent, provide remediation in an attack

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE has been at the forefront in encouraging businesses here to leverage the pervasive Internet connectivity to increase productivity and innovate new ways of working. But the increased reliance on Internet Protocol-based applications and processes means widening corporations' threat surface, and Palo Alto Networks believes this migration emphasises the need for more intelligent, proactive network security software.

According to Sharat Sinha, Asia-Pacific VP at Palo Alto Networks, this year will see a heightened need for more intelligent network security software. In this new era of securing the Internet gateways, such software will require more automated processes and in-built intelligence in order to "detect, prevent and provide remediation" should there be an attack on an organisation's network, he stated.

"This is especially important in industries such as government, education and healthcare, in which there are staffing shortages. Limited staff need maximum resources including security tools that give them the most visibility into their network traffic (yet) don't sacrifice business productivity," Mr Sinha said.

He noted that legacy security tools such as firewalls are no longer sufficient in capabilities and scale. Elaborating, the executive told BizIT that one such limitation of legacy tools is how its main focus is on detection while preventive capabilities are mostly manual. This means should an attack be detected on the network, internal IT staff will have to manually react and fend off the threat and this might not be possible if it was a large-scale attack.

Another limitation is in intelligence sharing. He observed that the sharing of information regarding potential malware attacks is not possible with legacy software, whereas products such as Palo Alto Networks' WildFire tool is cloud-based and offer real-time updates to all customers in its network.

"When an unknown malware is detected, our system immediately assigns a signature to it and releases the information to the cloud and all of our customers in the network," the executive explained.

Mr Sinha pointed to one local example that illustrated the inefficacy of legacy network security products. The unnamed conglomerate, which has businesses in steel and chemicals among others, was using outmoded firewalls and endpoint security software, which resulted in some trusted machines getting compromised. This, in turn, brought down its network for a significant period of time and proved costly for the organisation, he said.

While Mr Sinha did not know the exact nature of the attack, the Palo Alto executive said firewalls tend to protect the network via ports but not the actual application. So if the malware was piggybacking an existing application through the port, it would have not been stopped. This, he said, was just one of the many possible ways to penetrate the conglomerate's inadequate network security measures.

Since migrating to the company's WildFire product, the conglomerate has yet to face similar downtimes, according to him.

Mr Sinha believes more corporate organisations would be looking to upgrade their existing network security regime. This is because aside from tech-savvy industries such as financial services and government, others such as retail, healthcare, higher education and hospitality will face increased attention from hackers as they leverage more on IT to boost productivity.

For example, he said, the retail industry is huge in Singapore and contributes significantly to the nation's gross domestic product. However, companies face the same challenge as those faced by giant US retailer Target, which revealed its point-of-sale (POS) terminals infected with a malware designed to bypass PCI DSS encryption methods to steal customers' payment data.

Target first revealed last December that 40 million consumers were affected in the leak of payment card details, as well as other personal information such as mailing and e-mail addresses, following the POS system breach. It has since updated the figure to up to 70 million consumers in January this year.

Given that POS terminals are all linked to the network, the threat - whether in the US or Singapore - is relevant to all retailers, Mr Sinha said.

To better combat network security breaches, he advised companies to first look at their internal processes to determine what are the business-critical applications used. Once done, they should create network segmentation by which only employees who need to access such data can access it over the network.

This "zero-trust" network will detect and analyse every data transaction sent through the corporate network, which is a deeper inspection than those provided by firewalls that look only at ports and proxies, Mr Sinha said.

"Segmenting the network not only helps with detection of malware, it also helps localise the threat when it happens, find and fix the source of problem, and lower the chance of the same attack happening again," he said.

site_title: Acronis co-founder returns to storage
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Acronis co-founder returns to storage

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE business of storage and back-up software isn't the sexiest, Acronis CEO Serguei Beloussov admits. But having found success in the IT industry, the Russian entrepreneur is betting on storage's upward track, and returned to the company he co-founded after being away for eight years.

Mr Beloussov was last CEO at Acronis in 2007. At the time, the company was turning over US$150 million in revenue annually, when he decided to focus on Acronis's sister company, virtualisation software vendor Parallels. Parallels and Acronis were born in 2003, when SWsoft, founded by Mr Beloussov in 1997, split into two separate businesses.

He explained his departure: "I had a disagreement with a professional board member that we hired to run (Acronis), so I disengaged."

That year, Parallels had about 900 staff, and counted among enterprise clients large firms such as KDDI and StarHub.

Mr Beloussov is still the largest shareholder at Parallels, with a 50 per cent stake in the private company. In May last year, he decided to leave his role as its CEO, returning to Acronis at the helm.

"I'm back because of the opportunity in storage. I've built eight companies over the years, but none of them have hit US$1 billion in revenue yet. Acronis is my chance," he said.

He's eyeing the fast-growing storage and back-up industry which is expected to hit US$30 billion in sales by 2016. "The growing need for storage is inevitable," Mr Berloussov. This is being prompted by larger industry trends like the Internet of Things (IoT) and the constant generation of media from consumers and enterprise users.

IoT is a catchphrase describing a network of connected devices outside traditional computing gadgets. This includes smart fridges, or wearable technology that incorporate sensors to track data and connects to the Internet to communicate with other devices. Gartner predicts that as the cost of components go down and more manufacturers pack connectivity into their products, the IoT will grow to 26 billion units installed in 2020 - nearly 30 times the 900 million in 2009. This will translate to a US$300 billion market for the IoT's product and service suppliers, with services taking the lion's share of that pie in 2020.

The IoT will also exceed the number of "traditional" devices - smartphones, tablets and PCs - in 2020, which will reach 7.3 billion units.

Mr Beloussov said that his first task last year was to restore the "original DNA" at Acronis, refocusing on technology innovation. "I felt it was time to polish our technology, to make it faster and better," he said.

Acronis has two research labs globally, in the US and Russia. In Singapore, the company is collaborating with A*Star's (Agency for Science, Technology and Research) DSI (Data Storage Institute) arm to further research on storage technology.

"With them, we're looking to polish our cloud and mobility access products," he said.

Acronis is looking to roll out an enterprise-focused cloud service for Asia in the later part of the third quarter of this year, after it partners with a data centre provider to establish physical storage here.

With data sovereignty a sticky issue for many enterprises, situating a cloud data centre here is necessary if the company wants to attract corporate clients in Singapore. Currently, it has data centres in Europe and the US, where its enterprise customers there and global consumer data is being stored.

Mr Beloussov said that the company's cloud business now contributes about 10-15 per cent of revenue and this is growing quickly and is on track to cross the 20 per cent mark next year.

He is certain the company's next phase of growth will come from Asia. "Historically, we didn't focus much on the region - well, I did, but our American managers didn't. Now, I'm back and I'm re-focusing on the largest and fastest moving market," he said.

A third of Acronis's business comes from Asia - unusual for a global software firm, where Asia typically contributes about 10 per cent, he noted. The company's largest market in the region here is Japan, and he hopes to eventually move Acronis's global headquarters to Singapore within the next five years.

Mr Beloussov came to Singapore in 1994, after co-founding a PC start-up in Russia called Falcon Computers. He later started a company called Solomon Software in 1996, and took up Singapore citizenship in 2001.

Branson sounds warning over Qantas intervention

'Business people worldwide should think twice about investing in Australia'

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] British tycoon Richard Branson warned - in full-page newspaper ads yesterday - against possible Australian government help for national carrier Qantas, urging business to "think twice" about investing in the country.

Mr Branson, whose Virgin Australia carrier is in direct competition with Qantas, lashed out at the conservative government in an open letter to the Australian public published in yesterday's newspapers.

Qantas has been lobbying the government to ease limits on foreign investment or provide state intervention to help shore up its bottom line as it battles record fuel costs and fierce competition from subsidised rivals.

The Australian carrier claims a 49 per cent foreign ownership cap under the terms of its privatisation in 1995 leaves it at an unfair disadvantage to Virgin, which is majority-owned by state-backed Singapore Airlines, Air New Zealand and Etihad.

Australian Treasurer Joe Hockey last week described the cap as a "ball and chain around the leg" of Qantas, which he said was now confronting a "3,000-pound gorilla" - widely interpreted as a reference to Virgin. Mr Branson hit back, saying the description "would be flattering if it was not so laughable" and asking what that made Qantas, "which is four times our size". "Should the Australian taxpayer be forced by the government to prop up the Qantas group as Treasurer Joe Hockey is suggesting, business people worldwide should think twice about investing in Australia for fear of such intervention in their sectors," he said.

"Qantas has gone cap in hand to the government. If the government fills their hat, it will severely damage competition in Australia."

Last December, Qantas said it was facing some of its toughest-ever challenges as it flagged a half-year loss of up to A$300 million (S$341 million) and the axing of 1,000 jobs. It reports its interim first- half results later this month.

Mr Branson said Qantas already received most government travel spending and "should not be granted further special privileges over all its competitors", noting that until Virgin arrived on the scene in 2000, Qantas "enjoyed a virtual monopoly in most parts of the Australian market".

The Virgin founder said he did not care what the government did with the Qantas foreign ownership cap. "What is most important is that the government doesn't provide financial assistance to Qantas, enabling it to reinstate its monopoly. It's not right for the industry and won't benefit the Australian travelling public or economy." - AFP

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hair-raising affair

Despite the unstable economy, demand for hair-restoration procedures is on the rise. By Cheah Ui-Hoon

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE unstable economy of the last couple of years may have made people pull back on their spending - but it hasn't stopped balding men from ponying up for hair transplants. In fact, the demand for this procedure is growing, says last year's practice census of the International Society of Hair Restoration Surgery.

Between 2010 and 2012, the number of surgical hair-restoration procedures grew 10 per cent. The region where the highest number of such procedures were done? Asia, with 102,702 procedures in 2012.

Most of the patients - 86.3 per cent - were men, and more than half were aged 30 to 49. Chow Yuen Ho of TCS Aesthetics Central Clinic Robotic Hair Restoration service says that the rising numbers come on the back of improvements in technology that have minimised scarring, shortened recovery and downtime.

ARTAS robotic hair restoration makes use of digital imaging and precision robotics to scan and grade each hair so that the healthiest - and best-placed - hairs are harvested for transplant to balding areas.

Dr Chow, who has more than 10 years of clinical experience and a special interest in aesthetic dermatological procedures and lasers, says: "Optimal spacing is maintained between each hair, preserving the natural look of the donor area. Unlike older transplant methods, no stitches are required, and therefore, there's no risk of a visible linear scar."

The traditional method of hair restoration, called Follicular Unit Transplantation (FUT), is more invasive. It entails the surgical removal of a piece of scalp from the back and sides of the head, and the use of stitches or staples to close the wound. The strip of scalp is then handed to a group of technicians, who then manually separate the individual follicular units. These dissected follicular units are then transplanted onto the balding areas of the scalp by the surgical team.

A recovery period of several weeks would typically follow, and patients may suffer numbness, scalp tightness or lingering pain after that.

And then there is also the obvious linear scar and hairstyle limitations to contend with, adds Dr Chow.

Hair transplants are the only permanent solution to hair loss, he adds. Pills and creams may slow hair loss with continual use, but once these are stopped, their benefits stop as well.

Dr Chow says that the average person sheds between 50 and 100 hairs a day - a drop in the ocean, considering there are roughly 100,000 hairs on one's head.

It may be a first sign of hair loss, however, if one notices a significant amount of hair left behind on comb, pillow or shower stall grating.

In more than 95 per cent of cases, hair thinning in men is caused by androgenic alopecia, or male pattern baldness. This is a common hereditary condition resulting in hair follicles at the top and front of the head becoming sensitive to the hormone dihydrotestosterone (DHT). The hair in those regions becomes thinner over time. Eventually, the follicle becomes dormant.

Healthy hair follicles resistant to DHT are usually on the sides and back of the head, but these may even get weaker and finer in time, says Dr Chow.

He likens the cutting-edge ARTAS approach to a normal visit to the dentist - just more pleasant.

A local anaesthetic is administered so the patient stays awake through the procedure; he may even want to listen to music or watch a movie or take scheduled breaks during the procedure.

Before it, the physician would have developed a treatment plan based on goals, hair type and personal characteristics.

"During your procedure, the physician will transplant each hair individually. For most procedures, a new hairline is created and thinning interior areas are filled in," he says.

The transplanted hair, which is unaffected by the DHT hormone, takes root in a few weeks and grows. Patients see significant growth after about six months.

The cost of treatment depends on the amount of new hair desired, and will generally start from a ballpark figure of $5,500.

site_title: Going big in China
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Going big in China

Q&M's new China strategy is to acquire dental hospitals instead of clinics, reports CAI HAOXIANG

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE'S largest private dental chain Q&M Dental Group is going places in China after signing four memorandums of understanding (MOUs) in the last seven months and a major deal last Tuesday.

The deals, which include profit guarantees, cost almost $50 million and see Q&M acquiring stakes in six dental hospitals as well as the maker of a promising specialist dental material. The China assets will eventually be listed in an initial public offering in Hong Kong or Singapore that might be larger than Q&M's own market value here.

"Because of these four projects we have created a lot of interest in the Chinese dental market. More and more people have come to talk to us about deals and funding," CEO Ng Chin Siau told The Business Times in a recent interview.

The broking community is also sitting up. Maybank Kim Eng Research initiated coverage on the company last October with a "buy" call and a target price of 41 cents, calling it the "rarest gem in global dentistry". It raised its target price to 48 cents last Thursday. The same day, Voyage Research's deputy head of research, Ng Kian Teck, who has covered the company since 2010, also raised his intrinsic value of the company to 57.5 cents.

In its initiation report last year, Maybank Kim Eng said that Q&M is "the best-performing by margins, ROE (returns on equity) and growth in a sector where only four listed peers can be found (and) the cheapest. This scarcity value and strong balance sheet makes Q&M itself ripe for acquisition."

What made analysts excited were the chain's growth prospects in the untapped private dental market in China, where disposable incomes are growing, public hospitals tend to be overcrowded and smaller clinics unpopular. Q&M already has a steadily growing business at home with 57 dental clinics, a database of 600,000 patients and 6,000 to 9,000 new walk-ins a month.

"How big can we grow? The sky is the limit. We are already the largest dental player in the Asean region and the only company that is listed," Dr Ng says.

Going forward, Q&M will focus on growing outside Singapore, and especially in China. "Singapore only has a population of 5.3 million. Malaysia has 28 million, Indonesia 250 million, and China, 1.3 billion. China has more than 100 cities of more than one million people," he notes.

The Chinese government is also liberalising the medical healthcare sector there, with rules put in place that allow foreigners to own 100 per cent of companies there.

"I only have six dental hospitals. but there are 1,000 dental hospitals in China. There are 136,000 dentists in China, I'm only having 200. When I have 1,000 dentists there I'll be the single largest dental operation in China."

The strategy of acquiring dental hospitals in China is a lesson well learnt after four years of failing to gain traction with smaller clinics. Q&M began acquiring dental clinics from 2010, starting in Beijing and Nanjing. This eventually expanded to 10 clinics currently, with four in Beijing, four in Nanjing and two in Shanghai. But the clinics struggled to attract patients. "It took us a long time to understand that in China, people don't trust dental clinics," Dr Ng says.

In private dental clinics, patients could not swipe their state medical insurance card, or yibaoka, to get subsidies from the government. Some 80 to 90 per cent of the Chinese population have this card. "Yibao is a deep-rooted concept, where all patients go to hospitals when they have a problem," Dr Ng says.

Patients also try to bargain down prices at smaller clinics, which they do not do at hospitals. The insurance card can be used at approved dental hospitals, even private ones. These private hospitals are run by people with good relationships with the government, Dr Ng says. All six dental hospitals he is acquiring have yibao-approved status, he added.

So the bigger hospitals were the way to go.

"It's a learning curve. We took smaller risks initially when we bought into all these smaller clinics; the commitment was 10 million yuan ($2.1 million) per clinic," Dr Ng says.

And while the patient inflow and the returns on investments are higher, the first few years of a new hospital's operations may be loss-making, Dr Ng notes.

After a couple of years of searching for a suitable dental hospital investment, an opportunity finally arrived. Last July, in the largest deal in the history of Q&M, the company signed a memorandum of understanding (MOUs) to acquire a 60 per cent stake of Shenyang-based Aoxin Stomatology Group for $21.6 million. Aoxin owns three dental hospitals, three dental clinics, and a training centre.

The acquisition, to be paid for in shares and cash, is the first and largest China deal Q&M is involved in. It was effectively completed last Tuesday, with an announcement made. "They wanted to do an IPO exercise on their own for a while, but they're too small, and they know we want to do one," Dr Ng says.

The three remaining China deals are for Q&M to acquire two dental hospitals in Donggang and Dandong cities, also in Liaoning province like Shenyang, and a dental hospital and clinic in Weihai city, in nearby Shandong province. It is also acquiring Aidite, a zirconium oxide manufacturer in Qinhuangdao, Hebei province.

Zirconia blocks are used in a CAD/CAM machine, a computer-aided technology that can do tooth restorations in one hour or within the same day for a more complicated operation, instead of a few weeks traditionally. Q&M has invested in a number of these machines.

"The porcelain material is harder, more translucent like a natural tooth, patients can accept it. We strongly believe the market will go in this direction," Dr Ng says. "Now the machine is too expensive, but cheaper ones are coming out, and when patients know of it they will ask."

The China acquisitions came after an aborted attempt to acquire Singapore Medical Group after a material change in the latter's financial performance. When the deal was first announced in end-2012, Q&M originally meant to expand into the medical services business. "I learnt a lot about due diligence and applied the process to the China projects," Dr Ng says. "I think I'm more comfortable now dealing with dental hospitals and dentistry, which I understand very well compared to medicine."

Dr Ng, who sold his three-room flat to finance the takeover of a dental clinic in Bukit Batok in 1996 and built up his chain since, has come a long way. Funding is no longer a problem, with the company sitting on $20 million of cash, a US$15 million loan from World Bank's International Finance Corporation, and a $200 million medium term note programme from HSBC. "Now money is going out, I must make sure money comes in. Manpower, operational controls, all must be in place. We need to integrate and make sure everybody involved is happy with each other," Dr Ng says.

"I'm aiming to close the deals by the second quarter this year. My share price is moving, I need to close the deals soon," he quipped.

"I've spent the past three to four years understanding China's market and learnt the hard way. We did not lose money, just broke even, but it was a steep learning curve, and we're now prepared to grow aggressively, in a calculated way."

Q&M closed last Friday at 37.5 cents.

content:

UOB expects moderate growth this year

Loans growth may slow but fee income will sustain momentum

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

UNITED Overseas Bank (UOB) remains positive for the year ahead although it guided for slightly slower growth as fourth-quarter profits came in ahead of expectations.

"Despite short-term volatility in this part of the world, we remain optimistic on Asia's long-term economic fundamentals," chief executive Wee Ee Cheong said at a media briefing.

Singapore's third-largest bank by market capitalisation said net profit for the quarter ended December grew 11.1 per cent to $773 million, or $1.94 per share on an annualised basis, as net interest margin slipped to 1.74 per cent from 1.76 per cent on an annualised basis. Net interest income rose 13.3 per cent to $1.1 billion.

For the full year, net profit rose 7.3 per cent to $3 billion, or $1.84 per share, with net interest margin at 1.72 per cent as net interest income grew 5.2 per cent to a new high of $4.1 billion.

Street estimates were for a $2.8 billion profit, according to a poll of 21 analysts by Bloomberg.

UOB, which paid out 50 cents per share after its fourth quarter a year ago, is recommending 55 cents per share this year, comprising a 50-cent final dividend and a five-cent special dividend. The bank also paid a 20-cent interim dividend at the mid-year, bringing its full-year payout to 75 cents.

UOB shares closed at $19.90 yesterday, down by 0.4 per cent or eight cents, before the results were announced.

Despite a positive 2013, the year ahead is expected to see more moderate growth, the bank said.

"On the macro front, the world is adjusting to (quantitative easing) tapering," Mr Wee said. "In Asia, concerns have surfaced about capital outflows and China's debt issue, among others."

UOB expects loans growth to moderate to a high single-digit growth in 2014 against a slowing Asian economy. Net interest margin is expected to stay flat in the year ahead.

Fees are also expected to maintain their growth momentum in 2014 amid strength in the loans and wealth management businesses. Mr Wee said double-digit fees growth should continue this year.

Mr Wee reckoned that concerns about Asian vulnerability may be overblown in light of the nature of capital movements as well as the considerably stronger balances held by regional governments compared to during the 19197 Asian financial crisis.

"We believe the near-term impact of capital outflows from emerging markets should be manageable given their stronger balance sheets," he said, noting that outflows are likely to occur with financial, rather than strategic, investors.

"Importantly, the underlying economy and business flows are resilient given the ample opportunities in Asia with its rising middle income and intra-regional trade and investments," Mr Wee said. "These are areas UOB focuses on in growing our franchise business."
