content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tomb sleuth

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tomb sleuth

Raymond Goh can be contacted via

http://bukitbrown.com

SOME people call him the Tomb Whisperer.

If you want to trace your lineage and locate an ancestor's tomb in the Greater Bukit Brown complex of cemeteries along Lornie Road, then chances are Raymond Goh can do it. It might take him some time, however, depending on how many details you can provide him with, but the most important information would be the year of death, the dialect group, the person's name, as well as the names of his or her children.

"I can find it within a few hours if the details are enough and if he is buried in Bukit Brown. Sometimes I get so excited I drop everything to run and go look for it," says 50-year-old Mr Goh, who retains his full-time job as the director of a healthcare company and hunts down tombs as a hobby.

"But most of them take time, especially if there aren't enough details. So I can't actively look out for one. But it will be there at the back of my mind," he adds.

So far, his success rate is around 50 per cent, and the longest he has taken to locate a tomb is two years.

He uses a combination of different methods - for instance, "outsourcing" it to his friends, the tomb keepers. Since these are people who maintain the tombs on a regular basis, he asks them to help him keep an eye out once he receives a request. Other times, he relies on his own knowledge of history and Chinese culture, which he has gathered since he was young, to help him recognise different symbols and markings on each tombstone.

Mr Goh admits that it can be quite a mammoth task to track down the location of one tomb out of about 250,000, in almost 400 acres of forested cemeteries, including the Bukit Brown Cemetery, Seh Ong Cemetery, Lau Sua and Kopi Sua. In fact, only a handful of people are still able to do that because it takes too much time and dedication. He himself has spent at least three hours every weekend exploring the cemeteries for the last seven years.

"Many people can trace their own lineage nowadays, especially when you can do online tracing. It's easier. And maybe they can find the names (of their ancestors), but not the place. Those people who can really search and find the physical tombs like me, I can count on my two hands," says Mr Goh.

His own interest was piqued in 2006, when he visited Bukit Brown cemetery with his brother one day and noticed a tomb with the year 1842 engraved on the stone. Realising the potential historical value of the cemetery, he decided to devote some time to studying the history of the place.

Since then, he has seen more and more requests from people in search of their ancestry, and gets more than 10 requests a month compared to the initial one or two. "In the past when Singapore was still at the stage of development, a lot of people were more concerned with the struggle to make a living. But now people are richer, so heritage becomes important. They want to know their roots," he theorises.

"Still, there are a lot of people who don't care, and ask me 'Why do you care? All these people are dead.' But to me, all this is part of a broader picture. It's about filial piety. It's a very Asian thing."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

OCBC Q4 earnings up 8% at $715m

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

STRONG growth in net interest income and fee income helped OCBC Bank record a net profit of $715 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, despite lower life insurance and trading income. This was 8 per cent higher than the $663 million a year ago.

OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien said that the bank's net interest margin (NIM), a key measure of lending profitability, should remain stable at about "1.6 plus per cent" in the year ahead. The bank is also focusing on higher-growth territories outside of its Singapore base like Indonesia, Malaysia, China and Hong Kong. It is raising US dollar deposits so it can lend more in US dollars, notably to China corporates.

Costs are expected to rise percentage wise in the "single digits" for the year ahead due to technology investments and compliance requirements. Loan growth is targeted to slow to the "low teens" from 18 per cent year-on-year growth in 2013.

On the home front, new applications for housing loans have fallen by 40 to 50 per cent, but the bank expects its healthy inventory levels of loans to drive growth in the next two years. Mr Tsien said the global economic outlook is positive. "There will be events that cause capital flows between continents, we need to be careful about that," he said.

Core income for the quarter was up 2 per cent to $1.71 billion. This comprised net interest income, which grew 12 per cent to $1.03 billion, and non-interest income, which fell 10 per cent to $679 million. Net interest income went up due to steady asset and deposit growth.

Non-interest income was affected by a 49 per cent plunge in net trading income to $69 million and lower contributions from life insurance arm Great Eastern - life assurance profit declined 22 per cent to $165 million. Mr

Tsien said trading income is a "market-dependent activity", and the insurance income drop was due to unrealised mark-to-market losses not reflective of a strong underlying insurance business. "New premium sales are up 27 per cent year on year, and new business embedded value (a measure of future profits in today's terms) is up 22 per cent," Mr Tsien said.

OCBC declared a final dividend of 17 cents a share, unchanged from a year ago. Shareholders can opt to receive the payment in the form of shares. The total dividend for 2013 is 34 cents, up a cent from a year ago. This represents a yield of 3.6 per cent on its Friday closing price of $9.38. OCBC stock had been battered since the beginning of the year upon news of its takeover of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank. Investors have feared that OCBC is overpaying for the acquisition. But the counter has since staged a recovery after closing at a one-year low of $9.09 on Feb 4.

Yesterday, Mr Tsien declined to give new information on the takeover, citing Hong Kong takeover rules where he cannot provide new information or opinions on the transaction. "If the transaction proceeds, we will be sure to make any detailed announcements as appropriate, on the most timely basis," he said.

For 2013, OCBC recorded a full-year core net profit excluding divestment gains of $2.77 billion, 2 per cent lower compared to 2012. Total core income was unchanged at $6.6 billion, with net interest income up 4 per cent to $3.9 billion and non-interest income down 5 per cent to $2.7 billion. For non-interest income, growth in fees and commission income for wealth management, loan-related, fund management, brokerage and credit card was negated by a sharp fall in net trading income.

Under the interest income segment, loan growth was 18 per cent in 2013 to $170 billion at end-2013. All segments registered growth. Greater China saw the most, rising 56 per cent to $27 billion. Singapore, the largest segment, was up 12 per cent to $84 billion. There was a notable 44 per cent surge in US-dollar denominated loans to $46 billion.

Customer deposits grew 19 per cent year on year to $196 billion, with fixed deposits seeing a $10-billion jump in the last three months of 2013 due to OCBC fighting for its share of the pie amid numerous other bank campaigns advertising higher rates. Singapore dollar and US dollar deposits increased the most, with OCBC raising the latter to fund its US dollar loan book growth.

NIM, the difference between interest income from loans and interest payments to depositors relative to interest earning assets, fell to 1.64 per cent in 2013 from 1.77 per cent in 2012. This was due to the persistently low interest rate environment, where the cost of borrowing is low and competition heated up for existing mortgage loans. While 2013's NIM marked a third consecutive year of declines, Mr Tsien noted that it has stabilised at the 1.64 per cent mark effectively throughout all four quarters in 2013.

Stability indicators remained healthy, with capital adequacy ratios above regulatory requirements. The non-performing loans ratio was down 0.1 percentage point to 0.7 per cent.

Analyst reports yesterday noted the results were in line with or above their expectations. "A decent set of results on strong earnings top-line growth but focus will be on long-term strategy," said a Goldman Sachs note. OCBC closed at $9.38, up 5 cents or 0.5 per cent.

content:

Is your business secure?

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUSINESSES these days are increasingly exposed to cyber threats and need to take steps to enhance the security of their systems.

"Today, we work in an environment with 3.5 new threats created every second," says David Siah, country manager, Trend Micro. The Trend Micro 2013 Threats Report further highlights the soon-to-be outdated Windows XP as among the affected OS (operating systems) with as many as 45 Microsoft security bulletins released between July 2012 and July 2013.

No wonder Internet security is now a pressing concern among business operators, especially as companies make the OS switch from Windows XP to Windows 7 or 8.1. "With the new platform migration, SMEs (small and medium enterprises) will need to stay vigilant against potential cyberthreats," added Mr Siah.

Mr Siah is one of several speakers at a seminar organised by The Business Times next week on Internet security. Presented by HP, the seminar will bring together industry experts to address various solutions to real and urgent IT exigencies.

Mr Siah will be giving an overview of the cybersecurity landscape in Singapore and the risks and setbacks faced by companies. He will also touch on what businesses can do to safeguard against potential vulnerabilities, and present several case studies of actual commercial disruptions due to a poor systems discipline.

There will be presentations by other speakers during the event. These include:

site_title: Sip and tell
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sip and tell

Jeff Bell, head mixologist of legendary Manhattan bar Please Don't Tell, catches up with Debbie Yong over lunch - and tells it like it is

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

YOU may find it ironic that one of New York's most hidden speakeasies is also one of the world's most well-publicised, but Please Don't Tell's (PDT) head bartender Jeff Bell doesn't see anything contradictory in that.

"We want people to know about us. We are a legal operation, the bar has a liquor licence, so why don't we want people to talk about it?" says Mr Bell, 28, who was in town this week as the guest judge for the second semi-final of the Diageo Reserve World Class Competition's Singapore championships. Mr Bell himself finished as the top US bartender in last year's competition, and an overall second in the global finals. "We weren't meant to be hidden. The whole idea behind PDT stemmed from a fun way to separate the hot dog stand from the bar."

Founded in 2006 by Brian Shebairo and Jim Meehan in a space vacated by a bubble tea shop in New York's East Village, entrance to the reservations-only PDT is via a dimly lit phone booth within Crif Dogs, a no-frills hot dog stand.

In the seven years since, the bar has garnered unparalleled success, with both the bar and Mr Meehan constantly topping global bar rankings, the latter even literally penning the book on speakeasies, The PDT Cocktail Book.

Says Mr Bell of the Australian, Brazilian, Singaporean and myriad global tourists that now pack into PDT on a nightly basis: "Historically, bars were not destination spots, they were just somewhere you stop by periodically. But people come to PDT now because they want to try the drinks, we're no longer just a neighbourhood bar."

While he's not sweating the publicity nor the tourist to regulars ratio, what Mr Bell does find ironic, however, is the way Prohibition-era drinks are being romanticised and touted by speakeasies around the world.

"Traditional speakeasies weren't cocktail dens, they were hidden bars - and you couldn't drink very well in them. There were only illegal and homemade products during the Prohibition Era and all the bartenders left the industry," he says.

This is why the Prohibition Era is not an inspiration for the cocktail programme at PDT, which also means that he gets to concoct, inhibition-free, his signature potions such as the Lion's Den, a Japanese-inflected, togarashi and shishito pepper-dusted reboot of the margarita, and the Cuban cigar-inspired Romeo Y Julieta, which works in a subtle, smokey tobacco essence.

Besides conducting a masterclass for local bartenders yesterday, Mr Bell also did a public guest bartending stint at Jigger and Pony on Thursday evening. The Amoy Street cocktail bar was made-over as a PDT pop-up, right down to its taxidermy wall mounts and darkened phone booth entrance.

"I am pleasantly surprised by the calibre of bartenders in Singapore," he says. "A few at the top end were very well spoken, had great drinks, and a great story to tell. They're definitely of world-class calibre."

"There were some who could definitely work at PDT," he hints, adding that he prefers to hire younger people as bar backs and have them work their way up. "We hire people based on their personality and work ethic. You can teach people how to make drinks, but you can't teach someone how to work hard."

Putting in a hard slog, after all, was how he landed his coveted current role. A philosophy graduate from Seattle, Mr Bell got his break in 2010 when he was offered a bar back job at PDT while bartending for Mr Meehan's wife at the Gramercy Park Hotel. He held both roles until a full bartender's position opened up at PDT later that year.

"There's an awful lot of pressure. When you're working in a top bar like PDT, everyone wants you to mess up." But, he adds, "you just stick to your guns and if you belong on top, you'll impress people. There'll always be haters, but it comes with the territory."

Is it that bad? "It's terrible," he winks. Oh please, don't tell us that.

site_title: Courts Q3 profit up 1.7% despite S'pore sales dip
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Courts Q3 profit up 1.7% despite S'pore sales dip

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

COURTS Asia Limited yesterday posted a 1.7 per cent rise in net profit to $6.27 million from $6.17 million for the fiscal third quarter ended Dec 31, 2013.

The furniture, electronics and IT retailer said turnover rose 4 per cent in the quarter to $203.3 million. Singapore sales, which accounted for 67 per cent of group sales, registered a 2.9 per cent decrease in Q3 compared to a year ago, due to lower digital and electrical product sales. The fall was due to weaker consumer demand and lower bulk sales.

On the other hand, Malaysian sales, which contributed 33 per cent of the group's sales, grew by 20.8 per cent. Strong growth was mainly attributable to higher credit sales from an aggressive campaign and higher furniture and electrical product sales. The opening of new stores during the financial year also contributed to the increase in sales.

Gross profit rose 12.8 per cent, while gross profit margin increased 2.5 percentage points to 32.1 per cent, backed by higher service charge income from higher credit sales in Malaysia.

For the nine months to end-December, Courts reported a 28.8 per cent drop in net profit to $20.47 million from $28.77 million, while turnover rose 3 per cent year on year to $623.31 million from $605.27 million.

Earnings per share were 1.12 cents and 3.66 cents for the third quarter and cumulative three quarters, respectively.

Courts said consumer sentiment in Singapore is expected to remain soft in the next six months, and consumers in Malaysia are expected to remain cautious.

However, the group continues to implement a series of measures to cope with a weaker retail environment in Malaysia, including an aggressive campaign to ramp up credit sales. Malaysia's long-term fundamentals remain favourable and Courts continues to execute its expansion plans. The second Courts Megastore in Subang was opened in January.

In Indonesia, construction work for its first "Big-Box" Megastore in Bekasi is on track and the store is expected to open ahead of schedule, by the second quarter of FY14-15. Construction negotiations for the group's second Megastore in BSD City, Serpong, is ongoing and opening is targeted in the second half of FY14-15.

The counter ended trading unchanged at 57.5 cents yesterday.

site_title: Reliable Italian fare in upscale digs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Reliable Italian fare in upscale digs

Gattopardo moves from Fort Canning to Tras Street serving up a no-surprises, seafood-focused menu, writes JAIME EE

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NEW RESTAURANT

Gattopardo Ristorante di Mare

34/36 Tras Street

Tel: 6338-5498

Open Mon to Fri for lunch and dinner: 12pm to 2.30pm; 6.30pm to 10.30pm. Dinner only on Sat: 6.30pm to 10.30pm. Closed on Sun

ITALIAN restaurants must be the culinary equivalent of the white shirt. They never go out of style; they're your failsafe option when you can't decide what to wear; and there's always room for one more in your closet. But if you want something show-stopping, you'll need to widen your colour scheme.

That pretty much sums up Gattopardo, which has eschewed the old-world charm of Fort Canning for the conservation chic of Tras Street in a move which seems more physical than conceptual.

Now that it's in the centre of town within convenient reach of an ever-expanding upwardly mobile demographic, it's shed its old persona of "grill and pizza bar" in favour of something a little more classy such as "ristorante di mare" or seafood restaurant, as a nod to chef Lino Sauro's South Italian roots. The result is a cookie-cutter, three-storey eatery that takes its design cues from the "stylish shophouse decor" handbook. There's the obligatory bar on the ground level, and a small seafood display counter with a few seats squeezed into a tight corner.

Just a few feet from the welcome desk, the open kitchen concept hardly seems conducive for a comfortable meal, especially with people traipsing past to get to the main dining room on the second floor. The latter, meanwhile, is business-like with starched white tablecloths, neutral colour scheme and generic upscale feel.

It's the same with the food - attractively plated, served by staff with the necessary decorum of a high-end restaurant. The menu is naturally seafood-centric, in line with its new name and chef Sauro's emphasis on using only sustainably caught seafood.

Like the decor, the cooking and service are strangely impersonal, like meeting a polite stranger who goes through all the motions expected in a civil conversation - it's all very pleasant but not particularly satisfying.

Then again, the restaurant is only a couple of weeks old and technically in soft-opening stage. But while some restaurants have a knack of endearing themselves to you from the start even with teething problems, Gattopardo's staff need a bit more time to warm up to the idea that service is about hospitality and not just literally bringing food to the table.

Everybody's well-meaning and nice enough, but you can't help thinking that they're more pre-occupied with the physical issues of the restaurant - from a non-working ladies' restroom to the many unfinished touches around the place.

The cooking doesn't seem to be affected, though, as it's competent albeit not the most inspiring. A starter of Polipo ($36), for one, pairs wide strips of chewy grilled marinated octopus with a salad of shredded celery root and sundried tomatoes.

The acidic edge of the salad is tempered by the slightly sweet marinade of the octopus, but fails to clock any highs. Capesanti e Ceci ($34), is slightly more enjoyable with two plump Norwegian scallops grilled to an appetising semi-raw bounciness, slicked with a streak of mellow chickpea puree and sauteed broccoli rabe. But at $17 a scallop, your pleasure comes with a caveat.

Leaving us wanting is the Capellini alla Moresca ($36) - a bare handful of angel hair pasta in need of an al dente bite, swirled in a cloud of dried mullet roe dust and a smidgen of uni for a result that is more salty than tasty. Same with the Sicilian noodles Bucatini con le Sarde ($30) - otherwise deliciously chewy hollow pasta tubes tossed in a mixture of fresh sardines, raisins and pine nuts, but with more fruit and nuts than actual sardines.

Less reticent in flavour is the signature Zuppa di Pesce "Gattopardo" ($40) - a rich, earthy tomato-based broth with a punchy seafood infusion that compensates for the fresh but bland mussels, shrimp and fish.

And while we may forgive the less than crisp-skinned roast pork belly with barely there squid ink sauce and hardly a whisper of coffee and orange jam, we find the $40 price for two bite-sized chunks of pork a little hard to swallow. For that amount, surely a copy of the porker's Spanish passport should be made available for all to see.

Given its general priciness, the $36 set lunch is a steal in comparison. For that money you get a decent trio of vitello tonnato - thin shavings of boiled veal still slightly pink in the middle and drizzled with savoury sabayon and barely a taste of tuna; simple braised pork belly; and a very acceptable green apple tart. In fact, desserts and baked goods are Gattopardo's strong point, particularly its Tortino di Castagne ($18) with its comforting crumbly tart pastry filled with warm chestnut puree. And don't miss the chewy crisp biscotti that comes at the end of the meal.

Taken at face value, Gattopardo is one of your no-brainer, business crowd-oriented Italian eateries with middle-of-the-road cooking that's perfectly pleasant if not superlative-worthy. But it's early days yet - perhaps with a bit of time, it'll be able to show off its true colours.

Rating:

6.5

site_title: Firms calling numbers on Do-Not-Call list get warnings or fines
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Firms calling numbers on Do-Not-Call list get warnings or fines

Nine in 10 complaints involve unsolicited text messages; 100 warnings issued so far

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE Personal Data Protection Commission has censured several organisations for breaching the requirements of the Do-Not-Call (DNC) Registry, said the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) of Singapore yesterday.

Since the registry went live on Jan 2, the commission has received 1,500 valid complaints involving 580 organisations, from those who have registered their phone numbers so that they will not be bothered by marketing calls or text messages.

Nine in 10 complaints were about unsolicited text messages, including those sent through instant messaging services such as the ubiquitous WhatsApp.

The commission has so far issued about 100 warnings to errant companies. Some 94 per cent of complaints are isolated ones against companies, which have received or will soon receive these warnings from the commission.

Among companies that have each attracted a clutch of complaints, at least two have been handed down what are considered lenient fines - between $500 and $1,000.

Companies imposed a fine in this range would have sent out multiple text messages to phone numbers listed in the DNC registry, but would have cooperated with the authorities and reviewed their telemarketing practices after being contacted by the commission.

Investigations are also underway into what the IDA called a "recalcitrant organisation", which could be prosecuted in court and fined up to $10,000 per contravention.

Commission chairman Leong Keng Thai said: "We expect organisations to comply with the DNC provisions and will not hesitate to take enforcement action against errant organisations.

"We want to encourage consumers to come forward with information on errant companies."

About three in 10 of the complaints received so far have been made against private-education providers such as tuition centres.

Unwanted property advertisements and other property-related messages make up about a quarter of the complaints, and messages from banks and finance firms, about 10 per cent.

These three sectors have drawn the most complaints.

The commission has also received complaints related to unlicensed money-lending, and has referred these to the police.

It has also fielded complaints about unwanted calls from foreign companies with no presence in Singapore but which are offering their products and services. The number of this is, however, insignificant.

Organisations seeking to check the DNC lists also need to register themselves to access this information. The number of registered organisations stands at 1,800, up from 505 as at Jan 2. Collectively, these firms have run checks on more than 55 million phone numbers.

Among the complaints are some which are deemed invalid. These include complaints from consumers who received unwanted messages before Jan 2, or who had not registered themselves in the DNC Registry.

Some 550,000 phone numbers are on this registry, up nearly 40 per cent from the 394,000 "unique registrations" on the list as at Jan 2, when the registry was officially in place.

The IDA did not offer figures on the impact of the registry so far; it has only been a month. However, it said that anecdotal feedback has been positive.

site_title: Riot police reclaim Bangkok protest site
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Riot police reclaim Bangkok protest site

They favour cautious approach in operation and hope to seize back other locations soon

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Bangkok

THAI riot police reclaimed a main Bangkok thoroughfare yesterday that has been occupied for months by demonstrators seeking to topple caretaker Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, and said they would move to seize other protest sites in the coming days.

There were no reports of clashes in an operation that appeared designed to test the strength of the dwindling bands of anti-government protesters who have been disrupting life in the Thai capital since November.

Police pulled back from confrontation with protesters after a stand-off at another site in the north of the capital, and made no move against the largest sites at intersections in the city's main shopping and business districts.

"Our strategy is to do this slowly, and work inwards from areas outside of central Bangkok towards the main protest sites," said national police chief Adul Saengsingkaew. "We are not dispersing the protesters or using force; we are using negotiations as our main tactic."

Protesters want to oust Ms Yingluck, viewing her as a proxy for her elder brother, Thaksin Shinawatra, a self-exiled former prime minister who clashed with the establishment before he was overthrown by the army in 2006.

National Security Council chief Paradorn Pattanathabutr told Reuters that 5,000 police officers had been deployed to reclaim protest sites at Government House, the Interior Ministry, the Energy Ministry and a government administration complex.

Despite the cautious approach, which has at times seen protesters allowed to take over government offices unopposed, 11 people have been killed and hundreds hurt in sporadic flare-ups. The past week has been quiet, with most protest sites dotted around Bangkok sparsely attended during the day. "The number of protesters has gone down significantly, so that's one factor," said police chief Adul. "It makes our job to reclaim the protest areas easier."

A Reuters witness said there was no violence as at least 1,000 police officers cleared protesters from a site stretching from the Royal Plaza to the United Nations headquarters. A few of the officers were armed but most carried just batons and shields.

Some protesters hurled abuse but otherwise police met no resistance in a historic area of the capital that includes the prime minister's offices at Government House and the Metropolitan Police headquarters, scenes of violent clashes in November and December.

Police later said they had recovered firearms, ammunition and drugs from the site, where they removed barriers and tents set up by the protesters.

Protest leaders had urged supporters to come out in force over this weekend, and held "Love Thailand and Break-up with the Thaksin Regime" events in Bangkok yesterday, Valentine's Day, which coincided with a Buddhist public holiday.

"This isn't the first time the government and police have tested the waters. They are going for smaller groups; you could call them softer targets," said Boonyakiat Karavekphan, a political analyst at Ramkamhaeng University in Bangkok.

An election on Feb 2 failed to break the deadlock in Thailand, a country popular with tourists and investors but blighted by eight years of polarisation and turmoil.

Protesters blocked voting in a fifth of constituencies, a result that left Parliament without a quorum to approve a new government and Ms Yingluck's Puea Thai Party limping on as the main party in a caretaker administration with limited powers.

The deadlock has raised concerns about the long-term impact on an already weakening economy, with the caretaker government unable to approve spending on new infrastructure projects that would have supported growth.Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Swedish cuisine, with subtle Asian influences

Bjorn Frantzen of two Michelin-star Stockholm restaurant Frantzen is giving diners here the whole Nordic experience - for one night only. By Debbie Yong

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN leading Swedish chef Bjorn Frantzen comes to town next week, it won't just be a few twee Nordic lingonberries he'll be sprinkling on a plate. He's bringing his entire larder - or at least as much as he can squeeze into his hand luggage.

The plan is to make sure that diners at his one-night-only gig at Les Amis feel as if they're eating in his eponymous restaurant in Stockholm, says the two Michelin-starred chef. Highlights of his menu will include tartare of reindeer and beef with deep fried moss topped with Swedish caviar and a dusting of - grated reindeer penis.

Though Denmark has traditionally been forging the path for the new Nordic food movement, Sweden has been fiercely keeping pace. But Chef Frantzen, whose restaurant climbed up eight spots to 12th position on the World's 50 Best Restaurants list last year, has largely differentiated himself from the pack by working in subtle Asian influences into his Scandinavian cooking.

A sprinkle of seaweed here, a galangal root macaron there - and if you want to see how the magic all happens, you can even watch a condensed video of how his latest Winter menu was created online, in a practice that has become almost a tradition for the restaurant.

Of his fascination with Asian, largely Japanese, culture, Chef Frantzen, who once likened his food to a Nordic kaiseki, says: "When I visited Japan for the first time a few years ago, I fell in love with their cuisine and their tradition of food.

"I find their way of keeping things simple very elegant, and we have many things in common, such as our focus on the produce and tradition of fermenting, pickling and preserving," he says.

While South-east Asian flavours don't feature on his menu yet, he adds that he hopes to explore the local wet markets on his maiden visit to Singapore.

Acknowledging that the converse phenomenon - an Asian fascination with Nordic cuisine - isn't yet apparent, he believes that Nordic gastronomy is still very new, and will take time to find resonance in Asia. But interest is growing, thanks to awards and lists such as the World's 50 Best, he says. "The list has definitely helped international guests find us more easily. People who travel for food set our restaurant at the top of their to-do list and I'm sure the list will have the same response in Asia," he adds of the list's Asian spin-off, the second edition of which will be revealed in Singapore next weekend.

It has, after all, helped not just his restaurant, but the Swedish restaurant scene to soar. "Restaurants are opening every week in Stockholm, guests can pick and choose what they think is best. It's really fun to see Stockholm evolving from a small city to this," he says.

To stay ahead of the game, he's just installed a new test kitchen in the restaurant, for him and his two chefs to "try out every idea that comes to mind" in the day. By night, the 20-seater space turns into a room for private dining.

As for his role in the Nordic food revolution, he says: "That's a hard one. This question is easier to answer looking back. Please get back to me when I retire."

Three Michelin stars, perhaps? "No pressure," he says.

content:
Airshow sees deals worth US$32b sealed

Figure pips 2012 show's US$31b sales, boosted by commercial orders and growth of regional carriers

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE Singapore Airshow surprised on the upside with some US$32 billion worth of deals over the trade days, narrowly exceeding the US$31 billion recorded at the 2012 edition, fuelled largely by commercial orders from fast-expanding regional carriers.

This was welcome news for managing director of organiser Experia Events, Jimmy Lau, who had conservatively projected that this year's Airshow would underperform 2012 in terms of value. But, as widely expected, the number fell short of the US$200 billion or so seen at the Dubai Airshow last November, where the Gulf carriers Emirates, Etihad and Qatar placed massive orders for next-generation aircraft.

The biggest deal this week in Singapore came from Ireland-based leasing company Amedeo, formerly Doric Lease Corp, which firmed up an order for 20 Airbus A380 double-decker jets worth US$8.3 billion. Airbus also finalised an order with VietJetAir for 63 A320 family aircraft to the tune of US$6.4 billion as the budget carrier prepares to expand at home and in the region.

Boeing announced that Thai low-cost carrier Nok Air would buy 15 single-aisle 737s, comprising eight Boeing 737-800s and seven of the upcoming 737 MAX 8s, worth US$1.45 billion.

Bombardier inked firm orders and commitments for up to 17 aircraft totalling US$852 million, while Pratt & Whitney signed a 10-year fleet management agreement with Malaysia Airlines for its fleet of 43 PW4170 engines worth US$550 million.

And an order on Thursday from Indian start-up airline Air Costa for 50 of Embraer's E2 aircraft worth US$2.94 billion - with purchase rights for another 50 - helped boost the tally.

Even with emerging economies such as India and Indonesia grappling with weaker currencies in recent months, aircraft makers such as Airbus, Boeing and Bombardier this week downplayed concerns that the region might have more planes on order than it can absorb, pointing to rising passenger traffic and the need for newer, more fuel-efficient models, given stubbornly high fuel prices.

"(Demand) for smaller aircraft to ply domestic routes for the Indonesian market, India and even Thailand and Malaysia - I think that will trend up," said Mr Lau at a press conference yesterday. "There will be a fair bit of replacement of aircraft over the next few years. The MRO (maintenance, repair and operations) business will continue to flourish, as well as the growth for aviation training and the simulation market."

Singapore Airlines and Airbus, for instance, said this week that they would set up an $80 million flight training centre to cater to regional airlines.

Held at the Changi Exhibition Centre (CEC), the Singapore Airshow (Feb 11-16) attracted more than 1,000 exhibitors from the commercial and defence industries, and 279 delegations from 72 countries.

This year's edition also saw slightly more trade visitors, at over 40,000 from 125 countries during the first three trade days - compared with around 38,000 in 2012 - of which roughly a third were from overseas.

Highlights from the static display area this year included Airbus's upcoming A350 wide-body jet (which was pulled out of test flights to perform a flying demonstration here), Qatar's Dreamliner as well as business jets and military aircraft such as the V-22 Osprey. Some of these planes have already departed, with about 50 to be left on display when the Airshow is open to the public this weekend. Some 80,000 public visitors are expected to attend, with most of the tickets already sold yesterday.

Airbus's spokesman for Asia, Sean Lee, said: "In addition to presenting the A350 for the first time, we announced orders valued at almost US$15 billion. We were also pleased with the quality of visitors to the show, which included senior airline management representatives from across the region."

"It's a great venue. We've always been able to show the products very well here," said Roger Sperry, regional senior vice-president (sales) of Gulfstream, which brought its entire fleet of private jets. "It's a good place for people to do comparisons of the various models."

The biggest of 16 Airshows in Asia, the Singapore Airshow serves as a networking platform for firms, industry leaders and high-level government officials in the sector's fastest-growing region.

Experia Events said 72 per cent of the exhibitors from this year's Airshow had confirmed they will return in two years for the biennial event (Feb 16-21, 2016), with some pledging to take up more exhibition space.

The organiser is working with various government agencies to attract more firms from Asia, such as SMEs.

More than 1,000 meetings took place over the trade days, which could be the foundation for orders that might be sealed down the road.

At home, the Airshow generates economic spin-offs as well. A 2012 study showed more than US$250 million in spending going towards the economy.

In coming years, as Changi Airport expands to incorporate Terminal 5, the event organiser will need to look into how construction will affect accessibility to the CEC.

"What we will probably need to do is work with the authorities on accessing Aviation Park Road," said Mr Lau, referring to editions of the Singapore Airshow that will come after 2016.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China Minzhong's Q2 net slips 6.4%

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

HIGHER costs hit China Minzhong, which yesterday reported a 6.4 per cent drop in net profit to 201.9 million yuan (S$41.9 million) for its fiscal second quarter ended Dec 31, 2013.

Earnings per share of the Fujian-based vegetable producer fell to 0.31 yuan, from 0.39 yuan a year ago.

The group, which came under fire from shortseller Glaucus Research last year for accounting issues, said that this was due to much higher income tax expenses which more than quadrupled to 37.3 million yuan.

This was because it sold a higher proportion of brined products which are taxable, versus fresh-packed products and fresh vegetable produce which are tax-exempt in China, it said.

Administrative costs went up 29.6 per cent to 36.2 million yuan, while other costs tripled to 33.2 million yuan - the latter due to higher rental expenses, allowance for doubtful trade debts, and loss of biological assets due to adverse weather conditions.

Revenue rose 5.1 per cent to 905 million yuan, driven by higher sales in its cultivation (mostly fresh vegetable produce) and branded (mostly beverages) business segments.

China Minzhong's first-half net profit slid 25.8 per cent to 250.3 million yuan, on the back of a 4.6 per cent growth in revenue to 1.5 billion yuan, hurt by a poorly performing first quarter after Glaucus accused it of fraud and financial irregularities.

The two-week long saga eventually ended with PT Indofood Sukses Makmur launching a takeover of China Minzhong at $1.12 a share. PT Indofood garnered majority control quickly, aided by the shortseller-inspired crash that prompted traumatised shareholders to sell their stakes on the market.

As of Nov 6 last year, Indofood had an 82.9 per cent stake in China Minzhong, according to Bloomberg data.

While the company expects consumption demand for its products to stay healthy, it noted that the Chinese government's urbanisation programme has led to a shortage of farmers and rising labour costs.

It has since expanded into industrialised farming for higher productivity and cost efficiency and to be able to harvest all year round without weather disruption, it said.

Its counter rose 4 cents, or 4.4 per cent, to close at $0.955.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A quiet but firm week for the STI

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Straits Times Index managed to rise on the first four trading days this week, though volume remained low throughout. The five-day gain was 25 points or 0.8 per cent to 3,038.71, with the index slipping 1.19 points yesterday during which 1.8 billion units worth $872 million were traded.

On Tuesday, volume done of $792 million - of which $450 million or 57 per cent was done in the 30 STI components - was the lowest daily total for the year so far.

The rebound after several days of selling in January came after Wall Street, which itself came under tremendous pressure last month on worries over the health of the Chinese and US economies, managed to stabilise and recover almost all its losses.

Reasons for the US recovery, however, are not readily obvious. Economic releases have been mixed - the January employment and retail sales numbers have been weak but this has been attributed to bad weather - and the new Federal Reserve head Janet Yellen has not said anything new other than reiterate the already known fact that the Fed under her stewardship will continue along lines set by her predecessor, Ben Bernanke.

Conventional wisdom, though, is still that the US economy is recovering and that Fed tapering will end at the end of this year, and that the first interest rate hike will occur only next year.

In its assessment of Ms Yellen's testimony to Congress this week, Ideaglobal said she appears to be unveiling a moderate revision to forward guidance, with more labour market indicators being used to judge whether the labour market is tightening.

"This fits with the broader guidance that the Fed Funds rate is unlikely to rise until well into 2015, despite the prospect of ongoing Fed tapering," said Ideaglobal. Ms Yellen was also due to testify this week to the Senate Banking Committee but that was postponed because of bad weather.

Among the blue chips to release its results this week was land transport operator ComfortDelgro (CD), which reported a 5.7 per cent increase in net profit to $263.2 million and recommended a final dividend of four cents per share.

In its "buy" on ComfortDelgo, OCBC Investment Research said it has reworked its assumptions following a change in analyst coverage, and raises its dividend-discount fair value from $2.20 to $2.30.

"We are positive on the fact that management has been able to mitigate domestic challenges by making astute accretive overseas acquisitions," said the broker.

OSK DMG, in the meantime, also called a "buy" on CD with a fair value of $2.22 derived from a discounted cash flow model, but added that this has been reduced because it expects CD's local operating conditions to remain challenging. CD's shares yesterday closed unchanged at $1.94 with four million traded.

In the penny segment, Ocean Sky International (OSI) stood out, not because its share price rose but because it fell sharply. The civil engineering company was to be taken over by offshore marine company Ezion Holdings in a deal announced last September but that deal has been aborted.

In a Wednesday release, Ezion said the Singapore Exchange (SGX) had informed the company that the deal amounted to a reverse takeover, and because this would result in "protracted timings", the parties did not wish to extend the transactions and had decided not to proceed.

OSI's shares yesterday managed a 1.4-cent bounce to 14.3 cents with 70.4 million done but are still 15.2 cents or 52 per cent down for the week.

Other active low-priced issues were familiar names, such as HanKore, Charisma Energy, Albedo and SingHaiyi. Ezion's shares gained one cent over the week to $2.29.

site_title: Dishes bearing mixed heritage
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dishes bearing mixed heritage

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Nuvo

Marina Square, 6 Raffles Boulevard, #02-100

Hours: 11am to 11pm daily

Tel 6822 2098

HE'S youthful, brimming with brazen ideas, and most importantly - he's back. After a two-year hiatus as the head chef of modernist restaurant Keystone, which closed last year, Mark Richards has resurfaced on the local culinary radar. This time, he's heading things up at five-month-old Marina Square eatery, Nuvo, and his first task at hand: to give the menu a spiffy reboot.

Gone are the heavy pastas created by the restaurant's outgoing Japanese head chef, and in their place, lighter plates bearing mixed heritage - as though an Italian married a Japanese and bore local school-enrolled, Singlish-speaking children.

The Angel Hair Wakame ($18/24) is an Italian capellini sprinkled with Japanese seaweed and tossed in chilli oil like you would a bak chor mee. The Green tea Pan di Spagna ($12) is a matcha cake with the moist density of a nonya kueh, and is served topped with a comforting banana jam and a crumble of Hello Panda (yes, the chocolate biscuit you may still remember from your childhood). Likewise the Ricotta Cheesecake ($15), which bears a characteristically Japanese melt-in-your-mouth lightness and is served spiked with chocolate Pocky sticks.

"I've missed the kitchen - all the buzz and the noise in it. That was what drove my decision to return to the motherland," says the 38-year-old Eurasian chef, who spent his break consulting on restaurant projects in China, Mongolia and Russia. "Plus, I really liked the concept. Singaporeans are crazy about their Japanese food and their Italian food, so it's a no-brainer to come up with a menu that brings together both cuisines."

On his obsession with scientific cooking techniques - about 90 per cent of his dishes are sous vide, including the risotto - Mr Richards says it's something he picked up while working in Hawaii in 2003, and he hasn't looked back since. "It's a practical way of cooking, it gives a better, consistent result by eliminating human error, and you are giving more justice to the produce," he explains. "But at the end of the day, the base has to be in classical cooking, and then we evolve the food from there."

Fans of his bold, experimental strokes at Keystone, however, should be prepared to find a more restrained hand at Nuvo.

Instead of pureeing and dehydrating fresh squid into squid ink crackers as he would have done at Keystone, for example, they are deep-fried as crowd-pleasing calamari rings and served on a bed of rocket leaves with compressed watermelon. "As a mall restaurant, our food has to be easily relatable to everyone. I don't want to scare the aunties and uncles away," he laughs.

Still, to please the most ardent of his followers, Mr Richards can design degustation menus for 10 diners and above with a fortnight's notice. The 150-seater restaurant's cocktail lounge will double as a swish private dining area after its refurbishment later this month.

site_title: Minimum prices won't hurt overall market turnover
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Minimum prices won't hurt overall market turnover

Analysis shows small impact, ranging from 0.5% to 6.1% of total traded value

Published

Sun, Feb 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Imposing a minimum share price on Mainboard-listed companies could put only a small dent in overall market turnover despite affecting a relatively higher percentage of stocks, according to an analysis by The Business Times.

Proposed changes to the framework for questioning unusual trading activity, however, could see "Trade with caution" alerts put out for most companies queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and SGX are currently seeking feedback on a comprehensive set of proposed rules changes for the securities markets. Among those are rules that could impose a minimum share price on Mainboard-listed companies.

Separate from the public consultation, SGX will also change its querying framework from March 3, allowing the market operator to issue a "Trade with caution" note for queried companies who cannot explain unusual trading in their shares.

The BT analysis sought to assess what the proposed changes could mean if they were applied to Singapore-listed companies right now.

For the minimum share price proposal, the possible impact was assessed for different minimum prices, from five cents to 30 cents. MAS and SGX have set initial guidance at 10 to 20 cents.

The analysis showed that as many as 337, or 43.3 per cent, of all the listed companies could be affected if the minimum share price was set at 30 cents.

The question was then asked, what do those affected companies contribute to the market?

In terms of market turnover, the impact appears to be small, ranging from 0.5 per cent to 6.1 per cent of total traded value for minimum share prices from 5-30 cents.

In terms of volatility, while the affected companies tend to have higher-than-average volatility, the dampening benefits of a minimum price appear to diminish with higher price hurdles.

At a minimum of five cents, the affected stocks would have average 30-day volatility of 113.6 per cent compared to the market mean of 64.7 per cent. At 30 cents, the affected stocks' volatility would average about 75.6 per cent.

In terms of trading queries, BT classified all the replies to trading queries over the past year into five categories: Not aware; always looking at deals; could be explained by a previous announcement; insider trades that have yet to be announced; and specific but undisclosed potential deals.

About 64 per cent of the replies made did not give specific reasons to explain their share prices, saying that they were not aware of any pertinent undisclosed information or that they were always looking at deals. Those will probably receive "Trade with caution" notices under the new regime.

The analysis is not perfect.

Constraints in obtaining data limited the analysis to closing prices over the two-week period to Feb 12, when the consult suggests that volume-weighted price will be observed over a 180-day period. The universe of stocks also differs depending on the source of the data. The BT analysis used SGX's end-of-day numbers and excluded depository receipts, derivatives and exchange-traded funds.

The BT analysis deviates slightly from official data, which were also limited because they were current only until Dec 31 and only showed the impact of minimum share prices of 10 and 20 cents.

MAS data showed that with the minimum share price set at 10 cents, 22 per cent of Mainboard-listed companies could be affected. BT's analysis was 25 per cent. Those companies had average volatility of 123.6 per cent, according to MAS. BT's analysis had volatility of 94 per cent.

With a minimum share price of 20 cents, MAS data showed 38 per cent of Mainboard-listed companies affected, compared to 42 per cent for BT. Average volatility for the MAS stocks was 100.7 per cent, compared to 83.1 per cent for BT.

Croesus Retail Trust posts DPU of 2.02 cents for Q2

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

CROESUS Retail Trust (CRT), with a portfolio of four retail properties across Japan, posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.02 cents for the second quarter of FY2014 ended Dec 31, 2013, 1.8 per cent higher than its IPO forecast of 1.98.

Gross revenue for Q2 was 1.29 billion yen, which is 1.2 per cent higher than the IPO forecast. Net property income was 805.87 million yen, 2.4 per cent higher than the IPO forecast.

The main positive variance was from property management expenses. This was offset by increased sales and promotion expenses at suburban shopping centre Mallage Shobu. However, overall property expenses were lower than forecast by 0.8 per cent.

Income available for distribution was 713 million yen (S$8.8 million), which is 6 per cent higher than the IPO forecast. The higher income available for distribution was mainly due to property tax rebates. This was offset by the difference between the actual and forecasted distribution hedge rate for the period.

For H1 FY2014, distribution per unit is 5.24 cents, and income available for distribution is 1.85 billion yen. The net property income is 2.08 billion yen, and gross revenue is 3.29 billion yen.

This is CRT's first distribution and it will be paid on March 31, 2014.

Jim Chang, chief executive officer and executive director of Croesus Retail Asset Management, the trustee-manager of CRT, said: "Across 1H FY2014, we are seeing a healthy level of consumer activity at our properties as well as encouraging macroeconomic indicators that point to growing optimism and confidence in the Japanese economy. We are in a good place to benefit from these economic conditions given our close to 100 per cent occupancy rates and stable rents across CRT's four retail assets."

The company also said that its properties are expected to continue generating stable cash flows and that it is expected to meet its IPO forecast for the period ending June 30, 2014.

CRT's counter closed up 2.5 cents at 91.5 cents yesterday.

GLP Q3 profit jumps 56.3%

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

GLOBAL Logistic Properties' (GLP) third-quarter net profit grew 56.3 per cent year on year despite a slight dip in revenue.

Net profit for the three months ended Dec 31, 2013, rose to US$176.2 million, or 3.53 cents per share, from US$112.8 million a year, or 2.23 cents per share, a year earlier.

The improved bottom line was largely due to a higher contribution from jointly controlled entities and lower foreign exchange losses, but this was partially offset by lower fair value gains compared with a year ago.

Revenue fell 1.5 per cent to US$170.9 million, led by a 39 per cent decline in revenue in Japan to US$64 million, mainly from the sale of properties there to GLP J-Reit in Q4 FY2013 and the weakening of the yen against the US dollar, GLP said.

After removing the properties sold to GLP J-Reit and adjusting for foreign exchange changes, GLP said group revenue increased 29 per cent.

Revenue in China surged 53.8 per cent to US$105 million, while GLP's Brazil business grew 202 per cent to US$2 million.

For the nine-month period, net profit rose 14.1 per cent to US$525.2 million, boosted by a higher share of fair value gains of investment properties and results of jointly controlled entities.

Earnings per share rose to 10.52 cents from 9.42 cents. Revenue fell 13.4 per cent to US$447.9 million. Net asset value per share rose to US$1.81 as at end-December, from US$1.77 at the end of March. No dividend was declared.

GLP shares ended four cents higher at $2.80 yesterday, before the results were announced.

site_title: Loans growth lifts Q4 profits at S'pore banks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Loans growth lifts Q4 profits at S'pore banks

DBS, OCBC, UOB see strong business momentum, healthy asset quality, and shrug off QE tapering concerns

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

SINGAPORE's three local banks reported robust Q4 earnings, boosted by strong loans growth and broad-based gains in non-interest income.

All three which posted results yesterday said business momentum remains strong, asset quality is healthy and tapering concerns leading to higher interest rates were not likely to hit earnings given the tight employment situation here.

"The QE tapering in the US signals a recovering economy which bodes well for this part of the world," said United Overseas Bank chief executive Wee Ee Cheong.

"The near-term impact of capital outflows should be manageable given the stronger balance sheets in Asia. Despite recent uncertainties in a few countries, we remain positive on Asia's underlying economic fundamentals," said Mr Wee.

United Overseas Bank, the smallest of the three by market capitalisation, had the best performance. It recorded a 11.1 per cent increase in Q4 net profit to $773 million, led by strong growth in core income streams.

UOB also rewarded shareholders with a special dividend of five cents; raising the total payout for the year to 75 cents, up from 70 cents in 2012. DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank raised their final dividends, by two cents and one cent, respectively.

DBS core net profit in Q4 rose 6 per cent from a year ago to $802 million on a 10 per cent gain in total income. Including one-off items, DBS' Q4 net fell 20 per cent to $973 million. OCBC's net profit of $715 million for the fourth quarter of 2013 was 8 per cent higher.

For the full-year 2013, net profit of the three was a combined $9.45 billion, down from $10.6 billion in 2012 which had hefty $1.65 billion one-off gains.

The banks enjoyed strong loans growth of 17-18 per cent, fuelled by increases in business lending particularly from trade loans to China. Net interest margin or the profit made from loans continues to hold steady.

DBS said its loans increased 18 per cent or $38 billion to $249 billion, led by regional trade loans, Singapore corporate borrowing and secured consumer loans.

Customer loans at OCBC rose 18 per cent to $170 billion from broad-based growth in Singapore and key overseas markets, which was led by trade finance and loans to the housing and building & construction sectors.

UOB said loans from Singapore increased 17.7 per cent to $119 billion while those from regional countries grew 16.8 per cent to $52.7 billion (excluding currency impact).

Loans growth this year is expected to ease off, falling to low double digits as the impact of stricter loan rules on mortgages bites hard.

New mortgage applications have fallen as much as 40-50 per cent, said OCBC chief operating officer Ching Wei Hong.

"We've seen volumes come off 40-50 per cent. That's expected given all the cooling measures that were imposed," he said.

But the banks said the slower home sales which have seen prices falling and a possible hike in interest rates are not likely to hit earnings negatively unless people start losing jobs.

UOB chief financial officer Lee Wai Fai said the bank is less worried about increase in interest rates than unemployment.

"We have stressed (tested) interest rates through various forms ... and probably we felt that we can take easily 4 to 5 per cent increase in interest rate (hike) shock," said Mr Lee.

"For that to happen overnight, I think that will take a drastic attack on the currencies ... it's unlikely going to happen. So this worry about interest rates or default on non-performing loans (NPLs), if it ever happens in the mortgage market, will take some years to pan out.

"We saw that in the last crisis. Normally NPLs take three to four years to pan out, which will give a commercial bank like us time to react."

"So far, like I said, we've been monitoring that, the government is already ahead of the game. We ourselves are stressing that through various scenarios, and unemployment is something that we watch very, very closely," said Mr Lee.

site_title: Raise the lantern
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Raise the lantern

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Yeo Swee Huat Paper Agency

Blk 6, Lor 8, #01-1307, Toa Payoh Industrial Park

MOST artists paint on canvas, but not Yeo Hung Teo. He paints on lanterns, and is one of the rare few in Singapore who do this.

The 75-year-old runs Yeo Swee Huat Paper Agency, which was started by his late father. At 16, the younger Mr Yeo left school and joined the company, which produces traditional Teochew lanterns, and paper paraphernalia used in temples and for funerals.

In the past, Teochew families who could afford it would hang lanterns outside their homes. Each lantern would bear the family surname, and the location of their village in China. Besides families, temples, such as the Yueh Hai Ching Temple in Philip Street and clan associations, would also hang such lanterns, which often have auspicious characters written on them.

"These days, there are only a handful of families who hang these lanterns," says Mr Yeo, adding that it is only the Teochews who have such a tradition.

Making a lantern is a tedious chore, says Mr Yeo. Each lantern comes with a lattice bamboo frame, which is imported from China. Strips of cloth, or translucent paper, the same kind used in making Japanese shoji doors, are then stuck on the bamboo frame, using a special glue made from seaweed. Mr Yeo still follows the same traditional methods.

"Using glue from seaweed gives a better finish compared to glue made from flour," he says in Mandarin. Mr Yeo has staff to prepare the lantern, but he does the painting himself. "I studied art, and I've always had a strong interest in drawing and painting from young," he says. Apart from flowers, such as peonies and lotus, Mr Yeo also draws mythical creatures such as the phoenix and dragon. He learnt to draw on his own, when he first joined the company. He uses a pen to draw on the lanterns before using acrylic paint, sometimes in neon shades to colour in the lines. It is not hard to see that Mr Yeo has decades of experience, as the creatures look very life-like.

Lanterns all have words on them, which Mr Yeo also personally paints. He says he is a stickler for details and quality, and never does a rushed job on them. Each stroke is given at least seven coats of paint, to get a smooth and consistent finish, and to make them look more outstanding when the lantern is illuminated. "Some others do fewer coats, and you can spot the inconsistency," says Mr Yeo.

By sticking to his well-tested methods of production, Mr Yeo says his lanterns can last about a decade. Worn out lanterns are brought back to Mr Yeo, who strips off the covering, and reuses the bamboo frames.

"Our busy time is usually in December, when customers want a new set of lanterns for the new year," he says. Each lantern can take about two weeks to produce, and cost from $500 for a pair.

Mr Yeo knows that the younger generation has little interest in doing what he does. He has taught some university students the art of painting, but "you really need to have the patience and passion to stay in this", he says. He has no plans to retire.

Over the years, he's become known as the expert for painting dragons. But ask him what's the hardest to paint, and he says it is the tiger. "A tiger must be fierce. If you don't paint it well, it can turn out to be a pussy cat," he quips.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bell to boost commercial copter biz

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Bell Helicopters will look to grow its commercial helicopter business further to make up for lower military spending, says CEO John Garrison.

In an interview with BT yesterday, Mr Garrison said future production of military aircraft such as the tilt-rotor V-22 Osprey will slow, necessitating growth from commercial helicopters to offset it.

Bell delivered 41 V-22s last year, its highest ever, he said. But planned deliveries this year and the next will fall to 36 and 21 aircraft, respectively.

Mr Garrison said Bell will build more advanced and reliable helicopters, and leverage on strong service and maintenance support to differentiate itself and grow market share in the commercial helicopters sector.

"We've captured more of the market in 2012 and 2013," he said. "So we've enhanced our position in the marketplace."

Globally, commercial sales for Bell grew 13 per cent last year in a challenging market, he added.

The company has "a very active engineering and development programme", and is developing two new commercial helicopters scheduled for their first flights this year.

One is the five-seater Short Light Single (SLS) first announced last year in Paris, which will be unveiled at Heli-Expo 2014 in two weeks' time. The second is the larger Bell 525 Relentless that takes 16 passengers. It will be the first commercial helicopter to feature fly-by- wire.

On the military side, the company is developing the V-280 Valor, a third-generation tilt-rotor aircraft, as part of the US Air Force's search for a replacement of Apaches and Black Hawks.

The V-22 Osprey, on display for the first time at the Singapore Airshow, has received tremendous attention here, Mr Garrison said.

With reduced production for the US government, he said there is capacity available from Bell and Boeing for foreign governments, too. "There's no doubt the speed, capability and range of the aircraft are ideally suited for this region."

In Singapore, Bell's capabilities at its 165,000 square foot Seletar facility, shared with Cessna, have continued to grow.

Said Mr Garrison: "We are able to offer new (engineer) training, some training solutions, and we have received certification from Transport Canada to do some maintenance and customisation work."

site_title: Delicious off-cuts
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Delicious off-cuts

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Dibs

51 Duxton Road

Hours: 12-3pm,6pm-12am (Mon-Fri), 6pm-12am (Sat)

Tel 62233784

THE most fail-proof way of running a restaurant these days seems to be: order in a chunk of premium wagyu, mindlessly toss it on the grill (how bad can good wagyu turn out?), slap a high mark-up on it, serve.

But then again, where's the fun in that?

That is why budding local chef Leong Khai Git, 29, and his team behind three-week-old restaurant Dibs on Duxton Road set themselves up to do just the opposite. Their aim: to present inexpensive, off-cuts of meat in unexpectedly delicious ways.

A platter of beef short ribs ($34) is cooked sous vide for 24-hours to accentuate its tender marbling; a slab of pork cheek ($28) is dusted with a panko crust and served on a bed of pea and horseradish puree.

If it all sounds a tad Fergus Henderson to you, it actually is. For Cordon Bleu-trained Mr Leong admits to being enamoured of the nose-to-tail cooking philosophy, though not quite taking it to the extreme as Mr Henderson's St John's restaurant does.

So while you won't find any lungs or intestines on the menu at Dibs, neither will you get prime sirloin or tenderloin. It's not all bottom-of-the-barrel picks, either: the short ribs are from Black Angus cattle while the cheeks are from black pigs (kurobuta).

But the best part of the menu at Dibs is how the Asian elements play out in subtle, creative ways, such as a drizzle of fish sauce or gula melaka in the salad dressing, or a chicken roll with ginger, burnt rice and cucmber ($25) that's like a modern take on chicken rice. A starter of "meat butter", or bone marrow ($15), is laced with teriyaki sauce and bonito flakes for that extra umami and the bowl of smokey cockles ($8) is adapted from the favourite beer snack of kopitiam uncles, but dressed up with bacon dashi and a lively kick of smoked chillis.

The benefits of running a small restaurant is that new dishes are always being tinkered with, and the menu will evolve gradually, says Mr Leong, who previously worked at Italian restaurant Gaia at the Goodwood Park Hotel and Quest, a molecular Asian restaurant in Abu Dhabi. His two other partners, Jonathan Wee and Lawrence Lim, work in the finance and start-up industries respectively.

The restaurant currently seats 40 on the first floor, while a soon-to-open lofty second floor is used as a private events space for now. The trio also hope to open a second concept when things stabilise, such as a winebar offering homemade charcuterie, says Mr Leong.

site_title: Olam's shares rise as earnings beat forecast
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Olam's shares rise as earnings beat forecast

Q2 net profit down 12.5% at $134.9m , but Patmi falls by smaller 5.2% to $129m

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

OLAM International's shares rose 2.6 per cent to $1.58 yesterday, after its second-quarter earnings released in the morning came in ahead of estimates.

And in a sign that the firm's new three-year strategy is going according to plan, cashflow metrics have improved, while capital expenditure has moderated.

Net profit for the three months ended Dec 31 fell 12.5 per cent to $134.9 million on lower revenue, a net loss in the fair value of biological assets, and higher depreciation and amortisation charges.

But excluding exceptional items, operational profit after tax and minority interest (Patmi) dropped by a smaller 5.2 per cent to $129 million, said Olam.

This includes a loss in fair value of biological assets of $15.4 million, compared with a gain of $22.1 million a year ago, as the firm's Australian almond orchards mature.

After making adjustments for the fair value loss, "published Patmi appears to be ahead of street estimates", said Citi Research analyst Patrick Yau in a note.

Revenue slipped 8 per cent to $4.5 billion, as overall sales volume declined 5.3 per cent.

This was due in part to a high base last year, and also to the ongoing restructuring of five business platforms in Olam, said its executive director of finance and business development, A Shekhar, at a briefing.

"The first half is (usually) a slower half," said Mr Shekhar. With fixed costs such as depreciation and amortisation as well as taxes to remain constant, "we expect (that) as volumes and Ebitda kick in for the second half, you'll see potential for earnings growth."

Olam also made strides in its cashflow metrics.

Free cash flow to firm (FCFF) improved from negative $777.2 million to negative $282.2 million, while free cash flow to equity (FCFE) - which includes interest the firm has paid - went from negative $988.1 million to negative $533.5 million.

The firm is on track to becoming FCFF-positive by the end of the financial year, said Mr Shekhar, "and we're focused on ensuring that happens while we're growing our earnings as well as our Ebitda".

For the first half of this year, Olam moderated the pace of its capital expenditure, shaving it to $262.4 million, from $469.6 million last year.

Olam's negative free cashflow and high capital expenditure had attracted criticism from US shortselling firm Muddy Waters in November 2012. Subsequent to the saga, Olam in April last year unveiled a new strategy to accelerate free cash flow generation, reduce gearing and complexity in the business, as well as to promote a better understanding of its business.

Olam's gearing now stands at 2.06 times, compared with 2.21 times in the first half of last year.

The 10 initiatives that Olam has undertaken through sale and leaseback transactions and divestments, among others, will release about $446.5 million in cash for the current financial year, the firm said yesterday, adding that it is still in discussions for more of such transactions.

OCBC Investment Research yesterday increased its earnings forecast for Olam, and upgraded its call on the firm to "buy" on the better-than-expected set of results.

site_title: Journey to the heart of Teochew food
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Journey to the heart of Teochew food

Chaoshan is rich in history and culture but it is its Teochew cuisine that draws food lovers to this prefecture in China's Guandong Province. By David Yip

Published

Fri, Feb 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AS the saying goes, you are what you eat. But few take it quite as seriously as the folks in Chaoshan, where no conversation can begin without a cup of Gongfu tea, a social etiquette strictly adhered to since the Song Dynasty. The brewing of tea is itself a ceremonial ritual, and often, guests get to sample the best pick of the host's tea collection.

The Teochews - as the natives of Chaoshan are called - guard their history and culture so fiercely that even as other Chinese cities rushed to embrace the modern new lifestyles that economic growth brought, the Teochews paced themselves. Although Shantou was one of the four original Special Economic Zones, the city didn't develop as fast as Shenzhen, Xiamen and Zhuhai.

Shantou is part of Chaoshan, itself a prefecture of Guangdong Province together with Chaozhou and Jieyang. With a population of three million, this former fishing village is today a major toy-manufacturing centre in South-east China. As with many fast-growing cities in China, there is a sharp contrast of old and new, and modern high-rise buildings and old shophouses mingle cheek-by-jowl. Navigating the streets is easy, but be prepared for big city hassles such as bargaining with the taxi drivers (slashing taxi fares by as much as 40 per cent is possible!)

Even the food in Shantou has undergone some changes. While the majority of the residents prefer traditional food, the young have been seduced by Western and foreign cuisines. Journalist/author Zhang Xinming, an expert on Teochew cuisine, explains: "It is impossible to resist the changing of taste buds. The world has evolved, and people are exposed to new concepts and ingredients through various media."

Together with some friends, Mr Zhang recently set up Chao Cai Yanjiu Hui, a resource centre to promote Teochew cuisine within the prefecture as well as overseas. "It's a place to promote and exchange information about our cuisine and heritage," says Mr Zhang. "We even have a kitchen for training young chefs in both cooking techniques and plating."

Most Singaporeans strolling the stall-lined streets of Shantou will find the food familiar, even if the taste isn't what we're used to. Which is to be expected, considering that the recipes that the early immigrants prepared in Singapore have been modified over the generations. For instance, we eat our kway chap steamed while Shantou residents would pan-fry the rice sheets to give them a light crust. Even the broth is slightly starchier.

Supper is a compulsory ritual here - a full-blown version of Teochew porridge. Instead of boneless braised duck, though, the Teochews jostle for the more esoteric goose head. In fact, it appears at almost every meal as appetizer, with the Teochews being so finicky about it that a special breed of goose, known as Lion's Head Goose or Shi Tou E, is farmed for its head and liver only. Each head, after braising, weighs about 2kg, and costs as much as S$200 at a fine-dining restaurant.

An hour's drive from Shantou lies Chaozhou - Chaoshan's most famous historical and cultural city. For centuries, it was a rich arts hub known for its prowess in opera, music, tea drinking, lion dance and of course, cuisine.

The history of Chaozhou could be traced back more than 5,000 years. Many archaeological sites have been unearthed, including many Buddhist relics, and Ming Period architectural ruins are found within the city. Most social gatherings are still held at the local teahouses, accompanied by string ensembles, and in the north lies the famous mountain known for its Wu'long Chinese tea.

Driving into town, you can't miss the many porcelain shops with huge signboards. For more than 1,300 years, Chaozhou was a major porcelain-manufacturing centre; in recent years, it has also become a leading manufacturer of apparel, electronics and foodstuffs.

However, it is the rich cuisine of the city that attracts food connoisseurs. The Teochews are famed for their deft handling of seafood, in particular their skill at extracting the best flavours with various cooking methods, including some very simple ones. It is common to find fish, prawn or crab served raw, at most accompanied by a sauce, or cured with soy sauce. On the other hand, delicacies such as shark's fins, abalone and sea cucumber are often elaborately prepared for lavish dinners.

Puning, within Jieyang, is a relatively new county formed in the Ming dynasty. Most of the ancestors of the current 2.3 million residents of Puning were immigrants from Putian during the tumultuous period of the Song dynasty. It was under the Ming however, that the city became fully developed as a centre for agriculture and Chinese medicinal herbs.

Puning boasts a relatively small town centre, which resembles Singapore in the 80s. Outside this can be found many Ming-style villages that lie around the city. Although the buildings suffer from a lack of proper maintenance, the famed Teochew style of mosaic porcelain-work known as chien nien, or cut-and-paste porcelain, still form magnificent elaborate motifs along the roofs and archways.

Life in this city is laid-back, and many traditional foods can still be found along the roads and at makeshift stalls in the villages. Many traditional, artisanal businesses still exist, such as a three-generation-old noodle shop whose recipes have remained unchanged for more than 100 years. Everything, including the noodles, is still made from scratch each day. At another stall a husband and wife would arrange simple wooden boxes and stools to sell deep-fried ngoh hiang (five-spice meat roll).

Puning is home to the famous Puning miso sauce and tofu. Its makers treat the simple task of deep-frying tofu as seriously as studying for a university degree. Each family has its own recipe and method of achieving the crispy yet moist tofu, and little else. For them, and the people of the region, ensuring that they put simple, but fine-tasting and fortifying food on the table for family and friends is all that truly matters.

One can easily fly directly to Shantou from Singapore. For those who would like a holiday detour from Guangzhou, Shantou is only an hour's train ride with the newly launched express train.

One of the best-kept secrets in Shantou, this roadside stall serves some of the best braised goose dishes in town.

Do not expect the kway chap that is offered in Singapore. This kopitiam-style stall offers the authentic version, where the kway is pan-fried rather than steamed.
