site_title: Focus on innovation, not just productivity
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Focus on innovation, not just productivity

Panellists say that preoccupation with raising productivity comes at expense of creativity

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Companies shouldn't chase productivity for productivity's sake, but strive to create value through innovation instead, said participants at BT's Budget Roundtable. This would place more emphasis on tangible outcomes that ultimately boost output.

Explaining how attempts to measure productivity (such as unit labour cost) are "flawed to begin with", Mizuho Bank economist Vishnu Varathan said: "There is a risk that productivity and creativity could be almost mutually exclusive, if not slightly at odds at the very least. If productivity is measured within the year (as) how much more output you can have, (it does) to some extent exclude the creative process that may have a longer gestation period.

"The way to go about it is to not get hung up on year-to-year measures, (whether they reflect) slippages or spurts in productivity. We're in it for the long haul, and I think we ought to treat it as such," he added.

Other panellists shared their views on how recent curbs on foreign labour - aimed at heightening productivity - have sometimes had the opposite effect.

Ku Swee Yong, chief executive of property consultancy firm Century 21, noted the difficulty some of his clients have faced when trying to renew their foreign hires' employment passes - some of whom have worked in Singapore for half a decade.

"This is a complete drag on productivity, especially when it (has to do with) skilled labour (in sectors like) healthcare or engineering. To retrain (a new) person to understand our standards and how our environment works (is counterproductive)," said Mr Ku.

Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) chief executive Phillip Overmyer agreed, voicing multinational companies' (MNCs) frustrations at having to lose long-serving foreign staff due to tightened hiring measures.

"(Large multinationals) are more and more seriously saying: 'If this is something that's getting in my way, I shouldn't be here'," said Mr Overmyer.

Both he and Mr Ku believe that instead of turning down such renewal applications, the government should facilitate them - this would function as a reward to companies that have trained their staff from the ground up.

Beyond the issue of productivity, however, KPMG's head of tax Tay Hong Beng believes firms should not forget about value-creation activities either. These include building a strong brand, or attempts to internationalise.

Said Mr Tay: "A lot of companies, especially SMEs (small and medium- sized enterprises), have been very focused on productivity, (and that) has taken away their focus (on) longer-term perspectives - how they can explore new markets, identify new capabilities, and embark on the innovation journey altogether. But if you look at creating value itself - beyond the (issue) of productivity - you could possibly be creating demand for your services and products.

"So can we expand the output rather than just look at narrowing the input? If we look at it from that perspective, then maybe the government can look into how we can help businesses in Singapore build their brands, or whether we can possibly introduce certain tax incentives to incentivise self-generated brands," said Mr Tay.

Panellists also said that more can be done to encourage SMEs to expand beyond Singapore's small domestic market, since this would enable firms to enjoy greater economies of scale.

EY's head of tax, Chung-Sim Siew Moon, thinks the government can do this by allowing all foreign-sourced income to be fully exempt from tax, by removing qualifying conditions. At present, foreign income remitted into Singapore is exempt from tax only if it has been subject to taxes overseas, and if the country's headline tax rate is at least 15 per cent or more.

site_title: Parkson posts 2.8% rise in Q2 net
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Parkson posts 2.8% rise in Q2 net

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DEPARTMENT store operator Parkson Retail Asia has recorded a 2.8 per cent rise in second-quarter net profit despite a fall in revenue and other income, as a decline in expenses helped to prop up the bottom line.

The company said yesterday that net profit for the three months ended Dec 31, 2013, rose to $13.6 million from $13.2 million a year ago.

In earnings per share terms, the company made 2 cents per share, compared with 1.95 cents a year ago.

Revenue fell 3.4 per cent to $117.4 million from $121.5 million as merchandise sales and gross sale proceeds recorded falls for the group, which operates its stores in Malaysia, Vietnam and Indonesia.

For the half-year, net profit declined 3.9 per cent to $23.8 million, while revenue saw a 3.7 per cent drop to $226.1 million.

In its financial statement, Parkson said that its operating results will improve year-on-year in the second half of FY2014 as seasonal factors work to its benefit, and new stores open.

"The group's performance for the next reporting quarter will benefit from the festive retail buying arising from the Chinese New Year and Tet festivals, which will especially benefit the Malaysia and Vietnam operations and, to a lesser extent, the Indonesia operations," it said.

Parkson opened four stores in the first six months of FY2014, with three in the cities of Jakarta and Medan in Indonesia, and one in Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam. A further six stores are expected to open in the second half of FY2014 in Malaysia, Vietnam and Indonesia. These six stores have a total gross floor area of 67,433 square metres.

"Discretionary retail spending in Malaysia remains resilient despite significant headwinds to consumer sentiment, while retail spending in Indonesia continues to be strong. The group anticipates gradual improvement in discretionary retail spending in Vietnam in the second half of FY2014," said Parkson.

"Local currency weakness in the countries where the group operates remains a risk to the group's financials, which are presented in Singapore dollars. However, the group is of the view that operating results will improve," it added.

Net asset value per share as at Dec 31, 2013, was 37 cents, compared with 38 cents in end-June last year. Cash and cash equivalents held at end-December totalled $199.8 million, compared with $210.7 million a year ago.

Parkson's shares closed 1.1 per cent lower yesterday at 91 cents.

site_title: Martial arts melds with dance
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Martial arts melds with dance

Indonesian silat and Japanese jujitsu take centre stage in dance, writes CHEAH UI-HOON

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE beautiful forms, speed and creativity in Indonesian martial arts so fascinated Akiko Kitamura, an award-winning Japanese dancer/choreographer, that she spent several months learning them.

Subsequently, she fused what she learnt with contemporary choreography and a multimedia for a modern dance performance.

Her interpretation of the "Asian body" - one that fuses martial arts and dance across cultures - will be presented in two works in the upcoming NUS Arts Festival. One is part of a triple bill for the opening show, while the other premiered in Jakarta last year.

Musing on the similarities and differences between martial arts and dance, Kitamura notes how the purpose of the former is efficiency and the intent to win, while in dance, the beauty is often in the "showiness" and lacks a concrete purpose.

But both are sophisticated and about communication between bodies - so they're very similar in that sense. In Japan, the distinctions between martial arts and dance are, in fact, quite blurred, she says.

"There are very similar movements in karate and kabuki, for example, and 'laido' which uses the sword, which is now very popular in Japan as a way to cultivate calmness, good balance and beautiful form."

In Okinawa, traditional karate also has very similar forms with their traditional dance.

"But what's interesting is the differences in the process when the people try to develop the technique and expression," she shares, and the development of martial arts strategy is a great way to look at choreography and dance technique as well. "Sometimes it is as if they are solving mathematics and calculating energy flow, and from this, a new 'vocabulary' will emerge. It's very creative, like dance," shares Kitamura.

"In Perisai Diri, the basic concept is self-defence and the idea is to use the opponent's energy to win - which gave me inspiration to create dance movements out of that," she describes.

Kitamura was also fascinated with Sundanese Pencak silat like Panglipur and Minangkabau silat. "Silat has a very clear concept of self-defence and each party develops its own fighting strategy. But for them, to win is sometimes to continue to fight rather than injuring the opponent - and that thinking is fascinating."

Choreographing contemporary dance, for Kitamura, has become a way to harness that energy flow between bodies - derived from what she's observed in silat. "It's also a good experience to work with the dancers who have traditional techniques," she adds.

Her dance, To Belong - Cyclonicdream, considers how the spirit and the body are impacted by science and technology.

It was conceptualised by Kitamura in collaboration with leading Indonesian artists, including dramaturg/co-director Yudi Ahmad Tajudin (artistic director, Teater Garasi in Yogyakarta), and a team of Japanese artists. The dance production will have a narrative, and be presented with elements of wayang kulit, along with inspirations of aikido and jujutsu, besides silat. For the NUS performance, there will be changes in the presentation and staging.

Japanese contemporary dance has few roots in Japanese traditional dance, except perhaps Butoh, but in the true spirit of contemporary art which is borderless, Kitamura used traditional Indonesian martial arts to make something new out of the old.

Raffles Education Q2 profit up 20%

Performance achieved despite 5% revenue fall

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

RAFFLES Education Corporation yesterday said its net profit for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, rose 20 per cent year-on-year to $5.84 million despite a 5 per cent slip in revenue to $31.63 million.

The slight dip in revenue is due to a decrease in student numbers resulting from the closure of colleges as part of rationalisation.

On the other hand, other operating income jumped to $12.22 million from $1.72 million mainly due to a $4 million compensation confirmed by Langfang City Government, China, in October 2013 as Oriental University City (OUC) had assumed certain liabilities on their behalf in prior years.

Additionally, the private education provider through OUC received a $5.9 million grant from the Langfang Development Zone Treasury Authority as fund for education development.

Earnings per share for the reporting quarter were 0.57 cents, up from 0.48 cents a year ago.

For the six months to end-December, Raffles Education saw its net profit tumble 63 per cent year-on-year to $3.28 million (from $8.88 million) as contributions from associates fell 59 per cent to $55,000.

Turnover for the half-year slipped 4 per cent to $63.42 million (from $65.89 million).

Raffles Education has seen its China college revenue declining albeit at a slower rate and is expected to stabilise as the group begins to see positive outcomes from implementing new transformational strategies in the country.

The group is also continuing to see positive outcomes from its expansion strategy in the ex-China region.

RafflesEducationCorp's chairman and CEO, Chew Hua Seng, said: "The last five years have brought about a major transformation in the group. We are now a more mature company on a solid footing, with good assets backing."

The group's plant, property and equipment increased to $318 million from $304.4 million, with net additions of $18 million, and $4.7 million worth of advance payment reclassified from prepayment.

Net asset value as at end-December was 52.47 cents. Raffles Education shares ended trading yesterday up half a cent at 28 cents.

ComfortDelGro profit gets boost from UK bus line

Group's UK bus business helps raise net profit 5.7% to beat estimates

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A NEWLY acquired United Kingdom bus line helped ComfortDelGro Corp to grow 2013 net profit by 5.7 per cent to just beat estimates.

The land transportation group reported yesterday that net profit for the year ended December 2013 increased to $263.2 million, or 12.43 cents per share, in line with revenue, which also grew by 5.7 per cent to $3.7 billion over the same period. Net asset value per share increased by 6.1 per cent to $1.0137.

Average expectations was for a net profit of $262.1 million, according to a poll of 11 analysts by Bloomberg.

ComfortDelGro is recommending a final cash dividend of four cents per share, a 14.3 per cent increase from the 3.5 cent payout in 2012. The stock picked up 0.8 per cent, or 1.5 cents, on the day before the results were announced.

The UK bus business contributed $57.6 million to operating profit, a 33.6 per cent increase, during the year as the Metroline West business made its maiden contribution of $10.1 million. Total revenue from the UK and Ireland expanded 17.9 per cent to $802.3 million, forming ComfortDelGro's fastest growing market outside of Singapore and Malaysia.

All major business segments except rail posted operating profit growth.

The rail segment saw operating profit tumble 66 per cent to $4.8 million as the company incurred start-up costs related to the new Downtown Line in Singapore. Excluding advertising and rentals, rail would have turned in a loss of $5.8 million for 2013.

Excluding start-up costs for the Downtown Line, ComfortDelGro reported that operating profit for its North East Line would have increased by 22.5 per cent to $13.6 million in 2013.

The taxi business showed modest growth, with operating profit increasing 3.6 per cent to $146.2 million.

Looking ahead, ComfortDelGro expects cost pressures to persist. Nevertheless, revenue for the bus, rail and taxi segments are expected to increase in the year ahead.

Advertising and rentals in Singapore are also forecast to be higher with the opening of six new Downtown Line stations.

site_title: SMEs start to push back at rising rents
content:
SMEs start to push back at rising rents

ASME head bemoans 'cartel' of institutional landlords using 'draconian measures'

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are getting proactive about the mounting rent pressures they face.

The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) is studying the feasibility of a database to track industrial and retail rents. This would record effective rents rather than contractual ones, providing greater transparency for SMEs and their landlords, ASME president Kurt Wee said at BT's Budget Roundtable.

"There is a need for better transparency . . . We think that in the institutional landlord space, we are seeing signs of a bit of a cartel in operation. Because we do have limited real estate space in Singapore and, very often, we're hearing anecdotes of very draconian measures on individual tenants by institutional landlords," he said.

The report that ASME is working on could then form the basis of recommendations for a code of best practices for industrial and commercial landlords.

"You know, we've imposed the lemon law on business, we imposed the Do-Not-Call registry on business. We wonder if we should impose some better practice in this space. How is a business supposed to react when they want to renew their lease and are told they are going to face a 300-400 per cent increase in rent?" he said.

This is especially so given the current cost climate. Wage bills have swelled due to higher foreign worker levies and stricter quotas, while global commodity costs have been on the rise and minor compliance costs are adding up, Mr Wee added.

So it is local SMEs which are feeling the heat the most - calls for help with the affordability of business space have grown louder both in and outside Parliament in recent months.

Real estate investment trusts (Reits) - some of which were formed after JTC and HDB divested space to private owners - have been blamed for shorter lease renewals and sharper spikes in rentals. "That is not to say that Reits are bad. I think Reits are good because Reits have also redistributed wealth in various and positive ways as well. But we think that there are certain practices that need to be improved, so that there is a better balance between business and landlords," said Mr Wee.

For instance, ASME intends to question the practice of retail landlords collecting a percentage of turnover rung up at the tills as rent, on top of base rents. "Although it is globally practised, we probably are going to question this issue of linking point-of-sales systems to landlords," he said.

These concerns over business space rents are not new - they were raised in Parliament last October. But they remain, even as several rounds of administrative measures to cool the property market - along with rising supply and the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework - seem to have had some impact on official rental and price indices.

This has led to suggestions from property players that it may be time to tweak the property cooling measures. Century21 CEO Ku Swee Yong said at the roundtable that he does not expect major changes.

"If every quarter, property valuations drop islandwide by 2 per cent, such that over the course of the year we have a 8-10 per cent decline, I think that sort of gradual decrease doesn't hurt the banks' balance sheets, doesn't really hurt families' balance sheets - because over the course of the year, they are also paying down their loans. That sort of a stalemate, sideways situation, the government is probably very comfortable with."

It is the potential hike in interest rates as the US Federal Reserve rolls back its quantitative easing (QE) programme that the government will be watching, he said. When that happens, and Singapore's interest rates rise in tandem with rates in the US, the authorities may then remove a portion of the curbs put in place so far.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Roxy eyes investment openings in 4 cities

The group posts record net profits for fourth quarter and full year

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FRESH from selling 14 of its 21 floors in a building in a prime retail location in Hong Kong's Causeway Bay area this week, Roxy-Pacific is now eyeing investment opportunities in Sydney, Melbourne, London and Phuket.

The group is open to both property development and investment (ie, recurring income) ventures, including hotels.

Roxy-Pacific posted record net profits for the fourth quarter and full year. Its net profit of S$44.8 million for Q4 2013 was 91 per cent higher than the S$23.5 million in Q4 2012. Revenue trebled to S$169.7 million from S$56.2 million previously.

For FY2013, net profit was S$92.2 million, up 58 per cent from S$58.4 million in FY2012.

Revenue nearly doubled to S$369 million from S$190.6 million. Roxy said revenue from property development in FY2013 jumped 131 per cent to S$321.0 million - largely due to the 100 per cent recognition of revenue from WIS@Changi, a commercial property that obtained Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) in December, coupled with progressive recognition of revenue from seven other development projects - Treescape, The MKZ, Spottiswoode 18, Jupiter 18, Space@Kovan, Jade Residences and Whitehaven.

Roxy's executive chairman and CEO, Teo Hong Lim, said: "With a healthy balance sheet and strong cash position, we will draw on our financial flexibility to prudently source for suitable projects both locally and in overseas markets. We firmly believe in geographical diversification as a good growth strategy for our asset portfolio and to enhance shareholder value."

Roxy had S$354.2 million in cash and cash equivalents at end-2013, up from S$253.2 million a year earlier.

As at Feb 6, 2014, the group has balance attributable progress billings of about S$922.4 million, the profits of which will be recognised from Q1 2014 to FY2017. At the same time, the group has three development sites - in Lorong K Telok Kurau, Tampines Road and Kuala Lumpur - with a total gross floor area of 503,365 sq ft for development.

"We'll look for further opportunities to acquire land plots in Singapore and abroad and with our strong cash position, we're well placed for potential growth," said Mr Teo.

In Singapore, the group will be "very selective in identifying suitable sites that will appeal mainly to the mid to mass market segments", he added.

Although Roxy touched on its Hong Kong investment at 8 Russell Street opposite the famous Times Square, it did not reveal sales details.

However, it is widely known in Hong Kong that the joint venture between CLSA Capital Partners and Roxy that acquired the upper floors in the 999-year leasehold building, has found buyers for 14 of the 21 strata retail floors of 4,718 sq ft each.

The average price is said to be close to HK$30,000 (S$4,900) psf. An earlier BT article stated a back-of-the-envelope calculation estimating Roxy's profit at HK$350 million for its 30 per cent in the venture - assuming HK$30,000 psf average price on the 21 floors.

The space is currently occupied by Shama Serviced Apartments, which will cease operations in the building. Assuming the assets are spruced up and the units handed over to the buyers by year-end, Roxy should be able to book its profit from the venture for FY2014.

In Singapore, the group's fully sold Spottiswoode 18, Centropod@ Changi and Space@Kovan are expected to receive TOP this year.

The group is recommending 1.297 cents per share final dividend, taking the total payout for FY2013 to 1.913 cents - up from 1.2752 cents for FY2012.

Roxy's net asset value per share rose to 27.62 cents at end-2013, up from 21.25 cents at end-2012. Earnings per share increased to 7.73 cents in FY2013 from 4.90 cents in FY2012. The counter ended unchanged at 60.5 cents yesterday.

site_title: 2014 a banner year for jumbo mortgages in US
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

2014 a banner year for jumbo mortgages in US

Interest rates now almost on a par with those for conventional loans

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] The view of the Pacific Ocean from the San Joaquin Hills in Newport Coast, California is extraordinary. So, when Mohammad Taghavian started looking for a new home four years ago, he knew exactly where he wanted to be.

The housing market, however, wasn't so cooperative. Mr Taghavian, a 47-year-old engineer, jumped at any property that came on the market, only to find that whatever he bid, he was "edged out by a cash offer", he says.

He did what a keen home buyer would do. Mr Taghavian kept raising his offer, from US$600,000 to over a million. That placed him in jumbo mortgage territory - above US$625,500 in his part of the country, and above US$417,000 in lower-priced areas.

His real estate agent, Michael Salas of Coldwell Banker, homed in on one development and went on a letter-writing spree to about 60 homeowners with ocean views. When a US$1.4 million townhouse finally came on the market last year, Mr Taghavian snagged it.

He moved into his dream home just before the new year.

For buyers such as Mr Taghavian who are looking at luxury properties that require jumbo mortgages, 2014 is already a banner year, industry specialists say.

Interest rates on jumbo mortgages used to tower over conventional mortgages because they are considered riskier. But the rates for jumbos have dropped because of economic conditions, and are now almost on a par with conventional mortgages - or sometimes even lower.

In addition, new federal regulations that went into effect in January don't apply to jumbos, making them more flexible for buyers who want things such as interest-only loans or who have a high net worth but complicated finances.

This convergence of factors is helping move along the housing market recovery, says Harvey Grossberg, membership director of the National Association of Mortgage Professionals.

Because jumbo mortgages are so enticing, they are luring home buyers to consider "move-up" purchases, which, in turn, frees up inventory at the lower end of the market. "It's just been a great situation where you had a combination of low interest rates and appreciation," says Mr Grossberg.

The typical spread between jumbos and conventional mortgages is a quarter of a percentage point or less, compared to a half point or more in 2010.

For instance, Mr Grossberg, who brokers mortgages in the Orange County area of California, recently completed two refinancings for a client who had a main residence and a resort property, one a jumbo mortgage now at 4.75 per cent, and the other, a conventional one at 4.5 per cent.

In some cases, the rate parity actually flips, and jumbo mortgages are actually lower, depending on the creditworthiness of the borrower and the length of the loan.

Until recently, banks kept jumbo mortgages on their balance sheets, instead of selling them on a secondary market.

Tom Wind, executive vice-president of home lending for EverBank Financial Corp which originated US$800 million of jumbo loans in the fourth quarter of 2013, says that this is happening because banks keep jumbo mortgages on their balance sheets, instead of selling them on a secondary market. With interest rates low, banks are luring buyers with discounts of an eighth of a percentage point or more.

Even when buyers have enough cash, it can make sense to finance a home purchase with a jumbo mortgage.

Denise Andres, a real estate agent for ERA Landmark in Bozeman, Montana, had a client who recently downsized from a US$3 million property to a US$1.2 million one, and got a jumbo mortgage at a 4.125 per cent interest rate on the purchase, instead of paying all cash. "His thought was, with the gains in the stock market, why would I want to pay all cash if I can get 30-year money so low?" she says.

The new qualified mortgage regulations, enacted as part of the Dodd-Frank financial reforms, require strict debt-to-income and loan-to-value ratios, which determine how much mortgage one can afford and how much to put down. These and other stringent underwriting rules protect conventional mortgage borrowers and allow them to hold the banks accountable if there are problems down the line.

Jumbos don't have the same protections, and rules remain at the discretion of the lending institution.

Underwriting is still tough, because of the large loan risk, but banks can be more flexible with their offerings, says Joe Rogers, executive vice-president for Wells Fargo Home Mortgages, one of the largest jumbo lenders in the US.

This is especially useful for clients who might have variable or low W-2 income compared to their overall net worth, says Rhonda Hummel, a senior loan officer with First Capital Mortgage, in Newport Beach, California.

Such flexibility first stymied - then helped - Mr Taghavian. He got really frustrated when his lender repeatedly went over the value of his stock options, before eventually accepting them as a portion of his assets.

Another clause that aided Mr Taghavian was a "departing residence" exclusion, which meant he was able to rent his existing home and count 70 per cent of that income towards his bottom line. Otherwise, he would have had to sell the property, bought at the peak of the housing market, a time-consuming effort that wouldn't have netted him the profit he was after. - Reuters

site_title: Braving fire and brimstone
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Braving fire and brimstone

An unwed mother moves mountains to unite with her lost son, writes GEOFFREY EU

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT may be mere coincidence, of course, but the Catholic faith seems to be fertile ground to some people for human-interest stories that have little to do with religion and everything to do with retribution in the form of mental cruelty and physical abuse.

Philomena, a touching, tragic and troubling tale of a woman's quest to find her son 50 years after she was forced to give him away leaves no doubt as to who the villains are - showing, in more ways than one, that old habits die hard.

A group of heartless nuns in a remote Irish convent holds the key to a mystery wrapped in grim circumstance but the film, directed by Stephen Frears and based on the book The Lost Child of Philomena Lee by Martin Sixsmith, also has a lightness of touch that can be attributed to Frears's dexterity in dealing with a controversial topic.

The screenplay, adapted by Steve Coogan and Jeff Pope, treads the fine line between true mystery, dark drama and light comedy, and the result is a film that entertains while keeping the audience fully engaged.

Philomena, a rosy-cheeked teenager (Sophie Kennedy Clark), succumbs to a young man's advances at a fun fair and after scandalising her family with the resulting pregnancy, is sent away to a convent where the conditions are harsh and the nuns even harsher. In return for looking after unwed mothers (sinners of the worst order, as the film portrays them), the young women are made to work for years in a laundry and allotted only an hour a day to be with their babies.

Philomena's world is shattered when her three-year-old son is given away (for a fee) to adoptive parents from the United States. She has to relinquish all claims to the child but eventually marries and has a family of her own, burying her past for 50 years while wondering what happened to him and periodically trying to make contact. However, the nuns at the convent are unresponsive and deny any knowledge of her son's whereabouts.

That's when Sixsmith (played with admirable restraint by Coogan), a down-on-his-luck English journalist, hears of the story and reluctantly takes on an assignment to write a magazine article. Together with Philomena (Judi Dench), he embarks on a journey of discovery that takes them back to the convent, following a trail that leads across the Atlantic.

The wall of silence they encounter at the convent is frustrating but aided by the moral superiority of innocents in search of the truth - not to mention old home movies of a tousled-haired little boy happily at play - they eventually unearth a story of uncommon warmth. When it comes, the reveal of a life lost is both startling and beyond sad.

Philomena and Martin make for an odd couple and an unlikely pair of sleuths but one couldn't do without the other. For a story that has all the elements of tragedy, Philomena is ultimately about a triumph for a woman of courage.

"Have faith my dear, God will forgive you," says a priest to Philomena when she suffers a moment of doubt and weakness. The real question of course, is how she manages to forgive those who treated her so inhumanely.

site_title: Home ownership still a key social pillar: Boon Wan
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Home ownership still a key social pillar: Boon Wan

HDB's mission remains critical, relevant, he adds, on the 50th anniversary of Home Ownership Scheme

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Home ownership remains a key social pillar here, and the government will continue to help Singaporeans realise their dreams of owning a home, said Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan.

In a posting on his Housing Matters blog yesterday, Mr Khaw wrote that home ownership "gives Singaporeans a tangible stake in our country, financial security, and a critical sense of belonging".

"HDB estates are where Singaporeans build homes, start families and form strong bonds with their neighbours and communities. These are the lasting intangibles."

Yesterday was the 50th anniversary of the Housing & Development Board's Home Ownership for the People Scheme. The programme, introduced in 1964, offers subsidised mortgages to buyers of HDB flats. It has culminated in the Republic's high home ownership rate, where more than nine in 10 Singaporeans own a HDB flat. These apartments are home to more than 80 per cent of Singaporeans.

Mr Khaw said that former prime minister Lee Kuan Yew had envisioned making Singapore a nation of home owners through the scheme. Pioneers such as then national development minister Lim Kim San helped turn this vision into reality.

Today, a third generation of Singaporeans is embarking on their own home-ownership journey, and that desire to own a home has remained in the hearts of many Singaporeans, noted Mr Khaw.

During the 'Our Singapore Conversation" series of dialogue sessions held last year, an overwhelming 97 per cent of Singaporeans had said "yes" when asked if home ownership was still important to them. "So the core purpose of housing the nation remains the same. HDB's mission remains critical and relevant. We will continue to help Singaporeans realise their dreams of owning a home," said Mr Khaw.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

V-Day's hokey hook-ups

BT pairs up recent newsmakers for imaginary Valentine's Day dates. DYLAN TAN plays matchmaker

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Love can get so viral

He: Anton Casey, British expat who fled Singapore after his Facebook posts about poor people on stinky trains went viral

She: Steph Koh, the Singaporean-bashing online video star and alleged real-life aunty-beater

KOH, the youngster with a million accents, can give Casey, the permanent resident with a million bucks, a lesson on how to get a million hits without a million people baying for his blood. Hint: better camera angle, lots of cleavage and picking the right target (that is, the breakdowns, not the frustrated commuters, mate!). Casey can teach Koh how to enjoy Singapore for what it is. Hint: be filthy rich so you live in Sentosa Cove - where each bungalow comes with maid's quarters that are bigger than that spare HDB room Koh was fighting with her aunty over.

Pinkerton match point

He: Woody Allen, the award-winning ageing filmmaker with a dubious sexual past

She: Wendi Deng, the leery Asian cougar whose mantra surely must be old is gold

HOW they will hit it off: Woody Allen might not have Rupert Murdoch's wealth or Tony Blair's sexy body, legs and butt but one thing's for sure, age is on his side and that's going to make Wendi Deng all hot and bothered. His Asian fetish and her Pinkerton Syndrome make both of them a perfect match; whatever physique the geeky Allen lacks surely can be made up for by his filmmaking genius.

That should be enough to inspire the lovestruck teenager in her to pen another steamy missive in her hilariously broken "Engrish"; one that might read, "Oh sh*t, oh sh*t, whatever why I'm so so missing Woody? Because he is so so charming but his clothes are so yucky and brown. He has old man smell, saggy butt and short... like my Lupert last time. But I love his blain cos he's so crever... and what else and what else."

More GPS romance, less road rage

He: Quek Zhen Hao, the roly-poly Ah Beng road bully whose haircut is as bad as his driving and road manners

She: Samantha, the Scarlett-Johansson-voiced OS from Spike Jonze's futuristic rom-com She

When it comes to driving, every highway is Quek Zhen Hao's grandfather's road.

How else would you explain the new highway codes he's made up to justify his road antics (tailgate to "warn" road hoggers; brake immediately after successfully overtaking; stop vehicle anywhere to confront other road users if they have a problem with said codes). Sure, he's sorry now and asking to be punished (take away his licence; he could use the exercise anyway); but perhaps all that could have been prevented if he had an in-car GPS system pre-loaded with the OS that was featured in She. Long-distance drives will become less lonely with Scarlett Johansson's seductively husky and sexy voice providing company while giving directions. And like a real girlfriend, he'll only have himself to blame when she goes quiet and gives him the cold shoulder treatment when he lets road rage get the better of him.

An uninviting affair

He: Dr Tan Cheng Bock, presidential candidate who was recently uninvited from Istana Chinese New Year party

He: Ken Lim, owner of Don Quijote, a Spanish restaurant in Dempsey who dropped the F-bomb in an email reply to a customer who got turned away

IF only he'd won the 2011 Presidential Elections, Dr Tan wouldn't have to lament missing out on this year's Istana Chinese New Year party which he was unceremoniously uninvited from at the eleventh hour.

He's probably a little sore about missing out on the red packet the Prime Minister was distributing to the Pioneer Generation (no loss, Dr Tan, there wasn't any cash in it; only two gold chocolate coins which some of the diabetic senior citizens complained they couldn't eat anyway) but at least, he didn't take to Facebook to shame the host... like one diner did after he was declined service at a Spanish restaurant in Dempsey and proceeded to email the owner about his experience.

Unsatisfied with the reply he got, the latter published Don Quijote's owner Ken Lim's succinct eight-word response in full on Facebook to make him look like a Tapas Nazi. Both Dr Tan and Lim will have plenty to talk about over dinner regarding customer service and it can be held at the Indonesian VIP hospitality suite at the Singapore Air Show which we hear is unoccupied after the haze-starters too were struck off the guest list in the midst of a diplomatic row.

Seeing red, but not roses

He: Alex Ferguson, the red-nosed ex-manager of Manchester United

He: David Moyes, the current red-faced manager of the Red Devils

THESE two will have plenty of catching up to do; with Moyes doing most of the talking probably as he tries to explain how he's undone Fergie's 26 years of hard work in just six months. Week in, week out, the Internet trolls have been hard at work with new howlers after each defeat - "Be careful if you are driving past Old Trafford this week, a lot of people have been picking up three points there recently"; "A Manchester United lamp would make a nice birthday present because, like the team, it sits pretty in the middle of the table"; "It is so hard to win at Old Trafford because even Manchester United can't." Ironically, Moyes worked hard for 11 years trying to get his former team Everton to outperform their Merseyside rivals; with him in charge of the Red Devils now, it's finally happening.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Demand for JTC land, space down sharply

Net allocation of PIL falls 61% while that of RBF swings into negative territory

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

INDUSTRIAL landlord and developer JTC yesterday reported that net allocation of prepared industrial land (PIL) and ready-built facilities (RBF) declined sharply in 2013 from a year ago.

Net allocation refers to the total amount of land or space leased to companies (gross allocation) minus returns or terminations.

According to JTC's latest quarterly facilities report, net allocation of PIL (land offered by JTC for lessees to develop their own industrial facilities) fell by more than half (61 per cent) from 176.3 hectares in 2012 to 69.1 ha last year.

Gross allocation dipped by 4.4 per cent to 267.7 ha, while returns almost doubled from 103.7 ha in 2012 to 198.6 ha last year.

Land on temporary occupation licence (TOL) continued to form the bulk (55 per cent) of total returns, which JTC said was an expected outcome given the short-term nature (typically three years) of TOL.

"In fact, a significant amount of returned TOL land came from Jurong Island, and in particular, chemical companies which were allocated land for short-term construction laydown purposes," a JTC spokesman said.

Last year, 35 per cent of PIL was allocated to manufacturing companies, 46 per cent to other manufacturing-related and supporting industries, and the remaining 19 per cent to logistics companies.

Meanwhile, net allocation of RBF, which include various types of factories built by JTC in anticipation of demand, came to to negative 20,700 square metres last year, against a positive 9,400 sq m in 2012.

This came as gross allocation fell 25 per cent to 55,900 sq m, due mainly to lower allocation in the business park segment where a total of 5,800 sq m was allocated last year compared to 18,300 sq m in 2012. JTC attributed the strong take-up in 2012 to the completion of the CleanTech One building.

RBF returns, on the other hand, rose 18 per cent to 76,600 sq m last year. Most of the space returned - 47,400 sq m or 62 per cent - came from the standard factory segment, said JTC.

The occupancy rate of RBF also dipped from 2012 to 94.8 per cent last year, registering a demand of three million sq m against a supply of 3.2 million sq m - a "healthy" rate, according to JTC.

For the fourth quarter of 2013 alone, gross allocation of PIL reached 118.1 ha - JTC's highest since the second quarter of 2011. That for RBF was 13,500 sq m, down from 18,600 sq m in the third quarter.

JTC's MedTech One and CleanTech Two buildings will be completed in the first and third quarters of this year. Aside from these, Fusionopolis' Towers A through C, as well as BioMed One and aeroSpace buildings, will be completed between 2014 and 2015.

site_title: SBS Transit's full-year profit falls 39.8%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SBS Transit's full-year profit falls 39.8%

Revenue rises 6.9% but is outpaced by total operating expenses

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUS and rail operator SBS Transit posted a 39.8 per cent drop in full-year profit as higher costs outweighed revenue growth in its key businesses.

Net profit for the year ended Dec 31 fell to $11.2 million, or 3.62 cents per share, as net profit margin shrank by one percentage point to 1.3 per cent.

Revenue actually rose 6.9 per cent to $847.3 million, but topline expansion was outpaced by total operating expenses, which grew 8.5 per cent to $831.8 million for the year.

SBS is proposing a final dividend of 0.9 cent per share, down from its 1.65-cent-per-share payout the year before.

SBS shares closed flat at $1.27 yesterday before the results were announced.

Both of SBS' key business segments of bus and rail incurred losses for the year.

The bus business narrowed its operating loss by 2.5 per cent to $14.3 million as higher costs offset higher bus revenue and cheaper fuel. The average daily ridership increased by 3.4 per cent, but average fares declined, SBS reported.

Rail operations fell into a $5.8 million operating loss from an operating profit of $4.9 million a year ago as preparations for the start of the Downtown Line led to higher staff costs. Average daily ridership for the North-East Line gained 6.1 per cent, while the Light Rail Transit systems saw an 11.5 per cent increase in ridership.

Advertising operating profit also slumped by 13.5 per cent, to $20.3 million, as bus ad sales slowed.

The one bright spot came in rentals, where new shops and renewals helped rental operating profit to increase by 30.7 per cent, to $15.4 million.

The year ahead continues to look bumpy with bus ridership growth expected to moderate to a slower pace.

The opening of the Downtown Line, however, is expected to boost rail ridership as well as advertising and rental sales. Staff costs and other operating expenses, however, are expected to continue growing.

"The outlook for bus and rail segments will continue to be challenging," SBS stated.

SBS is a 75 per cent-owned subsidiary of listed ComfortDelGro Corp, which also runs taxi services in Singapore.

ComfortDelGro will report its full-year results after the close today.

site_title: Asian hedge fund capital hits new high of US$112b: report
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asian hedge fund capital hits new high of US$112b: report

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

TOTAL capital invested into Asian hedge funds reached around US$112 billion last year, surpassing the record set in 2007, according to the HFR Asian Hedge Fund Industry Report. The previous high of US$111 billion was recorded in 2007, before the onset of the global financial crisis, said HFR, a Chicago-based firm that specialises in hedge fund analysis.

Total assets managed by Asian hedge funds were boosted by investor allocations and performance gains, the report said. In the fourth quarter last year, investors allocated some US$4.2 billion of new capital in Asian hedge funds, the biggest quarterly inflow since the first quarter of 2008 when HFR started collecting data.

HFR president Kenneth Heinz said: "2013 was an exceptional year for the Asian hedge fund industry, posting strong performance gains across the region as assets surpassed the pre-financial crisis peak, both despite divergent equity market trends across developed and emerging Asia.

"The Asian hedge fund industry has now emerged as the preferred mechanism for both global and Asian investors to participate in the exciting growth opportunities while mitigating complex risks associated with quantitative easing, currency devaluation or prospective RMB appreciation and structural concerns regarding banking institutions. Despite emerging market-centric currency and equity volatility to begin 2014, investors are likely to increase allocations to Asian hedge funds as these themes evolve in H1 2014."

Asian capital inflows were strongest into Japanese-focused hedge funds, reaching US$4.5 billion last year. This was followed by inflows into emerging Asia funds, at US$3 billion. Data showed that two hedge fund strategies were in vogue: the equity hedge and event driven. In Q4, investors allocated US$2.5 billion to Asian equity-hedge funds and US$1.4 billion to Asian event-driven funds. Other funds attracted smaller inflows.

The equity hedge - or long/short hedge - is the most common hedge strategy. It involves buying stocks which are undervalued and shorting those which are overvalued. This can be executed by pledging long positions in expected gainers as collateral for short positions in stocks which are expected to make losses.

With an event-driven strategy, hedge funds can invest in distressed companies, such as those going through a bankruptcy. This is done, for instance, by buying senior debt - which is likely to experience the smallest haircut if the situation calls for it. The fund can wait for the company to go through a successful restructuring and sell the bonds for a profit. An event-driven strategy can also be executed through activism, where funds try to get onto corporate boards to steer a company according to their strategic direction.

site_title: A return to slow, patient, epic storytelling
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A return to slow, patient, epic storytelling

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

REMEMBER the theories of dreaming in that dazzling Christopher Nolan film Inception? One minute of dreamtime is the equivalent of 20 minutes in real life. So if you take 20 minutes to eat a steak, you'd take just one minute to dream the act of eating a steak from start to finish. Now, if you're dreaming within a dream, one minute of intra-dreaming supposedly feels like 400 minutes of real life.

Stan Lai's magnum opus of a play is called A Dream Within A Dream. And within its 7½-hour endurance test of a runtime, it criss-crosses continents, eras, characters and realities to tell a story-within-a-story-within-a-story: A doctor's attempts to get close to one of her patients prompts the latter to narrate the story of his life and friendship with another patient, who in turn narrates her own life story as a Shanghainese courtesan.

Condensing 80 years of history into 7½ hours, A Dream has none of the economy, thrilling action and high-tech concepts of Nolan's Inception, which also tells stories within stories. In fact, some reviewers have complained that Lai's story of an architect's romances that is linked to the dramatic upheavals of a courtesan's fortunes is so sprawling, it could have been cut by half without losing its essence.

But doing so would certainly diminish the languid, meditative quality of the story that elegantly evokes several histories and lifetimes; doing so would also weaken the communal underpinnings of Lai's brand of theatre experience.

For Lai has always been interested in bringing Chinese theatre back to its communal roots and narrative traditions, before Hollywood and YouTube quickened the pace of stories and replaced lengthy emotional trajectories with visual cues and narrative shorthands.

Lai does here what he doesn't do for any of his other plays - place some 240 members of the audience within a "lotus pond" arrangement surrounded by a square perimeter of platforms. The action occurs all around and in between the audience, who are seated on swivel chairs to facilitate their 360-degree view.

As one of the 240, one feels like a fly on the wall witnessing up close the drama of lovers and families unfold.

One feels not just the interwovenness of the stories, but also the intractable pull of Fate intervening now and again to set the characters on predestined paths.

Though A Dream Like A Dream sags sometimes under the weight of its own slow, patient and old-fashioned form of storytelling, there's still so much to admire in its epic narrative tapestry, technical ambition and logistical daring.

site_title: Powered by sustainability
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Powered by sustainability

Published

Thu, Feb 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT'S odd that an art festival that's all about light would be worried about saving electricity, but sustainability is one of the themes of next month's i Light Marina Bay 2014 next month.

The three-week long night festival, organised by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), will see over 25 colourful art installations from 11 countries decorating the Marina Bay waterfront area. In line with the theme Light+HeART, the artworks were chosen for their use of recycled or biodegradable materials, and carry a message of sustainability. The festival itself is powered by the energy savings from URA's "Switch Off, Turn Up" campaign, which encourages companies around the Marina Bay area to switch off unnecessary lights and raise the temperatures of their air-conditioners.

Here are some of this year's highlights:

1.26 Singapore by Janet Echelman (USA), The Float @ Marina Bay

In 2010, an earthquake in Chile shortened the earth's day by 1.26-microseconds, and that event gave American artist Janet Echelman the title for her colourful tsunami-like sculpture - 1.26.

The work was inspired by the traditional craft of fish net-weaving and lace-making, where Echelman used these materials to recreate the effects of the earthquake with research from NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

1.26 discusses the causes and effects of natural disasters and highlights how various populations are linked by their fight against the results of climate change.

The Pool by Jen Lewin Studio (USA) Marina Bay waterfront promenade (near The Promontory @ Marina Bay)

This large interactive artwork by American artist Jen Lewin has absolutely nothing to do with swimming or water. Instead, its name refers to the verb "pool" and the idea of things being joined together or combined. Some 100 interactive circular pads are arranged in concentric circles, where each pad reacts to foot pressure, as well as the speed and position that the foot lands on - creating swirls and splashes of colour. The work allows several people to interact with it at any one time as it spans a large open space - a common trait among the artist's works.

CLOUD by Catlind r c Brown & Wayne Garrett (Canada), The Float @ Marina Bay

Up to 7,000 new and re-appropriated light bulbs make up this installation. Passers-by can pull on strings to switch some of them on and off. As the light in different parts of the "cloud" flicker, they mimic the look of an actual cloud when lightning flashes in a thunderstorm.

Only 200 of these bulbs are actually working energy-efficient bulbs that produce the glow, while the rest are recycled incandescent bulbs that are only meant to be an ornamental layer.

Artists Catlind r c Brown & Wayne Garrett combined these traditional lightbulbs with modern energy-efficient ones with the intention of drawing people to interact and work together to turn the entire sculpture off or on.

Light Rain by Troika (UK), The Float @ Marina Bay (under the Seating Gallery)

What do you do when you're walking outdoors and it starts to rain? Run, of course. And chances are when you're running in the rain, there isn't much time to notice and appreciate the falling raindrops.

But with Troika's work titled Light Rain, festival-goers can comfortably watch the hypnotic pitter-patter of rain falling on the ground without getting themselves wet, as light is projected onto the ground forming the rhythmic rippling pattern of water droplets.

The piece created by artists Sebastien Noel, Eva Rucki, and Conny Freyer aims to explore the simple and often neglected wonders of nature especially in the context of bustling city life.

Digital Wattle by Out of the Dark (New Zealand), Near The Float @ Marina Bay

Perhaps you've heard of the Golden Wattle, which is a tree that produces fluffy yellow flowers and also happens to be the floral emblem of Australia.

That was what inspired a series of contemporary light installations titled Digital Wattle, a "tree" of glowing orbs of light, created by the New Zealand-based company Out of the Dark.

This artwork explores the co-existence of various individual ethnic groups in a city, where the changing colours of the "flowers" represent the mixing of new cultures.

i Light Marina Bay 2014 runs from March 7 to March 30 around the Marina Bay waterfront, from 7.30pm to 11pm daily. Admission is free. Log on to

www.ilightmarinabay.sg

for more information

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SIA, Airbus form flight training venture

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore Airlines (SIA) is flying into new territory with a flight training centre in a joint venture (JV) with Airbus that will cost $80 million upfront.

The facility, known as the Airbus Asia Training Centre (AATC), will be 55 per cent-owned by Airbus and 45 per cent-owned by SIA. The initial investment will be contributed by both parties in proportion to their respective stakes in the joint venture.

"It is a new line of business for SIA. We're excited to get into this venture because it adds to our portfolio of companies, and is something that we've been known to do very well in - which is train our pilots," Goh Choon Phong, SIA's CEO, said at a media briefing at the Singapore Airshow yesterday.

The AATC will start out at the existing SIA Training Centre near Changi Airport, and move to Seletar Aerospace Park when a dedicated facility is completed.

"Eventually, we do expect the business to grow rapidly, and Seletar will be where we will expand further," Mr Goh said. Asked when the move would take place, he replied: "We will have to work on that because . . . we have to go through the regulatory approvals."

Expected to be operational before year-end, the AATC will provide training services to airlines in the region, using full-flight simulators for Airbus A320, A330, A340, A350 and A380 aircraft types.

In response to queries on what proportion of AATC's revenue would come from third-party business, Airbus CEO and president Fabrice Brégier said it would be premature to answer that. "Our goal is clearly to attract as many Asian customers as possible . . . so the question for me is not this percentage, but whether in the coming years, we have to invest jointly in more simulators here."

This training centre will be the latest in Airbus's global network of training centres, including those in Beijing, Miami and Toulouse.

SIA's move into this area comes at a time when the industry faces mounting demand for trained pilots. Airbus had previously estimated that from 2013 to 2032, the Asia-Pacific region's carriers will take delivery of 10,940 new passenger and cargo aircraft worth US$1.8 trillion. This would make up 37 per cent of the 29,200 planes forecast to be required globally.

The deal is not expected to have a material effect on the net tangible assets or earnings per share of the SIA group for its financial year ending March 31, 2014, it said in a statement yesterday. The group's counter closed at $9.95 in trading yesterday, up 20 cents.

site_title: Big banks resist lure of new offices in NY
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Big banks resist lure of new offices in NY

Many opting to renew leases after considering moves to new skyscrapers

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] As Manhattan developers plan millions of square feet of office towers featuring the most modern amenities, some of their biggest potential tenants have decided they're better off staying in their current homes.

Five of the six largest New York leases since the end of 2012 have been renewals, according to data from brokerage Newmark Grubb Knight Frank.

Credit Suisse Group AG, Citigroup Inc and UBS AG - the types of large financial companies that traditionally have made up the core of the city's office market - opted to stay put after considering moves to new skyscrapers.

"Major financial institutions are not expanding dramatically," said Joseph Harbert, eastern region president of Colliers International, a commercial-property brokerage with offices in Manhattan. "If you're going to lease up a new building, you're going to have to do it with other tenants."

The renewals highlight the challenge faced by developers seeking tenants for the technologically advanced towers planned at Manhattan's World Trade Center site and the Far West Side.

Financial companies are scaling back space needs or seeking to cut costs, while many of the technology and media firms that were the market's most avid office consumers over the last three years have largely chosen older buildings.

Manhattan has more than 25 million square feet of new office space either just completed, under construction or ready to start, according to Newmark data. Another 6.3 million sq ft of offices are in the planning stages.

At the same time, the Real Estate Board of New York, the trade organisation for the city's commercial landlords, is pushing for a revival of former Mayor Michael Bloomberg's aborted attempt to re-zone the office districts surrounding Grand Central Terminal to replace old and obsolete towers.

The group cited a study by the city's Independent Budget Office issued in September that projected that the city needs about 52 million sq ft of new office space between now and 2040 to accommodate expected job growth and space that could be lost to conversions and demolitions.

It's an "open question" whether there will be enough appetite for new offices to fill that amount of space, Mr Harbert said.

The trade organisation's president Steven Spinola argues that the 2013 data represent current market realities that could reverse abruptly. The average Manhattan office building is more than 70 years old, according to trade group.

The tenant mix has shifted more to technology, advertising, media and information firms that tend to take smaller blocks of space. Such "creative" companies represented 24 per cent of the leasing market last year, about the same share as financial services, according to brokerage Cushman & Wakefield Inc.

In 2005, financials made up 29 per cent of the market, while the creative industry was only 17 per cent. Law firms have fallen to 8 per cent of the market from 11 per cent.

Of the 344 leases last year by financial companies - including banks, hedge funds and private equity firms - only 20 were for more than 50,000 sq ft, according to Cushman.

The "vast majority" of tenants seeking 250,000 sq ft or more - enough to anchor a new skyscraper - have chosen to remain in their existing locations, Isaac Zion, co-chief investment officer for SL Green Realty Corp, said at an investor presentation in December. The trend is likely to continue, he said in a phone interview.

"When you relocate, you've got to spend all that capital at once," said Mr Zion, whose company is Manhattan's biggest owner of office buildings. "If you stay where you are, you can manage that over a long period of time. You can stage it better to spread out that risk. Once you move, you have to do it at once. Then what if your business changes? What if things evolve?"

Many companies are opting to stay put because of a shortage of new construction in East Midtown, a "prime location" for office tenants, said SL Green chief executive Marc Holliday.

Last month, Zurich- based Credit Suisse said it intends to remain at 11 Madison Avenue, a 1931 tower once used as a setting by Woody Allen for the movie Radio Days, for its US headquarters.

The second-largest Swiss bank came close to a deal to anchor a skyscraper at Brookfield Office Properties Inc's Manhattan West, according to brokers at Cushman & Wakefield, which represented the developer.

Brookfield is planning four million square feet of new offices at its Manhattan West project, part of an effort to transform the now largely industrial area west of Pennsylvania Station into a commercial district.

The area also is where Related Cos is building Hudson Yards, a 17.4 million sq ft development built largely over a 26-acre (11-hectare) train yard. About 10 million sq ft will be offices.

Credit Suisse's decision came about four weeks after Citigroup extended its lease for 2.6 million sq ft at SL Green's 388-390 Greenwich St, in Tribeca, last year's biggest New York office lease. The bank is poised to leave its headquarters at 399 Park Ave, according to landlord Boston Properties Inc.

Citigroup, the third-biggest US bank, had weighed anchoring the proposed Two World Trade Center tower in Lower Manhattan, according to two people with knowledge of the negotiations who asked not to be named because the process was private.

It also rejected a move to the Hudson Yards project earlier in its decision-making process.

A Citigroup spokesman declined to comment on its space decisions.

In December 2012, UBS renewed its lease for about 860,000 sq ft at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, an office tower near Rockefeller Center. Switzerland's largest bank was in negotiations to lease offices at the trade centre site before withdrawing from talks in 2011, say people with knowledge of the matter.

Credit Suisse and Citigroup intend to rework and upgrade their properties.

Credit Suisse plans to move to the less-expensive lower floors of 11 Madison, and spend the next four years renovating those offices, according to a statement to staff by Rob Shafir, the bank's CEO for the Americas. It expects to save close to US$700 million over the life of the lease.

As a general rule, moving into new space is cheaper in the long run than retrofitting old offices, said Richard Bernstein, a New York-based executive vice- chairman at brokerage Cassidy Turley. New space is more energy-efficient and conducive to open layouts that allow more people to fit into less space, he said.

Meanwhile, many technology companies, such as Google Inc, Twitter Inc, Facebook Inc and EBay Inc, have chosen to move their New York operations into vintage buildings in the area roughly between 30th and Canal streets known as Midtown South, rather than to new construction.

Midtown South is "the centre of New York's technology universe", Jonathan Mazur, Newmark Grubb's capital markets research director, wrote in a report last week.

With large financial companies staying out of the market for new towers, at least for now, landlords are going to have to offer "significant concessions", said Mr Bernstein of Cassidy Turley.

"Rents will hold up," he said. "But in order to realise the kind of absorption they need, until we see signs of more growth, I think they're going to have to take that kind of strategy." - Bloomberg

Portugal drawing property investors once more

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LISBON] Property investors are returning to Portugal, bolstered by signs of an economic recovery and the approaching end of the country's bailout programme, according to broker Cushman & Wakefield Inc.

Spending on commercial real estate tripled to 322 million euros (S$554 million) in 2013 compared with a year earlier, Eric van Leuven, managing partner at Cushman & Wakefield in Portugal, said at a press conference in Lisbon yesterday. Home sales in Lisbon increased 40 per cent in the first nine months of 2013 from the whole of 2012.

"There is more interest and a greater willingness to invest in real estate in Portugal," Mr van Leuven said. "There were a lot of people hiding their money under the mattress, waiting for an opportunity."

Last year's total remains low compared with the boom that preceded the financial crisis. Investment in Portuguese commercial real estate was more than one billion euros in 2007 and has averaged 600 million euros a year over the past decade, according to Cushman.

The southern European country's economy may expand more than one per cent in 2014 after coming out of the worst recession in at least 25 years in the second quarter of 2013, Economy Minister Antonio Pires de Lima said last month.

Signs that the economy is recovering have played a major role in terms of attracting investors back to the property market, Mr van Leuven said. He said that he was "optimistic" about 2014 because investment in the property market has continued to increase this year.

Portugal is trying to regain full access to debt markets as the 78 billion euro rescue programme, put in place in 2011 by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, approaches its end in May. -Bloomberg

site_title: India's luxury hotels in a flux as growth slows
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

India's luxury hotels in a flux as growth slows

Some players bet on future growth and expand as some quit

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[MUMBAI] Less than nine months after opening the first hotel in Mumbai under its brand, Hong Kong luxury chain operator Shangri-La Asia handed the keys back to the owner.

Now, US-based Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide is in talks with the same owner to take over management of the property under its St Regis brand, sources said, part of a shakeout at the luxury segment of India's ailing hotel industry.

Slowing economic growth and an oversupply of new hotels conceived during the boom years of 2006 and 2007 have led to falling room and occupancy rates in India, straining relationships between hotel owners and the global chains brought in to run them.

But while some global operators are leaving, others like InterContinental Hotels Group, Hyatt Hotels Corp and Starwood are jumping in, using the now unbranded hotels to accelerate their expansion in a country they believe has long-term potential.

"More than half the future deals we are looking at are conversions in the four and five-star category," said Dilip Puri, India head and regional vice-president for South Asia at Starwood, which currently runs 38 hotels in India and plans to have 100 in operation or under construction by 2015.

Mr Puri declined to comment on Starwood's interest in the erstwhile Shangri-La. The hotel, now called the Palladium, is owned by mall developer Phoenix Mills and both the company and Shangri-La declined to comment on why the partnership ended.

Six years ago, a night at a luxury hotel in the Delhi region cost on average 10,429 rupees - about US$259 at the time and on par with several five-star hotels in Singapore. Occupancy rates were an enviable 74 per cent, according to hospitality consultants HVS, as business travellers flocked to India, an economy that was then growing at nearly 10 per cent.

Since then, economic growth has halved, reducing the flow of corporate guests who make up about 70 per cent of the business for five-star hotels in cities like Delhi and Mumbai.

Average room rates in the capital region have also almost halved to around 6,850 rupees (US$110), while occupancy rates were 55 per cent, according to HVS. The declining economy, and revenues, have sparked a blame-game between owners and operators, prompting the "reflagging" of several properties.

Operators say the owners are demanding unrealistic returns after over-leveraging themselves, while owners say operators over-promised on performance.

"The relationship is breaking because somebody made a promise and the reality is far from the promise - both due to economic reasons and sometimes due to performance lapses," said Ashish Jakhanwala, chief executive of Samhi, an Indian firm that owns hotels.

Global players with long-term ambitions are encouraged by the prospects for India's hospitality sector, where revenues are expected to more than double to US$36 billion by 2018 from US$17 billion in 2008, according to research firm Technopak Advisors.

Starwood is emerging as one of the more aggressive players in India. About 86 per cent of the company's pipeline of new rooms is outside the United States, mostly in Asia Pacific.

India is currently Starwood's fourth-largest market by hotel numbers and by the end of next year, it will move up to third place, overtaking Canada. By building its brand domestically, Starwood also hopes to court the loyalty of Indians travelling abroad.

Other operators are also expanding.

Hilton, controlled by private equity giant Blackstone Group, exited a handful of properties in India last year while opening three new hotels. This month, it also announced plans to open its first Conrad hotel next year.

Rival Hyatt, which runs 17 hotels in India and has 40 under development, is in advanced talks to manage a 228-room Delhi property that until the end of 2013 was a Hilton, according to sources.

London-based InterContinental, which runs 18 hotels in India and aims to have 57 over the next four to five years, is also seeking to take over two hotels that were run by Hilton in New Delhi. - Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Malaysia's GDP expands 5.1% in Q4 last year

This caps overall growth figure for 2013 at 4.7%

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUOYED by private-sector demand and an improved performance in exports, Malaysia's gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 5.1 per cent in Q4 last year, capping the overall growth figure for 2013 at 4.7 per cent.

While there have been concerns that the government's subsidy rationalisation measures could crimp spending, this was not reflected in the Q4 figures, which showed that consumer spending had not eased off yet.

Even so, the pace of expansion of private consumption eased to 7.3 per cent in Q4 from 8.2 per cent in the preceding quarter.

"Household spending continued to be supported by stable employment conditions and sustained wage growth especially in domestic-oriented sectors," Bank Negara, the central bank, said in a statement yesterday.

Growth in public consumption eased to 5.1 per cent from 7.1 per cent in the previous quarter. This was largely due to lower outlays for government emoluments.

Private investment continued to blaze away, registering growth of 16.5 per cent, up from 15.2 per cent in the previous quarter, thanks largely to Prime Minister Najib Razak's Economic Transformation Programme which sets great store on capital-intensive infrastructure works.

Public investment shrank 2.1 per cent against a smaller contraction in Q3, reflecting lower spending by public enterprises and the smaller development budget for the year.

On the supply side, all sectors, except for commodities, grew strongly. Commodities declined owing to the lower production of oil, palm oil and rubber.

What will concern the government is the headline inflation figure. The central bank said inflation during the last quarter jumped to 3 per cent from 2.2 per cent on the back of rises in fuel and sugar prices.

The trade surplus widened to RM27.4 billion (S$10.4 billion) in Q4. The good news is that the current account surplus on the country's balance of payments in 2013 was a comfortable RM37 billion, though that is considerably lower than the RM50 billion registered for 2012.

More disquieting was the fact that net outflows accelerated in Q4 to RM9.7 billion from RM1.5 billion in the previous quarter. The outflows could accelerate considerably this year as the US Federal Reserve's tapering effort quickens.

The central bank's international reserves stood at a comfortable US$133.1 billion at the end of January.

"While domestic demand is expected to moderate following the ongoing fiscal consolidation, the external sector is expected to benefit from the improving global conditions," noted Bank Negara. "The growth momentum is therefore expected to remain on a steady trajectory."

SUBSCRIBERS

Biosensors Q3 gain drops 55% to US$11.1m

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BIOSENSORS International's net profit for the third quarter ended December fell 55 per cent to US$11.1 million from US$24.9 million a year ago.

Revenue crept up one per cent to US$82.5 million from US$81.3 million. This was largely due to growth in product revenue, which was offset by lower licensing revenue. Product revenue grew 6 per cent year-on-year to US$71.7 million, even as licensing and royalty revenue fell 21 per cent to US$10.8 million.

Basic earnings per share (EPS) fell to 0.65 US cents, from 1.41 US cents (before exceptional items) and 1.45 US cents (after exceptional items).

"In the third quarter, the operating environment for our business continued to be challenging. EMEA (Europe, the Middle East and Africa) and APAC (Asia Pacific) were the leading drug-eluting stents (DES) sales growth regions, although lower average selling prices remained as headwinds. In China, the weak market sentiment continued to cause some pressure on our revenue there," said Biosensors CEO Jack Wang.

For the nine months ended December, revenue dipped 2 per cent to US$242.2 million from US$247.4 million because of lower licensing and royalty revenue. Net profit fell 60 per cent, from US$85.7 million to US$34.5 million. Excluding exceptional items - which include provision for the restructuring of European operations and fair-value adjustments of derivatives - net profit for the nine-month period was US$34.7 million, compared with US$81.9 million a year ago. Basic EPS fell from 4.75 US cents to 2.03 US cents before exceptional items, and from 4.97 US cents to 2.01 US cents after exceptional items. Net asset value as at end-December was 73.85 US cents, compared with 72.43 US cents at the end of March.

Given lower royalty income from Terumo, overall weak market conditions in the short run and lower average selling prices in various markets, the company expects sales growth for the fiscal year ending March 2014 to be weak.

The company expects revenue to be comparable with FY2013.

"Looking ahead, in our core DES franchise, we anticipate key regions such as EMEA and APAC to continue to lead growth. In China, we expect the market sentiment to gradually improve over time. We will also continue to work closely with Terumo in Japan to improve Nobori sales," said Dr Wang.

Biosensors collaborates with Terumo Corp to promote the Nobori DES system at specific specialist cardiology centres in Japan. The counter ended unchanged at 87 cents yesterday.

site_title: Nordbank ready to sell shipping loan package
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Nordbank ready to sell shipping loan package

Move follows failed 300m euro attempt late last year

Published

Wed, Feb 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HAMBURG] HSH Nordbank AG, the world's largest financier of vessels, is preparing a portfolio of shipping loans for sale after a previous package worth about 300 million euros (S$516 million) failed to attract investors.

"We dropped one transaction at the end of last year, as the portfolio made up of container ships and bulk carriers wasn't ideal with regard to the size and age of the bulk carriers," Wolfgang Topp, who heads the Hamburg-based bank's restructuring unit, said in an interview.

"Now we're wrapping up a new portfolio, which we expect to sell in the market by the end of the first quarter," he said.

The size of the transaction will resemble a deal agreed on with Greek shipping company Navios Group in April 2013, with about 10 ships, he said.

Under that transaction, the bank was able to reduce its risks on loans by about US$300 million. Piraeus, Greece-based Navios paid US$130 million for about 40 per cent of the loans and guaranteed to operate five tankers and five container ships for at least six years, Nordbank said in a statement at the time.

The remaining US$170 million is converted into a participating loan for 10 years, in the course of which Nordbank will receive 80 per cent of the returns generated by the ships, excluding operating and capital costs, according to the statement.

Germany's top shipping lenders face rising credit default risks this year as bad debt from clients struggling to emerge from the industry's crisis mounts, Moody's Investors Service said in December.

Nordbank confirmed recent comments by chief executive officer Constantin von Oesterreich that the lender expects "a clear triple-digit-million-euro loss after tax" for 2013, as already indicated on April 11 of last year.

Contributing to the 2013 loss, the bank set aside 127 million euros in provisions after it discovered last year that traders executed questionable dividend arbitrage, or dividend stripping, with a "handful of foreign brokers", chief financial officer Stefan Ermisch said in December. The trades generated tax credits on capital gains for deals that the state-owned bank didn't pay tax on in the first place, he said.

To cover potential losses at Nordbank, Hamburg and Schleswig-Holstein raised a guarantee to 10 billion euros from seven billion euros, which was approved by the European Union on a preliminary basis.

This year, the bank expects to post "a significant profit before and after tax" on lower risk provisions. - Bloomberg
