content:
Tweak cooling measures, urges Leng Beng

He suggests taxing foreign buyers who offload properties within 3-4 years instead

Published

Fri, Feb 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

IT is time for the government to tweak some of its property cooling measures such as the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD), given concerns over the global economy and signs that the property market here is slowing down, said Kwek Leng Beng, executive chairman of Hong Leong Group Singapore and property developer City Developments.

He suggested that the government consider lifting the hefty stamp duties imposed on foreigners when they buy property here, and replace it with a tax on sellers who offload their property three or four years after snapping it up.

"Everybody is attracting foreigners today to their countries. We should attract foreigners. But if . . . you penalise them by having to pay additional tax, then they (will) say you don't welcome me.

"So why don't you (the government) just say, if you sell within three years, four years, then I tax you. You come in (and buy property) I don't want to tax. I think this is one way," said Mr Kwek, who was speaking to reporters on the sidelines of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) Spring Festival lunch yesterday.

The government can also consider lifting ABSD for locals - who are subject to the additional tax when they purchase more than one home - and permanent residents, he said.

"I don't think there is a lot of speculation. The prices are high because developers have got no land stock . . . in the land bank. (At the same time) they have to survive, they cannot let business come to a standstill.

"So I think for some of these, we will (need to) have a dialogue with the government . . . I think the government has the bigger picture. We leave it to them. They are trying their best. They want a stabilised market. We will cooperate with them."

Mr Kwek's comments come amid signs that the housing market is slowing down. Statistics from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) showed that for the last three months of 2013, private home prices fell 0.9 per cent - the first quarterly drop in about two years. For the full year, URA's overall private home price index ended 1.1 per cent higher - a smaller gain compared with the 2.8 per cent recorded in 2012.

Besides working closely with the government to build a healthy property market, developers will also work closely with the government on the next phase of nation-building and real estate development to achieve a "distinctive, high-quality living environment for all", said Chia Boon Kuah, president of Redas.

This means that construction activity will remain at high levels and continue unabated for several years, making it "ever more important to re-focus our collective attention on workplace safety and welfare of the some 30,000 migrant workers in our industry", he said.

"As developers, we should support our contractors in showing duty of care for the health, safety and welfare of these workers. This enhances productivity, which, in the long run, translates into benefits for all."

Last month, a worksite accident in Sentosa left one foreign worker dead and 10 others injured.

The death of the worker takes the number of fatalities at worksite accidents to nine in just over a month, prompting Acting Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin to write on his blog that the recent spate of accidents was "not tenable".

Developers and contractors should, therefore, "up the ante on workplace safety training and communication" and "recognise the contributions these workers make to our country", said Mr Chia, who is also group president and chief executive of developer GuocoLand.

Redas would hold a forum to identify and discuss common causes behind construction workplace accidents, challenges to risk reduction and best practices, he said.

Yesterday, Redas presented Mr Kwek with its inaugural Redas Lifetime Achievement Award, which it established to honour a pioneering group of industry leaders.

The Redas citation said that Mr Kwek has helped to shape the property industry and guided Redas through several difficult periods, such as the property crash in the early 1980s.

Together with other developers, he also helped to reform the sector by introducing the Developers' Fund to protect buyers. This ensured that money collected for a specific project could not be used for other purposes.

Mr Kwek received his award from Education Minister Heng Swee Keat, who was guest-of-honour at the event.

Truly, madly, deeply

Seasoned concierges around town share their most memorable requests

Published

Fri, Feb 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

"ONE of our members was planning her wedding and among her list of guests was a long lost nanny from the time when she was child. We didn't have any information on her besides a photograph and the name she would often fondly call her by. With help from our regional offices and after much searching, we were able to track her down and make the necessary arrangements for her to attend the wedding," says Caroline Lam, executive director at Quintessentially Lifestyle.

"A businessman client had a meeting in Shanghai and before boarding a plane home in the evening, he called to ask for 1,000 roses to be sent to a girl in Shanghai by midnight. We managed to source for 1,000 roses to be sent to the girl by his deadline," says Andrew Quake, general manager, Aspire Lifestyles Singapore and senior director of global accounts, Aspire Lifestyle Asia.

"My personal favourite is from a husband who asked us to make a CD with the number one song of each year that he and his wife had been together since their marriage," says James Eyton, Asia Pacific CEO of LesConcierges, supporting partner of Visa Concierge Services.

"We arranged a bathing ritual in our elegant Presidential Suite bathroom which overlooked the city from the 20th floor. This meant filling up the bathtub with ice cubes, rose petals and bath foam. Though not requested, we also placed a selection of aromatherapy oils and a bottle of champagne for the guest," says Bernard Theseira, head of concierge services at the St Regis Hotel.

"We stopped one of our bubble lifts for a guest and his partner to have a private dinner in, replete with butler service while the sun set against the city skyline behind them. It was a stunning wedding proposal that took place on a Valentine's Day and the cost of the six-course dinner was $8,888," says Pan Pacific Singapore's chief concierge, Alvin Koh.

"We arranged for a member to bring his girlfriend to an Italian piazza and convince her to have her caricature drawn by a local artist. While she sat in anticipation of a funny image, he actually drew the boyfriend proposing with a speech bubble with the immortal words of 'Will you marry me'. The artist then turned the portrait around for the woman to see," says Andrew Long, chief executive officer, Ten Group Asia Pacific.

site_title: Sun never sets on Empire's musical adventure
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sun never sets on Empire's musical adventure

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LUKE Steele never stops working because he knows he can't afford to in the music business. Which explains why the Australian singer-songwriter is constantly collaborating with other musicians - including hip hop's First Couple, Jay-Z and Beyonce - in addition to starting his own bands.

One of his most commercially successful projects, synth-pop duo Empire of the Sun, is making its return to Singapore later this month to play its first ever headlining show. The band previously performed here in 2010 at the now-defunct Avalon-At-Large music festival.

A collaboration between Steele and fellow Aussie Nick Littlemore - whose band Pnau recorded an album with Elton John in 2012 - the gig finds the duo touring behind Empire of the Sun's new critically acclaimed full-length release, Ice On The Dune.

The album took five years to make and is the follow-up to their equally successful 2008 debut, Walking On A Dream.

Over the phone from his home in Perth where Steele is taking some time off before the duo kicks off their 2014 world tour with the Singapore show, he reveals that the album wasn't the easiest to make and was borne out of one long mystical road trip.

"We became explorers; we got lost at sea for a while and spent months in the desert before we finally made it back to civilisation with the artifacts that we found . . . that became the music," he says cryptically, as if describing scenes straight out of the music video for the album's lead single, Alive.

Steele also insists there was no difficult-second-album-syndrome and the pair felt no pressure from having to live up to expectations of their critically lauded debut.

"It's really more about raising your own expectations and musical abilities - to see how your ears have grown," he clarifies.

Ice On The Dune cracked the top 20 and 30 album charts in the US and UK respectively - no mean feat for an Australian act. Back home, it was nominated for five Arias, Australia's answer to the Grammys. Though it missed out on the major categories such as Best Pop Release and Best Group, the cover art - featuring Steele and Littlemore in their trademark stage makeup and costumes - picked up an award.

The band's flamboyant image also extends to its visually arresting "live" shows which typically feature over-the-top sets, dancers in gaudy costumes and musical instruments that light up on their own.

Critics have compared Empire of the Sun's light-and-sound extravaganza to Cirque du Soleil (minus the acrobats, of course) given their knack for dramatically mixing music with art; and Steele says that the show is constantly evolving to be even brighter and bigger than the last one.

The band's catchy dance anthems, such as Alive and Walking On A Dream'sWe Are The People, have also appeared outside of their albums and are being used in television advertisements, games and movies.

Unlike some music artists who refuse to license their works for commercial purposes, Steele has no issue with it. "I think it's great that more people get a chance to hear our music," he explains.

That's probably because he is hardly ever short of a song idea and comes from a musical family. His father and sister are musicians in their own right; while his brothers have played in The Sleepy Jackson, the indie neo-folk band that Steele broke into the business with in 1998.

"Music is in my blood," he states matter-of-factly. "It's hard to capture it sometimes but it's also so harmonious and doesn't ever lie."

Dying to run? Think again

A study has shown that sedentary middle-aged people should seek medical clearance before plunging headlong into a vigorous exercise programme

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Feb 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WITH the greater promotion of exercise as being good for health, there has been a substantial increase in those aged 35 years and above taking up regular physical exercise. This has led to an increasing number of those in this largely sedentary middle-aged group participating in physically demanding exercise events, including marathons.

Over the last three decades, marathon running has seen an explosive 80-fold increase in participants. It is not uncommon to hear of people dying suddenly during a marathon. Hence, it is important to understand whether it is safe to participate in vigorous exercise programmes.

While data from observational studies have suggested that regular exercise may reduce the likelihood of developing heart disease, there is now substantial evidence to show that vigorous exercise can result in the sudden development of a heart attack, sudden death, stroke and a tear in the wall of the main artery of the body (aorta). These events occur mainly in those who have underlying disease of their heart arteries, known or unknown.

site_title: Property sector hopes for the pain to end
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Property sector hopes for the pain to end

Tweaking or removing some curbs would give foreign investors the 'right signal'

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] For property players, there is one Budget wish above all else: that some of the cooling measures introduced previously - including the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) and additional buyers' stamp duty (ABSD) - might be tweaked or even rolled back.

"Our wish is for the government to consider scaling back or loosening up certain measures which have yielded the desired results," said Donald Han, managing director at Chesterton Singapore.

After all, sub-sales and foreigners' participation rates are now at a new low compared to two years ago, largely due to the successful implementation of the sellers' stamp duty (SSD) and ABSD. Also, the TDSR framework has single-handedly put a check on escalating property prices and transaction volumes.

Reviewing these policies would send the "right signal" to foreign investors, said Mr Han.

According to Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) data, prices of private residential properties decreased 0.9 per cent in Q4 last year - the first time that overall prices have fallen since Q1 2012.

Consultants concur that this is due to the combined weight of TDSR, ABSD and SSD, which have effectively slowed down the pace of the private property market in terms of transaction volumes and the rate of price increases.

Nicholas Mak, executive director at SLP International, echoed Mr Han's views, but conceded that it is unlikely the government will remove or reduce any of the cooling measures.

Indeed, while Budget 2014 may be more "neutral" on property and provide some preconditions for which measures may be eased, the earliest relaxation of measures will probably be in late 2014 or early 2015, said Bank of America Merrill Lynch economist Chua Hak Bin. "Any relaxation will likely come from changes in stamp duties rather than leverage ratios," he added, referring to the loan-to-value ratio (LTV) and TDSR.

On the stamp duties front, tweaking the SSD policy might be the way forward, suggested Christine Li, head of research at Orange Tee. Under the current SSD regime, losses are amplified for sellers who bought at a high price and are forced to sell at a loss, she said, adding that this could be catastrophic should interest rates rise or property prices soften.

"Also due to SSD, many units which have received their Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) are not put on the market, restricting supply. Owners will be forced to rent out the units, intensifying competition in the already weakened rental market," she added.

While cooling measures preoccupy the industry, the Budget is expected to touch on other areas, including construction and real estate investment trusts (Reits), market watchers said. The construction sector would get some air play, given the continued productivity drive.

The most pressing issue would be the looming expiration of the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme. Introduced in 2010, the scheme offers tax deductions and payouts to businesses, including construction firms, that spend on productivity-related investments. It is due to expire in 2015.

Many have called for the scheme to be extended or, better yet, improved.

PwC Singapore, for instance, recommended that greater flexibility be introduced in applying the expenditure cap on the scheme.

"A combined cap or a higher cap for the more commonly undertaken activities would encourage companies to invest more in the activities that are relevant to their businesses," it said.

SMEs, for instance, could be allowed to claim higher PIC deductions or allowances for training and the acquisition of IT and automation equipment. Multinational corporations which focus on innovation- led activities on the other hand could enjoy a higher expenditure cap on their research and development and acquisition of intellectual property expenses.

KPMG recommended simplifying the incentives and regulations.

"More streamlined and effective business regulations and easily accessible tax incentives are particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) . . . The PIC scheme needs revisions to make it less prescriptive and simplified, using principle-based rules," said Tay Hong Beng, head of tax at KPMG Singapore.

KPMG suggested that the Land Intensification Allowance scheme (LIA) be extended to other industries outside of the manufacturing sector given that other sectors, such as logistics and transportation, may also invest in new premises or upgrade their current premises to achieve higher productivity.

"The LIA should therefore be extended to all promoted industrial sectors, for buildings built on land zoned for industrial use (that is, Business 1, Business 2, and Business Park zones). This could be facilitated initially on a case-by- case basis," it said.

Apart from providing grants and tax incentives to lower the development and implementation costs of new technology, more incentives to encourage innovation should be introduced, said Chua Yang Liang, head of South-east Asia research at Jones Lang LaSalle.

He added: "Strengthening the ties and collaborations between the industry and polytechnics/research institutions could prove more economical in the longer term."

site_title: Bank Negara's delicate balancing act
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bank Negara's delicate balancing act

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MALAYSIA'S central bank, Bank Negara, has a tricky balancing act on its hands. It has now maintained its overnight policy rate at 3 per cent for over 10 straight quarters, sticking to its accommodative stance to keep the country's growth engine ticking.

Among other reasons, the cheap credit has unfurled an unprecedented borrowing binge that's resulted in one of the highest household debt to gross domestic product ratios (85 per cent) in Asia, second only to South Korea. That's a potential, although admittedly limited, risk to the financial system, so 2014 could be the time when the central bank takes the punch bowl away from the party. Inflation is only expected to rise given the government's subsidy rationalisation measures and the imposition of a goods and service tax in April 2015. Real interest rates are now negative. As rates rise in the United States with its gradual recovery as well as the tapering of quantitative easing, Malaysian yield spreads will narrow, tempting investors to cut and run. That's seriously not a good idea. Since 2008, when US interest rates dropped sharply, foreign holdings of Malaysian government securities have increased sharply - almost 50 per cent at its peak in May last year. A sell-off would be pretty damaging to the ringgit, which is why the central bank will probably raise rates sometime this year.

The local currency hasn't been faring too well either. It has already depreciated 2 per cent against the greenback since the beginning of the year, making it the second worst performing currency in Asia in 2014. The sliding ringgit, in turn, exacerbates imported inflation. A hike in interest rates can, and probably should, stem the slide.

But Bank Negara has limited room for manoeuvre, perhaps around 25-50 basis points at the most. Raising rates even more could hurt both the indebted government and its equally burdened citizenry. The trick is not to allow spreads to narrow so much that there would be a collective rush for the door by foreign investors. Neither should the ringgit be allowed to appreciate too much as this could hurt Malaysian exporters.

Indeed, given improving global economic conditions all around, exports will rise but a relatively cheap ringgit - much as it is now - also makes them more competitive. That will be a plus for Malaysia's external account. The current account surplus on Malaysia's balance of payments has declined to around 4 per cent of GDP from almost 25 per cent in 2008. That has got to be reversed if Malaysia's international reserves are to be preserved. In 1998, it was the combination of a budget deficit coupled with a current account deficit that triggered the speculative attacks on the ringgit.

A reasonable uptick in rates isn't likely to unduly hurt growth either. The World Bank thinks that the Malaysian economy will grow by around 4.9 per cent while the central bank is more optimistic, predicting that growth will be between 5 and 5.5 per cent. That isn't blazing growth but in the circumstances, it's respectable.

Other than Perennial Jihua, PCRT has three other operational assets in Shenyang held under a joint venture, which was hit by a net loss of $7.7 million for the year due to a $13.4 million revaluation loss. This was caused by PCRT's share of the Shenyang Red Star Macalline Furniture Mall being revalued 104 million yuan (S$21.8 million) lower, partially offset by revaluation gains in the other two assets.

Due to foreign exchange fluctuations, net asset value per unit rose from 70 cents in end-2012 to 77 cents in end-2013. PCRT closed at 53 cents, up half a cent or one per cent.

site_title: Tokyo polls to test Japan's rapid swing to the right
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tokyo polls to test Japan's rapid swing to the right

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SUNDAY'S poll to elect a new governor of Tokyo is turning into a major political power play involving Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as well as two former prime ministers as forces mobilise for or against what is seen as the Japanese government's accelerating swing towards the right.

Two issues nominally dominating the election campaign are the future of nuclear power in Japan and the Olympic Games which Tokyo is due to host in 2020. But a key "hidden" factor, some say, is whether a credible political opposition can be established to counter Japan's new direction.

This would create a much bigger threat to the government of Mr Abe than the embarrassment he would suffer if Tokyo voters elect a governor who is opposed to nuclear power in Japan and to the "extravagant" Olympic Games, both of which Mr Abe is pushing, analysts say.

The outcome of the election, they argue, is likely to have a strong bearing not only on the direction of Japanese domestic politics but also on the country's increasingly fraught diplomatic relations with some of its neighbours. As such, it will be widely watched.

What appeared at first to be a straightforward contest to elect a replacement for former Tokyo governor Naoki Inose, who stepped down following a political funding scandal, has rapidly escalated into something much larger.

After former prime minister Morihiro Hosokawa (who in 1994 headed a party that broke the Liberal Democratic Party's near 50-year hold on power) stepped into the ring as a candidate, supported by another popular former prime minister, Juichiro Koizumi, the political stakes were quickly raised.

Mr Abe and the LDP then threw their weight behind former health minister Yoichi Mazusoe who is the leading candidate for the Tokyo governor's position, making it clear that the battle is being fought out at the highest political levels.

The aim of Mr Koizumi and Mr Hosokawa, sources told The Business Times, is to use the Tokyo gubernatorial election as a springboard for forming a credible new political opposition force in Japan to counter the LDP, which since last year has enjoyed an almost total grip on power.

This has allowed Mr Abe to push through Parliament controversial legislation to form a New National Security Council, to pass a heavily opposed new State Secrets Law and to promote a "reinterpretation" and possible revision of Japan's postwar "pacifist" constitution.

Mr Abe's controversial visit last month to Tokyo's Yasukuni Shrine, where the names of a number of "Class A Japanese war criminals" are enshrined, brought unusual criticism from the US government, which voiced "disappointment" at the move, and this week Britain's Ambassador Tim Hitchens urged Mr Abe to exercise "care" on the issue.

Under Mr Abe too, the chairman of Japanese public broadcaster NHK has been replaced by Katsuto Momii, whose public statements have suggested that NHK could become something of a government mouthpiece in future rather than a "neutral" public broadcasting organisation.

"Abe-appointed governors now have control of the NHK board, together with the new, like-minded chairman," said former Goldman Sachs (Asia) vice-president Kenneth Courtis.

"The new chairman said in his first press conference that it is 'only normal' for NHK to support government views.

"The Abe/Aso government (a reference to Mr Abe and Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso) is appointing people of similar far right political and ultra-nationalist views to key positions in the bureaucracy, the judicial system, military, and sensitive media positions," Mr Courtis added.

Naoki Hyakuta, another NHK governor said to have been hand-picked by Mr Abe, is meanwhile reported to have described the Nanking Massacre as a fabrication, during a speech supporting another candidate in the Tokyo election, former Air Self-Defence Force chief of staff Toshio Tamogami.

Mr Tamogami is being backed by former Tokyo governor Shintaro Hashimoto who like Mr Abe and some of his close aides is said to have strong nationalist leanings. Mr Tamogami claimed this week that Japan has been unfairly demonised by the victors of World War II.

Although Mr Hosokawa is trailing behind Mr Mazusoe in media polls of voter intentions for Sunday's Tokyo gubernatorial election, sources say that Mr Hosokawa and yet another candidate in the election, Kenji Utsunomiya, may join hands in order to win the election and lock out Mr Mazusoe.

Meanwhile, Mr Koizumi plans to use his still-strong support among Japanese voters to promote further candidates in local elections so as to establish a political opposition base, these sources say. Mr Koizumi's son Shinjiro, himself a politician, may serve in this new movement, it is said.

The former governing Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ), which was swept from power by Mr Abe at the end of 2012, is said to be close to disintegrating, and veteran politician Ichiro Ozawa, who left the DPJ to form the People's Life Party, is backing Mr Hosokawa in Sunday's poll.

site_title: Lego transforms into animated blockbuster
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Lego transforms into animated blockbuster

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ANYONE who has ever played make-believe with their Lego set will dig The Lego Movie. In it, little figurines come to life in different universes recreated from 15 million pieces of the toy brick. It's the Danish toy company's first foray into film and one that took five painstaking years to complete. Using CGI to cleverly mimic stop-motion animation, the concept is a refreshing change from the highly-polished 3D digital fare from Pixar and Dreamworks.

With The Lego Movie, director-writers Phil Lord and Christopher Miller (Cloudy With A Chance of Meatballs, 21 Jump Street) have slyly put together a colourful cartoon that the audience will only realise is a feature-length commercial for the toy company when the final credits start to roll. That's because the laugh-a-minute script - riddled with various pop-culture references - works hard on its own instead of sitting back and letting the nostalgic brand name do the legwork alone. Not only that, Lego's extensive licensing deals also means the film features an exhaustive list of star cameos including characters from the Harry Potter, The Simpsons and Star Wars franchises; as well as Batman and Superman, just to name a few.

With all that competition, it's no wonder the protagonist Emmet (Parks and Recreations' Chris Pratt), a construction worker in Bricksville, feels like a nobody. The opportunity to prove himself comes up when he's mistaken by his love interest, the feisty Wyldstyle (Elizabeth Banks), to be The Special One aka The Master Builder who will save the Lego Universe from being destroyed by the evil tyrant Lord Business (Will Ferrell). Together with Batman (Will Arnett) and the wizard Vitruvius (Morgan Freeman), the quartet embark on a road trip through different worlds while Good Cop/Bad Cop (Liam Neeson playing a single character with two interchangeable faces) remains hot on their heels.

It's a deceptively simple plot - easy enough for children to follow - but also high on satire and brimming with pop culture in-jokes so it doesn't ignore the older audience and keeps them equally entertained with high comic energy. At times, it can get too much though as the film moves a little too fast for its own good by constantly changing genres - from Western to sci-fi to high seas drama.

Still, The Lego Movie is mostly a blast from start to end and brings to mind the original Toy Story which was smart, funny and entertaining with a multi-layered storyline. More importantly, despite being a tie-in, The Lego Movie doesn't feel too much of a hard-sell; for that alone, this deserves to be a blockbuster.

Rating:

B

PEC wins $79m in new contracts

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SPECIALIST engineering group PEC Ltd has clinched $79 million in new contracts from repeat multinational firms, which it said would contribute to its earnings for the current financial year.

This adds to its last-announced orderbook of $176 million as at Sept 30.

The new orders include engineering, procurement and construction jobs for a storage facility terminal in Singapore that is expected to be completed in September next year.

PEC will also provide field piping-erection works for a liquefied natural gas plant in Malaysia. This will be completed by January 2016.

Other contracts for civil, mechanical, structural and piping works for refinery facilities in Singapore will be completed in the next 12 months, the group said.

These contract wins underscore PEC's strong position in the downstream process engineering industry, said PEC group chief executive Robert Dompeling.

"Over the long term, we will remain focused on building up our business, especially in the maintenance service sector, as well as in exploring opportunities to expand our reach in target markets across Asia and the Middle East."

The announcement by PEC group yesterday comes amid a challenging environment in the process industry.

The group's revenue fell 16 per cent to US$100.9 million for the quarter ended Sept 30, as project works in the Middle East and the Asia-Pacific contributed less in sales, and lower maintenance activities in Singapore led to a decrease in maintenance services.

Heftier finance expenses - due to an increase in issuance of bank guarantees, performance bonds and interest charges for short-term financing - and higher taxes led to PEC's net profit tumbling 28 per cent to $2.39 million.

The group said then that it would remain vigilant in managing costs and improving efficiencies. "At the same time, we will remain selective in bidding for projects and be diligent in our execution."

In the stock market, the counter last closed at 53.5 cents on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia's December exports up 14%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Malaysia's December exports up 14%

Strong growth led by shipments to S-E Asia and increase in exports to China and Europe

Published

Fri, Feb 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Kuala Lumpur

MALAYSIA'S exports surged 14 per cent in December from a year earlier, surpassing the street's prediction of 9 per cent and paving the way for a stronger-than-expected rise in gross domestic product (GDP) for the fourth quarter of 2013.

The news will come as a relief for the administration of Prime Minister Najib Razak, as it indicates that the global economic recovery is buoying exports to the point that they take up some of the slack from flagging domestic demand.

Private investment is expected to remain reasonably robust this year, thanks to Mr Najib's Economic Transformation Programme (ETP), but domestic consumption could come off considerably. Inflation has surged owing to the government's programme to rationalise subsidies, which has crimped spending.

Even so, the news is completely unexpected. Net exports had been recovering in the fourth quarter, with export growth helped along by a weak ringgit; the local unit depreciated 6 per cent against the greenback in 2013, and has slipped a further 2 per cent year-to-date.

Indeed, that investment was still strong was indicated by a 14.8 per cent year-on-year rise in imports, driven primarily by capital goods (17.8 per cent up). And the trade surplus was still strong at RM9.5 billion (S$3.6 billion), though down from RM9.7 billion in November.

Reflecting the pick-up in the developed world, Malaysia's exports were led by electronics (12 per cent), refined petroleum products (62.7 per cent) and liquefied natural gas (16.2 per cent). Overall export growth came in at 2.4 per cent last year, improving from the dismal 0.7 per cent in 2012.

The Department of Statistics said that export growth last year was led by shipments to South-east Asia and an increase in exports to China and Europe.

Technology exports recovered, expanding 2.4 per cent for the year, after contracting 2.5 per cent in 2012, largely on the global economic recovery.

Chua Hak Bin, an economist with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch, said in a report released yesterday that the surge will impact GDP growth. "We expect growth to improve to 5.2 per cent in the fourth quarter, versus 5 per cent in the third quarter.

"The boost likely came from exports. This will bring full-year GDP growth to 4.7 per cent, down from 5.6 per cent in 2012."

Mr Chua added that the central bank was likely to raise the policy rate by 25 basis points in the second half of this year to check inflation. So long as exports continue to take the slack, the central bank should be more prepared to raise the policy rate, given that rising prices are a clear and present danger.

Mr Chua said: "The rate hike should also be seen as normalisation as the US Federal Reserve tapers its bond purchases."

site_title: Redas-NUS index throws up mixed signals
content:
Redas-NUS index throws up mixed signals

Developers' mood improves, but more see sliding prices in next 6 mths

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Developers' sentiment may have improved marginally in the fourth quarter of 2013, but concerns over potential declines in residential property prices and rising costs continue to cap their outlook.

In the latest Real Estate Sentiment Index (RESI) survey, the Composite Sentiment Index that captures the overall market sentiment of property developers increased to 4.0 in the fourth quarter of 2013, up from 3.9 in the third quarter.

The Future Sentiment Index also edged up to 4.0 from 3.9 over the same period.

In this index, developed by the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) and the National University of Singapore, a score under five is a flag for deteriorating market conditions.

But some 62 per cent of the developers surveyed anticipate a moderate decrease in residential property prices in the next six months, up from 51.3 per cent in the third quarter.

The mixed signals in the survey reflect market uncertainties, said Ku Swee Yong, chief executive of property consultancy Century21. "This is solid evidence that we are uncertain about the prospects of the market over the next six months."

Some 39 per cent of the developers surveyed expect new property launches to hold at the same level in the next six months while 22 per cent expect moderately more launches and 14 per cent indicated that they would launch substantially more units, up by 11.3 per cent from the preceding quarter.

"Unless there are changes to external factors affecting the real estate market, the sentiments are expected to hold for (the) time being," said a survey respondent. "The sentiment will not be improving because government will intervene to cool the market."

Prime and suburban residential sectors were the worst-performing segments in the fourth quarter.

Sentiment in the prime residential segment showed a current net balance of -53 per cent and a future net balance of -44 per cent while the suburban residential segment showed a current net balance of -47 per cent and a future net balance of -57 per cent.

The net balance is the difference between the proportion of respondents who were optimistic and those who were pessimistic.

In a bid to cool the residential property market, the Singapore government introduced the TDSR (Total Debt Servicing Ratio) framework last June, requiring financial institutions to consider borrowers' outstanding debt obligations and ensure that their monthly debt obligations stay within 60 per cent of their monthly income. This has since dealt a blow to developers' sentiment.

"The cooling measures are taking effect. It depends on how the market reacts for developers to moderate lower price launches on new units," said another survey respondent.

"Developers who do not have any holding power may dispose units at further discounts at about 3-5 per cent. However, a market crash is unlikely due to fairly strong underlying demand."

Seen as more resilient, the office segment is viewed by developers as the best performing with a current net balance of +27 per cent and a future net balance of +20 per cent in the fourth quarter.

Developers expressed concerns over rising costs, with 46 per cent of the respondents saying that they are very concerned about higher land costs and 54 per cent flagging concerns about labour costs.

Around Town

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pick of the week

My Fair Lady:

Take a trip back in time to 1912 London, as the classic musical My Fair Lady by Alan Jay Lemer and Frederick Loewe takes centre stage at the Sands Theatre next week.

This acclaimed musical tells the story of Cockney (working-class Londoner from East End) flower girl Eliza Doolittle, who takes lessons under an arrogant phonetics professor Henry Higgins to transform her accent into a proper English one so she can pass off as a member of the upper class. And stopping in Singapore for less than three weeks is the US National Tour, featuring Aurora Florence as Eliza Doolittle, and Chris Carsten as Henry Higgins.

My Fair Lady originally started out as a stage play titled Pygmalion by George Bernard Shaw, published in 1912. It was later adapted into a film in 1938 and became a musical that debuted on Broadway in 1956. The musical starring Julie Andrews and Rex Harrison went on to win six Tony Awards in 1957, while the 1964 film version starring Harrison and Audrey Hepburn won eight Academy Awards.

My Fair Lady will run from Feb 11 to March 2 at the Sands Theatre at Marina Bay Sands at 6pm from Tues to Sun, with an additional 2pm show on weekends. Tickets cost from $95 to $195. Log on to

www.sistic.com.sg

for more information or to purchase tickets.

>Stage

Bane:

Guinness world record holder Joseph Bone will be in Singapore over the weekend to perform the first instalment of his trilogy of productions titled Bane. The comedic drama tells the story of a hitman named Bruce Bane, who discovers that there is someone trying to kill him, so he tries to find out who it is. Bone holds the world record for the most number of characters played by a single actor, because of the 140 different people he plays in the Bane trilogy. Accompanying Bone is musician Ben Roe who will play the entire soundtrack live on his guitar.

Bane runs on Feb 8 and Feb 9 at the Drama Centre Theatre at 8pm daily. Tickets cost $50, $70 and $90. Log on to

www.sistic.com.sg

for more information and tickets.

Yotam Silberstein Live at the Sultan Jazz Club:

If you're looking for a little music to get you through next week, then stop by the Sultan Jazz Club and hear Israeli jazz guitarist Yotam Silberstein perform on Tuesday and Wednesday night. Silberstein has collaborated with performers like James Moody, The Heath Brothers, Paquito D'Rivera and the Dizzy Gillespie Alumni All-Stars. He will be performing with two local jazz musicians, Kerong Chok on the organ and Wen Ming Soh on drums.

Yotam Silberstein will play at 9pm on Feb 11 and 12 at the Sultan Jazz Club at 101 Jalan Sultan. Tickets cost $35. Log on to

www.sultanjazz.com

for more information or call 9384 7096 to buy tickets.

Lunar New Year 8-Artists Exhibition:

Eight artists from the Federation of Art Societies (Singapore) are putting up a joint exhibition in conjunction with the Chinese New Year Season at the Alliance Francaise de Singapour. The exhibition is mainly based on a horse theme, in line with this new year's Chinese Zodiac. The artists involved are Stephen Leong Chun Hong, Yong Cheong Thye, Grace Chen Liang, Sim Pang Liang, Tan Ching Yam, Goh Yau Kee, Lau Kim Yet and Khan Siong Ann.

site_title: RHT's India deal raises questions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

RHT's India deal raises questions

Its board should be asked to provide more clarity about the transaction which merits greater scrutiny by unitholders

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT WAS probably good news to unitholders when Religare Health Trust (RHT) announced its proposed acquisition of a clinical facility known as Mohali Clinical Establishment in Punjab, India, signalling further room for growth. What isn't so favourable is that it will soon have to vote on other transactions linked to this deal, even as some questions are left unanswered.

In a regulatory filing on Feb 2, RHT said it had agreed to acquire Mohali Clinical Establishment from Radha Soami Satsang Beas (RSSB) for $55.1 million.

It also agreed to enter into separate agreements, which are interested person transactions (IPTs), with its sponsor Fortis Healthcare for the purchase of related equipment and services.

By the looks of things, the acquisition itself is not an IPT as the vendor of the facility is a third party legally separated from RHT.

This therefore does not require the approval of RHT unitholders, unlike the IPTs where RHT has proposed to enter with Fortis.

Nothing further was said about the identity of the vendor RSSB. Meanwhile, there is much speculation in India about the connections between RSSB and RHT's indirect parent company, Religare Enterprises.

This raises the question of whether it is appropriate to deem RHT's acquisition a non-IPT.

Even if the deal is technically a non-IPT, the issue of the relationship between RSSB and Religare should spur curious investors here to ask the RHT board crucial questions at the upcoming unitholders' meeting.

Spiritual movement

So far, RHT has made no mention of any potential links with RSSB or connections between RSSB and its sponsor Fortis Healthcare, except to say that Fortis operates the hospital at Mohali Clinical Establishment.

Gurinder Singh Dhillon, father of RHT CEO Gurpreet Singh Dhillon, heads RSSB as its spiritual guru.

According to its website, RSSB is one of India's largest spiritual movements and derives its philosophies from the teachings of all religions. Its guru is regarded by disciples as "god in human form".

Financially, the Dhillon family has become one of the richest in India. Mr Gurinder's nephews, Malvinder Singh and Shivinder Singh, control the extensive healthcare and financial services businesses respectively under Fortis Healthcare and Religare Enterprises.

While interweaving relationships in family businesses are not uncommon, investors would be keen to know if there is any influence on decision-making at RHT arising from a connection with RSSB.

After all, some investors do base their investment decisions on the values and culture of the company they buy into.

The deal merits greater scrutiny by unitholders.

Firstly, RHT's planned acquisition of a clinical facility from RSSB would seem like a new approach from RHT's past practice of acquiring healthcare facilities from its sponsor Fortis Healthcare which make up its initial portfolio. Secondly, it is worth noting that the proposed deal accounts for about 8.8 per cent of its net tangible assets.

Singapore Exchange listing rules state that an associate of the CEO is deemed an "interested person" in the case of a business trust. An IPT greater than 5 per cent of the group's latest audited net tangible assets would require the approval of the unitholders.

Sale deed

While no clear links between RHT and RSSB have yet to be determined, the relationship between RSSB's spiritual head and RHT's CEO warrants that more light be shed on RHT's latest transaction.

Unitholders will have to convene soon to vote on the IPTs between Fortis Healthcare and RHT. RSSB has undertaken to execute the sale deed for Mohali Clinical Establishment after the approval of unitholders for these IPTs. At this point, the board of RHT should be asked to provide more clarity.

site_title: Bringing Indonesian 'archaeologic art' to life
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bringing Indonesian 'archaeologic art' to life

Prayitno tells the stories behind old Peranakan Chinese artefacts, reports CHEAH UI-HOON

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PERANAKAN artefacts are highly sought after as antiques here, but for Indonesian artist Yuli Prayitno, Indonesian Peranakan objects don't just signify a unique and exquisite material culture. Instead, he incorporates them into his "archaeologic art" - in his bid to highlight a suppressed culture and history in Indonesia.

Instead of the usual collector's interest in precious Peranakan ceramics or jewellery, which is the case in Singapore and Malaysia, Prayitno is more interested in the spirit of multi- culturism they embody in Indonesia.

"What the artist is saying is that the Peranakans contribute to an important cultural heritage in Indonesia, and their wisdom and knowledge deserve to be acknowledged as important," says Seng Yu Jin, curator for Prayitno's solo exhibition titled Unity in Diversity: Archaeologic Excavation of the Peranakan Tionghua at Equator Art Projects.

The artist's latest works revolve around Tan Gwat Bing, the first person to establish a photography studio in Yogyakarta in the early 20th century. Prayitno had heard about the imminent demolition of Tan's house and studio, which prompted him to go there to salvage what he could.

The Yogyakarta-based artist is known for his installation-sculptures using a variety of materials to highlight contemporary social issues such as gender and identity, by remixing forms. Seng, currently a senior curator at The National Art Gallery, Singapore, explains that he's been following Prayitno's works since 2006.

"He isn't Peranakan, but he understands the importance of multiculturism," notes Seng. "Not just the Peranakans - many ethnic minority groups in Indonesia suffered during the New Order under President Suharto as they could not practise their culture, since Indonesian culture was narrowly defined as Javanese."

Working like an archaeologist, Prayitno began to survey and research the Peranakan Tionghua in Yogyakarta before coming across the "artefacts" such as photographs, postcards and books left behind by Tan Gwat Bing.

He dug into the history of photography in Indonesia and the carpentry techniques used to con- struct Peranakan Chinese furniture that was different from other furniture produced in Indonesia. "But Prayitno departed from the methods of an archaeologist when he began dismantling the furniture and intervening in these artefacts by inserting Chinese characters," says Seng.

Prayitno's "archaeologic art" is made through the construction of narratives by recovering previously overlooked culture and knowledge of the Peranakan Chinese in Indonesia. The Chinese had brought modern technologies and ideas - stemming from their desire to be a part of global modernity. They were rooted in their hybrid cultural practices that have produced the famed Pekalongan batik featuring both Chinese and local motifs, Peranakan cuisine and jamu, a form of traditional herbal medicine.

"Prayitno's reassembly of the furniture into artwork is meant to highlight the historical injustice they suffered through discrimination since colonial times. He also makes visible the lost knowledge and wisdom of the Peranakan Chinese as a community that forms a part of Indonesia's cultural diversity," adds Seng.

Seng and Prayitno discussed the artist's concept to focus on the national motto, "Unity in Diversity", that initially symbolised the country's recognition of its cultural diversity as a strength under earlier President Sukarno. This changed during Suharto's regime.

One of his works uses a Garuda Pancasila in which Prayitno had included the Chinese character ping, which means peace. "The use of Chinese characters was his decision as he wanted to capture the wisdom of the Peranakan Chinese and how the different cultures can learn from each other," says Seng.

His use of history is in a revisionist vein to question the overlooked and suppressed histories of the Peranakan Chinese and, by extension, other ethnic minority groups in Indonesia. He calls his interdisciplinary approach "archaeologic art" since he selectively adapts real cultural artefacts and inserts speech bubbles. "This is very South-east Asian as this region is about the history of selective adaptation to foreign cultures through its history," notes Seng.

"The issue of cultural diversity and how multiculturalism should be embraced rather than treated with suspicion are still issues pertinent today," he highlights.

Due to the shipment of the artworks being affected by recent floods in Jakarta, Yuli Prayitno's exhibition has been postponed to Mar 7 - Apr 6,

at Equator Art Projects, 47 Malan Road, #01-21, Gillman Barracks.

For more information, please go to

www.eqproj.com

site_title: Defence business faces tough environment: Boeing chief
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Defence business faces tough environment: Boeing chief

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Boeing Co expects its defence business to continue facing a tough environment with "flatish" profit margins, chief executive Jim McNerney said on Wednesday.

A recent federal government budget deal has pushed off automatic spending cuts known as sequestration by two years, but "sequestration has not gone away", Mr McNerney said at a Cowen & Co investment conference.

In contrast, the commercial jetliner business is better than Mr McNerney has seen it in his career, which includes time running General Electric Aviation, the maker of aircraft engines. Commercial aircraft business margins have room to widen, he said, due to faster jet production and the ability to get better prices from suppliers.

But he said it is a "fair criticism" that Boeing needs to do more to help suppliers on engineering and process improvement that will provide better prices.

He said that about one-third of Boeing's suppliers are involved in the company's "partnering for success" programme, under which they work together to reduce costs and share the benefits. The remaining two-thirds are either in discussion or not engaged in the programme, he said. He said he expects the programme to continue to grow. "We have volume to offer and they have efficiency they can offer," he said.

Mr McNerney also acknowledged that Boeing is hiring contract workers to help fix production problems at the 787 Dreamliner factory in South Carolina, and that some work was being moved to the Seattle area to be finished.

He also acknowledged that there were "still some hard feelings" with machinists in the Seattle area after an acrimonious contract vote last month that ensured Boeing's new 777X jet programme would be located in Washington state. The contract required machinists to give up their pension for a defined contribution plan.

Boeing's commercial jet business is not being affected by weakness in emerging markets, Mr McNerney said. But there is more divergence among emerging countries and China and the Middle East remain strong. Demand in the US is improving, while a pick up in Europe is "still to come", he said.

Boeing likely will announce new aircraft orders at an upcoming airshow in Singapore next week, but not at the level of the record orders announced last November, he said. - Reuters

site_title: StarHub Q4 profit down 4.8%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

StarHub Q4 profit down 4.8%

Revenue dips on lower equipment sales; 60,000 new customers gained

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

STARHUB has posted a 4.8 per cent dip in net profit to $83.7 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2013 on lower overall revenue.

The topline's decline of 6.2 per cent to $613.7 million was driven by lower equipment sales, which almost halved from $90.8 million in the previous year to $49.9 million.

Service revenue was flat at $563.8 million over the same period.

For the full financial year, net profit grew 3.2 per cent to $370.7 million, while total revenue stood at $2.36 billion, a 2.6 per cent decrease.

This year, service revenue is expected to grow in the low single-digit range, with an Ebitda (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) margin of about 32 per cent, the group announced yesterday.

Cash capital expenditure is slated to account for about 13 per cent of total revenue.

For the fourth quarter, all of StarHub's divisions managed to eke out an increase in revenue, save its broadband segment which registered a 10.5 per cent decline to $56.3 million as intense price competition in the crowded market continued to be felt.

"To be able to stay competitive, we have to be able to offer competitive packages as well. This, without a doubt, will impact our revenue," StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai explained in an earnings call yesterday.

In the mobile services segment, there was more reason for cheer, with revenue up 0.8 per cent at $310.5 million, on the back of a whopping gain of 60,000 postpaid customers against the previous quarter .

This was attributed to a secondary line programme for family members of subscribers that StarHub had introduced, as well as growth in the enterprise sector.

By the end of the quarter, close to 50 per cent of StarHub's postpaid customers were on the tiered data price plans, with 16 per cent of that group busting their monthly data limits.

At the same time, postpaid average revenue per user (ARPU) stood at $69 for the quarter, against $70 from a year ago.

The pay-TV segment recorded the second consecutive quarter of net subscriber gains, aided by StarHub's ability to offer the Barclays Premier League matches on its platform.

In the fourth quarter, it added 2,100 residential customers to the fold against the previous quarter, taking the total to about 533,000.

Revenue for the segment grew 2.1 per cent to $99.7 million for the quarter, while ARPU stood at $52, up from $51 in the previous year's fourth quarter.

While the World Cup looms this year as the next major battleground for pay-TV operators, negotiations remain ongoing and no conclusion has been reached yet, according to StarHub.

Revenue for StarHub's fixed network services segment also grew from $94.7 million to $97.3 million - a 2.8 per cent increase.

For the group, earnings per share stood at 4.9 cents for the quarter, down from 5.1 cents for the last quarter of 2012. For the year, EPS rose from 20.9 cents to 21.5 cents.

StarHub has declared a final dividend of five cents a share, unchanged from the previous year.

Its shareholders are slated to see more of the same this year, as StarHub said that its annual cash dividend of 20 cents per share would remain in place for 2014.

Noting the challenging conditions in the pay-TV and broadband space, as well as the general uncertainty of the year ahead, StarHub chief financial officer Nicholas Tan expressed the need to be "cautious" and "circumspect" where dividend pronouncements were concerned.

The group's counter closed at $4.23, up four cents, before its earnings were announced.

site_title: The Whites have it
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The Whites have it

2010 and 2011 are two vintages in white burgundies which are must-buys, says NK YONG

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT was a surfeit of riches that marked the Paulée de Singapour 2014, a convivial gathering of wine-growers and friends - the second such Paulée held in Singapore. Eight famous wine-growers from Burgundy and two from Spain graced the occasion and presented their wines. In addition, one Spanish and five Burgundian growers who were unable to be present were represented by their wines.

Starting on Friday, Jan 24, with a Gala Charity Wine Dinner and Auction and continuing through to Sunday morning, the Paulee was held to highlight and raise funds for three charities which run vocational training courses for Singapore's autistic young adults.

In all, 84 wines (63 burgundies and 21 Spanish) were shown in three half-day sessions chaired by wine authority Serena Sutcliffe M W. Her commentaries and tasting notes alone were worth the price of admission!

In addition there were the extremely interesting comments from the wine-growers present about their wines.

Present from Burgundy were Veronique Drouhin, Domaine Drouhin; Pierre-Henry Gagey, Domaine Louis Jadot; Erwan Faiveley, Domaine Faiveley; Jean-Charles le Bault de la Moriniere, Domaine Bonneau du Martray; Dominique Lafon , Domaine Lafon; Jean-Luc Pepin, Domaine Comte Georges de Vogue; Nicolas Potel, Domaine/Maison Roche de Bellene; and Olivier Halley, Château de Meursault & Château Marsannay.

From Spain came Pablo Alvarez of Bodega Vega Sicilia (Ribera del Duero), Bodega Alion (Ribera del Duero), Bodega Pintia (Toro) and Benjamin Rothschild & Vega Sicilia (Rioja); and Alvaro Palacios of Palacios Remondo (Rioja), Descendientes de J. Palacios (Bierzo) and Alvaro Palacios (Priorato).

The theme for the Burgundy tasting was "Burgundy 2010 and 2011". Readers may remember the unanimous acclaim that greeted the Burgundy 2009 vintage and which was repeated when the 2010 vintage came along - two very fine vintages.

The 2011 vintage was beset by unfavourable conditions during the growing season but was saved by better weather in the final period leading up to the harvest. The 2010, in contrast, had more favourable conditions and produced a vintage which rivalled the preceding 2009 for acclaim and fame.

The consensus today is that 2010 is one of the greatest Burgundy vintages ever, a classic and long keeper. 2009 is great but different; more rounded, more lush, and will be ready earlier. Some very good wines can be found in 2011 - and will be less expensive.

For those wishing to know what to buy, the advice is easy. Buy whatever you can find of all three vintages!

WHITE WINES

It is easy to wax lyrical about the reds, but for me it was the whites which stood out. They were great whites, two vintages in white burgundies which are must-buys.

Chablis Premier Cru Vaillons 2011 and 2010, Domaine Drouhin Vaudon

The 2010 was slightly bigger-bodied than the 2011, both giving forth lovely aromas - roses and ripe berries. Great freshness and acidity in both, perhaps slightly more conspicuous in the 2011. Overall not much to differentiate between the two. I find both irresistible and would buy both.

The drawback, if you can call it one, is that both need ageing - 10 years at a minimum, 20+ years preferably.

The advantage is that Chablis as a whole are not as expensive as the Pulignys and Meursaults, and you will have two magnificent inexpensive white wines to enjoy early, but even better after some bottle age.

Bourgogne Blanc 2011 and 2010, Domaine Comte Georges de Vogue

This wine is the de-classified De Vogue Musigny Blanc Grand Cru. 1993 was the last vintage and was released as Musigny Blanc Grand Cru. The following year, the vineyard was extensively replanted, and today the vines are not yet old enough to qualify for Grand Cru certification.

This pair of wines was sandwiched between the Chablis pair and the Puligny-Montrachet Pucelles (Leflaive) and the comparisons and contrasts could not have been more fascinating, and especially more demonstrative of the influence of "terroir".

First, the two Bourgogne Blancs. Bourgogne Blanc they may be labelled but on the nose and on the palate, these two wines literally blew all the other wines, white and red, away.

Both light gold, glistening in the light. Very fragrant aromas, showing great minerality - it was difficult to choose which had more minerality. Both were big wines, the fragrance of 2010, and 2011's minerality. Both were big-bodied, in volume and density. The similarities between the two were very close. On balance the 2010 appeared a little more concentrated and consequently tasted drier.

Puligny-Montrachet 1er Cru Les Pucelles 2011 and 2010.

Domaine Leflaive

The white burgundies of Domaine Leflaive are for most wine lovers the gold standard in white burgundy. And Pucelles Premier Cru the finest of the Premiers Crus.

The way in which the soil of Puligny-Montrachet influences the palate was fascinating. The beautiful aroma in both was dominated by lime, with a small hint of dried orange peel in the 2010. Aroma in both was incredibly fine, light and haunting, with the 2011 a shade finer, almost rapier-like and haunting in its finish. On balance I preferred the 2011, although it would be folly not to buy the 2010 also.

A fascinating comparison of Corton Charlemagnes next, the 2011 and 2010 of Domaines Bonneau du Martray, Faiveley and Louis Jadot.

Corton Charlemagne 2011 and 2010

Domaine Bonneau du Martray

(Disclaimer: I am involved in the distribution of the wines of this Domaine.)

The 2011 was big-bodied, very ripe fruit, very, very long; light flavour of orange peel and nuts (predominantly peanuts).

The 2010 was marginally riper, similar flavours on the palate, but denser and richer. Very, very long; a tour de force.

Domaine Faiveley

An interesting contrast in styles.

Faiveley's wines are distinctly bigger and broader in body, the 2011 almost chewable, more orangey in flavour and denser texture, especially the 2011. A bigger and denser style of Corton Charlemagne.

From past and recent experiences with older vintages (1988 and 1986) of this wine it should be noted here that there has been in recent vintages a distinctively different emphasis in the style of Faiveley's wines, both white and red.

The wines in the past were very reserved and profound, taking more than a decade to mature. In contrast, the more recent vintages are more approachable even in their youth, showing a style which might colloquially be called "user-friendly".

Domaine Louis Jadot

The 2011 had a scent of talcum powder amidst the lime and orange scents on the nose, while the 2010 was more minerally and citrus scented. On the palate, 2011 was more forward with very orangey fruit flavours in the mouth and very, very long. The 2010 also showed very ripe fruit, but with broader and denser flavours, with pronounced nutty flavours on the finish.

To choose between these three growers would be invidious. They are all wines eminently worthy of Grand Cru status, and all aristocrats of white Burgundy. Choice would come down to a matter of personal taste. If credit- worthiness allows, I would happily recommend all six wines. And the bonus is, they are all sensibly priced.

site_title: A sweet-natured black and white endeavour
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A sweet-natured black and white endeavour

Nebraska is a sensitive movie with some real-life lessons, says GEOFFREY EU

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHO wants to be a millionaire? Woodrow (Woody) T Grant of Billings, Montana, that's who - and he truly believes he has just joined the newly-minted millionaire ranks, having received a letter informing him of his good fortune. The only problem is, Woody is old, damaged and delusional - and an alcoholic to boot. The sweepstakes letter he keeps so close to him is merely one of thousands that are sent out each week by a marketing firm, hoping to secure new subscribers for the magazines it represents.

Welcome to Nebraska and the world of Alexander Payne, a director who has a genuine talent for making quirky, quintessentially American films about different facets of US society. In previous films such as Election (1999), About Schmidt (2002), Sideways (2004) and The Descendants (2011), he tackled issues as diverse as high school politics, road trips and journeys of the human spirit with intelligence and humour, and could always be counted on to keep the relationships between central characters at the heart of each film.

And so it is with Nebraska, a mid-western state and state of mind that Payne - a native of Omaha - is intimately familiar with, and confident enough of depicting, in black and white. Nebraska the movie is filled with numerous shots of endless farmland, deserted country roads and small-town decay, revealing a sensitivity that other filmmakers may not have.

Indeed, few directors would have attempted to make a film about a rumpled old man limping along an interstate, stubbornly heading towards a payday that doesn't exist. The film, written by Bob Nelson, moves at a sedate pace and a small scale - and it's the little things that make Nebraska interesting.

When Woody (Bruce Dern) insists on travelling hundreds of miles to Lincoln, Nebraska to collect his imaginary winnings, his son David (Will Forte) decides to play along and drive him there. Their journey takes them through rural Nebraska to Woody's birthplace, a small town where members of his family still live - although exist might be a more appropriate word. There, news of his windfall spreads like wildfire and while some of his old friends in town are pleased for him, others - including his relatives and former business partner Ed Pegram (Stacy Keach) - hover around hoping for handouts. Woody, high on beer and oblivious to events around him, simply staggers towards his goal. It's left to the ever-patient David to clean up after him.

The entire cast, including Woody's delightfully trashy-mouthed wife Kate (June Squibb) and newsreader son Ross (Bob Odenkirk), often resembles characters from a reality show. In several scenes involving the Grants interacting with the townsfolk, Payne proves he has a firm grip on the arcane goings-on in small-town America.

Many of these scenes ring true - but the parts don't always make for an authentic whole. For example, the film could probably have done without Woody's nephews Cole (Devin Ratray) and Bart (Tim Driscoll), cartoonish simpletons inserted for no other reason it seems than comic relief.

Woody drifts in and out of coherence but he remains single-minded in the pursuit of his prize, while David struggles mightily to bring his father back home with his health and dignity intact. He also sees some of his father in himself - and that scares him. During their scenes together, Nebraska reveals itself to be a sweet-natured endeavour, complete with some real-life lessons. "The guy just needs something to live for," says David. Now isn't that the truth.

Rating:

B

site_title: And then there was sound
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

And then there was sound

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A SMALL but potent exhibition is now on at Lasalle College of the Arts. Its subject? Sound.

As you might imagine, it's difficult to show pictures here of anything that looks remotely exciting from the exhibition. Its most direct pleasures may be had, instead, at the 16 listening stations placed around the small gallery.

Pull up a seat, put on a headset and be transported by myriad sonic creations by Singapore artists.

They range from indecipherable cacophonies and dull throbbings, to melodic lullabies and gentle waves of near silences.

One would need minutes of careful listening to discern the sonic arcs of the works.

Since the 1980s, various artists have been experimenting with new sonic forms and alternative instrumentations. But because most works tend to be ephemeral and take place in music gigs and record stores, they remain largely under the radar of art history.

Curated by Bani Haykal and Joleen Loh, the exhibition titled Sound: Latitudes and Attitudes is the first survey of its kind to document the elusive history of sonic arts in Singapore.

Only a few works, such Tang Da Wu and Joe Ng's To Make Friends Is All We Want (1989) and The Artists Village's The Time Show (1990), have attracted some form of documentation.

And these have been duly borrowed from the archives of artist-historian Koh Nguang How, the Substation and other individuals and organisations to show at the exhibition.

Loh says: "Sonic arts are difficult to document and write about. There are so many interpretations and no simplistic signifiers. Obviously, there's no such thing as a sound art curator in Singapore either. But it is an important form of expression and not to be ignored."

Several of the 17 artists featured in this exhibition began making sonic arts after working on an entirely different media for years.

For instance, Zul Mahmod and Kai Lam were trained as sculptors. But they found sound art to be similar to creating sculptures - even if the former is not presented in a physical form that the eye can see.

For other sonic artists such as theatre sound designer Darren Ng and musician Evan Tan, it may be a natural extension of their practices.

Interestingly, the curators have also included the gorgeous soundscapes of acclaimed band The Observatory as important contributions to art form.

Curator Bani, who is himself an acclaimed musician, says: "The way to appreciate sonic arts is to listen without prejudice. We are all conditioned to interpret sounds in a certain way. But we need to forget that and instead be sensitive to what we hear here. Forget about trying to formulate a structure or meaning - just listen."

The exhibition, which opens to the public today, also features works by notable artists such as Gilles Massot, Song-Ming Ang and Joyce Koh, There are sonic art performances at 7pm by Lam and Shaun Shankaran on Feb 19, Brian O'Reilly and George Chua on March 5, and Gulayu Arkestra, Dennis Tan and Delphine May on March 12.

Sound: Latitudes and Attitudes is now on till March 18 at Lasalle College of the Arts, Earl Lu Gallery. Lasalle is located at 1 McNally Street, next to Sim Lim Square.

content:

Chia Boon Kuah re-elected as Redas chief

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The guesswork is over. Current president of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas), Chia Boon Kuah, has been re-elected for the two-year term ending this year.

The question of who the position would go to was thrown in the air, after it was announced in October that Mr Chia would be leaving Far East Organisation for GuocoLand.

This is because membership of the management committee is tied to the company and not the individual.

Mr Chia was formerly the chief operating officer of property sales and executive director at Far East Organisation. He took over from Quek Chee Hoon as group president and CEO of Guocoland from Monday.

Under the Redas constitution, the industry body elects 15 members and can co-opt up to five more to its management committee. This committee then decides on various office holders from among themselves, for roles such as first and second vice-presidents and honorary secretary.

Mr Chia was elected president last year, for a two-year term.

With the shuffle in personnel, Far East was to nominate a new representative to the management committee to replace Mr Chia.

However, since Guocoland is also one of the management committee members for the current two-year term, Mr Chia was eligble as a candidate (for president) once nominated as Guocoland's representative.

In a statement yesterday, Redas said that Mr Chia was "unanimously re-elected" to be the president again for the current term.

"Mr Chia expressed his appreciation to management committee members for their strong support," it added.

site_title: Sochi-bound airlines get possible terrorism warning
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sochi-bound airlines get possible terrorism warning

They're told to watch for toothpaste tubes containing explosives

Published

Thu, Feb 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] Airlines flying to Winter Olympics host Russia are being warned to watch for toothpaste tubes containing materials that could be used by terrorists to make a bomb, according to a US law enforcement official.

The official declined to elaborate on the intelligence that sparked the alert, which was sent on Wednesday to US and foreign carriers, just two days before the start of the 2014 Games in Sochi, Russia. The official wasn't authorised to discuss the warning publicly and asked for anonymity.

Security at Sochi is tight in response to threats of terror strikes by Islamic militants. The Black Sea resort is just a few hundred kilometres from the North Caucasus region, where Russia has been battling Islamic extremists.

US Representative Peter King, chairman of the House subcommittee on counterterrorism and intelligence, said on Wednesday that airlines and people attending the Games should take such threats seriously. The New York Republican declined to go into detail about the warning to carriers.

"Odds are nothing is going to happen, but the odds are higher than for any Olympics, I believe, that something could happen," Mr King said in an interview on CNN.

Even with heavy security at the Olympics sites, he said "there's real cause for concern" in areas outside of official venues. Mr King said that while fans and guests are "reasonably safe", he wouldn't attend the Games as a spectator.

The warning to carriers was reported earlier by ABC News.

In a statement, the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) said the agency "regularly shares relevant information with domestic and international partners, including those associated with international events such as the Sochi Olympics".

"We are not aware of a specific threat to the homeland at this time," the DHS said in the statement. "This routine communication is an important part of our commitment to making sure we meet that priority."

Delta Air Lines Inc is alone among the major US carriers in serving Russia, with one daily Moscow flight from New York's John F Kennedy International Airport. Spokesmen for Delta, American Airlines and United Airlines declined to discuss security issues, as is customary in the industry.

The Transportation Security Administration, which is part of DHS, restricts the size of carry-on containers of gels and liquids, including toothpaste tubes, to no more than 3.4 ounces (100 millilitres). The limit doesn't apply to checked bags, which are scanned by explosives detection machines.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has vowed to keep Sochi safe by locking down the seaside city of about 345,000, deploying 40,000 troops and state of-the-art equipment.

Sochi, which lies west of the Caucasus Mountains, borders one of Russia's most economically distressed regions, stretching from Chechnya to Dagestan. A separatist movement in Chechnya grew into an Islamist insurgency that spilled into nearby provinces and which Russia has struggled to suppress.

Three suicide attacks last year rocked Volgograd, about halfway between Moscow and Sochi. Russian security forces staged a raid in Dagestan earlier on Wednesday, killing the leader of an extremist group suspected in two of the attacks.

Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday that the US has 140 people, including FBI agents, Homeland Security personnel and the military, working with the Russians on security.

The Olympics in Sochi will be as "safe as you can make any large public event in a place where obviously we all know there have been some threats of late", Mr Kerry said in an interview on CNN. "We feel that everything has been done that can be done to try to guarantee people safety and security."

The Games open today and run through Feb 23. As many as 10,000 Americans are expected to visit Sochi, according to four Obama administration officials who briefed reporters on Jan 24 on condition of anonymity.

The US has warned athletes and fans planning to attend the Olympics to be aware of recent terrorist threats from Islamic militants, and the Pentagon has said it's prepared to evacuate Americans from Russia if needed. - Bloomberg

content:
Golf clubs to know lease renewal fate on Feb 16

The government is expected to announce policy on lease extensions

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Feb 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

GOLF clubs, which have held off major developments as they await confirmation on the renewal of their leases, will learn of their fate come next Sunday.

A LONG-LEASE industrial site in Tuas South has been launched for sale by Expression of Interest for $8.9 million, says exclusive marketing agent Jones Lang LaSalle.

The 34,189 square foot site at 17 Tuas South Street 5 consists of a two-storey building with production and storage space, and a mezzanine office. The gross floor area (GFA) is approximately 39,795 sq ft, and the lease tenure has about 45 years left.
