content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Manufacturing growth slows in January

New export orders decline for first time since October

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Factory activity in the United States expanded in January at the weakest pace in eight months as orders slumped, a sign manufacturing cooled at the start of the year along with the weather.

The Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) factory index decreased to 51.3 from 56.5 the prior month, the Tempe, Arizona-based group's report showed yesterday. The median forecast of 85 economists surveyed by Bloomberg called for a decrease to 56. Readings above 50 indicate expansion.

Colder-than-normal temperatures in the US and weakness in some emerging markets helped slow factory demand last month. Sustained gains in consumer purchases, improvement in the labour market and a pick-up in capital spending will be needed to keep assembly lines humming in the world's biggest economy. Manufacturing accounts for about 12 per cent of the economy.

"Manufacturing activity was on a roll late in 2013, and a lot of economic activity and data has been suppressed somewhat because of the extraordinary weather that we've had," Ward McCarthy, chief financial economist at Jefferies LLC in New York, said before the report. "Right now it's just hard to figure out weather distortions and the fundamental developments and how to disentangle them."

But Bradley Holcomb, chairman of the ISM's manufacturing report, was more sanguine during a conference call with reporters.

"Comments from the panel this month show a mix of concern over severe weather conditions from the coldest January in many, many years," said Mr Bradley. "The outlook for the rest of the year remains solid. This is a blip on the screen."

About 55 minutes into trade, the Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 156.92 points (1.00 percent) to 15,541.93. The broad-based S&P 500 sank 18.85 (1.06 percent) to 1,763.74, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index fell 51.31 (1.25 percent) to 4,052.57.

The factory gauge averaged 53.9 for all of 2013. The ISM's new orders measure slumped to 51.2 last month, from 64.4 in December, while a gauge of production dropped to 54.8 from 61.7. The index of bookings waiting to be filled decreased to 48 in January from 51.5. The measure of factory employment fell to 52.3 from 55.8 in December.

Another report earlier also showed manufacturing grew less briskly in January after hitting an 11-month high the prior month as output and overseas demand slowed, an industry report showed on Thursday.

Financial data firm Markit said its final US Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index fell to 53.7 in January, matching an advance reading earlier in the month. The index hit an 11-month high of 55.0 in December.

Output fell to 53.5, a four-month low, from 57.5. Some firms attributed the slower pace of growth to the extremely cold weather in large swaths of the country.

New export orders meanwhile declined for the first time since October.

Firms took on new workers, however, for the seventh straight month, though the pace of hiring eased slightly, with the sub-index dropping to 53.2 from 54.0.

"The rate of job creation remained solid and was only slightly less marked than December's recent high," Markit said in a statement. "Panel members attributed increased workforce numbers to rising production requirements."

Construction spending meanwhile rose modestly in December to its highest level since March 2009, as a jump in private residential projects offset weakness in the public construction sector.

The sector was up 0.1 per cent to an annual rate of US$930.5 billion, the Commerce Department said yesterday. Economists polled by Reuters had expected an increase of 0.2 per cent. Construction spending in November was revised to show a 0.8 per cent rise instead of the previously reported 1.0 per cent increase.

The December construction spending data was buoyed by a 2.6 per cent jump in private residential construction. Overall private construction spending increased 1.0 per cent to an annual rate of US$663.9 billion, the highest level since December 2008.

Public construction spending, however, fell 2.3 per cent, its biggest drop in a year, with state and local outlays falling 2.7 per cent. Federal construction spending was up 2.0 per cent in the month. - Bloomberg, Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

DBS, OCBC see jump in brand value

While both improve their global ranking this year, UOB slips two spots to 89th

Published

Tue, Feb 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DBS and OCBC have improved their global brand ranking among lenders in the world with double-digit growth, a study by Brand Finance has found. UOB, however, experienced tepid growth and saw a fall in its global ranking.

According to the annual Top 500 Banking Brands ranking, the three local banks collectively have the greatest brand value of any Asean country, with a total brand value of US$8.5 billion.

Brand valuation agency Brand Finance calculated brand value by examining the royalties which a company would have had to pay to license its brand if the firm did not already own it. This form of calculation for intangible assets is known as the "royalty relief" method.

DBS is ahead of its local peers with a brand value of US$4 billion this year, up 15.4 per cent from a year earlier. It is ranked 54th place among 500 global banks this year, up four positions from 58th place previously.

DBS also took pole position among all Asean banks in terms of brand value, maintaining its top spot last year.

OCBC came in second with a brand value of US$2.3 billion, a 35.7 per cent jump over the previous year. It is ranked 81st globally, rising several notches from 102nd position in 2013.

UOB registered a much smaller growth in brand value this year, at US$2.2 billion, a 3.3 per cent year-on-year increase.

UOB also fell two spots to 89th position globally.

Samir Dixit, managing director of Brand Finance Asia Pacific, said the strength of these bank brands will be tested this year amid earning risks in the region.

"Constant downgrades to GDP estimates, coupled with the slowdown in mortgages, will likely create some business downside in the next few quarters," he warned.

"That is where a strong brand will play a significant role to help retain customers, reduce churn, build customer confidence and improve profitability".

Wells Fargo remains the world's most valuable bank brand, with a brand value this year of just over US$30 billion, up 16.1 per cent over the previous year. It is followed by HSBC, with a brand value of US$26.9 billion, up 17.5 per cent year on year.

Wells Fargo overtook JP Morgan to become America's biggest bank by profitability last year. It has also enjoyed "a more favourable reputation" than its peers, Brand Finance noted. This is on the back of Wells Fargo's strength in traditional banking, and a perceived distance from Wall Street.

Of the top 10 banks with the highest brand value, just three are from Asia, and specifically, China. ICBC stands at sixth spot, China Construction Bank is ninth, and Agricultural Bank Of China edged into the top 10 list this year, moving up one spot from 11th in 2013.

site_title: TripAdvisor redesigns site to break down cost of airline seats
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

TripAdvisor redesigns site to break down cost of airline seats

Published

Tue, Feb 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] The online travel company TripAdvisor is set to introduce an ambitious redesign of its flights search feature that will provide detailed information globally on any given flight's price - including added charges for options such as extra legroom - as well as on in-flight amenities such as the availability of Wi-Fi and in-seat power ports.

Underscoring the rapid growth in international travel and the demand for easily accessible comparison-shopping information, the feature will be localised for 31 countries and in 17 languages.

"Not all flights are the same; not all airlines are the same," said Bryan Saltzburg, general manager for new initiatives at TripAdvisor.

Mr Saltzburg's understatement underlines the complexity in choices and options that travellers encounter, as airlines in the United States and around the world refine a successful business model based on charging customers what they choose to pay for service, comfort and convenience.

TripAdvisor describes its redesign as a move to simplify what can be an enormously complicated shopping experience for those who book their own flights, as a growing number of business travellers do. A given search result will show all available flights, with fare comparisons and a breakdown, by flight segment, of amenities and services on a particular airplane.

Mr Saltzburg said: "Customers will have transparency while they're making a booking decision between Flight A and Flight B, which might be the same cost. Are extra-legroom seats available for sale? That's clearly indicated on the initial results page."

Other information is presented, such as seat pitch, flight on-time records, and availability of Wi-Fi and in-seat power ports, as well as seatback video and TV. Search results will also display what Mr Saltzburg called "candid photos" taken by customers on thousands of flights.

For many business travellers, the old days of faithfully booking the airline on which the traveller has loyalty status are waning, as airlines around the world put a price tag on many perks - better coach seats, upgrades and the like - that used to be given as awards for mileage-programme status.

Meanwhile, as airlines have merged and begun sharing more flights through global alliances, the experience of booking an international trip, even on a favoured airline, has become more complicated.

"With airline consolidation, customers have more choice of who they can fly, even within their loyalty network, while the value of loyalty programmes has been diminishing year over year," Mr Saltzburg said.

Comparing and evaluating costs and services airline by airline, even airplane by airplane on specific flight segments, can be a real challenge.

In all flying classes, legroom and seating comfort are by far the main considerations passengers cite when asked about the most important in-flight amenity, assuming that they are given a choice.

TripAdvisor, which was spun off in 2011 by the online booking company Expedia, operates more than a dozen other travel sites. They include SeatGuru.com, which provides diagrams and evaluations of airplane seats and cabin layouts by model of plane and airline.

In booking a flight, Mr Saltzburg said, the revamped features "will help consumers understand they can have a very different experience at the same dollar, whether it's a four-hour flight or a 15-hour one". - NYT

site_title: Want a NY condo with a personal shopper?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Want a NY condo with a personal shopper?

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] On Central Park South here, a luxury building is offering its residents direct access to Bergdorf Goodman's buyers, who can find them that special accessory from Paris. In Tribeca, a developer hired educators from the 92nd Street Y to design the basement playroom.

But perhaps nothing quite says modern chic like having a poet on board, like Howard Altmann, who wrote a short work, Once, as part of the marketing of the Schumacher, a new condo on Bleecker Street: "Once," the poem closes, "In the lifetime of a neighbourhood / An opportunity emerges / To make a singular imprint / In how we live."

It is old hat that a well- known architect and interior designer are required to play in New York's field of ultra-fancy real estate development. But with the intense competition to capture the US$3 million-plus buyer, the cast of characters and add-ons involved in the city's most luxurious new condominiums is growing ever longer.

"If you look back six or seven years ago, amenities were kind of Sheetrock boxes in the basement of buildings where you put a few treadmills and called it the gym," said Michael Iannacone, the executive at Related Cos who is leading the redevelopment of One Madison, a luxury building that will have, among various perks, a glass-walled steam room with a floor-to-ceiling view of Madison Park.

These days, expectations have skyrocketed. "What people want is really a curated amenity package that's an extension of their home," Mr Iannacone said.

Just as luxury consumers might want a Prada bag and a Chanel jacket, so might they respond to building amenities that reflect how they see themselves in the marketplace. That is the idea at 22 Central Park South, a newly overhauled landmark building with seven residences, priced from US$6.7 million to US$26.5 million, that is teaming up with Bergdorf Goodman, the department store around the corner.

The model apartment - the only completed unit so far - is stocked with brass sculptures, fine china and vintage books from Bergdorf's decorative furnishings floor. Sequined ball gowns glimmer in the master closet, and the store's 2013 catalogue rests on a table.

The touches are meant to illustrate what the developer, Elad Group, hopes will entice prospective foreign pied-à-terre buyers: the building's VIP relationship with Bergdorf's, whose staff will be on call for services including personal shopping and at- home salon treatments.

"This is our target customer anyway, and now we're having direct access to them," said Andrew Mandell, vice-president of decorative home at Bergdorf's.

With wealthy families increasingly choosing to stay in the city, rather than decamp to the suburbs, children's playrooms have taken on new significance. In Tribeca, for example, Taconic Investment Partners asked the 92nd Street Y, whose nursery school has among the city's most competitive admissions, to design the playroom for its new development on Laight Street, where apartments average US$2,700 per square foot.

The basement playroom at the development, Sterling Mason, will have reading and art stations and an area sensitive to the needs of nursing mothers.

"To some extent, there is only so much you can do different," said Dan McInerney, a vice-president at Taconic, given that buyers have come to expect a full complement of amenities from catering kitchens to gathering spaces. "I think the way you do distinguish yourself is the level of service and doing things a little more thoughtfully."

One quirk to the latest emphasis on amenities is the level of name-dropping in a building's marketing as a way to indicate its quality. In part, this might be a reaction to the kind of luxury fatigue that emerged from the city's last condo building boom, from 2003 to 2007, when units began to look so standardised, with the same finishes, that developments "felt more commoditised than I think was the intention", said Jonathan J Miller, president of the real estate appraisal firm Miller Samuel.

These days, boutique condos are more apt to look like the Schumacher, a 20-unit condo at 36 Bleecker Street created from a repurposed 1800s industrial building, where units - known as mansions, penthouses or residences - range from US$3.5 million to US$25 million. Its website features photos of people who, while accomplished in their fields, are not exactly household names, like the public space curator (Cristina Grajales, who owns a SoHo gallery) and Altmann, the poet. "There's a personal component to luxury that is always there, but right now you are seeing it marketed on steroids," Mr Miller said. Brochures list even obscure designers with such confidence, he said, that "even if you've never heard of him, you don't really want to say that you've never heard of him."

Altmann said he had participated in the building's marketing campaign to help support his non- commercial poetry. "I'd like to imagine the day poets will get paid as many a painter has been paid to don some white shirt for some billboard overlooking the highways and biways of America," he said.

Roto Group, a design firm based in Dublin, Ohio, that usually works on commissions like children's museums and aquariums, designed the playroom at Greenwich Lane, the luxury development rising on the former St Vincent's Hospital site in the West Village. The president, Joseph Wisne, said he was pleasantly surprised that the company's name was featured on the property's sleek website because "it's pretty rare in our industry to be credited."

With the high prices of land and construction, developers use amenities to create value in new projects so that they can achieve the kind of pricing - often starting at around US$3,000 psf - that they seek. But there are several ways to do it.

One way is to go bigger, like at Extell Development's three West Side Manhattan condo towers - One Riverside Park is the latest - which share a 40,000 sq ft exercise space managed by a private gym and wellness firm called La Palestra. It has a 75-foot-long indoor pool, a bowling alley, a rock-climbing wall, a basketball court and a golf simulator room among its features.- NYT

site_title: Yoma faces new landscape on its path of diversification
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Yoma faces new landscape on its path of diversification

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ANDREW Rickards, the chief executive of Yoma Strategic Holdings, is fond of telling people that he wants to turn the real estate company into the Jardine Matheson of Myanmar. His choice of Jardine Matheson, the storied conglomerate of the Orient, is well thought out, because history is littered with the debris of failed or struggling diversified groups such as Korea's Daewoo or Brazil's EBX Group.

Yoma's diversification efforts offer exciting exposure to the expected growth of Myanmar's economy. But as the diversification becomes more substantial, the company and shareholders will have to watch out for the pitfalls of conglomerates.

Yoma, one of the purest listed Myanmar plays in the world, has been stepping up its diversification over the past year.

In February 2013, it moved into the auto after-sales service business through a joint venture with Mitsubishi. The company's presence in the auto business now includes distribution, not just for Mitsubishi, but also for Sumitomo Corp's Hino brand trucks and buses, as well as rental and leasing.

After failing to win one of the two mobile network licences offered by the Myanmar government, Yoma has nevertheless kept a foot in the door. Ooredoo, one of the winners of those licences, has contracted a Yoma joint venture to help build the infrastructure equipment.

Yoma also has a balloon tourism business that is already up and running.

All of that is in addition to Yoma's traditional real estate business, which has been growing at a steady clip and has been expanding as well into mixed-use projects.

What does all of this diversification mean for Yoma?

The immediate answer is not much, yet. A lot of the new businesses are still in extremely early stages, so real estate still accounts for about 90 per cent of Yoma's business. It remains to be seen how much of Yoma's ambitions today will actually be fulfilled.

The market has also been wary about over-optimism. After its stellar climb in 2012, Yoma's shares now appear to be stuck in a range. The stock has closed between 70 and 80 cents since October 2013, last changing hands at 73 cents on Thursday.

In general, those new businesses can be seen in a positive light.

Yoma happens to operate in what is expected to be a high-growth market in Myanmar. It also happens to be one of the most attractive joint venture partners for companies looking to build a presence in Myanmar.

Which means that from Mr Rickards' office in Myanmar, the world outside looks like juicy growth opportunities everywhere, and he just has to take his pick. That is an enviable position to be in, and it is perfectly reasonable that Mr Rickards and Yoma should strike when the right opportunity comes along. Why leave that money on the table for someone else?

Diversification could also bring benefits in terms of risk management. If Yoma can spread out the sources of its revenue, it could be less exposed to cycles in one particular sector, such as property, or so the theory goes.

The risk argument, however, can be a little, well, risky. That is because the jury is still out on the benefits of conglomerates.

Conglomerates can get too big and complex, which adds costs and inefficiencies into the various businesses, rendering them less competitive than more focused rivals.

Markets also sometimes exact a "conglomerate discount" on diversified companies. The recent example of the Fraser and Neave group suggests that breaking up a conglomerate can be more profitable than keeping it together.

The fact is that conglomerates around the world have had vastly different fortunes. Among India's family empires, for example, the Tata group's strong growth over the past decade contrasts with the fortunes of the Reliance group, which found itself under a mountain of debt.

BCG, the consulting group, has a theory about "premium conglomerates" that management quality is the difference maker.

That is a good place to start for Yoma shareholders. While it is still too early to say what Yoma's new ventures will eventually grow into, shareholders can at least begin to assess whether management has what it takes to run an empire.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Rex jumps on news of Oman hydrocarbon find

Discovery made using firm's virtual drilling technology

Published

Tue, Feb 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DEFYING a weak market, Swedish oil and gas exploration firm Rex International's shares rose 8 per cent to 65 cents yesterday amid heavy trading, after it said that a joint-venture unit had found hydrocarbons in a second exploration well in Oman.

The discovery, made using the Rex Virtual Drilling technology, is a testament to the accuracy of Rex's direct hydrocarbon detector, said its executive chairman, Dan Brostrom.

This comes after a setback in its first exploration well in Oman, when its share price fell 8.6 per cent in late December.

Drilling at that well had been stopped owing to mud losses, which posed risks of a blowout. Masirah Oil Limited, an indirectly owned subsidiary of Rex, had drilled to a depth of about 1,000 metres below the mean sea level, short of the target depth.

In a statement yesterday, Masirah said it had successfully reached the planned depth of more than 3,000 metres in the second exploration well in Oman, where hydrocarbons were discovered in several formations.

Rex International holds a 65 per cent stake in Lime Petroleum, which in turn owns 64 per cent in Masirah. Masirah has a full stake in the Block 50 concession in the east of Oman.

Masirah began drilling work on the second well early last month.

"The discovery of hydrocarbons in (the) second exploration well is a significant step towards the deepening of our knowledge and understanding of the offshore geology in the east of Oman, where no discovery has been made before," said Masirah chairman Hans Lidgren. "The results from this well are vital for the future development of this block."

The development will boost investor confidence in the efficacy of the Rex Virtual Drilling technology, said DBS Vickers analyst Suvro Sarkar.

Rex's technology allows the firm to directly identify liquids such as oil, condensate gas and water in the ground from seismic data, compared with the industry practice of looking at geological structures from seismic data and making probability estimates of finding oil.

This boosts its success rate in exploratory drilling to more than 50 per cent, far above the global industry average of 10-15 per cent, it claimed.

Rex also said last month that Lime Petroleum had been awarded five new offshore licences in Norway, taking its portfolio there to 12 and 21 internationally.

site_title: S'pore brand to ride on WTA event: STB
content:
S'pore brand to ride on WTA event: STB

Agency prepares to ramp up efforts to plug prestigious tournament here and abroad

Lee U-Wen

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] That Singapore will be home to the prestigious Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Championships for five straight years - the longest run for a host city - is a major advantage for the Republic's branding as a top destination for events.

Singapore Tourism Board (STB) chief executive Lionel Yeo said staging this world-class tournament here for such a long stretch is a "plus" as his agency prepares to ramp up its efforts to promote the event, both at home and abroad.

"We have a longer runway to build that brand recognition that the WTA Championships are in Singapore and a longer period of time to reap the returns on our investments in terms of marketing," he told The Business Times in an exclusive interview.

A key factor driving STB's philosophy when it comes to choosing which events to support is whether there is enough time to develop the association between that particular event and Singapore as the host, he added.

"(There's) no point having a one- shot deal, or many one-shot deals. It doesn't help us to build up the destination awareness and branding."

The season-ending WTA Championships will feature the top eight women's singles players and doubles pairs competing for a record prize purse of US$6.5 million.

The 10-day event will be held at the Singapore Indoor Stadium at the new $1.33 billion Singapore Sports Hub, which will open its doors this April.

Tens of thousands of spectators are expected to throng the venue to catch their favourite stars in action, with millions more tuning in "live" from around the world.

Singapore will become the ninth city to host the WTA Championships in the event's 42-year history, following in the footsteps of Boca Raton (Florida), Los Angeles, Oakland, New York City, Munich, Madrid, Doha and Istanbul.

When the Republic was unveiled as the new host last May, Mr Yeo said the tournament would net about $15 million in tourism receipts for each of the five instalments - a figure that he is sticking to today.

To attract as many visitors as possible to the October event, Mr Yeo said STB plans to reach out to countries where tennis is a popular sport, such as China, India, Indonesia and Thailand.

He is confident that tennis fans will get their money's worth when it comes to the WTA Championships because the quality of the matches are "as good, if not better" than those at the four Grand Slam events such as Wimbledon or the US Open.

"We are working hard with the event promoter (World Sport Group), as well as the WTA, to make sure that the WTA Championships in Singapore will be the best ever for them," said Mr Yeo. "That is important from our perspective because we see this event as burnishing our credentials as the events capital of Asia. It's got to be done well, and it's got to be done in a way which Singapore excels in."

While the final line-up of players coming to Singapore will not be confirmed until much closer to October, the current top eight women's singles players include Australian Open champion Li Na of China, Serena Williams of the United States and Poland's Agnieszka Radwanska.

At last year's tournament in Istanbul, Williams defeated Li Na in three sets to win her career-high 11th title of 2013 and fourth WTA crown.

site_title: Aussie home prices up 1.2% in Jan
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Aussie home prices up 1.2% in Jan

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Home prices across Australia's major cities rose 1.2 per cent in January, from the previous month, extending a strong run that has boosted household wealth and confidence.

Figures from property consultant RPData-Rismark showed that overall dwelling prices were up 9.8 per cent compared to January last year, led by a 13.4 per cent jump in Sydney. Prices in Melbourne followed with a gain of 11.9 per cent while Perth saw an increase of 6.9 per cent.

Home values were now 4.8 per cent higher than their previous peak in October 2010.

While higher prices have stirred talk of a bubble, they are considered by policymakers as necessary to encourage a much-needed revival in home building.

The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), which cut interest rates to a historic low of 2.5 per cent last August, has been counting on home construction to provide vital support to the economy as a long boom in mining investment cools.

The central bank holds it first policy meeting of the year today and is widely expected to hold rates steady given signs that they are working to revive demand in the economy.

"The sustained growth in dwelling values is another factor the RBA is likely to consider when deliberating on any movement in the cash rate," said RP Data research director Tim Lawless.

Still, Mr Lawless doubted that prices could continue to rise at the current pace given very low rental yields, increasing affordability constraints and higher levels of housing supply. - Reuters

Ryanair bookings up amid fare war

Discount carrier trimmed tariffs on almost 1,000 routes

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] Ryanair Holdings plc said it's winning a fare war embroiling Europe's network and discount carriers as lower ticket prices spur bookings and charges for reserved seating and priority boarding help lift revenue.

Ryanair shares rose the most since May 20 after the Dublin-based company said non-ticket sales rose 13 per cent in the fiscal third quarter through December and that bookings for the current period are significantly ahead of a year ago.

Europe's biggest discount carrier responded to a tougher pricing environment this winter by trimming tariffs on almost 1,000 routes and grounding about 70 jets to pare capacity. The measures helped boost passenger numbers 6 per cent to 18.3 million in the third quarter, even as it posted a 35.2 million euro (S$60.6 million) loss from the competition over fares.

"The weakness has eased," chief financial officer Howard Millar said yesterday in an interview. "The market is still soft, but the rate of decline has stopped and bottoming out or stable would be our view at the moment."

The stock has gained 17 per cent in the last 12 months, valuing the airline at 9.07 billion euros.

Chief executive Michael O'Leary reiterated in a statement that full-year profit through March 31 will be about 510 million euros.

While yields, a measure of pricing, will still drop about 8 per cent in the fourth quarter, that's less than the 10 per cent previously forecast, the company said.

Ryanair and discount rival EasyJet plc are looking to expand their networks as former flag carriers undertake the latest revamps of their short-haul units. Deutsche Lufthansa AG and Air France-KLM Group have bolstered European offerings and British Airways owner International Consolidated Airlines Group SA has bought new planes for its low-cost Spanish unit Vueling.

The Irish carrier opened four Italian bases in December and plans to station planes in Brussels, Lisbon, and Athens and Thessaloniki in Greece. The new locations will help boost the customer total to 110 million from just over 80 million over the next five years, it said in a statement.

"Substantial" growth will come from primary airports, according to the release, marking a shift away from its focus on secondary bases, where the travel market tends to be more discretionary and fares generally lower.

Ryanair offered an introductory fare of 14.99 euros on about 400 routes in October and November, adding to 600 links already on sale. Grounding jets from November through March will remove 750,000 seats from the market, Mr O'Leary has said.

The carrier plans to triple its marketing spend this year to about 35 million euros and is moving to fully-allocated seating this month in a push to draw business passengers and customers looking for higher service levels.

Early trials to ensure a smooth roll-out of designated berths should protect the carrier's 25-minute turnaround time, Mr Millar said.

"We have the weakest month in terms of passenger volumes, which is February, to iron out the teething problems, so our view is we should be in a pretty good situation," he said. "We need reserved and allocated seating take-up to be positive because we have reduced other charges."

Other refinements to the airline's ultra-low-cost model include a de-cluttered website, reduced baggage fees and specialised products targeting corporate customers and groups.

The carrier's online booking process has been streamlined to five "clicks" from 17 and Ryanair will begin issuing mobile boarding passes in April.

The carrier extended its fiscal-year 2015 fuel hedge to 90 per cent at US$960 per tonne on the back of a weaker US dollar and lower oil prices. Fuel and currency hedging will deliver cost savings of about 80 million euros in 2015, Ryanair said. - Bloomberg

SIAEC's Q3 net down 9.7% on higher costs

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) saw its net profit for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, decline 9.7 per cent year-on-year to $60.5 million, due in part to higher costs.

Revenue edged up 2 per cent to $283.8 million, although expenditure grew at a faster pace, increasing 4.7 per cent to $258.6 million, on the back of higher staff costs, subcontract and material costs. This caused operating profit to drop $6 million to $25.2 million. There was also a smaller exchange gain of $0.1 million in the quarter under review versus a gain of $1.6 million in the third quarter of last year.

Share of profits from associated and joint venture companies rose 2.5 per cent year-on-year to $41 million.

Earnings per share for the third quarter slipped to 5.43 cents, down from 6.08 cents in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

For the nine months ended Dec 31, 2013, net profit came in at $200.5 million, down from $204.2 million previously, while revenue was 0.5 per cent higher at $867.1 million.

SIAEC warned that yields for maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) would continue to come under pressure because of the uncertain outlook for the global economy in the near term, as well as increasing business costs, especially where labour is concerned.

"The group remains focused on managing costs by pursuing improvements in productivity and enhancing operating efficiencies. Overall, the performance of the group is expected to remain stable," SIAEC said.

The group's cash balance stood at $462.1 million as at Dec 31.

The counter closed at $4.91 yesterday, down two cents.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Thai stocks, baht advance after voters defy protesters

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] Thailand's baht rose the most in three weeks yesterday and stocks gained after voters defied protesters' efforts to disrupt polls and cast ballots across 90 per cent of the country on Sunday without triggering major violence.

The currency strengthened 0.2 per cent - the most since Jan 14 - to 32.945 per US dollar at 5pm yesterday in Bangkok, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The baht fell every day last week, declining 0.6 per cent. The SET Index of shares climbed 1.5 per cent - the biggest gain since Jan 16 - to 1,292.81, following last week's 3.1 per cent drop.

Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra said she was pleased with the situation because there was no violence, after polls closed at 3pm local time on Sunday. She deployed 10,000 police in Bangkok, having declared a state of emergency to avoid a repeat of the disturbances that obstructed advance voting in the south and most of the capital on Jan 26. Global funds have pulled a net US$4.7 billion from the nation's bonds and stocks since the protests began last Oct 31, official data shows.

"There was some concern surrounding the election but it ended without any chaos, leading to some buybacks of the baht," said Kozo Hasegawa, a currency trader at Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp in Bangkok. "But a rebound in the baht may be limited as there's no change in the situation with political unrest continuing."

The country's third general election since a 2006 coup will do little to quell street protests by groups demanding Ms Yingluck's resignation and the installation of an appointed government. The results of the poll, which the main opposition Democrat Party boycotted, won't be announced until by-elections are held in dozens of districts where protesters blocked candidates from registering.

Ten people have been killed and almost 600 injured since the protests began. Suthep Thaugsuban, a former Democrat powerbroker who has led a three- month campaign to oust Ms Yingluck, said the election will be annulled because his group blocked candidates from registering in some provinces and shut down polling stations during advance voting. Protesters have also occupied several major intersections in the city since Jan 13 in a bid to prevent Ms Yingluck's government from functioning.

"Thai equities got a boost from a more peaceful election than people had expected," said Teerada Charnyingyong, an investment strategist at Phillip Securities (Thailand) Pcl in Bangkok. "Still, the gains will be limited as the election won't result in the formation of new government in the next few months. The delay will have a significant impact on the economy and corporate earnings."

Abhisit Vejjajiva, leader of the main opposition Democrat Party, said in an interview with Bloomberg Television that he didn't vote in Sunday's elections because he thinks the polls were unconstitutional. Ms Yingluck's ruling party betrayed the trust of the Thai people by attempting to pass a bill that would have given amnesty to her brother, Thaksin Shinawatra, he said.

The Democrat Party plans to file a petition to the Constitutional Court today, asking it to annul the general election on grounds that it was unconstitutional, Mr Abhisit told reporters.

The Finance Ministry lowered its 2014 growth forecast for the second time in a month on Jan 16 to 3.1 per cent from a December prediction of 4 per cent.

One-month implied volatility in the baht, a measure of expected moves in the exchange rate used to price options, fell four basis points, or 0.04 percentage point, to 7.38 per cent.

The yield on the 3.125 per cent government bonds due December 2015 declined one basis point to 2.44 per cent. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brokers' take

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Small-mid cap property

OCBC INVESTMENT RESEARCH, Feb 3

FOR its Q1FY14 (end-Sept 2013), Oxley Holdings announced a net income of S$250.8 million, up 37 times y-o-y. This comprised cash earnings, not valuation gains, and almost matched the combined earnings of CapitaLand and City Developments, the two largest domestic developers, over that quarter.

What caused Oxley's earnings spike? Under International Financial Reporting Standard 115, its 728-unit industrial project, Oxley BizHub, had its profits booked wholly upon attaining TOP (temporary occupation permit) over the quarter. This is known as the Completion of Contract (COC) recognition method and is required for commercial and overseas projects, unlike the progressive profit recognition (POC method) usually seen for domestic residential projects.

We note that the full visibility of COC profits can be price catalysts for small-mid cap companies, particularly if they are not well-covered; Oxley's share price subsequently appreciated as much as 40 per cent after its results announcement.

We highlight two companies likely to see similar earnings boosts ahead. First, Roxy-Pacific is expected to see a boost from Wis@Changi attaining TOP in its upcoming Q413 earnings. In addition, Lian Beng is also likely to have their next quarterly Q3FY14 earnings bumped up by its 55-per cent stake in M-Space achieving TOP. Both Roxy and Lian Beng are rated "buy" with fair value estimates of S$0.65 and S$0.58, respectively.

Genting Singapore

Feb 3 close: S$1.34

MAYBANK KIM ENG, Feb 3

MBS reported a 14 per cent y-o-y drop in Q413 Ebitda to US$258.8 million due to a 17 per cent y-o-y contraction (in USD terms) of Q4 VIP volume that was exacerbated by a low VIP hold rate of 1.92 per cent.

Q413 mass market GGR (table and slot) did not help much either, posting just 3 per cent y-o-y growth (in USD terms). The only silver lining is that the Japanese casino liberalisation process may be fast-tracked by a year.

Assuming Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) commands a 47-48 per cent VIP volume share, we can expect Genting Singapore (GENS) to also report Q413 VIP volume contraction of about 17 per cent y-o-y to about S$16 billion.

This would bring RWS' 2013 VIP volume to S$74.5 billion, in line with our forecast of S$75.3 billion.

For mass market GGR, if RWS retained its Q313 market share of 44 per cent in Q413, we estimate its Q413 mass market GGR would have eased by 5 per cent y-o-y. This would bring its 2013 mass market GGR to S$1.7 billion, or a tad below our forecast of S$1.8 billion.

GENS will release its Q413 results on Feb 20. While likely to be within expectations, we expect it will report a sequentially higher Q413 Ebitda of about S$350 million and net profit of S$200 million as we do not think its VIP hold rate will be as poor as MBS'. We leave our estimates unchanged for now.

Nonetheless, we believe the consensus is too bullish on GENS' earnings outlook and it is still premature to assign any "Japanese casino" option value to its share price as request for proposals are only likely to be issued in 2015, at the earliest. Maintain TP of S$1.31, based on 10x FY14E Enterprise value/Ebitda.

SELL

Cache Logistics Trust

Feb 3 close: S$1.085

UOB KAY HIAN, Feb 3

WE recently hosted Cache Logistics Trust's (Cache) management to a post-results feedback session with investors.

Positive reversions are likely for the master-leases coming due in 2015 (34 per cent of portfolio), based on current market rents.

Management was more optimistic on the prospects for higher reversions for properties in the eastern region of Singapore, where slower growth in new supply will ensure that occupancies remain high.

We estimate that the IPO portfolio could see double-digit rental reversions of 10-12 per cent in 2015, providing an organic growth catalyst, while annual rents under the master-leases have been growing at 1.5-2.0 per cent per annum over the four years from listing, with market rents for logistic facilities having risen 22 per cent since Q210.

While we anticipate that the bulk of the master-leases will be renewed in the next one to two years, management is preparing for the prospect that some master-leases may not be renewed and that Cache will assume the underlying management of the properties. To this end, management continues to engage with sub-tenants to ensure that underlying occupancies remain robust.

Asset divestments from the sponsor are still the preferred avenue for inorganic growth, but will be dependent on the sponsor CWT's timeline and funding needs. Sale-and-leaseback opportunities from the sponsor remain the favoured approach to further acquire master-leased properties at reasonable cap rates.

Management continues to explore third-party acquisition opportunities, although this has become more difficult in Singapore due to JTC policies requiring upfront payment of land premiums.

Management has acknowledged that sale-and-leaseback of master-leased properties will also become increasingly uncommon and that acquisitions of multi-tenanted facilities will be more typical moving forward. Overseas acquisitions in Malaysia and China remain a possibility, especially in or near the fringes of key tier-one cities.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hedge funds bet on gold as demand rises

Net-long position in gold up 40% to 60,672 futures and options last week

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Hedge funds raised bullish gold wagers by the most since July and sold copper holdings as emerging-market turmoil boosted concern that the global economy will slow and increased demand for precious metals as a haven.

The net-long position in gold jumped 40 per cent to 60,672 futures and options in the week ended Jan 28, US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) data show. Long wagers rose 5.5 per cent to the highest since September, and short bets dropped 16 per cent. Net-bullish copper holdings tumbled 62 per cent as shorts gained by the most in 11 weeks.

About US$1.9 trillion was erased from the value of global equities last month as China's economy slowed and the Federal Reserve further cut stimulus on Jan 29.

South Africa's central bank increased interest rates, Turkey more than doubled them and Argentina's peso dropped 19 per cent against the US dollar in January, more than any other currency tracked by Bloomberg. The tumult drove gold to its first monthly gain since August and copper to the worst start to a year since 2010.

"China rules the copper market, and it's obvious that there are no reasons for this market to move higher as supply is ample, and demand is sluggish," said Peter Jankovskis, who helps oversee US$3.5 billion as co-chief investment officer of Lisle, Illinois-based OakBrook Investments.

"Gold, on the other hand, is seeing some buying given the turmoil in many countries, but what remains to be seen is if the rally can sustain in the face of tapering."

Gold futures gained 3.1 per cent last month to US$1,239.80 an ounce, while copper dropped 5.9 per cent on the Comex in New York. The Standard & Poor's GSCI Spot Index of 24 commodities fell 1.6 per cent. The MSCI All-Country World Index of equities declined 4.1 per cent. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, a gauge against 10 major trading partners, rose 1.2 per cent. The Bloomberg Treasury Bond Index climbed 1.8 per cent.

Net wagers across 18 US-traded commodities rose 6.5 per cent to 782,818 contracts last week, the highest since October, the CFTC data showed.

The US Mint sold 91,500 ounces of gold coins last month, the most since April, joining counterparts from Australia to Europe in reporting higher demand. Prices rebounded more than 5 per cent since reaching a 34-month low in June as physical buying rose. Bullion shipments to China from Hong Kong in 2013 more than doubled to a record 1,108.8 tonnes from a year earlier, according to customs data. Gold for April delivery gained 0.5 per cent yesterday to US$1,246 an ounce on the Comex in New York.

Copper stockpiles monitored by the Shanghai Futures Exchange jumped 18 per cent last month, the first increase since October. Global production will outstrip use by 167,000 tonnes this year, following a deficit of 137,000 tonnes in 2013, Barclays plc estimates. The London Metal Exchange Index of the six main metals traded on the bourse fell 3.7 per cent last month, the worst start to a year since 2010.

The economy in China, the world's biggest consumer of everything from copper to cotton to pork, will expand 7.4 per cent this year, the slowest pace since 1990, a Bloomberg survey showed.

Robust growth in the US will help stem declines for industrial metals, and the rally in gold will be short-lived, according to James Paulsen, the Minneapolis-based chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management.

US household purchases, which account for about 70 per cent of the economy, climbed more than expected in December, Commerce Department figures showed on Jan 31. The Fed last week cut its monthly bond purchases to US$65 billion from US$75 billion, a second straight US$10 billion cut. Goldman Sachs Group Inc is forecasting more declines for gold after it fell 28 per cent last year. Prices will reach US$1,050 in the next 12 months, the bank said in a Jan 12 report.

Bullion holdings through exchange-traded products fell 33 per cent in the past year, erasing about US$71 billion from the value of the funds.

"What we are seeing is broadening of economic growth, and China is not contracting - the growth rate has slowed, but it's still growing," Mr Paulsen said. "Industrial metals may slowly see an upturn once the turmoil in emerging markets calms. At that point, there will not be much upside for gold."

Banks from Goldman to Citigroup said that raw materials are heading for more losses in 2014 as rising supplies and slowing demand compound slumps that led to bear markets last year in gold, copper and corn. The super cycle that led commodities to almost quadruple since 2001 is reversing, with prices set to drop 3 per cent in 12 months, Jeffrey Currie, Goldman's head of commodities research, said in the Jan 12 report. The asset class will be a "wallflower" compared with equities, Citigroup said in a Jan 6 note.

"The time when people were buying anything has moved, and now people are taking a view on individual commodities," said Frances Hudson, a strategist at Standard Life in Edinburgh.

"The super cycle has ended. The story for copper is neutral. The days of seeing high numbers from China may be ending. People saw gold was oversold last year, and money was moving to equities. There has been some reshuffle, but I don't think there has been a reversal of fortune for gold." - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Company Briefs

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Swiber clinches 5 deals worth US$235m

SWIBER Holdings said yesterday that it had secured five "sizeable" contracts worth a total of US$235 million.

Three of the contracts, which amounted to US$145 million, were awarded to the group for works that will be executed in Latin America and South-east Asia.

The remaining two contracts were awarded to Swiber's associate company and joint-venture firm, for services that will be executed in South-east Asia.

These contracts will begin immediately and are expected to be completed in the next two years, it said.

Strong demand for SP AusNet euro bond issue

SP AusNet said yesterday that its 350 million euro (S$603 million), 10-year euro bond issue to raise A$543 million (S$609.8 million) has met with "strong demand" and was close to four times oversubscribed.

This is the electricity distributor's second euro bond issue completed in the past 12 months. The earlier one was a 500 million euro, seven-year bond issue to raise A$707 million.

Like the earlier bond issue, the proceeds of the latest issue will go towards refinancing its existing debt and funding capital expenditure.

The bonds mature on Feb 13, 2024.

Stratech to upgrade Changi's surveillance

STRATECH Systems has clinched a contract from the Singapore government to upgrade iFerret™ infrastructure at Changi airport for airfield surveillance.

The IT and advanced technology systems developer declined to disclose the value of the deal.

"Airfield surveillance is critical for real-time incident management as well as post-event analysis for runway incursions and excursions, and other emergencies," it said.

The contract win marks the entrance of iFerret™ - Stratech's intelligent vision-based foreign object and debris detection system - into airfield surveillance.

The contract is not expected to impact substantially the company's financial results for its fiscal year ending March 2014.

Otto Marine promotes exec director

OTTO Marine has promoted Michael See to group executive director.

Prior to his promotion, Mr See was an executive director on the company's board. He has also served as group CFO since 2007, a post he will relinquish in conjunction with his promotion.

In his expanded role, Mr See will mainly support group CEO, Garrick Stanley, in the functions of business development and corporate services, while continuing to oversee the financial aspects, human resource management, office administration and information technology of the group.

Concurrently, Otto Marine has appointed Denville Wee as the new CFO to be in charge of the group's finance and accounting matters. Mr Wee has been in charge of similar functions across the technology and marine sectors in Singapore and overseas.

site_title: Betting on the winning Horse
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Betting on the winning Horse

How do you think the Year of the Horse will turn out for your industry or profession? What do you wish most for your organisation, and for Singapore?

Published

Sun, Feb 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive Singapore and CEO Private Banking Asia & Middle East ABN Amro Bank NV

2014 is the year of the Green Wooden Horse, which some say embodies optimism and compassion. In the spirit of optimism, we believe global recovery is on track, with economic growth in Asia likely to gain momentum. If the year were a race, our top picks would include Asian countries such as Singapore, which has sound economic fundamentals and a stable government, which we hope will enter the year on a gallop and aim for a strong finish.

The "wood" element is also said to help balance one's positive and negative characteristics. At ABN Amro, our wish is for our clients to continue maintaining balanced investment portfolios to increase diversification and resilience, so as to withstand any uncertainty that may occur in 2014.

For Singapore, we wish that everyone will not only be optimistic about the economy, but also to be more compassionate - just as we intend to continue keeping a lookout for the not so fortunate and to contribute to the sustainability of the community we do business in.

Dan Neary

Vice-President

Facebook APAC

IN 2014, reaching the relevant target audience at scale will no longer be restricted by traditional definitions of primetime. Primetime will be all the time, as time spent on digital networks, particularly on mobile, continues to rise. The year will see an increasing number of brands using mobile and digital tools such as location-based technology to reach out to customers at various touch points of the consumer journey, as well as to build rapport and brand identification. Social media will increasingly become mainstream as marketers continue to leverage digital platforms such as Facebook to engage people at scale and deliver core marketing outcomes. Businesses in Singapore will begin to better utilise targeting and measurement tools available to reach prospective customers on the digital and mobile landscape. These tools will level the playing field for businesses of all sizes and can reach the right people with more accuracy and efficiency than ever before.

Prakash Mallya

Country Manager

Intel Singapore and Malaysia

THE Year of the Horse is going to be exciting for Intel and our partners, whether it's bringing new devices to consumers or giving them a "sneak peek" into the next frontier of technology.

Leveraging the talent and experience, we aim to address new emerging form factors that are multi-tasking powerhouses and are capable of interacting with consumers in new ways. Touch it, type on it, or talk to it, we want to be the ones to make these devices a reality.

In the burgeoning age of the Internet of Things, we will dive into the world of wearable devices where we will provide tech-savvy Singaporeans with more meaningful and valuable experiences that will change the way they live. Our goal is to provide consumers the ability to experience tomorrow today.

Jean-Michel Dumont

Chairman, Asia

Ruder Finn Asia

AS we enter the Year of the Horse, the one word that would define the public relations industry is "nimble". This will be an asset public relations professionals will need to have. We need to recognise that communications is a multi-stakeholder process - the strategies and tactics we develop and implement must take this dynamic into consideration. More important, it is also about anticipating and listening to our audiences and responding effectively. Asia is at a crossroads economically and socially, and hence the need for engagement and effective communication is greater than ever.

Adam Judd

Vice-President, Asia Pacific

Brocade

The Horse is an auspicious animal in the Chinese zodiac which symbolises good luck, vitality and power. We are hopeful the Year of the Horse will help accelerate economic recovery globally and bring upon new opportunities and financial growth. In our industry, we expect new technologies such as software-defined networking and network functions virtualisation to gain momentum which will enable service providers to launch cloud services and drive new revenue streams. Brocade has always been at the forefront of industry trends. We are poised to continue building on our strengths and leadership position by tapping unprecedented opportunities that exist today and will reshape the networking industry tomorrow. We will continue to leverage our strong innovation heritage and excellent customer focus for growth this year. Let's not forget that the Horse can be wild and temperamental at times. Vigilance and agility are, therefore, key to success and surmounting challenges whenever the going gets tough.

Mark Billington FCA

Regional Director - South East Asia

ICAEW

ASEAN'S continuing growth and sound finances bode well for the accountancy sector in Singapore. The reforms to the professional qualification will be embedded this year, making it another key year for the profession as a whole. The challenge for the accountancy profession is always to attract and retain the best and the brightest talent, and on my wishlist for the New Year would be ensuring that access to the profession is further broadened so that anyone with the aptitude and ability to become a chartered accountant has the opportunity to enter the profession. This may mean increasing efforts in recruiting through non-traditional routes, or raising awareness of the profession among groups that might not traditionally have considered accountancy. It may also mean providing mentors and role models that inspire younger professionals to become business and finance leaders, and considering how we work so that the profession is seen as a "role for life". In the long term, it is in everyone's interests to recruit from the widest possible talent pool and this will ensure the profession remains relevant and dynamic going forward.

Lim Tit Meng

Chief Executive

Science Centre Singapore

THERE is a new energy in our pre-school education arena with many recent initiatives from both the public and private sectors. With good infrastructure, quality pre-school systems and early childhood education programmes, our young parents will have a conducive and nurturing environment to bring up their young ones. These developments may also encourage married couples to consider starting a family earlier or to have more children. Hopefully we will see a reverse trend in our declining birth rate. Science Centre Singapore will open a new Children Science Centre specially designed for age 8 and below in the middle of 2014. Through purposeful play, it will be an exciting place where children get to "imagine, experience, discover and dream". We aspire to become a significant part of the early childhood education ecosystem, building upon our 36 years of experience in intriguing the minds of millions through science, technology and creativity.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

WHILE Singapore continues to focus on tackling economic challenges and restructuring, we must not lose sight of the needy, poor, marginalised, disadvantaged, sick and incarcerated. Singapore has some way to go tobecoming a giving nation. To arrive there, it will require the active participation of the whole of the public, private and people sectors. So far, it is fair to say that the private sector has been leading the way. The call to give has often been to the private sector. It is timely to extend the call to the public sector to play a bigger role. It is vital that the public sector, represented by our civil servants in their private capacities, contribute more to giving. More civil servants, especially those in the higher echelons, can now afford to give, as compared with their peers in the past. Fund raisers should, therefore, not be wary of approaching civil servants to offer them the opportunity to give, be it to their alma maters, VWOs, charitable organisations or for a laudable cause. I wish the Year of the Horse will see this significant shift in our giving ecosystem, that more of our civil servants will ride together with their private sector counterparts and gallop to a new high in giving. It can be only for the good of Singapore, the community and businesses but more importantly for those who need the most help.

Marc Mathenz

Senior Vice-President and Head of Asia Pacific

First Data

2014 promises to be an exciting year for the payments industry. We are witnessing rapid digitisation of payments, as we continue a global shift away from paper to electronic. This is the greatest period of innovation we've seen, with new payment methods, business models, and even currencies reported by the media on a daily basis. In the New Year, we hope to see e-commerce in Singapore reach new levels, spurring wider adoption of alternative payment methods in addition to cash and credit and debit cards. We believe Singapore has the potential to develop breakthrough innovations that reduce consumer reliance on cash, and export those innovations to other countries in Asia. As a leading global payments solutions provider, First Data sees itself playing a pivotal role in driving these innovative products and powering transactions. We aim to expand further into South-east Asia, leveraging on Singapore's strategic position as a financial services hub.

Daniel Lim

Director

Soo Kee Group

THE Year of the Horse is believed to be an auspicious one for the Chinese and at SK Jewellery our outlook is equally bullish. Gold is traditionally seen as a symbol of wealth, prosperity and blessing. Recent adjustments in the gold price means that 999 Pure Gold items have become more accessible to all. SK Jewellery expects to see more people looking to our 999 Pure Gold collections as special gifts in 2014. Not only for the solid value that 999 Pure Gold represents, but also because giving gold signifies shared feelings of optimism for the future. On behalf of the Soo Kee Group, I would like to wish one and all a very happy and prosperous Chinese New Year, and I hope for a stronger and more stellar performance for the Singapore gold and diamond industry this year.

Alex Caro

Chief Technology Officer and

Vice-President of Services - Asia Pacific & Japan

Akamai Technologies

AKAMAI'S mission is to make the Internet fast, reliable and secure. The Year of the Horse indeed portends fleet growth for our customers across a range of industries. From online video broadcasts of live events, to expected record growth in eCommerce, to even more enterprise software moving to the cloud, the Internet will come one step closer to being the most pervasive, most adaptable communication medium in history.

But with great growth comes great risks. We expect the Year of the Horse to also bring a record-breaking number of cyber attacks. Cyber attacks drain productivity and confidence from the economy. As it relates to the Chinese zodiac, the Horse is characterised by its acute senses. Businesses should be alert and vigilant to cyber threats and our wish this year is for greater collaboration between business and government to address these important threats proactively.

Hari Krishnan

Managing Director

LinkedIn Asia Pacific & Japan

BIG Data will get bigger as the membership and engagement on social media platforms such as LinkedIn continue its northward trend. LinkedIn's professional member base in Singapore grew more than 30 per cent in 2013 to well over one million, for example. This rise in digital consumption is either a competitive advantage or a threat for companies. To get ahead of their peers, more companies will look to harnessing insights from big data to inform key initiatives such as marketing, so that they can build even more rewarding relationships with their audiences. As the talent crunch intensifies, we should also see more companies leveraging data analytics to make more effective hiring decisions, up from about a quarter of companies we surveyed globally in 2013.

As we go about fulfilling our vision of creating economic opportunities for all professionals, we also hope to contribute to Singapore's continued prosperity in the Year of the Horse.

Herbert Vongpusanachai

Managing Director

DHL Express (Singapore)

IN the Year of the Horse, the logistics industry will remain vibrant with key sectors such as marine, aerospace, oil & gas and life sciences well positioned to achieve record growth. 2014 is the year for Singapore to sharpen its competitive edge to strengthen further its strategic regional hub position for trade and supply chain.

One of DHL's key thrusts will be to continue providing great services to our customers to ensure seamless delivery and forge strong partnerships. The implementation of efficient logistics technology and solutions will enable our customers' growth and success through enhanced productivity. SMEs in Singapore remain our core focus and DHL will continue to play a strategic role in helping local firms expand in the region and globally.

Looking forward, DHL Express Singapore will continue enhancing its position as a regional hub to tap the new opportunities emerging in the South-east Asian region, as we strive to stay ahead of the pack and be the best of breed in the logistics industry.

Ng Eng Kiong

President

Singapore Green Building Council

THE construction industry has been doing well in the past couple of years and is expected to remain healthy this year. With the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) regulating a minimum standard of environmental performance in buildings since 2008, most building professionals are now familiar with green building design concepts. The challenge now is to take the greening process through the entire building supply chain, so that all materials, fixtures and fittings that go into a building are green too. SGBC provides a green building certification framework to guide companies on that. My wish is for more Singaporeans, including the man in the street, to understand the impact that buildings can cause to the environment and the difference that consumers can make. By demanding more environmentally friendly buildings and building products, we can help conserve natural resources, use energy and water more efficiently, and minimise harm to the environment. Green buildings deliver improved health and productivity of occupants too, so that, in itself, is a good enough reason.

Seah Kian Peng

CEO (Singapore)

NTUC Fairprice Co-operative Ltd

THE virtues ascribed to the zodiac Horse encompasses reliability, strength and speed. These attributes also describe the character of NTUC FairPrice and the values we embrace - performing with determination and diligence to deliver our brand promise to customers. For 2014, the commitment to our social mission of moderating the cost of living for our customers and offering quality products at best value will continue to form the core of our strategic focus. The two key challenges of labour shortage and rising cost of business will have its full impact on us. Hence it is an imperative that we further strengthen our business by embracing a spirit of innovation, increasing productivity and enhancing our service initiatives while placing our customers' interest at heart. These will not be easy but try we must so that we can do well and continue to do more good. The support of our various business partners is also an integral and key success factor for FairPrice and we will continue to stand by them - especially our local SME suppliers - and complement their efforts in growing their businesses. Above all, I wish for our country, businesses and individuals alike, good health, fulfilling times and prosperity in the Year of the Horse and a dose of good luck too.

Dennis Rose

Senior Vice-President for APAC and Japan

Brightcove

THE Year of the Horse looks set to be an exciting year with online video developments influencing the digital industry, and businesses must embrace the changing trends to reap the benefits. As the industry moves towards greater live-streaming of high-quality video content via the Web, apps and social channels, businesses are presented with the exciting possibilities of brand-produced live content designed to coincide with major events such as the World Cup and Winter Olympics.

There will be more opportunities for businesses to better target, revise and streamline their advertising creative and dollar spending, especially as the industry transitions from linear broadcasting to digital distribution. With cloud-based advertising, they can enjoy superior data acquisition from digital ads and achieve far more than through traditional broadcast advertising.

Lastly, as media companies enhance online programming with new approaches to provide continuous playback or lean-back experiences, video on-demand will increasingly mimic the traditional TV viewing experience, providing brands with opportunities to make online advertising more frequent, but with less invasive touch points.

Venkatraman Sheshashayee

Chief Executive Officer/Executive Director

Jaya Holdings Ltd

THE Jaya Group of Companies operates in the offshore oilfield services business. We believe that the Year of the Horse will be good for this domain and for our group. We expect the markets to be increasingly active, leading to higher capacity utilisation and enhanced revenues. We hope to, through improved productivity and efficiency, reduce costs and downtime. I believe that our group will see measurable progress towards our long-term goals and, in the process, achieve and surpass our near-term objectives. I hope that this will energise our people further, as they enjoy the fruits of their planning and actions.I believe Singapore will accelerate on its path to re-inventing itself. I wish all Singaporeans the knowledge of new avenues, exciting opportunities, achievable objectives and, most important, the realisation that, together, we can be whatever we choose to be.

Ammar Hindi

Managing Director for Asia Pacific

Sourcefire, now a part of Cisco

AS we ring in 2014, we expect Singapore businesses to continue riding on the momentum from the previous year to generate substantial technological advances and financial growth. However, as organisations increasingly look to the cloud and rely on new technologies to enhance productivity, save cost and speed deployment, the increase in cyber attacks on these innovations is inevitable.

The reality is that cybercriminals are professionals and hacking today is an industrial process that follows the money trail. As a result, security has also rapidly emerged as a boardroom topic. There is no doubt that the battle between IT security and cybercriminals will continue in 2014 and beyond - it is no longer a question of whether you will be attacked, but when.

While there is no silver bullet approach to IT security, Singapore organisations can plan their corporate networks assuming they will be compromised at some point. This would ensure that they would be well-equipped to contain and repair any damage to their brand and reputation when the attack hits. Given the new levels of sophisticated attacks, it is clear that the foundation of any security solution requires a threat-centric approach that addresses the full attack continuum - before, during and after an attack.

Wong Heng Chew

President

Fujitsu Singapore

MANY companies across industries are looking to improve the way they leverage IT in support of wider business strategies and operational goals. Recent reports are also expecting expansion in products, services and reach for companies in the finance, commercial and technology sectors. In both cases, innovation will be a main part of discussions as these organisations seek support to maximise the use of current technological assets and provision for future needs. It is certainly going to be a busy year for the technology industry, as reflected in the current strong demand for IT professionals.

The Year of the Wooden Horse represents a year of speedy success. Fujitsu Singapore will continue to work closely with its customers to help them achieve success through continuous innovation and new technology breakthroughs. As Singapore's positive outlook and competitiveness continue into 2014, I believe it is well placed to achieve further success as a nation. My wish would be for the country to continue its focus on developing talent in IT, in support of the IT needs of growing companies.

David Topolewski

Chief Executive Officer

Qooco

DIGITAL will be the game changer in education for Singapore and the region. 2014 is the year where the big move from traditional learning to mobile learning methods will take place. Organisations are increasingly replacing expensive classroom learning that yields mediocre results with innovative solutions that deliver measurable results at a fraction of the cost. Mobile learning addresses the need for change on the back of the growing smartphone penetration rates in the region. Huge demand for domestic travel as well as booming international visitor growth is driving the demand for more hotels. We are seeing a surge in demand for mid-scale accommodation as intra-Asia travel continues to rise. The Gen Y traveller will shape the industry, with hotels such as our mid-market Park Inn by Radisson brand focusing more on technology-based services to capture this increasingly important market segment. Building on our strong growth momentum of the last three years, we have aggressive growth plans for the Year of the Horse. Carlson Rezidor Hotel Group in Asia will see 15 new hotels opening in the region this year, which will take our operating portfolio in Asia Pacific to 110 hotels by the end of this year. My wish for 2014 is that the world's financial markets are stable, and that people travel for business or leisure as frequently as they are able.

Lionel Lim

President, Asia Pacific & Japan

CA Technologies

The horse is a symbol of energy, passion and intelligence. These are qualities crucial for businesses to succeed. In a year of volatility and cautious optimism, it is necessary to be a gamer-changer, to constantly innovate and drive agility. I wish for CA Technologies, the IT industry and Singapore, a prosperous and successful year ahead.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China home price gains slow in Jan, surveys show

Published

Mon, Feb 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BEIJING] Gains in home prices in China eased in January, two private surveys showed, adding to signs of stabilisation in the housing market as government curbs start to take the edge off years of sustained gains.

Prices of new homes in 288 major cities in January rose 9.39 per cent in January from a year earlier, easing from December's annual rise of 10.04 per cent, a poll by real estate services firm E-House China showed on Saturday.

That was the slowest gain in nine months, snapping seven consecutive months of double-digit annual gains.

A separate survey by the China Real Estate Index System (CREIS) showed average prices in the 100 biggest cities rose 0.63 per cent in January from December, when they had risen 0.7 per cent, to post a 20th straight month gain.

On average, prices rose 11.1 per cent in January from a year earlier, CREIS said in a statement, moderating from 11.5 per cent annual gains in December and marking the first easing in annual gains since January 2013.

"Many local governments have tightened property market curbs since the fourth quarter in 2013 and these measures have cooled the local markets," said CREIS, a consultancy linked to China's largest online property information firm, Soufun Holdings.

Home supply and sales in most cities dropped to seasonal low levels in January due to the Chinese New Year, which also helped cap home prices, CREIS added.

China's property market began to show signs of stabilising at the end of 2013, with home price rises easing in some major cities as local governments took further tightening measures in November.

Still, China's home prices are at record highs and well beyond the reach of ordinary people, suggesting Beijing won't let up on its tightening campaign anytime soon.

The hot land market in major cities continued to challenge policymakers. Residential land prices hit records in Shanghai and Hangzhou in January, which may fuel speculation that China's home prices will continue to rise in key cities in 2014.

A parcel of land in a suburb of Shanghai sold for a record 10.1 billion yuan (S$2.1 billion) at auction last week, the most expensive plot of residential land ever sold in the city.

China's statistics bureau is due to publish official home prices data for 70 major cities for January on Feb 24. - Reuters
