site_title: Secular shift big opportunity for Oracle
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Secular shift big opportunity for Oracle

The company also say it is uniquely poised to help customers use big data to solve problems, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Feb 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MARK Hurd, Oracle's co-president and director, is not very enamoured by catchy IT keywords - such as cloud, big data, IoT (Internet of Things) - that get most people excited.

He notes: "If you run to the top of a building (in Singapore) and shout big data, it's interesting, but at the end of it, if you cannot bring it down to something that's easily understood, the customer doesn't know what to do with it. . . (Similarly), Cloud, cloud! A lot of companies think that if they scream cloud enough times then their stock prices would go up!"

"What we as an industry need to do is quit using terms and start turning these things into meaningful use cases," he says.

Mr Hurd tells BizIT: "I believe to the core that IT is hard. I believe having great IT is even harder. To achieve great IT you need to have strong leadership, not just at the CIO (chief information officer) level but also at the CEO level as well."

Mr Hurd notes that big data, at its core, are typically voluminous amounts of data that give insights at the granular or atomic level. This helps in formulating better decisions faster. And he thinks Oracle is uniquely poised to help customers use big data to solve problems.

"We have a customer in France which makes big aeroplanes. It takes them roughly a year from the time the plane comes off the assembly line for testing till it can be delivered to the customer.

"They typically fly these planes and test them. In some cases, it takes them five to six days to get the data from the tests, make changes and then send the plane back for more tests. For a big plane, there can be as many as 100,000 senors generating huge amounts of data.

"We (Oracle) have the capability to gather all of that data economically for the customer and analyse it and give timely results. Now you can imagine the opportunity that unfolds for the customer to take big data and turn it into more test flights and deliver the plane faster to the buyer."

Big data is inexorably linked with cloud infrastructure as well as analytics, and this is why Mr Hurd feels Oracle is uniquely positioned to take advantage of the paradigm shift taking place in the IT industry.

Bookings for Oracle's SaaS (software-as-a-service) cloud applications grew 35 per cent last quarter, reflecting a continuously improving win rate versus the new generation of SaaS specialists.

"What's behind that growth? Certainly our products are good. But I think the secular shift in IT is helping us," he says. In SaaS, Oracle has a suite of applications including HR (human resources), financial, sales automation, and marketing.

The company has made a host of cloud-based acquisitions, including RightNow (CRM or customer relationship management software), Taleo (talent management software), Eloqua (marketing automation), Responsys (campaign management), Nimbula (infrastructure) and Corente (application delivery). Oracle has also introduced Oracle Fusion applications, designed for cloud delivery as well as on-premises deployment.

Mr Hurd notes that Oracle has fundamentally rewritten its applications for the cloud. "We have ERP (enterprise resource planning) for the cloud today. And we are pushing it hard. We have a big opportunity to gain marketshare."

At the second-quarter earnings call in December, Larry Ellison, Oracle's CEO & director, noted that the company enters 2014 with refreshed versions of the key products that are expected to drive growth over the year. Oracle's latest database, version 12c was specifically designed for the cloud. He added that Oracle's Fusion cloud applications for HCM (human capital management), CRM and ERP, all have a "new simplified user interface, and an integrated social network that makes our enterprise applications as easy-to-use and familiar as Facebook, while enabling better collaboration and teamwork. . . All these new application interfaces were specifically designed for use on modern mobile devices like telephones and tablets."

Elaborating, Mr Hurd tells BizIT that each of Oracle's applications has the best features, capability as well as built-in analytics. "Oracle in the cloud is now the No 1 in ERP, No 1 in marketing automation , No 1 in service automation. . . We believe cloud is going to give us a chance to change the application landscape. We are the only one with the differentiators I described and the first to market with all these capabilities."

To a question on whether this shift to cloud was affecting Oracle's traditional software licensing business and the hardware business that it got from its acquisition of Sun Microsystems, Mr Hurd says that the company has built up its cloud business to more than US$1 billion while at the same time posting record overall margin growth. "Remember Oracle has done some very interesting things simultaneously. We bought a hardware company and everyone said: 'How can you have great margins in Oracle with this hardware company?' We integrated this hardware company (Sun) and this has became the bedrock of our engineering systems business." Overall, the company's hardware business, including hardware support, grew 2 per cent, with hardware system product revenue up US$714 million in the last quarter.

According to Mr Hurd, not only has the engineered systems business continued to show "excellent growth", but they've actually become a material part of Oracle's overall hardware business, now accounting for nearly 30 per cent of all hardware product sales. "Exadata and all our engineered systems had booking growth of nearly 35 per cent on top of similar growth last year, in the quarter," the Oracle official says.

Mr Hurd adds that all six engineered systems saw double-digit revenue growth, including the Big Data Appliance and Sparc SuperCluster, which saw triple-digit growth.

He adds that the company has "dramatically" increased the size of its sales force and has transitioned much of the force into the cloud and "we've done all this while we bought probably 30 companies over the past three years. We've had a lot of transformation and we've done all this while we delivered very impressive numbers".

Asia-Pacific growth

In the second quarter of fiscal 2014, whose results were announced in December, Oracle noted that the Asia-Pacific region declined 10 per cent with Japan "continuing to be challenged".

However, as Mr Ellison pointed out during a conference call, the company performed quite strongly in China. The company has shown some weakness in Australia and New Zealand as well as Japan. Mr Ellison added: "We really feel all around that we've got a very strong upside opportunity in Asia. We put . . . some new energy into Asia, some new excitement into Asia, and we expect it to pay off."

Echoing Mr Ellison's sentiments, Mr Hurd says the company is "pretty excited about Asia".

"Every time somebody says Asia to me it's something different. It's not a homogeneous entity. I think there are several very large economies. And then you have some other exciting economies in the region, such as Vietnam, Hong Kong and Singapore.

"I think our view is that Oracle is poised to gain in Asia. And we are growing in Asia. . . We will be adding sales people. We will be investing in Asia and so I see Asia as a place to grow. I see it as a place to take marketshare and hence this is a place we will invest in."

Oracle feels that three product areas - database, cloud applications and engineered systems - will drive growth for the company this year. Mr Hurd adds that the company has an opportunity to extend its "domination of IT".

"We think that there aren't many opportunities that you get. We are not the biggest applications company out there. However, through cloud we can become the biggest.

"We think there will be an opportunity as one of our big competitors hasn't done the work to rewrite its applications for the cloud. I think this opens up a window for us that is just fantastic and we think that it's opened up globally. And therefore we want to extend our leadership position."

He adds that Oracle has the "leading e-commerce capability in the world right now". It also has the leading service automation capabilities in the world. "So these secular changes play perfectly into our portfolio of capabilities and the interruption caused by cloud and SaaS gives us an opportunity to extend our leadership position."

site_title: UFS's Golden Energy pursuit hits snag
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

UFS's Golden Energy pursuit hits snag

Published

Sun, Feb 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FORESTRY and pulp producer United Fiber System's (UFS) proposed acquisition of a 67 per cent stake in Indonesia's Golden Energy Mines Tbk (Golden Energy) has been plunged into doubt because of a failure to meet certain conditions relating to the deal.

UFS had entered into a share purchase agreement (SPA) last July with PT Dian Swastatika Sentosa Tbk (DSS) to purchase the Indonesian company's 67 per cent stake in Golden Energy, the holding company of several Indonesian coal-mining firms, for S$1.88 billion, as well as a 5 per cent bonds issue, worth more than S$45 million, which was announced in August 2013.

UFS and DSS had originally agreed in the SPA that the long-stop date for the proposed DSS acquisition should be no later than Jan 31, 2014, but, according to a UFS statement to Singapore Exchange on the specified date, not all the conditions relating to the deal had been satisfied or waived, causing the long-stop date to lapse.

The statement said that both parties are currently discussing if the long-stop date should be extended so that the deal can be completed, and to amend other items in the SPA accordingly to the new time line, or not.

Because of this development, the deadline for the bond issue of Jan 31, 2014, may also be extended to correspond with the suggested extension of the long-stop date.

UFS is warning investors and shareholders to exercise caution in trading their UFS Shares as the proposed acquisition and the bond issue are "still subject to numerous conditions precedent and there is no certainty or assurance" that all of the conditions will be satisfied or waived, or completed at all.

site_title: Political paralysis looms after Thai polls
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Political paralysis looms after Thai polls

Legal challenges could further rattle the already battered baht, stock market

Published

Sun, Feb 2, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] Controversial elections in Thailand passed peacefully yesterday, but the country was no nearer to ending its intractable political conflict, with the government facing the prospect of months of paralysis, protests and complex legal challenges which could further rattle the already battered baht and the stock market.

Voting was disrupted in about a fifth of the country's constituencies, but no major violence was reported, despite armed clashes between supporters and opponents of embattled Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra that wounded seven people on the eve of the ballot.

No results were to be announced yesterday, meaning little change to an uneasy status quo. Ms Ying-luck will remain caretaker premier for weeks, facing continued anti-government protests and the prospect of a slew of legal challenges aimed at invalidating the poll.

The usual campaign billboards, glossy posters and pre-election buzz were noticeably absent this time, as were many voters fearful of violence or bent on rejecting a ballot bound to re-elect the political juggernaut controlled by Ms Ying-luck's billionaire brother, Thaksin Shinawatra.

Further voting is already scheduled for Feb 23 after problems with advance balloting last Sunday, while polls in nine southern provinces where candidates were unable to register may not happen for weeks. "To those of you who went out and prevented ballot boxes from being delivered, thank you," protest leader Suthep Thaugsuban said in a speech at one of seven rally sites in Bangkok, where anti-Thaksin sentiment is strong.

Voting was disrupted in 18 per cent or 69 of 375 constituencies nationwide, the Election Commission said, affecting 18 of 77 provinces, where demonstrators calling for an appointed government succeeded in sabotaging the vote.

With the main opposition Democrat Party boycotting the poll, Ms Ying-luck's Puea Thai Party is expected to win comfortably.

Its leader said that the election showed the public believed in democracy. "The people are not afraid and they came out to vote today," said Jarupong Ruangsuwan, who is also Interior Minister. "We've fought hard for democracy in Thailand and we proved that most Thais believe in the democratic process."

Even if the results were known, victory celebrations for Ms Yingluck would probably be muted. With many parliamentary seats unfilled, she could be exposed to legal attacks, intensified protests and unable to pass bills and budgets crucial to reviving the economy, South-east Asia's second-biggest.

The latest round of tumult in the eight-year political conflict erupted in November and underscored Thaksin's central role in the long-running struggle, both as hero and villain.

Ms Yingluck was largely tolerated by Thaksin's opponents, but her party miscalculated when it tried to introduce a blanket political amnesty that would have nullified Thaksin's graft conviction and allowed him to return home.

The judiciary has taken on an unusually large number of cases in the past two months in response to complaints against Ms Ying-luck and Puea Thai that could result in the party's dissolution and lengthy bans for its top politicians.

There is also a chance the election could be annulled, as it was in 2006, over a technicality. The Election Commission is bracing for a deluge of complaints and challenges.

Even if Ms Yingluck wins a fresh mandate, analysts say that opposition against her remains entrenched and continued stalemate is almost certain. - Reuters

site_title: Out to lighten the mood here
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Out to lighten the mood here

Published

Thu, Feb 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IF you're ever at Toast Box in Katong 112, you might spot local author Felix Cheong sitting in the corner by the window, hunched over a few sheets of paper and possibly giggling to himself.

It's his favourite writing haunt, reveals the 48-year-old. And if he isn't busy writing, then he's probably there to get inspiration the old-fashioned way: by observing people around him and eavesdropping on their conversations.

That's exactly what he did last year while working on his latest book: Singapore Siu Dai: The SG Conversation in a Cup. The book is a collection of 50 short stories satirising daily life in Singapore, like the woes of taking public transport, our kiasu behaviour, and obsession with Hello Kitty plushies, peppered with single-page cartoons by a graphic artist who wants to be known only as PMan.

This book is Cheong's first attempt at writing humour and, according to him, it came about entirely unplanned - especially since his last eight books have mostly been poetry collections, with a couple of young adult novels.

But he believes it's a good time to release such a book, because the time is just right for a little satire here in Singapore, says Cheong, who has a background working in the media industry for about 22 years and now lectures part-time at local institutions.

"I've noticed since the 2011 elections that Singaporeans are getting very unhappy," he says. "A lot of the rhetoric and unhappiness stems from the fact that we take ourselves very seriously. To quote a famous cartoon character, "Why so serious?" . . . That's why now we have shows like The Noose, and websites like New Nation, and I think this book is contributing to that conversation too."

It all started with Cheong taking long commutes between home and schools, so he decided to challenge himself to write a short story within each 45-minute time frame and post it on Facebook. When more of his friends liked it, he realised there was a market for that kind of short satire.

One of his favourite stories in the book is titled Language Therapy for Teens, and it follows the dialogue between two unnamed people: person A who obsessively uses the word "like" as a filler in every sentence, and person B who tries to convince person A to drop the filler and speak proper English.

This story was inspired by some of his own students at the schools where he teaches, because a lot of his students have that habit while giving presentations, says Cheong.

"I don't really base my characters on real people though, because I may get sued. So I tweak them enough so they are types that people can relate to, rather than recognisable individuals," he adds.

And by relating to his characters, Cheong hopes his readers will have a good laugh and learn to take themselves less seriously.

"That's what a satirist does, after all. I notice the gap between what is and what could be, and that's where I come in and poke fun at it," says Cheong.

"I hope it will help lighten the mood in Singapore - that's my big aim."

'Singapore Siu Dai: The SG Conversation in a Cup' is available at $13.91 (after GST), at Times bookstores, Books Kinokuniya, MPH bookstores, and Books Actually

site_title: UOL logs 3% dip in profit to $785.8m
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

UOL logs 3% dip in profit to $785.8m

It will be 'much more selective and niche' in its land banking

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

UOL Group posted a 3 per cent fall in net profit to $785.8 million for the financial year ended Dec 31 as weaker sales of residential units offset stronger hotel revenue and higher rental income from offices and shopping malls.

The group revenue for fiscal 2013 slipped 8 per cent from a year ago to $1.06 billion while fair value gains on the group's investment properties and associated companies fell by nearly 9 per cent to $500.9 million.

Given the recent softness in the residential market, the group will be "much more selective and niche in its acquisition of land bank", Liam Wee Sin, president of UOL Group's property division said at a briefing yesterday. "We have gone into investment in properties with recurring income. That strategy remains," he said.

The group will still seek to strengthen its three key pillars of property development, property investments and hotel operations going forward, Mr Liam added.

Revenue from property developments fell 27 per cent in fiscal 2013 to $410 million due to weaker residential sales.

Boosting the group revenue was the hotel division, which grew 11 per cent to $420.4 million, buoyed by contributions from new hotels under fully owned Pan Pacific Hotels Group.

The hotel arm has a pipeline of six hotels to be opened in Myanmar, Indonesia and China over the next few years.

Property investments saw a 9 per cent rise in revenue to $180.2 million.

Mr Liam said that the office sector is likely to remain positive while the retail sector may see mixed results due to rising operating costs and a labour crunch. The hotel sector may face some moderation in revenue per available room as room supply increases. While the residential sector will see some easing in selling prices, a "hard landing" is unlikely, he said.

Conceding that buyers are taking a longer time to snap up homes and investors have downsized their purchases, Mr Liam added that the group is under no pressure to lower the selling prices of its recent project, Riverbanks @ Fernvale, at Sengkang where he believes the group has gotten the strategy right for pricing and unit sizes.

UOL has proposed a special dividend of 5 cents per share and a first and final dividend of 15 cents. UOL closed trading yesterday at $6.12, up five cents.

site_title: Japan consumer spending up sharply in Jan
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan consumer spending up sharply in Jan

Customers try to get as much spending done as possible ahead of April's hike in national consumption tax

Published

Fri, Feb 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tokyo

CONSUMER spending and industrial output in Japan moved sharply into higher gear in January, as consumers tried to get as much spending done as possible ahead of next month's increase in the national consumption tax.

The move to raise it from 5 per cent to 8 per cent from April 1 has raised economists' fears that the nation's accelerating economic recovery could be thrown into reverse as a result.

In January, home buyers rushed to close purchases, sending housing starts up by 12.3 per cent in January, compared with their level a year earlier.

Inflation also spiked.

All this, along with the solid employment data also released yesterday, is proof-positive of the success of "Abenomics" - Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's package of monetary and fiscal stimulus measures and structural reforms.

The key question, though, is what happens next, analysts said.

In previous years, when the sales tax was raised, consumers reacted badly and consumption sagged in the wake of the hikes. The result was that the Japanese economy slowed or even slid into recession after a brief run-up in consumption ahead of the increase.

Japan's former vice-finance minister for international affairs Eisuke Sakakibara believes, however, that it will be different.

He told The Business Times yesterday: "I don't think it will set back Japan's recovery this time."

The man better known as "Mr Yen" added that the April 1 rise "has already been incorporated in the markets".

"When you announce it in advance, people take it for granted. There may be some increase in consumption before the tax increase, and there may be some decline. But I am not worried about it."

The Ministry of Economy Trade and Industry said Japanese retail sales rose 4.4 per cent in January from their level a year earlier, marking the sixth consecutive monthly gain; the rise was also comfortably ahead of the 3.8 per cent gain predicted by economists.

Household spending rose 1.1 per cent in January from a year earlier in price-adjusted real terms; this was more than the median market forecast for a 0.2 per cent annual rise and followed a 0.7 per cent increase in the year to December.

With Japanese companies boosting their production of motor vehicles and other consumer durables ahead of the April hike, industrial output rose 4 per cent in January, in a second consecutive monthly gain.

The jump in output again was ahead of analysts' expectations of a 3 per cent rise.

However, February data on the Japanese purchasing managers' index, which was also released yesterday, showed a slowing from the eight-year high reached in January. Analysts said this could be the start of some modest slowing in production as the April tax hike draws closer.

Japanese core consumer prices - excluding volatile fresh food prices but including energy costs - rose 1.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, rising for an eighth consecutive month.

The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 3.7 per cent and the jobs-to-applicants ratio improved further.

Bouncing back from closures

With the recent string of high-profile restaurant closures, what happens to foreign chefs when the restaurants that bring them in shut down? Debbie Yong looks at the different factors chefs consider in deciding to stay or to go

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Feb 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT was like a clarion call for the foreign-born chef - go East and you will be rewarded with a cushy expatriate package and a chance to spearhead a new restaurant in Singapore. But for those who heeded that call, a new reality has set in.

With almost as many restaurants closing as there are opening (575 new restaurants versus 435 restaurants which closed down in the first 11 months of last year) - big names included - an increasing number of foreign chefs are finding themselves sidelined with an uncertain future ahead.

Rather than pack their bags in the wake of a dream gone sour, more chefs are staying put, either striking out on their own or doing consultancy work even as their original employers go bust.
